Speaker: NA
Text: Tuesday, 8 October 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: The House met at 2 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: ABSENCE OF MR SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-I inform the House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: absence of the Speaker, who is on parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary business overseas. In accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 14, the Chairman of Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tees, as Acting Speaker, will take the chair.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Mr Ronald

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards) thereupon took the chair, and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Wills-Prime Minister)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House that the Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, is

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas holding discussions on GATT and

Speaker: NA
Text: will return to Australia tomorrow. In his

Speaker: NA
Text: absence from Question Time today questions

Speaker: NA
Text: which normally would be addressed to Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Blewett should be addressed to the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, Mr Duffy.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Interest Rates

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that on one

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the interest rate debate we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury and lined up opposing them are the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Blaxland and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor of the Reserve Bank? Does this

Speaker: NA
Text: open conflict signal to the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Hawke Government does not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: clue about the direction of interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: midst of the worst recession in 60 years a

Speaker: NA
Text: -ecession engineered by extremely high

Speaker: NA
Text: mterest rates?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: The honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: raises the issue of sources of advice on what

Speaker: NA
Text: should happen to interest rates. Let me make

Speaker: NA
Text: one point to him which should be without

Speaker: NA
Text: debate at all: I would not look to him-nor

Speaker: NA
Text: would any sensible person-on the question

Speaker: NA
Text: of what should happen to interest rates. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the House of the statement made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition when we com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced the reduction of interest rates in

Speaker: NA
Text: January of last year. His classic comment at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time was, 'The Treasurer, his

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and, indeed, the Reserve Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: should hang their heads in shame'. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: in January 1990, when we commenced the 8t h

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage point reduction in interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: which is now being effected. The position of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition was that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was an incorrect decision and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should have kept interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: higher for longer than it did. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of the Leader of the Opposition, so

Speaker: NA
Text: he speaks from no position of strength on this

Speaker: NA
Text: question of interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the processes are concerned, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: not comment on any speculation in the news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers, but I will m-ke some points about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's co-uct o- monetary policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: We observe due process m this matter and

Speaker: NA
Text: unlike the Leader of the Opposition, w-

Speaker: NA
Text: respect the position of the Reserve Bank, its

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor and its board. We do not undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: a process qf public denigration of people

Speaker: NA
Text: occupying positions of important responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind the House that the last interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction was based on the unanimous advice

Speaker: NA
Text: of the board, formulated at its regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduled meeting. That is what happened on

Speaker: NA
Text: the last occasion. This Government and its

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers, including the Reserve Bank will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to monitor developments ht the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and to ensure that the setting of

Speaker: NA
Text: monetary policy remains closely attuned to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving the economic objectives of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The stance that we have estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished is designed to facilitate the recovery

Speaker: NA
Text: in the which is now becoming evident without re-

Speaker: NA
Text: igniting inflationary development. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that everyone in this House would agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it clear that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not intend to forgo growth, including job

Speaker: NA
Text: growth, to achieve zero inflation-which is so

Speaker: NA
Text: glibly talked about by the honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man who has asked this question-by having

Speaker: NA
Text: !hat unrealistic inflation objective, nor does it

Speaker: NA
Text: mtend to have an excessive easing of policy

Speaker: NA
Text: to launch Australia on the path of boom that

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitably would be followed by bust.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since January 1990, the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has conducted monetary policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: against the position of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, has been to the benefit of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. There has been an 81/2 percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: point reduction in interest rates-a process

Speaker: NA
Text: which, as I say, was opposed by the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition. At all times we have

Speaker: NA
Text: followed due process; we will continue to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so and, in following due process, we will not

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in that tactic of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition of, without any basis at all, attack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the integrity of people who have a statu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory duty to uphold the position of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country in regard to the responsible conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: of policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Council of Social Service:

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance to Needy

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Text: My question is ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform

Speaker: NA
Text: the House what action has been taken to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: those affected by the economic downturn?

Speaker: NA
Text: Does he intend to take any additional meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures to assist Australians affected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: This is a very timely ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and I thank the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxley for it. I spoke to ACOSS last week and

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined that the Government, Mr Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, as you know, has a comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net for those people directly affected-

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: Answer the question.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I know the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition wants to interrupt; after last week,

Speaker: NA
Text: he will not want to hear anyone talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS. He should be ashamed of his per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance, as I will show. We will come to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition and ACOSS in

Speaker: NA
Text: a moment. Let me say, as I pointed out to

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS, that we have this comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net in place. First, we have substantial-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly increased in real terms benefits for those in

Speaker: NA
Text: need. For an unemployed single adult, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased real benefits by 26 per cent;

Speaker: NA
Text: for those not renting privately and for those

Speaker: NA
Text: renting privately, we have increased benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: by 54 per cent. Secondly, we have, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of Newstart, assisted the unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed to find jobs through a-tive job search

Speaker: NA
Text: and training. Finally, of course, the last line

Speaker: NA
Text: of defence in the safety net is emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: relief. You will know, Mr Acting Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the Budget that emergency relief

Speaker: NA
Text: funding was increased by $3m to a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1O.84m and that last week, when I was

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to ACOSS, I announced an increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in additional funding of $3.5m this year to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the total funds available in 1991-92 to

Speaker: NA
Text: Against that background of the demonstrat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed real concern of the Government for look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing after those who have been adversely

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by the economic downturn, I imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: that most members in this place, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: those on this side of the House but many on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side, would have been bemused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the amazing speech of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to ACOSS last week. For exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, the Leader of the Opposition said to

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS:

Speaker: NA
Text: I put it to you that the Coalition is just as interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in welfare and just as interested in assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely needy as the Labor Party . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet in the same speech he confirmed the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Opposition to throw onto the

Speaker: NA
Text: street after nine months those who are unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed. That is the measure of this man who

Speaker: NA
Text: wants the Australian public to believe he is

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate. The revelation of the working

Speaker: NA
Text: of the mind of the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was in fact contained in an article in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Morning Herald on 3 August this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. I would ask members of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: just pick up closely how the mind of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition works. This is what

Speaker: NA
Text: he had to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The basics of my beliefs are in economics. They

Speaker: NA
Text: stem originally from a lot of theoretical work that

Speaker: NA
Text: I did myself, building multi-country computer

Speaker: NA
Text: models of regulated financial systems, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: then breaking down the regulations in the models.

Speaker: NA
Text: And then cranking out all the properties to see what

Speaker: NA
Text: effect it has on interest rates, growth and employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and things like that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Simmons-What about people?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: correctly interjects, 'What about people?'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where are people in this desiccated calculat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing machine? There is no concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: people-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: The Opposition Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: gave us another revealing insight in this

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. I ask the House to take note of what

Speaker: NA
Text: he said when speaking to ACOSS, this collecon

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of honourable people of integrity who

Speaker: NA
Text: make up ACOSS. I will table a list of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members who make up ACOSS. Without an

Speaker: NA
Text: being exhaustive about it, these are the

Speaker: NA
Text: who were so viciously attacked by the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition: the Anglican Church of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; the Social Responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, the Australian Conference of

Speaker: NA
Text: Leaders of Religious Institutes, the Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian Jewish Welfare Societies;

Speaker: NA
Text: Legacy Coordinating Council; the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Anglican Caring Organisations Network; the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Association of Community Based

Speaker: NA
Text: Children's Services; the National Catholic

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of Family Agencies; the Salvation

Speaker: NA
Text: Army, Southern Command and Eastern for

Speaker: NA
Text: Command; and the Society of St Vincent de

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul. These are the organisations to

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition had this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: By concentrating on expanding and approving

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of welfare, in one sense at least,

Speaker: NA
Text: is just reinforcing the Biblical reminder that

Speaker: NA
Text: poor are always with us.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did the Leader of the Opposition mean

Speaker: NA
Text: by that statement, reminding us that the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: are always with us? Does he mean that by

Speaker: NA
Text: taking away welfare from people, the people

Speaker: NA
Text: whom he calls the poor will

Speaker: NA
Text: the scene? Or does he mean that because the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor are always with us that it is not worth

Speaker: NA
Text: doing anything to help them? The Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition owes it to the House and to

Speaker: NA
Text: the hundreds of thousands of decent people of

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity involved in working with those 55

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations of ACOSS to explain what he

Speaker: NA
Text: means about the proposition that the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: always with us.

Speaker: NA
Text: This gentleman in his speech to ACOSS has

Speaker: NA
Text: demeaned the concept of parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to those in need in this

Speaker: NA
Text: community. He has made a mockery of any

Speaker: NA
Text: concept of compassion. Those opposite will

Speaker: NA
Text: stand condemned and will reap their reward

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable Member for Blaxland

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Text: Is the Prime Minister improving.

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of comments by the Victorian State

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of the AMIEU, Mr Wally Curran,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable member for Blaxland

Speaker: NA
Text: should be elevated to the prime ministership

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of his support for job creation?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it the Prime Minister's view that their

Speaker: NA
Text: combined experience-the former in creating

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment pool of one million, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people latter in reducing the work force of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader Victorian meat industry from 7,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,800-ideally equips them to guide Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the recession we had to have?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: That is a very uncharitable

Speaker: NA
Text: question indeed. It is uncharitable to me, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: uncharitable to the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Blaxland, and it is uncharitable to Mr Curran.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: May I say in response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the interjection from the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo that I dream about him, that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: very little time for dreaming and what I do

Speaker: NA
Text: whom the have I do not waste on Curran.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have indicated, I am quite relaxed

Speaker: NA
Text: the about the way this great Labor movement

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS operates. We have been going for 100 years

Speaker: NA
Text: the now. In that time we have found that sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the political movement talk to sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the industrial movement. It is good for busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness. As far as we are concerned, we will do

Speaker: NA
Text: what we have to do; that is, having slowed

Speaker: NA
Text: down the Australian economy, as we had to

Speaker: NA
Text: disappear from do in the period-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Broadbent-Slowed it down!

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Corinella!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I have explained the

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics before. When the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Blaxland was the Treasurer we had to

Speaker: NA
Text: are slow the Australian economy down. We did

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We did it, as I have indicated in my

Speaker: NA
Text: previous answer, with a concern for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who would be adversely affected. Now we are

Speaker: NA
Text: able to point to the fact that we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: emerging from that recession and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it from an infinitely stronger base than

Speaker: NA
Text: we had before.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a rate of inflation which is signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly lower than that of our major trading

Speaker: NA
Text: partners. Our external position is steadily

Speaker: NA
Text: As we go into the second half of

Speaker: NA
Text: this financial year, employment will begin to

Speaker: NA
Text: recover significantly. As a nation comes out

Speaker: NA
Text: of recession, employment is always the last

Speaker: NA
Text: indicator to recover because employers keep

Speaker: NA
Text: on an excess of labour in times of recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: My colleagues in Government and I are

Speaker: NA
Text: going about that business. If people-whether

Speaker: NA
Text: on the side of government, in the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement or in ACOSS-have specific

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals that they want us to consider, we

Speaker: NA
Text: will do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trends in Disposable Income

Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Text: Is the Minister repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the Minister for Social Security aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of a survey of trends in disposable income in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia during the last eight years? If so,

Speaker: NA
Text: would he tell the House the conclusions of

Speaker: NA
Text: that survey and its implications?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fraser.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Are we going to have a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: of retribution?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I do not mind being labelled

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennelong may not like to be regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: such, but if that is a label he wants to put on

Speaker: NA
Text: me, I accept it. The study by Dr Harding and

Speaker: NA
Text: John Lant carefully demonstrates the signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant progress that this Government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: in alleviating poverty among the most vul-

Speaker: NA
Text: nerable groups in our society-the aged, the

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled, sole parents, the unemployed and

Speaker: NA
Text: low income and single income families with

Speaker: NA
Text: young children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The study shows that the real disposable

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes for social security recipients in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased sharply after taking full account of

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation. For example, the real disposable

Speaker: NA
Text: income for a full rate pensioner couple rose

Speaker: NA
Text: by almost 15 per cent. Increases were higher

Speaker: NA
Text: for those renting privately or with children

Speaker: NA
Text: under 16. The real disposable income for a

Speaker: NA
Text: sole parent with two children renting privately

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by almost 26 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition, in his speech

Speaker: NA
Text: to the ACOSS congress, was outraged that

Speaker: NA
Text: those who were unemployed experienced a

Speaker: NA
Text: real increase in their disposable income of 26

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent over the last eight years-a stagger-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing 54 per cent if they received rent assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. These increases were understood by

Speaker: NA
Text: social security recipients. When we hear

Speaker: NA
Text: interjections from the Opposition about work

Speaker: NA
Text: being the solution, it is hardly the solution for

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged when they are in poverty or disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged. The aged certainly remember that

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1983 the pension was only 22 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: average weekly earnings. They understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is now 26 per cent of average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings. The suggestion that somehow the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Government favours welfare over

Speaker: NA
Text: work is erroneous.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition asserts that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a large number of people receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: the dole who feel no pressure to go out and

Speaker: NA
Text: get themselves jobs. That is an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: statement coming from the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. The reality is that no government

Speaker: NA
Text: has done more than this Government to link

Speaker: NA
Text: the social security system to an active em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment strategy. Unlike the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: when it was in government in 1982-83, when

Speaker: NA
Text: little was done to create any relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: between the unemployment benefit and work

Speaker: NA
Text: and training, this Government has placed a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of emphasis on seeking to maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mise the opportunities for people to leave

Speaker: NA
Text: dependants on benefits and take up the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities to find work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, there is no clearer contrast between

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and the Opposition than that

Speaker: NA
Text: between a policy that would simply cut

Speaker: NA
Text: people off after nine months, simply saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'After nine months you don't get paid any

Speaker: NA
Text: more, you don't deserve any more assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments; after nine months you go on the scrap

Speaker: NA
Text: heap', and a policy that, when people reach

Speaker: NA
Text: long term unemployment, seeks to structure

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance more in line with training and other

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of assistance for unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Programs such as JET and Newstart and

Speaker: NA
Text: disability reforms are all about offering people

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to get into the mainstream of

Speaker: NA
Text: our community life. Rather than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government looking at the issue of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment as a welfare issue, it has seen that

Speaker: NA
Text: issue as one that needs to be addressed,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly in terms of improved benefits while

Speaker: NA
Text: people are outside the work force, and it has

Speaker: NA
Text: also seen it as one that maximises the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities that can be taken to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: people return to meaningful work.

Speaker: NA
Text: When one returns to the ACOSS speech by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition, in a sense one

Speaker: NA
Text: is looking through a window back into the

Speaker: NA
Text: nineteenth century, looking at the attitudes

Speaker: NA
Text: that were there1in the depression of the 1890s.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey- Mr Acting Speaker, I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. Standing order 145 deals with

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of relevance. It would be a great

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for you personally, Mr Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, to demonstrate to this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that you at least understand its meaning,

Speaker: NA
Text: which clearly the Ministers do not. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Minister has no responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for speeches made by other people and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a good idea if he told us how he

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to fix the unemployment problem

Speaker: NA
Text: and not talk about handouts.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. The answer is still relevant to

Speaker: NA
Text: the question. However, I am sure the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will assist the House by drawing his answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to a conclusion.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I am happy to do that. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: simply drawing the parallel that when one

Speaker: NA
Text: looks at the language of the speech, what one

Speaker: NA
Text: returns to is the nineteenth century, when at

Speaker: NA
Text: least towards the end of that period progress-

Speaker: NA
Text: ive social workers recognised that there was

Speaker: NA
Text: something somehow wrong about a distinction

Speaker: NA
Text: between the deserving and undeserving poor,

Speaker: NA
Text: that we could do a little better in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: conceptualisation than talk about people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are genuinely poor, as if those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed, those who happen to be in a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of dependency because of marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdowns, those who suffer from a disabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty, are somehow responsible for their own

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey-I have a point of order. I

Speaker: NA
Text: applauded your decision, Mr Acting Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is now ignoring you, insulting

Speaker: NA
Text: you, and should bring his answer to a conclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion as you suggested.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: I am listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister's summing::-up of his answer.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: That is the tenor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: speech by the Leader of the Opposition. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a tenor which is not simply out of touch with

Speaker: NA
Text: contemporary welfare, but it has been out of

Speaker: NA
Text: touch with good thinking in terms of social

Speaker: NA
Text: policy for a century. That is what is wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: with it. It is an intellectual contribution that

Speaker: NA
Text: ,represents all of the conservative values for a

Speaker: NA
Text: class which may have dominated the nine-

Speaker: NA
Text: teenth century but ought to take its place in

Speaker: NA
Text: the twentieth century and work with people

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than against them in the insulting way

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested by the Leader of the Opposition at

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister

Speaker: Mr REITH
Text: My question is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer him to an interview

Speaker: NA
Text: with his former Deputy, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blaxland, Mr Keating, that was

Speaker: NA
Text: published in the Sydney Morning Herald last

Speaker: NA
Text: weekend. In this interview the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blaxland is quoted as saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: I won't serve a person who can't keep their word.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Prime Minister's close colleague of

Speaker: NA
Text: eight years does not trust him, why should the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: All I can say is that some-

Speaker: NA
Text: time in 1993 the Australian people will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given the opportunity to decide whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: trust me or the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders, if he is still here. There is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of certainty in Australian politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be leading the Government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: election in 1993. I am not sure whether Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hewson will be leading the Opposition. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: our even less sure whether the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders will be the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party. But whoever is there, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people will have the chance, as

Speaker: NA
Text: they did in 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990, to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose between a government-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-Why don't you create jobs?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: To that quiet little sotto

Speaker: NA
Text: voce interjection 'Why don't you create

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs?', I will tell the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: what we have done. Including the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in the last 12 months, this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has created on average each year

Speaker: NA
Text: 177,000 new jobs. That is three times faster

Speaker: NA
Text: than in the period of the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's predecessors, when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: advising them how to run the economy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: made an absolute mess of it then; he is now

Speaker: NA
Text: showing that he is incompetent. He will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase inflation with his goods and services

Speaker: NA
Text: tax-theoretically, because he will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing it in.

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: Oh, come on!

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Of course he will not. He

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be elected, so he will not be there to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring it in. But, conceptually, if he were to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the chance to bring in his goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services tax, he would smash the gains on

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation that we have made, he would lose

Speaker: NA
Text: our competitiveness, and he would increase

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, particularly when the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion talks about slashing expenditures by $4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. As I have said in answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the chance

Speaker: NA
Text: will be given to the people sometime in 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: to make their choice on whom they want to

Speaker: NA
Text: rely upon. As they have done on the four

Speaker: NA
Text: previous occasions, they will pick the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party under my leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: because we leave the Opposition for dead in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of economic management and social

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Occupational Superannuation

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Text: Has the Treasurer seen

Speaker: NA
Text: reports proposing that occupational superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation be scrapped to save 100,000 jobs?

Speaker: NA
Text: What would the effects be of such a measure?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it the intention of the Government to scrap

Speaker: NA
Text: occupational superannuation?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: No doubt the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is provoked by the sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that came from the remarkable speech of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition to the ACOSS

Speaker: NA
Text: national conference where he saw fit to attack

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations such as the Salvation Army and

Speaker: NA
Text: the St Vincent de Paul Society. But I find it

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible that even this Opposition Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: would get up in front of the nation's peak

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare organisations and tell them that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should scrap a policy which will

Speaker: NA
Text: allow all working Australians to provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: their old age. Already something like 70 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of wage and salary earners are covered

Speaker: NA
Text: by occupational superannuation. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition made that statement know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that our population is ageing and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will become an increasing burden over

Speaker: NA
Text: coming decades for those in the work force to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the existing level of age pension for

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees. It is obvious what the implication of

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be for the living standards of future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations of Australian workers. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: absence of occupational superannuation, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to be taxed more heavily to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide age pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: ill years gone by most people would have

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed that a Leader of the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: would be enthusiastic about a measure which

Speaker: NA
Text: would help people provide for their old age

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than rely on the social security system,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly a measure which would give them

Speaker: NA
Text: a better standard of living in retirement. Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, I am amazed. People would wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: why the Leader of the Opposition said in a

Speaker: NA
Text: doorstop on 18 August this year:

Speaker: NA
Text: .. ' . I don't believe that occupational superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion makes any sense in a country like Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: People would be asking: what is the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: prescription of the Leader of the Opposition?

Speaker: NA
Text: Anyone listening to the ABC on 31 July this

Speaker: NA
Text: year might have heard him say:

Speaker: NA
Text: People can prepare for their superannuation (by)

Speaker: NA
Text: not only putting it into a few superannuation funds

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the:>: may save in banks, they may keep their

Speaker: NA
Text: money In a stockmarket and invest in equity

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know when it was that the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition went back to Welfare Avenue,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I doubt whether his old neighbours have

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reuters screen installed next to their beds.

Speaker: NA
Text: The regrettable fact is that not enough

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians have had the capacity to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately for their retirement. The Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition needs to recognise that not

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australians fit his computer driven

Speaker: NA
Text: model. Through non-compliance, many do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have any superannuation cover, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: present level of award superannuation cover

Speaker: NA
Text: is insufficient to provide a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living in retirement. We cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to dismiss this problem for later on. It

Speaker: NA
Text: takes in excess of 30 years for ordinary wage

Speaker: NA
Text: and salary earners to save sufficient money to

Speaker: NA
Text: finance an adequate retirement income. With

Speaker: NA
Text: the first of the baby-boomers reaching 65 by

Speaker: NA
Text: the year 2011, there is no practical alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: to the current timetable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition has tried a

Speaker: NA
Text: scare campaign, suggesting that occupational

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation will cost 100,000 jobs; and he

Speaker: NA
Text: is using the recession to suggest that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: not the time for reform. Of course, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Opposition in general, it is never the

Speaker: NA
Text: time for any reform. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ignores the facts. No employer

Speaker: NA
Text: will face an indease in superannuation contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: butions under these arrangements before 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1992, by which time the recovery will be

Speaker: NA
Text: well under way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-I'll tell you what: you will eat

Speaker: NA
Text: those words.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Those opposite put on a

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax. What do they want-19

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent inflation like New Zealand had? That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a good way to stymie recovery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-You tell that to the unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed. That is absolute hypocrisy.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders!

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: New Zealand had 19 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation and interest rates of 25 per cent. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the prescription that those opposite put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward. Where are the jobs in that? Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite are berserk. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ignores the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: for many employers who are already comply-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with the 3 per cent obligation there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no additional increase until 1 July 1993.

Speaker: NA
Text: He ignores the fact that improvements in

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation will be taken into account in

Speaker: NA
Text: future award negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: No, we will not be scrapping occupational

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation; no, we will not be scrapping

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000 jobs; no, we will not be scrapping

Speaker: NA
Text: the welfare of future Australian retirees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Prime Minister, and it follows

Speaker: NA
Text: up on behalf of the one million jobless. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian Premier, Mrs Kirner, said that she

Speaker: NA
Text: has been telling him for some time that what

Speaker: NA
Text: we need in this country is a 'national jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: policy'. Now that this Labor Premier has

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed that the Federal Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have a jobs policy, and given the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of the drought, when will the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: face up to his responsibilities and put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that will create long term economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth and sustainable jobs?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I remind the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of something that I pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: \n the House some time ago about the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of the policies that the honourable member is

Speaker: NA
Text: advocating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-What about Kirner?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: We will come to the Premi-

Speaker: NA
Text: er of Victoria in a moment, if the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will just contain himself. Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite should recall that what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are advocating to deal with employment in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country is a goods and services tax. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to remind them of some figures that I

Speaker: NA
Text: gave recently about what happened in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand with the introduction of a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: based consumption tax. In New Zealand, since

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of the consumption tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: employment has fallen by 6 per cent. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what has happened in New Zealand. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members cannot just wipe New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: off, because every one of the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Ministers is beating a path across

Speaker: NA
Text: there. They want to make Australia a nation

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kiwis. New Zealand is their role model. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think that that is something to which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians particularly look forward, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what honourable members opposite want to

Speaker: NA
Text: do. They say that this is the example that they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to follow.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tell the gentleman who asked the question,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the National Party that, since

Speaker: NA
Text: the broad based consumption tax was intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in New Zealand, employment has fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: by almost 6 per cent. At the same time in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, including the employment losses of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most recent period, there has been a 9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase in employment. That is a 15 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent difference. That is what honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite would do to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: They would smash any opportunity for eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic recovery. Just as this has happened in

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand, so it would happen here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The situation is that the record of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is, as I have said before in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, the creation of 177,000 jobs per annum,

Speaker: NA
Text: on average, since we have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: had their opportunity. We have created jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: three times faster than honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite created them when they were in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. The honourable member opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: can shake his unknowing head, but he cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: change the statistics. Our rate of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: creation is three times greater than that of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: While employment in New Zealand-the

Speaker: NA
Text: country which the Opposition uses as its

Speaker: NA
Text: model and on which it wants to base its

Speaker: NA
Text: experiment in this country-was going down

Speaker: NA
Text: by 6 per cent, Australia's was up by 9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, a difference of a million jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer- Mrs Kirner?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: We have pointed out-it is

Speaker: NA
Text: true for the Premier of Victoria; it is true for

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone in the State-that one cannot change

Speaker: NA
Text: the statistics. The statistics are very simple

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will remind the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party what they were and what we had to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with. We had a situation in this country where

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure was increasing twice as fast as

Speaker: NA
Text: production. The Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: will admit in the privacy of his room that if

Speaker: NA
Text: we had not slowed down the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy the world would have imposed a

Speaker: NA
Text: much more drastic solution upon us. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact, so we had to slow the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we are starting to see the indisputable

Speaker: NA
Text: signs of recovery which will mean that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: second half of this financial year employment

Speaker: NA
Text: will grow, and it will grow on a much more

Speaker: NA
Text: secure base. As part of the slowing down of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy, which had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done in those circumstances, we now have a

Speaker: NA
Text: position which is distinct from any other

Speaker: NA
Text: recession out of which this country has come,

Speaker: NA
Text: including what those opposite gave us. We

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited their recession. What was the infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion rate that they gave us? It was 11.2 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. They gave us a massive recession but

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not do anything about inflation-it

Speaker: NA
Text: was still 11.2 per cent. So we had to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: this country out of recession in 1983 with an

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited inflation rate of 11.2 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, we had to recess the economy-

Speaker: NA
Text: that has happened. But now, in the process,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the range of relevant policies we

Speaker: NA
Text: will have in this year an inflation rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, which is significantly less than that of

Speaker: NA
Text: our major trading partners. That will mean

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian industry will be increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive. It will mean that jobs that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will create, as we go back to the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of job creation that we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: over our period of government, will be more

Speaker: NA
Text: secure in an Australian economy which is

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly more competitive than it has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: been before.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had the courage to bring in the

Speaker: NA
Text: processes of micro-economic reform about

Speaker: NA
Text: which all those opposite have ever done is

Speaker: NA
Text: heehaw. They have never done anything about

Speaker: NA
Text: it. They are the people who kept tariff rates

Speaker: NA
Text: as high as they possibly could be, which

Speaker: NA
Text: rendered our industry uncompetitive. They

Speaker: NA
Text: never did anything about our transport infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure in order to make it more competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. All they did was talk. They never did

Speaker: NA
Text: anything.

Speaker: NA
Text: They gave to this country in 1983 a legacy

Speaker: NA
Text: of a taxation system which was the worst in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world-a totally unreformed infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. We have changed those things. That

Speaker: NA
Text: means that as we come out of this recession,

Speaker: NA
Text: as we will and as we are doing now, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to resume the employment growth

Speaker: NA
Text: which has characterised all the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: period of the Hawke Labor Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing

Speaker: Mr KERR
Text: My question is to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Health, Housing and Community Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the significance of the most recent

Speaker: NA
Text: ABS figures on housing finance approvals and

Speaker: NA
Text: dwelling approvals?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Denison for his question. Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, as the Prime Minister has been indicat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in regard to the signs of recovery, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased activity in the housing industry is an

Speaker: NA
Text: early indicator of broader economic recovery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently released figures from the ABS

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that we will see broader steady

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery over the course of the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The statistics for housing finance in July

Speaker: NA
Text: this year show that the number of loan ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: provals for owner occupied dwellings in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased by 8 per cent over June and by 36 per

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 per cent compared with July last year. More

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, loan approvals over the three-

Speaker: NA
Text: month period to July this year increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 per cent over the previous three months,

Speaker: NA
Text: with demand growing strongly in this period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics also show that in the three months

Speaker: NA
Text: to August dwelling approvals increased by 8

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent over the previous three months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Figures froIll the Housing Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Association for the same period show that net

Speaker: NA
Text: sales of houses increased by 21 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: These trend increases are moderated by slight

Speaker: NA
Text: declines in August, which indicate that growth

Speaker: NA
Text: is proceeding at a moderate pace. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: sign that the housing market will overheat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall increased demand, assisted by

Speaker: NA
Text: declining home loan interest rates, should

Speaker: NA
Text: flow through to a significant increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: housing commencements in the September

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter. This is, of course, consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indicative Planning Council's forecast of an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in dwelling commencements to

Speaker: NA
Text: 135,000 in 1991-92. Increased activity will

Speaker: NA
Text: generate employment opportunities not only

Speaker: NA
Text: in the building industry but also in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponents of production, industry and retail

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consistent with the answer to the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: question, we are beginning to see the early

Speaker: NA
Text: signs of a steady recovery. That is particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in the area of housing. Of course, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is against that background that the issue ?f

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation is clearly so important. In Austraha

Speaker: NA
Text: most building materials are exempt from

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax. Indeed, it represents only

Speaker: NA
Text: about one per cent of the cost of a new home.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even allowing for the abolition of wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax and fuel excise, a goods and services

Speaker: NA
Text: tax of 12112 per cent would increase the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to which new houses are taxed by some 10

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reith-Where did you get that figure

Speaker: NA
Text: from?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I will tell the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member what I can get. I can get this particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar clipping, which indicates the views of Ron

Speaker: NA
Text: Silberberg of the Housing Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Association on the impact of a goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services tax on the housing industry in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Ron Silberberg is quite independent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government and is someone who, I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand, is not uncritical these days of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's policies. He talks about the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact under a 15 per cent tax. He suggests

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cost of a $130,000 house and land

Speaker: NA
Text: package would increase by $10,000. He says

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is a ferocious impact and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty for new home buyers is that it is all

Speaker: NA
Text: front-end loading.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have an Opposition that decries any

Speaker: NA
Text: sign of recovery; we have an Opposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: says that it wants to go forward into -ew

Speaker: NA
Text: policies in relation to the goods and servIces

Speaker: NA
Text: tax; and we have an Opposition that says that

Speaker: NA
Text: that tax ought to be a comprehensive tax, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, it ought to be as simple and cle-. as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. So the Housing Industry ASSOCIatIOn

Speaker: NA
Text: makes its assessment; it sees What the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: means. It means that new home buyers-

Speaker: NA
Text: people at a stage which obviously is not

Speaker: NA
Text: lacking in difficulties-are going to be loaded

Speaker: NA
Text: with a $10,000 impost or something of that

Speaker: NA
Text: order in terms of a new tax with all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences in terms of employment and all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the opportunities to abort the recovery that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been speaking about.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by simply saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is pleased to see the genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: signs of recovery that are occurring in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. We are horrified by the prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: of what Ron Silberberg calls a ferocious tax

Speaker: NA
Text: that might be imposed by the Opposition if

Speaker: NA
Text: ever the opportunity came up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare

Speaker: Dr BOB WOODS
Text: My question is direct-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has still not finalised its Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: decision on Medicare? Is it also a fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: Caucus is divided on the matter? Given that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is clearly split over health

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, is it a fact that, if you cannot govern

Speaker: NA
Text: yourself, you cannot govern the country?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: I am afraid that I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: resist the temptation. If we are going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about health care policy, it is an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate moment to-

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: Come on. We support you on

Speaker: NA
Text: this one and you cannot even deliver.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: We will see about the

Speaker: NA
Text: credentials of these people opposite to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about health policy. I remind the House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: immortal words of Mr Shack.

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member-Just put it on

Speaker: NA
Text: CD.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: We will, I think. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: what he had to say on 25 January 1990. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were great words, Peter, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: second paragraph, which is not always men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned. The second paragraph really is better

Speaker: NA
Text: than the first. The first paragraph-and this

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Liberals on health policy-reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: Now I want to say to you with all the frankness

Speaker: NA
Text: that I can muster-

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is not a lot, but on this occasion it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a good deal. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal and National Parties do not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly good track record in health and you

Speaker: NA
Text: don't need me to remind you of our last period in

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: And unless they are the world's greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: masochists, they would never want to be

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded of their record in health during their

Speaker: NA
Text: last period in government. But the next

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph was even better.

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: They are asleep; look at

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Yes, look at them, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: laughing-and they will be laughing in a

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Opposition members will

Speaker: NA
Text: not divert attention from the next paragraph.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is what Mr Shack had to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: You might accuse us of a lot of things but one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the things I don't think we are guilty of is learning

Speaker: NA
Text: from our past mistakes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, he was right. Those opposite do not

Speaker: NA
Text: learn from their mistakes: they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: produced a health policy; they still do

Speaker: NA
Text: have one. We on this side of the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: have a health policy in operation which is

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed by over 70 per cent of the speculation

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian electorate. They are the facts.

Speaker: NA
Text: than 70 per cent of the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: endorse the health policy of this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members-Where is your undertaken.

Speaker: NA
Text: policy?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: We have a policy; those It is

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite do not. At this time we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: process under way: the Caucus has been given

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity, as it should be given

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity, of examining proposals put responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in the Budget. That process will go kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: on through this week. Out of this process, the

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast will still remain: on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, a Party and a government which have

Speaker: NA
Text: a relevant, compassionate, universal, equitable

Speaker: NA
Text: health policy; on the other side, none.

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Venture by Australia Post and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Airlines

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: My question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Land Transport. I refer the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-Who?

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: The Minister for Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, Bob Brown.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Burke will ask his question.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Land Transport about recent speculation that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post and Australian Airlines were

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at forming a joint venture. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister aware of that speculation? Can he

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House on the situation?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer Mr Acting Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise on a point of order. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member made a mistake by using the term

Speaker: NA
Text: 'speCUlation'. Standing order 144(g) states

Speaker: NA
Text: that a question should not contain 'hypotheti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal matter' as well as other aspects. That

Speaker: NA
Text: question clearly has been badly drafted and is

Speaker: NA
Text: out of order.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The question is

Speaker: NA
Text: in order. The Minister for Land Transport.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Text: I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: not honourable member for Burke for the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I acknowledge his vigilance in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to questions of this kind. I am aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: which surrounded the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: More of some type of joint venture between

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post and Australian Airlines. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted, as well, to have this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that such a joint venture has been

Speaker: NA
Text: It was announced this morning by

Speaker: NA
Text: the managing directors of both those bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly important as far as the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector generally is concerned, because both

Speaker: NA
Text: these government business enterprises have

Speaker: NA
Text: the been given a commercial charter with the

Speaker: NA
Text: of pursuing initiatives of this

Speaker: NA
Text: We can all feel particularly pleased about

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that, when corporations of that kind

Speaker: NA
Text: are given the opportunity to pursue commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial imperatives, they willingly undertake that

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility -d, on occasions of this kind,

Speaker: NA
Text: they take advantage as well of the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of initiatives being pursued. As honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members know, and for some particular

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons which the honourable member in his

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity as Chairman of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and communications committee

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to my attention, there is a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: important spin-offs from this. I know the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Burke is delighted to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear that the announcement has been made.

Speaker: NA
Text: We expect that the joint venture will be

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken sometime early next year. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: make . it possible to bring together all the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing customer contacts that we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to develop through Australia Post with

Speaker: NA
Text: all the freight expertise and a lot of the

Speaker: NA
Text: electronic arrangements that have been built

Speaker: NA
Text: into the operations of Australian Airlines. As

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Airlines is one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: government business enterprises that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been looking at in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalise public sector involvement and

Speaker: NA
Text: public sector ownership, the proposed joint

Speaker: NA
Text: venture is even more relevant.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as contact with customers-with the

Speaker: NA
Text: community-is concerned, the joint venture

Speaker: NA
Text: will have access to 1,400 post office outlets

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia and another 3,100 post office

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies. The joint venture will make it

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for that to spread into rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: remote Australia and to bring together all the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing functions of those two operations. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have the well-developed courier service which

Speaker: NA
Text: is now being operated by Australia Post,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with the well-developed freight

Speaker: NA
Text: service which is operated by Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Airlines. Each day there would be about 200

Speaker: NA
Text: separate air movements that would be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute towards the development of that

Speaker: NA
Text: service. Also, a considerable number of

Speaker: NA
Text: separate operations presently being pursued

Speaker: NA
Text: by both of those companies will be brought

Speaker: NA
Text: together.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole operation will provide a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant share of domestic air express business

Speaker: NA
Text: among air courier services, both express

Speaker: NA
Text: parcels and air freight. I know this will be

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on a decision by government to

Speaker: NA
Text: endorse the joint venture. I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be any likelihood of its being

Speaker: NA
Text: delayed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal certainly has my goodwill and

Speaker: NA
Text: my support. It is an extremely important

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative that has been undertaken by

Speaker: NA
Text: government business enterprises operating

Speaker: NA
Text: under the reforms which have been introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Hawke Labor Government. As a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, these government business enterprises

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing a much more effective job for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people through the public sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have no doubt that this will be another

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding success on the part of two very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant and important government business

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interest Rates

Speaker: Mr REITH
Text: Does the Treasurer agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: his senior colleague Senator Button, who

Speaker: NA
Text: today in Question Time in the Senate has

Speaker: NA
Text: ruled out a further drop in interest rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: We have appropriate mecha-

Speaker: NA
Text: nisms in place for dealing with monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on an ongoing basis. I am not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: business of fattening people's pockets by

Speaker: NA
Text: speculating about interest rates; we will

Speaker: NA
Text: follow due process. The only person who

Speaker: NA
Text: really got the last drop in interest rates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely wrong was the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in his totally unprincipled attack on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor of the Reserve Bank-

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: You have got it wrong.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has it completely wrong. His attack on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor of the Reserve Bank not only was

Speaker: NA
Text: unprincipled but also probably was actionable.

Speaker: NA
Text: He completely misunderstands the relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Reserve Bank and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Power Stations

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: My question is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-Here he is, Kerry

Speaker: NA
Text: Packer's little mate.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: It concerns the electricity indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and the future of those working at power

Speaker: NA
Text: stations on the central coast of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. Is he aware of claims made in

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday's Australian Financial Review that

Speaker: NA
Text: current State Government plans to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: private investment in power stations will not

Speaker: NA
Text: result in significant competition or micro-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic reform of this industry? What steps

Speaker: NA
Text: have been taken to improve the efficiency of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian electricity industry?

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dobell for his question. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: known to members of the House that in his

Speaker: NA
Text: former role the honourable member for Dobell

Speaker: NA
Text: was regarded as one of the finest electrical

Speaker: NA
Text: engineers since Edison; accordingly, he has an

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing interest in these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear to members of the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity is a key component in determining

Speaker: NA
Text: costs and competitiveness and, accordingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the real level of our incomes. This industry

Speaker: NA
Text: a very significant one. It has capital assets

Speaker: NA
Text: the order of $100 billion, and sales in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of $10 billion annually. In that context it

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be put in some perspective, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective is that as an industry in value

Speaker: NA
Text: adding terms and capital terms it is, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, significantly bigger than our motor

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle industry and many times larger than

Speaker: NA
Text: our iron and steel industries and, accordingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: a major industry for government attention. It

Speaker: NA
Text: did not have much government attention, I

Speaker: NA
Text: might say, for many decades. Just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago when-rhetorically, I admit-I

Speaker: NA
Text: asked members of the Opposition to name but

Speaker: NA
Text: one significant micro-economic reform in

Speaker: NA
Text: their nearly three decades of government,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a barren silence. This is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter for record: the Opposition comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue with not a very good record at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I may go back to the issue, it goes

Speaker: NA
Text: without saying that the supply of reliable, low

Speaker: NA
Text: cost and clean energy is essential to underlie

Speaker: NA
Text: our economic well-being and our future

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity. That is why the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken a very significant role in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: developments which, of course, go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of a national electricity grid. The

Speaker: NA
Text: catalyst for these very dramatic reforms was

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's new federalism mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: which has seen the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: National Electricity Grid Council. To reflect

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's views on the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: that mechanism, it is worth informing the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that the Commonwealth nominee is Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Geoff Miller, the Secretary to the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Primary Industries and Energy. It is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant body with significant potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the working together for the

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest-the common good-there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be very major developments arising out

Speaker: NA
Text: of this process. I think the first and most

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious one is prospectively very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: cost reductions in electricity prices but of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal importance is that, to the extent that we

Speaker: NA
Text: can gamer greater efficiency at a national

Speaker: NA
Text: level, we of course have less call on our

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and, therefore, we have better

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental outcomes. There will be sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant benefits to all Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just before I conclude, it is worth making

Speaker: NA
Text: is this point: in a few short years Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: in electricity has moved from being the seventh

Speaker: NA
Text: cheapest in the OECD to now being, accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the most recent reports, the third least

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive in the OECD. We are getting better

Speaker: NA
Text: fast, but I think the Commonwealth's role in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of acting as a catalyst to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: these further and very significant reforms,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly, as I say, in the context of a

Speaker: NA
Text: national electricity grid, can potentially move

Speaker: NA
Text: us not to third best in the OECD but, even

Speaker: NA
Text: with the challenge of some of our competitors

Speaker: NA
Text: with their hydro-electricity, to a position

Speaker: NA
Text: where we can genuinely, in my view, aim for

Speaker: NA
Text: world's best.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lee Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I am informed by one of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland referred to me as 'Packer'S little

Speaker: NA
Text: mate' at the start of the answer to my ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I assume that is a reference to my

Speaker: NA
Text: chairmanship of the print media inquiry. I

Speaker: NA
Text: find that offensive and ask him to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: I have to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Chair did not hear that interjection. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would only rely upon the judgment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Gippsland as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not he made that remark. If he did

Speaker: NA
Text: so, clearly it is appropriate to withdraw.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-It is not appropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey- Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. Does the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: consider being called 'Packer's mate' an

Speaker: NA
Text: insult?

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for 0' Connor has no point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interest Rates

Speaker: Mr REITH
Text: My question is addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer. Given the Treasurer's last

Speaker: NA
Text: answer, is he saying that it was inappropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: for Senator Button to make such comments on

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-Yes or no?

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: No.

Speaker: NA
Text: Waste Water Treatment

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Text: I direct my ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister aware of an article in today's

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian claiming that the Australian waste

Speaker: NA
Text: water treatment company Memtec is about to

Speaker: NA
Text: move offshore because of a lack of State

Speaker: NA
Text: government support and the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: national water quality standards? What are the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for water quality management in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia? What progress has been made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of national standards?

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for his question and for his continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing interest in Australian industry. I am aware

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am very concerned that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: company Memtec is considering moving its

Speaker: NA
Text: main base of operations overseas. The Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been very supportive of

Speaker: NA
Text: Memtec's research and development program.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has already provided, through the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Industry, Technology and Commerce,

Speaker: NA
Text: over $3.6m to Memtec, with a further $1.1m

Speaker: NA
Text: committed. So the Government has been very

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of this new technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: This technology is important to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: because it offers the prospect of very high

Speaker: NA
Text: quality waste water treatment for our cities

Speaker: NA
Text: and our country areas. It provides a clean

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative to offshore disposal of inadequatethat

Speaker: NA
Text: ly treated sewage. It is important to note

Speaker: NA
Text: the Memtec technology is not just concepts

Speaker: NA
Text: on the drawing board. Memtec is a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: company and there is a great deal of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in it overseas. It already has a small plant

Speaker: NA
Text: operating out of Blackheath in the Blue

Speaker: NA
Text: Mountains. It is a very good example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: clever country at work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has promised a great deal to

Speaker: NA
Text: Memtec, and to people in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: but has not delivered. Last year, on 27 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990, at a press conference between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Environment, Mr Tim Moore; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier, Mr Nick Greiner; and also the Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Board a commitment was given that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be proceeding with a $20m Memtec

Speaker: NA
Text: filtration plant in Cronulla in Sydney. On that

Speaker: NA
Text: date Mr Greiner said that the Sydney Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Board remained prepared to take responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: risks to seek to provide better than tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment standards at plants such as Cronulla

Speaker: NA
Text: where this could be achieved by using this

Speaker: NA
Text: radical new Australian technology. But what

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened? Nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. Standing order 142 says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: public affairs with which he is officially connected,

Speaker: NA
Text: to proceedings pending in the House, or to any

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of administration for which he is respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is now giving us a case for State

Speaker: NA
Text: government support of an industry, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: find hardly within the parameters of her

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio responsibility in this House. She

Speaker: NA
Text: could even do as the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lalor once used to do and tell us about some

Speaker: NA
Text: new developments, but she is putting a case

Speaker: NA
Text: which is quite commercial and appears to be

Speaker: NA
Text: within the realm of a State government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think her answer is totally irrelevant.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: still within the boundaries of the question that

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked. However, I am listening to the

Speaker: NA
Text: answer of the Minister.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: That shows how little those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite know about the priorities of this

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio, because waste water is a major

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental issue in this country. I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: it was a priority for the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: that Government. Unfortunately, all the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales Government has done is put out

Speaker: NA
Text: a press release about it and given a commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to a company which has already provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed infrastructure, but it will not sign the

Speaker: NA
Text: contract. What has this company, a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian company, got to do? Now it has

Speaker: NA
Text: got to look overseas. I think that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: shame for Australian industry and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the Federal Government's point of

Speaker: NA
Text: view-and the Opposition might like to listen

Speaker: NA
Text: to this-it would be very unfortunate, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, if Memtec were to be forced offshore. settled.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say that because the Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the recently announced Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection Agency, will be involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of national environmental quality

Speaker: NA
Text: standards, including standards of water

Speaker: NA
Text: ty. This will be done in cooperation with

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments through mechanisms being

Speaker: NA
Text: developed through the inter-governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on the environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that these standards will 1.

Speaker: NA
Text: be extremely rigorous and will require the

Speaker: NA
Text: best available technology to meet them. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is hardly surprising given that clean

Speaker: NA
Text: one of Australia's scarcest commodities. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would be crazy to force a home grown

Speaker: NA
Text: company offshore when that company has

Speaker: NA
Text: developed technology which is amongst the

Speaker: NA
Text: most advanced water treatment technologies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world. Not only would we reduce our

Speaker: NA
Text: options to achieve high water quality but we

Speaker: NA
Text: would lose the opportunity to generate huge

Speaker: NA
Text: export dollars.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask that further

Speaker: NA
Text: questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lee Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I understand that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Orders it is up to you to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: whether a member should be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw an allegation against another. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland, in response to you, said that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not appropriate that it be withdrawn. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: wondering whether he should be asked whe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther he made the statement that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Packer's little mate'.
