Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-If the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: feels hurt or wounded in any way, I am happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to withdraw. But I do not like the sleazebag

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education prompting him, given

Speaker: NA
Text: his record on Reid and the others in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s. The Minister has been tutoring him for

Speaker: NA
Text: the last five minutes.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: great honourable member for Gippsland will not

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse the privilege of the chamber by speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in such a manner. Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government did not assist the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gippsland in his process of

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal. I believe that the matter is now

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HOWARD {Bennelong)- Mr Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may proceed.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: In today's Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a report regarding proceedings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Inc. royal commission. In

Speaker: NA
Text: a story under the by-line of Jane Hammond

Speaker: NA
Text: it is said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The former leader of the Opposition, Mr John

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard, and the former West Australian Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: senator, Mr Fred Chaney, strongly supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: West Australian government's decision to indemni-

Speaker: NA
Text: fy a $150 million line of credit to Rothwell's Bank,

Speaker: NA
Text: the WA royal commission heard yesterday.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently that is a report of some evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the former Deputy Premier of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia, Mr David Parker. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report goes on to say that Mr Tony Oates,

Speaker: NA
Text: who I understand was, is or has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Liberal Party in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, was a Bond Corporation director at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time and he allegedly told Parker that he

Speaker: NA
Text: had discussed the matter on the telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: with both me and the honourable member for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pearce.

Speaker: NA
Text: That report is totally incorrect. At no stage

Speaker: NA
Text: have I voiced to anybody any support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision by the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of a line of credit. It is true, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I told the House some weeks ago, that during'

Speaker: NA
Text: the weekend of the Rothwells bail out, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Bond telephoned me complaining that Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Barry MACKinnon, the Leader of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party in Western Australia, would not cooper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate in giving a political indemnity to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Report Burke Government in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government guarantee. That was the first I

Speaker: NA
Text: knew of Mr MACKinnon's role and the first I

Speaker: NA
Text: knew of the bail out. I subsequently spoke to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MACKinnon, who explained his position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I then rang Mr Bond back and told him that

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as I was concerned if private sector

Speaker: NA
Text: people wanted to put money in to bail out

Speaker: NA
Text: Rothwells that was fine, I certainly would not

Speaker: NA
Text: offer any criticism of that and I could under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand some positive reasons for it occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I made it perfectly clear that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was not a case for government involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: and that I totally supported Mr MACKinnon's

Speaker: NA
Text: position. I also understand, in fairness to him,

Speaker: NA
Text: that that was the position consistently taken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the former Senator Chaney and he has

Speaker: NA
Text: issued a press release to that effect today. I

Speaker: NA
Text: categorically deny the allegation that I in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way supported it. I also deny having had any

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with Mr Oates on the matter as

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged. I do not remember having met the

Speaker: NA
Text: man; I may have received a letter from him,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I certainly do not recall any personal

Speaker: NA
Text: approach. So the claim is completely and

Speaker: NA
Text: utterly untrue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr DUBOIS {St George)- Mr Acting

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr DUBOIS
Text: I do.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-You are in favour of a third

Speaker: NA
Text: runway.

Speaker: Mr DUBOIS
Text: Just listen. In an article in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunday Telegraph of 8 September its

Speaker: NA
Text: correspondent Mark MCEvoy identified me as

Speaker: NA
Text: one of six Federal members publicly support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the councils against a third runway propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sal. That is not true. I have never supported

Speaker: NA
Text: the councils. I do in fact support the third

Speaker: NA
Text: runway. The article went on to claim that I

Speaker: NA
Text: also endorsed a proposal to impose a $5 noise

Speaker: NA
Text: tax plan, whereas I do not. All I know about

Speaker: NA
Text: that plan is that it would generate some

Speaker: NA
Text: income for the councils to distribute as they

Speaker: NA
Text: see fit, and I think it is rather bizarre.

Speaker: NA
Text: The article went on to say that I was one

Speaker: NA
Text: the six MPs who opposed a third runway,

Speaker: NA
Text: claiming that it would be cheaper to build

Speaker: NA
Text: new airport at Badgerys Creek. That is not

Speaker: NA
Text: true. It is clearly cheaper to build a third

Speaker: NA
Text: runway than to build a new airport at ister

Speaker: NA
Text: Badgerys Creek. I conclude by saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: long-suffering people of St George are lookaccountancy

Speaker: NA
Text: ing forward to some relief from aircraft noise

Speaker: NA
Text: when the third runway is built.

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Wholesale Sales Tax System

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Text: I have received

Speaker: NA
Text: a letter from the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo proposing that a definite matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: public importance be submitted to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The enormous cost to business of the outdated

Speaker: NA
Text: ramshackle wholesale sales tax system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Standing Orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: Mayo) (3.12 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: current wholesale sales tax system in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, which reaps something like $9.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion a year for the Government, is believed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be the oldest living tax system of a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption kind left in the world. It is a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system that was introduced before Winston

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill became Prime Minister of Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain, before the jet engine was invented,

Speaker: NA
Text: when sound was just coming to the movies

Speaker: NA
Text: and when the Prime Minister of Australia ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) was a tiny baby. It is a taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: system which is so old that I believe it has

Speaker: NA
Text: very real tourist potential, for as long

Speaker: NA
Text: lasts accountants will swarm to Australia from

Speaker: NA
Text: all over the world to look at this historic

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation system with disbelief that any

Speaker: NA
Text: government in the modem world could retain

Speaker: NA
Text: a tax system so ancient, so decrepit and

Speaker: NA
Text: crippling to the business community of its

Speaker: NA
Text: country. They will find it indeed unbelievable.

Speaker: NA
Text: One only needs to begin by looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of the wholesale sales tax system to

Speaker: NA
Text: business just of administering it, let alone the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of paying it. I am not talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: of payment of the tax; I am simply talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of administering it. Accountants in

Speaker: NA
Text: a Australia estimate that something like $400m

Speaker: NA
Text: a year is spent by the business community on

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries alone in employing people to admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: the wholesale sales tax system. It spends

Speaker: NA
Text: the something like $100m a year on legal and

Speaker: NA
Text: fees, $14m on preparing whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: sale sales tax returns and, for those who like

Speaker: NA
Text: detail, $360,000 a year on posting the returns

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian Taxation Office. On top of

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian Taxation Office costs

Speaker: NA
Text: something like $23m worth of taxpayers'

Speaker: NA
Text: money to administer its side of the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax system. So in monetary terms the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax system-just to administer

Speaker: NA
Text: it-is costing the business community in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country something like $500m per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a lot of reasons why it costs the

Speaker: NA
Text: and business community so much. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: main reasons is that it costs so much in trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish within the business community

Speaker: NA
Text: places. how it can and should comply with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax law. One of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: problems is that goods are taxed at different

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. Some things are not taxed at all, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course. Consequently, there is a whole range

Speaker: NA
Text: of borderline problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us take the example of books. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt from the wholesale sales tax unless

Speaker: NA
Text: they are books of maps, in which case they

Speaker: NA
Text: are subject to a 10 per cent wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax rate, unless those books of maps are

Speaker: NA
Text: marketed exclusively for use in schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges or universities, in which case they

Speaker: NA
Text: revert to being exempt, unless they are of an

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising nature, in which case they are

Speaker: NA
Text: taxable at 20 per cent. Somebody has to work

Speaker: NA
Text: all that out, and that is where the $500m in

Speaker: NA
Text: as it administrative costs comes from.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people who follow the issue of sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax will know of the very famous and, admit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tedly, rather crude example of the difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: of administering the tax in the edible under-

Speaker: NA
Text: so wear case. I do not know how many people

Speaker: NA
Text: are aware of this product, edible underwear,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I have checked up and it exists. It is for

Speaker: NA
Text: sale in novelty shops. The edible underwear

Speaker: NA
Text: case is a cause celebre, let me tell honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members, in the folklore of the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax system in Australia. What is edible

Speaker: NA
Text: underwear?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-No, don't tell us.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: In terms of taxation-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to tell honourable members in detail

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is; and I have never eaten any, let me

Speaker: NA
Text: hasten to add-edible underwear, if defined

Speaker: NA
Text: as clothes for human wear, is exempt from

Speaker: NA
Text: the wholesale sales tax. If it is defined as

Speaker: NA
Text: food for human consumption it is exempt. But

Speaker: NA
Text: if it is defined as confectionery, as apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: licorice is used in edible underwear, it has a

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent tax. If it is classed as a savoury

Speaker: NA
Text: snack it has a 10 per cent tax. If it is defined

Speaker: NA
Text: as food for birds-and that is something to

Speaker: NA
Text: think about-and if it is for birds which are

Speaker: NA
Text: kept as domestic pets, it has a 20 per cent tax;

Speaker: NA
Text: but if it is for native birds there is no tax at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. So one can see that in the famous edible

Speaker: NA
Text: underwear case, which is a true case, the sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax office was thrown into a state of confu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are more serious cases. There is the

Speaker: NA
Text: famous example of these so-called health

Speaker: NA
Text: bars, muesli bars and so on where the Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Office and the manufacturers, and ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: the wholesalers, have had to try to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they are food or confectionery. But

Speaker: NA
Text: on top of those simple definitional problems

Speaker: NA
Text: there are valuation problems. Generally, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sale value is the equivalent wholesale value

Speaker: NA
Text: of goods. But what if the goods are not in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact sold by a wholesaler? In that case one

Speaker: NA
Text: has an extraordinarily complex problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to work out how one values the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct which is taxed at the wholesale level

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is no apparent person who is the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesaler.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is the problem which, of course, we

Speaker: NA
Text: allude to continually about the failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt a wide range of business inputs,

Speaker: NA
Text: which creates further borderline problems. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, manufacturers get an exemption on

Speaker: NA
Text: fork-lift trucks if they are used in manufactur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing premises, but they pay tax if they are used

Speaker: NA
Text: in a storage area. Wholesalers and retailers

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not manufacture goods at all end up

Speaker: NA
Text: not getting the exemption. Indeed, the failure

Speaker: NA
Text: to exempt business inputs gives rise to the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst aspects of the wholesale sales tax-its

Speaker: NA
Text: propensity to impose tax on top of tax over

Speaker: NA
Text: and over again.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, just in terms of the cost of adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tering the tax to business, the failure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax to keep pace with advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ces in commercial practices and technology

Speaker: NA
Text: has led to an enormous amount of work

Speaker: NA
Text: having to be undertaken by the Tax Office

Speaker: NA
Text: itself in trying to rectify these anomalies and

Speaker: NA
Text: in introducing administrative edicts and,

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately, in persuading the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce amendments to the law. For exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, in 1985-86 the Government decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: it would tax computer software. By the way,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is part of the Australian Labor Party's

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to broaden the scope of the whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: sale sales tax system. So in that year it decid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to tax computer software, only to find that

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of that legislation was

Speaker: NA
Text: simply impossible to carry out and subse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently it had to be repealed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are examples like that which go on

Speaker: NA
Text: and on and on-some trivial, some serious-

Speaker: NA
Text: but the fact is that, in order to administer this

Speaker: NA
Text: ramshackle, old-fashioned, totally out-of-date

Speaker: NA
Text: and historic taxation system, it is costing

Speaker: NA
Text: business about $500m a year. But the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of this old tax, this grandfather of sales taxes,

Speaker: NA
Text: of consumption taxes, on the direct sectors of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community is also absolutely exorbitant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, none of these costs to business-

Speaker: NA
Text: none of these sales taxes on their inputs-is

Speaker: NA
Text: in any way rebatable, as they would be with

Speaker: NA
Text: a goods and services tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all, there is the cost to exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exporters pay wholesale sales tax on many of

Speaker: NA
Text: their inputs, even though the goods which are

Speaker: NA
Text: actually exported are supposed to be exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: That adds something like $1.2 billion to

Speaker: NA
Text: export prices, thereby making Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exports relatively uncompetitive. This point

Speaker: NA
Text: was made in Helen Hughes's famous report

Speaker: NA
Text: on Australian export industries and the failure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country to compete in export markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the points that Professor Hughes made

Speaker: NA
Text: was that this country needed a goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services tax so that it could compete, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: in taxation terms, on an equal footing with

Speaker: NA
Text: most other countries which have a sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system of that kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sales tax effect on the tourism industry

Speaker: NA
Text: is also very great, and it is often unknown.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us take, for example, the effect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax on accommodation alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the tourism industry, its cost is something

Speaker: NA
Text: like $66m a year. Travel agents pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax on all of their inputs-to

Speaker: NA
Text: suppliers of services and for entertainment

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, transport and so on. They are all

Speaker: NA
Text: paying wholesale sales tax on their inputs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hire cars, taxis, trucks, refrigerated vans and

Speaker: NA
Text: so on, all of which are extensively used in the

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism industry, are all subject to the whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: sale sales tax-and none of it is rebatable. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, it is a very real impost directly

Speaker: NA
Text: on the business community, with no relief

Speaker: NA
Text: through a rebate system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecom, arguably Australia's biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: business, spent something like $375m last

Speaker: NA
Text: year in wholesale sales tax on its capital

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment purchases. Let us look at the road

Speaker: NA
Text: transport industry. The Road Transport Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Forum, in a recent article in a magazine

Speaker: NA
Text: called Truckin' Life, estimated that something

Speaker: NA
Text: like $1 billion a year in sales tax was being

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by the transport industry-none of it

Speaker: NA
Text: rebatable; all of it adding to the costs of any

Speaker: NA
Text: goods which are carried by transport to any

Speaker: NA
Text: part of Australia, and sometimes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wharves of this country, to get those products

Speaker: NA
Text: exported.

Speaker: NA
Text: People who live in regional and country

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia all have on them a greater sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: impost because of their greater dependence on

Speaker: NA
Text: transport to get goods to them-none of it

Speaker: NA
Text: rebatable under the Government's system; all

Speaker: NA
Text: of it rebatable under the goods and services

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system. Think of those two or three very

Speaker: NA
Text: major national transport companies. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: spending around $lOm each in sales tax on

Speaker: NA
Text: spare parts, tyres and new transport vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of that is rebatable, as it would be with

Speaker: NA
Text: a goods and services tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at the impact of the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax on the motor vehicle industry, an

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which is totemic to Australia-it is

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as the most symbolic of all of our

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industries. It is a savage impost

Speaker: NA
Text: on that industry because the motor vehicle

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in this country alone bears 30 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the burden of the wholesale sales tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: New car dealers also pay wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on most of their business inputs-that is on

Speaker: NA
Text: top of the 20 or 30 per cent sales tax that is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid on the motor vehicles. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: car dealer-whether it is a new car dealer or

Speaker: NA
Text: one who sells second-hand cars, and typically

Speaker: NA
Text: dealers will do both-pays sales tax on office

Speaker: NA
Text: furniture and furnishings; office equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: such as computers, fax machines and photo-

Speaker: NA
Text: copiers; advertising brochures; price lists;

Speaker: NA
Text: business cards; office, showroom and caryard

Speaker: NA
Text: lighting; serviCing equipment; equipment and

Speaker: NA
Text: tools used to carry out warranty repairs;

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrator vehicles-and so the list goes

Speaker: NA
Text: on. None of it is rebatable, remember; all of

Speaker: NA
Text: it is borne by the dealer himself or herself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Car manufacturers pay wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on many of their inputs as well, even though

Speaker: NA
Text: their products, once manufactured and whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: saled, have to bear the wholesale sales tax on

Speaker: NA
Text: top of that. They pay wholesale sales tax on

Speaker: NA
Text: goods for general administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, computers, the sales representatives'

Speaker: NA
Text: cars, advertising videos-on a whole list of

Speaker: NA
Text: things that car companies produce and need

Speaker: NA
Text: for efficient manufacture. They are slugged

Speaker: NA
Text: with a wholesale sales tax and again, in

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast with the goods and services tax

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal that we on this side of the House put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, none of that tax is rebatable; all of

Speaker: NA
Text: it is fully borne by the industry and simply

Speaker: NA
Text: adds to the cost of the industry. That makes

Speaker: NA
Text: it uncompetitive in the face of imports, and

Speaker: NA
Text: uncompetitive in the international market-

Speaker: NA
Text: place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noticed-as other readers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Financial Review today will also

Speaker: NA
Text: have noticed-that some people have been

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the potential costs to the racing

Speaker: NA
Text: industry of a goods and services tax. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: another of the great scare campaigns that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is rushing around mounting, as if

Speaker: NA
Text: there were no wholesale sales tax impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: the racing industry now; as if any impact

Speaker: NA
Text: were rebatable, which it is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the racing industry-just to

Speaker: NA
Text: take that one admittedly rather emotive

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in this country-is subject to a

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax burden of around $100m

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. None of this is rebatable. Admission

Speaker: NA
Text: tickets and course entry tokens are hit with a

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax. The fertilisers which are

Speaker: NA
Text: used to keep the track in good order are hit

Speaker: NA
Text: with the wholesale sales tax. The hoses used

Speaker: NA
Text: to water the track are hit with a 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax. The Minister for Science

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technology ( Mr Free), who is at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, might recall that mobile barriers and

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicles used to tow the mobile barriers

Speaker: NA
Text: are subject to a sales tax of 20 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-The cameras.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: The lighting for the track,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cameras, as the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party of Australia points out, the electric

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment used by the starter, air conditioning

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and duct work in the enclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: viewing areas, floor coverings, tables, chairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: cutlery, food preparation and preservation

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment, cash registers, food and drink

Speaker: NA
Text: vending machines and trophies attract a 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent sales tax. Sashes, horse mgs, totalisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor machines, totalisator display boards and

Speaker: NA
Text: television monitors are also subject to a 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent wholesale sales tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not bore everybody by going through

Speaker: NA
Text: every single thing on a racetrack. When one

Speaker: NA
Text: goes to the races on a Saturday or a

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, as one does in Strathalbyn in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, all of those things are subject to a

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax and none of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: reb-table. They are simply borne by the

Speaker: NA
Text: -acmg club; they are borne by the racing

Speaker: NA
Text: mdustry; they are borne ultimately by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ?o?Sumers. It is an impost, though, because

Speaker: NA
Text: It IS not rebatable. This simply makes busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness inefficient and uncompetitive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say in conclusion, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that the great difference between the

Speaker: NA
Text: iniquitous and irrational wholesales sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. G.G.D.

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholes)-Order! The honourable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: time has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer continuing to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! Before

Speaker: NA
Text: I call the Minister, I might remind honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that remarks that are made after a

Speaker: NA
Text: member has been told that his time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired are not recorded.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Text: Lindsay-Minister for Science

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technology and Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer) (3.27 p.m.)-Whatever else one

Speaker: NA
Text: can say about the contributions of the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able mem-er for Mayo ( Mr Downer), they

Speaker: NA
Text: seldom fad to amuse. Rarely does one learn

Speaker: NA
Text: very much by listening to him, but today we

Speaker: NA
Text: might in fact have learnt a little more about

Speaker: NA
Text: the continuing mystery and saga of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's consumption tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Mayo was keen

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell us about the longevity of the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax. I would have thought that that was

Speaker: NA
Text: an excellent argument in favour of a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: which has clearly stood the test of time. We

Speaker: NA
Text: learnt of his great interest in edible underwear

Speaker: NA
Text: and other items of entertainment. Regrettably,

Speaker: NA
Text: he did not treat us to quotes from Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: -anstone's . little red book. That was a great

Speaker: NA
Text: pIty. We mtght look forward to his doing that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future. Towards the end of the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought he was actually speaking about a

Speaker: NA
Text: life after politics operating 'a lift in a depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment store.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member referred to the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of -e wholesale sales tax to exports, the

Speaker: NA
Text: tounsm industry, telecommunications, road

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and the motor vehicle industry. He

Speaker: NA
Text: argued that these costs were not reba table

Speaker: NA
Text: under a wholesale sales tax system. Is he

Speaker: NA
Text: telling us a little more about the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax policy? Is he telling us that

Speaker: NA
Text: goods and services in categories related to

Speaker: NA
Text: those areas are likely to be exempt from a

Speaker: NA
Text: GST?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-No, they are not rebatable'

Speaker: NA
Text: you don't understand the words. '

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Text: We need to know a lot more

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Opposition's policy than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people have been told to date.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me put the question of wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax into the context of Labor's proud record

Speaker: NA
Text: in taxation reform. I remind the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: when this party won office in 1983 it inherit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed a taxation system which was in disrepair

Speaker: NA
Text: and disrepute. Years of neglect had resulted

Speaker: NA
Text: in a system which was inequitable, inefficient

Speaker: NA
Text: and complex. The previous coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, led by Mr Fraser and guided by

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic adviser who is currently the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson),

Speaker: NA
Text: simply ignored the basic principles of taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: policy-that is, equity, efficiency and sim-

Speaker: NA
Text: plicity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1983 the Labor Party has developed

Speaker: NA
Text: a taxation system which is fairer, more effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient and no longer open to massive abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me remind the House of some of these

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms. The top personal marginal taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: rate is now 47 per cent; in 1983, it was 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. The bottom personal marginal tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rate is now 21 per cent; in 1983, it was 30

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. The company tax rate is now 39 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; in 1983, it was 46 per cent. The effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive rate of company taxation in 1983 was an

Speaker: NA
Text: astonishing 78.4 per cent. So much for an

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition which, when in government,

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed these kinds of burdens on business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The introduction of the capital gains tax by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has meant that the privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: leged, who take a proportion of their income

Speaker: NA
Text: in capital gains, are now taxed. Before 1983

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation was an optional extra for the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: heeled. Fringe benefits are now taxed, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this raised over $1.26 billion in 1990-91.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under previous conservative governments, tax

Speaker: NA
Text: free fringe benefits were substituted, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, for cash income. The reforms institut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed by this Government have ensured fairness

Speaker: NA
Text: in the taxation system. People are now paying

Speaker: NA
Text: their share.

Speaker: NA
Text: Entertainment expenses are no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised as a tax deduction. As a Party, we

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished the long free lunch previously

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed at the expense of the average

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian. By introducing franked dividends,

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has reduced the effective company tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rate. It has meant that income received from

Speaker: NA
Text: equity investments is no longer double taxed

Speaker: NA
Text: and a longstanding bias against equity invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in favour of debt financing has been

Speaker: NA
Text: corrected-again by Labor. In addition, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: has ensured that foreign income is properly

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed. The reforms of the Hawke Government

Speaker: NA
Text: have meant that elaborate company structures

Speaker: NA
Text: established in offshore tax havens cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to disguise foreign income. In addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community now receives an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate return from the use of its natural

Speaker: NA
Text: resources through the resource rent tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wholesale sales tax system has been

Speaker: NA
Text: changed over those years. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo would have one believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the wholesale sales tax system has been

Speaker: NA
Text: immutable and not subject to change. This, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, has not been so. It has been altered

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years to reduce compliance costs. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of reforms introduced by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, wholesale sales tax collections,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a proportion of total taxation revenue, have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased at the rate of only 1.2 per cent since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84. Further, as a result of Labor's tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms, the amount of tax paid by individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: as a proportion of total taxation revenue has

Speaker: NA
Text: declined. So much for the alleged burden on

Speaker: NA
Text: business of the wholesale sales tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I indicated earlier, the longevity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax is an indication that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: stood the test of time. Let me deal briefly

Speaker: NA
Text: with some of those reforms to which I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred earlier. Reforms of the wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax have been directed to improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency and fairness of the system. I point

Speaker: NA
Text: to changes over the years that have done

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly that; for example, measures introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: in May 1985 to reduce evasion and avoid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance, saving the taxpayer $400m. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: changes introduced in September 1985 to rate

Speaker: NA
Text: classes and applied to base broadening and

Speaker: NA
Text: correction of anomalies and inconsistencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further base broadening and correction of

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies and introduction of changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax rates on wfue were introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986-87. In 1987-88, the sales tax exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: for commercial government authorities was

Speaker: NA
Text: removed, a move designed to put these

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities on an equal footing with private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector firms competing for the same re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources. In 1988-89, the sales tax exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: was removed from beer. Further adjustments

Speaker: NA
Text: were made in 1990-91, including the exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of exemptions for computer software and

Speaker: NA
Text: a move to provide for quarterly payments for

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses. All through its period of

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Government has quite sensib-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly looked at the wholesale sales tax system

Speaker: NA
Text: and made those adjustments where it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: thought necessary and desirable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make the point that the wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system is an established one. It is one that

Speaker: NA
Text: is well understood; it is one that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: impose on business the burden that the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition would have the House believe.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, during this debate something

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made of the impact of varying rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of wholesale sales tax on different goods. Far

Speaker: NA
Text: from this being the confusing aspect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax that the Opposition would have us believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: this very often gives government the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to use the wholesale sales tax to discri-

Speaker: NA
Text: minate in various ways either in favour of

Speaker: NA
Text: groups in the community or in favour of

Speaker: NA
Text: particular products. I give two examples. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of the measures introduced as a result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's Budget is the provision of assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled people in purchasing motor vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: and equipment associated with the transport

Speaker: NA
Text: of disabled people. As a result, wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax has been reduced in that area. A

Speaker: NA
Text: specific measure has been applied to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled people. This is the kind of positive

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination that would simply not be

Speaker: NA
Text: available under a consumption tax regime.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before that the Government took a deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion-a decision I think supported by the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of the Australian community and, I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope, by a majority of the Opposition-that

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be in our national interest to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of recycled products and, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: recycled paper. As a result, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to remove sales tax on recycled

Speaker: NA
Text: paper-a move which I hoped had the support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, but perhaps not the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mayo. This is again I think

Speaker: NA
Text: an instance where-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-Have you read the Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission report?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo will remain silent. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: heard in silence and he will remain silent or

Speaker: NA
Text: I will warn him.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Text: This is again an instance in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government can use the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax system to work towards desirable

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes in areas of general policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now ask this question: if the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to remove the wholesale sales tax, what

Speaker: NA
Text: will it replace it with? Those opposite tell us

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will have a goods and services tax-a

Speaker: NA
Text: GST, a consumption tax. They have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: terribly good at providing the details of

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what shape this consumption tax will

Speaker: NA
Text: take, the rates at which it will be applied, and

Speaker: NA
Text: what kinds of attempts might be made to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide compensation. We are told that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will get details at some stage in the future. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that many members of the press gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: and certainly many people interested in the

Speaker: NA
Text: shape of politics in this country were ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proaching 25 September with bated breath;

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition had booked the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Press Club for that day and excite-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rose. But unfortunately Dr Hewson

Speaker: NA
Text: squibbed it on that day. Yet again, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: to wait for the details of the consumption tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat what my Leader and other

Speaker: NA
Text: government members have said: a consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion tax is simply not on Labor's agenda. We

Speaker: NA
Text: reject it because of the simple fact that a

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax represents an attack on

Speaker: NA
Text: individual Australians. Further, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: increase inflation. A major objective of our

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policy is to see further reductions

Speaker: NA
Text: in inflation. By doing so, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: establishes the basis of sustainable increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in employment. In addition, a permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in inflation means sustainable wages

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes, resulting in an automatic advance-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in welfare for those on fixed incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: and then further reductions in interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a major objective of current economic

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What effect would a consumption tax have

Speaker: NA
Text: on inflation? What effect would a consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion tax have on those employment outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: which I hoped were an objective shared by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition and the Government? Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: give honourable members the evidence from

Speaker: NA
Text: Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: Association. He argues that a 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax would result in an immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 per cent increase in inflation. This is borne

Speaker: NA
Text: out by what happened in New Zealand, where

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation shot to a massive 18.9 per cent after

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of a consumption tax at 10

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Only now in New Zealand, after

Speaker: NA
Text: four years of recession, has inflation come

Speaker: NA
Text: down. Imagine what the results would be if a

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax at the rate of 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: were to be introduced in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at the general effect of a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption tax should it be introduced. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Catholic Social Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission summed it up rather well in June

Speaker: NA
Text: this year when it said that shifting from

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax to a goods and services tax would

Speaker: NA
Text: increase tax burdens for low income earners

Speaker: NA
Text: and families, both urban and rural. A con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption tax is clearly regressive. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: it hits hardest are those on the lowest in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes. A consumption tax would also mean

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia would forgo jobs and forgo

Speaker: NA
Text: growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at the impact of a

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax on business, the sector

Speaker: NA
Text: currently allegedly suffering such a burden.

Speaker: NA
Text: My colleague the Minister for Small Business

Speaker: NA
Text: and Customs ( Mr Beddall) told me that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are 930,000 reasons for rejecting a consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion tax. The introduction of a consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: tax would provide for approximately one

Speaker: NA
Text: million collection points. There are currently

Speaker: NA
Text: 70,000 collection points for the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax. In other words, it would provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase in collection points for tax of

Speaker: NA
Text: 930,000 in this country-hence the 930,000

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for rejecting the Opposition's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Small businesses would be forced to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count in detail to the Australian Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: Office for every item purchased and for every

Speaker: NA
Text: transaction made in order to claim rebates on

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumption tax. It would mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: every small business would have to institute

Speaker: NA
Text: new accounting and cash flow procedures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every small business in Australia would be

Speaker: NA
Text: collecting tax and would be monitoring the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of its business neighbOurs. The cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of complying with a consumption tax would

Speaker: NA
Text: fall most heavily on small business. The

Speaker: NA
Text: British experience shows that for every $100

Speaker: NA
Text: earned, just in complying with the task of

Speaker: NA
Text: administering a value added tax $1.20 is paid

Speaker: NA
Text: out by those in small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, a consumption tax means

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced profitability and increasedadministra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive burdens for business overall. It is unfortuwith

Speaker: NA
Text: nate that I am running out of time, as I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: refer in detail to the likely impact of a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption tax on the racing industry, a subject

Speaker: NA
Text: which apparently interests the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Text: MCEwen) (3.42 p.m.)-I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe that there has ever been such

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread and unified condemnation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax system. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Technology ( Mr Free) is indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: a rare species in supporting a system of

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax that is so iniquitous. The

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'equity', 'simplicity' and 'efficiency'

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister used in his speech certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: do not apply to the wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system. In fact, most of what the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said did not apply to the wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system or the problems that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo ( Mr Downer) raised.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are in the worst economic condition

Speaker: NA
Text: since the 1930s. We have a country riddled

Speaker: NA
Text: with high levels of debt and with unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment officially hovering around the one

Speaker: NA
Text: million mark. Business bankruptcies increased

Speaker: NA
Text: over 50 per cent compared with the same

Speaker: NA
Text: period last year. The Confederation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Industry's survey of investor

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence showed continuing high levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: business pessimism. In faCt, 87.5 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the respondents surveyed described the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate for investment as poor, very poor or

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply depressed. Make no mistake, it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate policies of this 60vernment that are

Speaker: NA
Text: directly responsible for the very sick state of

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The tragedy is that those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government benches have had the opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for reform, but they have frittered them

Speaker: NA
Text: away. Never has there been a more critical

Speaker: NA
Text: time for this Government to reform our

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax system and provide some

Speaker: NA
Text: much needed relief to business, to remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy imposts of tax on business so that

Speaker: NA
Text: growth can be stimulated and so that employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment opportunities can be provided. But this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government lacks the resolve. We have said

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate today that the wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system is outdated, unfair and ramshackle.

Speaker: NA
Text: The list of business, industry, manufacturing,

Speaker: NA
Text: mining and farming organisations that agree

Speaker: NA
Text: this statement is growing at a daily rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Blaxland was

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely correct when on 13 June 1985,

Speaker: NA
Text: while speaking to the Sydney Morning Her-

Speaker: NA
Text: ald, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The existing wholesale sales tax is fraught with

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies and complexities which render adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration and compliance unduly burdensome.

Speaker: NA
Text: Among its other features Which make it an undesir-

Speaker: NA
Text: able tax are: its multiple rates and exemptions,

Speaker: NA
Text: which distort both demand and supply decisions;

Speaker: NA
Text: valuation difficulties in determining a wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: price in a world of widely varying distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements; the fact that the tax must be carried

Speaker: NA
Text: by retailers when goods sit in stock, with retail

Speaker: NA
Text: margins applied to the tax-inclusive wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: price; a high proportion of the tax, about a half, is

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed on industry inputs.

Speaker: NA
Text: These features represented enormous cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: business in 1985. As the former Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: widened the wholesale sales tax base to

Speaker: NA
Text: collect more indirect tax to compensate for his

Speaker: NA
Text: lost opportunity for reform, today they repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent even greater cost to business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Cnossen, in the Australian Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Forum Journal, agreed that more than half of

Speaker: NA
Text: the initial incidence of wholesale sales tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on business inputs. A study prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Business Council of Australia by

Speaker: NA
Text: Monash University in March 1991 also

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed, and it estimated that 49 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the initial incidence of wholesale sales tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: on business purchases of inputs not eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for exemption as aids to manufacture. A

Speaker: NA
Text: further 14 per cent of wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: initially falls on business purchases of invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the very nature of the wholesale sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax system that makes it unfair, outdated and

Speaker: NA
Text: such a huge cost to business. It is the cpm-

Speaker: NA
Text: plexity of the system-with multiple rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: exemptions, anomalies and compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: costs-that is of such enormous cost to

Speaker: NA
Text: business. Multiple rates of 10 per cent, 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent and 30 per cent are applied to different

Speaker: NA
Text: categories of goods, unless those goods are

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt. The rationale used for applying

Speaker: NA
Text: different rates to different categories of items

Speaker: NA
Text: is arbitrary, but the onus of compliance falls

Speaker: NA
Text: on the business taxpayer. It is these mUltiple

Speaker: NA
Text: rates and exemptions that lead to costly

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes with the Australian Taxation Office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even if a business wins a decision against

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tax Office, the Tax Office can appeal to

Speaker: NA
Text: a higher court. While that appeal is pending,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tax Office insists that tax is payable in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with its interpretation of the law

Speaker: NA
Text: until the dispute finally is resolved by a

Speaker: NA
Text: higher court. This places the business in

Speaker: NA
Text: question in an invidious position. If that

Speaker: NA
Text: business acts on the lower court decision,

Speaker: NA
Text: should that decision ultimately be over-

Speaker: NA
Text: turned-often years later-the business

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer is unable to recover the tax from

Speaker: NA
Text: customers and so must bear the cost from his

Speaker: NA
Text: or her own resources. On the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: should a business charge and return tax to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tax Office on the basis of the Tax Office's

Speaker: NA
Text: advice, that business may not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: recover that tax if it becomes overpaid tax on

Speaker: NA
Text: a later decision. It is because of the day-to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day nature of the wholesale sales tax system

Speaker: NA
Text: that businesses are often inhibited .from

Speaker: NA
Text: exercising their objections and rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal. Often it is another cost on top of the

Speaker: NA
Text: already high cost of administering the system

Speaker: NA
Text: that business simply cannot afford.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me give some concrete examples of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these day-to-day problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses face in dealing with this outdated

Speaker: NA
Text: system. On the one hand the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: in his 12 March industry statement, exhorted

Speaker: NA
Text: business to export more manufactured goods

Speaker: NA
Text: and services and to substitute more quality

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian production for imports. No-one

Speaker: NA
Text: would disagree with that sentiment. But on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, by maintaining the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax system, the Prime Minister is mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our export industries uncompetitive to the

Speaker: NA
Text: tune of over $1 billion per year because of

Speaker: NA
Text: business input costs. But it is even worse than

Speaker: NA
Text: that. The whole question of whether or not

Speaker: NA
Text: particular processes applied to goods consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute manufacture for wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes is central to the whole meaning of

Speaker: NA
Text: the system. But, in spite of this crucial im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance, the actual definitions of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'manufacture' and 'manufacturer' have been

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of numerous legal challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, the reassembling of motor-

Speaker: NA
Text: cycles which previously ha"d--been assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: and tested by an overseas supplier and then

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked down into parts for shipping to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was not defined as manufacture; yet

Speaker: NA
Text: the assembling for the first time in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: of a motorcycle or car from completely

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked-down parts was defined as manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. The making up by a florist of wreaths,

Speaker: NA
Text: bouquets, posies, floral baskets and sheaves

Speaker: NA
Text: of flowers constitutes manufacture; yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: assembling of a bunch of flowers does not.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole wholesale sales tax system is not

Speaker: NA
Text: only a huge cost to business but also a night-

Speaker: NA
Text: mare for business to administer. Imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: being in the position of a business involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the building industry. Building materials

Speaker: NA
Text: may be unconditionally exempt, conditionally

Speaker: NA
Text: exempt, taxable at 10 per cent or taxable at

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent. Often the point of distinction is

Speaker: NA
Text: clouded, to say the least. Roller doors which

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporate a built-in motor qualify for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: emption as builders' hardware; but if the

Speaker: NA
Text: motor is external to the roller door, the motor

Speaker: NA
Text: is subject to tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of classification of wardrobes

Speaker: NA
Text: and so-called built-in cupboards, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: broom cupboards, over many years frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: has been subject to different interpretations by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Taxation Office and the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: in different States. At one stage, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: tests such as the provision of screws to build

Speaker: NA
Text: in a wardrobe or the absence of a back have

Speaker: NA
Text: been used to differentiate exempt built-in

Speaker: NA
Text: joinery from taxable freestanding furniture.

Speaker: NA
Text: Retail businesses experience cash flow

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties. The Government's own Beddall

Speaker: NA
Text: report recognised these huge costs. Of the 23

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations dealing with tax reform, the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation to have further discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Treasurer seems to be the rule of

Speaker: NA
Text: thumb. The meaning of exactly what is

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture, conditional exemptioIL<;, compli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance costs, anomalies, cash flow problems and

Speaker: NA
Text: the added costs that make our efforts uncom-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive all add up to these huge costs of this

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair system. (lime expired)

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Text: Forde) (3.52 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to oppose the matter which the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mayo ( Mr Downer) has

Speaker: NA
Text: raised. I look at it in terms of the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which I find people talking about equity. To

Speaker: NA
Text: talk of equity in relation to the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal to change the wholesale tax system

Speaker: NA
Text: to a consumption tax is extraordinary; mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Opposition are the very group of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are pursuing inequity in a system

Speaker: NA
Text: that they propose as a substitute for the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wholesale sales tax system enables us

Speaker: NA
Text: as a Government to target areas, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has responded to the Beddall

Speaker: NA
Text: report and to those demands of small business

Speaker: NA
Text: by announcing in the 1990-91 Budget the

Speaker: NA
Text: review that was undertaken by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation Office, the Treasury, industry repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives and other professional bodies. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government looked at the range of issues

Speaker: NA
Text: within the wholesale sales tax area. That area

Speaker: NA
Text: is efficient in that it allows targeting. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard that already from the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Technology ( Mr Free), who is at

Speaker: NA
Text: the table. He showed the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can show its compassion in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area by addressing issues concerning those

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities. It can also respond to

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs and demands of business in the way

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has by dealing with recycled paper,

Speaker: NA
Text: software and other issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has attempted, and pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: sued, a streamlining of the wholesale sales tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system. But honourable members on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side, while they talk about a range of figures

Speaker: NA
Text: within a wholesale sales tax system, have

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to look at the one figure which many

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians know and recognise-that is, zero.

Speaker: NA
Text: On many of our services and on necessities of

Speaker: NA
Text: life we pay no sales tax at all. What the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members are endeavouring to

Speaker: NA
Text: change is that zero, which would become

Speaker: NA
Text: something in the region of 15 per cent to 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: We find that the kinds of concerns for the

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism industry about which the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: bleat are not shared by the Opposition's own

Speaker: NA
Text: partners in the Northern Territory. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: placed a consumption tax and a levy on

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism beds-an attempt to gain more tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists by putting up more fees which has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought about a reverse effect. Indeed, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need only look at that to know that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of direction in which members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition are leading us, and that the kinds

Speaker: NA
Text: of arguments which we have heard trotted out

Speaker: NA
Text: against the wholesale sales tax are in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: quite spurious. We heard the sleazy story

Speaker: NA
Text: from the honourable member for Mayo about

Speaker: NA
Text: underwear. I listened to that part of his speech

Speaker: NA
Text: with disgust. His behaviour can only be

Speaker: NA
Text: described as outrageous.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other tenn which is bandied around by

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition is a 'rebatable'

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax. Either we pay consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: tax or we do not. What sort of nonsense do

Speaker: NA
Text: we have here? We have an Opposition which

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposing a change in tax policy, a shift in

Speaker: NA
Text: tax policy, but then says, 'Don't worry folks,

Speaker: NA
Text: none of you will have to pay it; it is all

Speaker: NA
Text: rebatable'. We understand that very well

Speaker: NA
Text: because that is what the Opposition's tax

Speaker: NA
Text: policy was right through the 1950s, 1960s and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970s when paying tax was simply an option

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rich-not, I might add, for the poor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the capital gains tax, the fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits tax and the tax file number are all

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of tax refonn which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: vigorously opposed by the Opposition. Why?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because everybody would have to pay them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we are presented with some grand

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme of things which says, 'We will all

Speaker: NA
Text: pay'. Those of us who lived through the years

Speaker: NA
Text: of those opposite know that is never the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not all pay. We on this side, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: poorer and less well off, will all pay; we

Speaker: NA
Text: know that very well. The richer and the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: heeled, of course, do not pay and will never

Speaker: NA
Text: pay under the system which the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has proposed. So I find it very interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: now to hear the honourable member for Mayo

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about rateable allowances, and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption tax which is rebatable. Good heav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ens, what new jargon is this? What indeed is

Speaker: NA
Text: this goingAo do? What is it about? We also

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the consumption tax touted as the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the black economy will be covered,

Speaker: NA
Text: those dreadful people out there who are

Speaker: NA
Text: operating in an economy in which they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: pay tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-That also applies to SP book-

Speaker: NA
Text: makers.

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Text: Indeed, SP bookmak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, as the Minister says. But there are very

Speaker: NA
Text: many people who will argue that in fact the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax is just what the doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: ordered for those people wishing to evade tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and join the market economy. There will be

Speaker: NA
Text: those of us who perhaps have a tradesperson

Speaker: NA
Text: come to our house who suggests a price for

Speaker: NA
Text: some work to be done and then says, 'But, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, if you pay me in cash and none of us

Speaker: NA
Text: do anything, then neither of us need pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption tax or the income tax'. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what is going to happen. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: very many tax consultants who see the growth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the black economy, the growth of the black

Speaker: NA
Text: market, as playing a very real part in the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the consumption tax will affect our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other matter which we have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: being bleated about today is the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the wholesale sales tax affects business, and

Speaker: NA
Text: small business in particular, but this new and

Speaker: NA
Text: grand scheme will be a panacea for all in

Speaker: NA
Text: business. Those people who have not had the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to travel to Canada or England

Speaker: NA
Text: will be unaware of the vast teams of people,

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of people, who scour

Speaker: NA
Text: the countryside day and night in their role of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax inspectors and value added tax collectors,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of the range of jokes about them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: paperwork, the administration, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely mammoth.

Speaker: NA
Text: We heard the Minister for Science and

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology say that not only will we have

Speaker: NA
Text: 930,000 extra people filling in forms-even

Speaker: NA
Text: if they only have to fill in one extra fonn-

Speaker: NA
Text: but also the administrative charges and the

Speaker: NA
Text: time spent by small business on this will be

Speaker: NA
Text: simply outrageous. Small business now does

Speaker: NA
Text: not pay and has never paid tax on its ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices-for example, its heating and its light-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-What about lights? There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a 20 per cent tax on lights.

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Text: It does not pay tax on

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity, or on the service for the lighting ---

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that this will come about. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: again, the concern for small business is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply a shield to hide the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: friends, the big business world, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: know, as does Australian society in general,

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumption tax will fall heaviest on

Speaker: NA
Text: people with low incomes and also on the

Speaker: NA
Text: smallest businesses. Those businesses who

Speaker: NA
Text: have fewer customers and employees and

Speaker: NA
Text: lower turnover will spend a disproportionate

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of their time and the time of their

Speaker: NA
Text: staff filling out fonns, collecting the material

Speaker: NA
Text: and sending it in.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Britain, the experience has been that, for

Speaker: NA
Text: every $100 earned, $1.20 is paid by small

Speaker: NA
Text: business just to comply with the administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the VAT. The VAT in Britain is a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: which has a huge number of exemptions, not

Speaker: NA
Text: a tax, as is proposed here for small busines-

Speaker: NA
Text: ses, which has no exemptions. Both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders ( Mr Reith) have been at pains to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that there is to be no exemption, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can have a nice simple method of

Speaker: NA
Text: operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House are anxious to

Speaker: NA
Text: see a tax system, a tax reform package, which

Speaker: NA
Text: ensures that all Australians, be they individu-

Speaker: NA
Text: als or people in business, are paying fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: and equitably, contributing to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The system should be fair-and it is fair. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: constantly being overhauled, as the wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax system is. It has stood the test of

Speaker: NA
Text: time, as indeed a consumption tax would not.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House reject such

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense. We believe this system would be

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely iniquitous on small business in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, on Australians in general and on

Speaker: NA
Text: society. We know that Australians everywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: will reject such an iniquitous and blatant tax

Speaker: NA
Text: that will in fact favour the rich and yet again

Speaker: NA
Text: penalise those people who are less well off in

Speaker: NA
Text: our community.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. M.J.R.

Speaker: NA
Text: MACKellar)-Order! The debate is concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSENT TO BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Assent to the following Bills reported:

Speaker: NA
Text: Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Crimes Amendment Bill 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: Crimes (Aviation) Bill 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990].

Speaker: NA
Text: Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: CORPORATION BILL 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNATE DEBATE:

Speaker: NA
Text: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVI-

Speaker: NA
Text: SIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMEND-

Speaker: NA
Text: MENTS) BILL 1991]

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 12 September, on

Speaker: NA
Text: motion by Mr Free:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. M.J.R.

Speaker: NA
Text: MACKelIar)-I understand it is the wish of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House to debate the Export Finance and

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Corporation Bill 1991 concurrently

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Export Finance and Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation (Transitional Provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991. There

Speaker: NA
Text: being no objection, the chair will allow that

Speaker: NA
Text: course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: Mayo) (4.03 p.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition supports these Bills which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has introduced to make some

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the way that the Export Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Insurance Corporation works. The chan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ges are twofold. Firstly, the Export Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Insurance Corporation Bill hives off the

Speaker: NA
Text: Export Finance and Insurance Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: from Austrade and establishes it as a

Speaker: NA
Text: government business enterprise and, secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it provides for a $200m supplement to EFIC's

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves in the form of a callable capital

Speaker: NA
Text: facility. The second Bill, the Export Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Insurance Corporation (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions and Consequential Amendments)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, is a transitional arrangement to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that EFIC can continue to operate during the

Speaker: NA
Text: period of transition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In supporting this Bill, though, we on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House would like to raise several

Speaker: NA
Text: issues in relation to EFIC and the way that

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC operates, and we would hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and EFIC, in particular, will take

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991. up some of these points because I think no

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation is perfect and, in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC, there are certainly areas where examin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation could be made into possible improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and better liaison with the banking

Speaker: NA
Text: sector of the business community in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one aspect of this Bill which we

Speaker: NA
Text: would take issue with; that is, the decision by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to retain the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for EFIC with the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Button) rather than to transfer it to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters responsible for the Department of Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Trade. I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been correct to transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade to the Department of Foreign Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Trade. I hope that, under the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Gareth Evans)-whoever is going to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the day to day responsibility for Austrade-

Speaker: NA
Text: that organisation will take the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: become substantially more efficient and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible than it has been in years gone by.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also noteworthy that the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs and Trade is responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the operation of ADAB, the Australian Devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment Assistance Bureau, which has carriage

Speaker: NA
Text: of the development import financing facility

Speaker: NA
Text: which interlinks with the work that EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: does. By definition, the Department of For-

Speaker: NA
Text: eign Affairs and Trade has responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: trade policy matters. I would have thought all

Speaker: NA
Text: would agree that EFIC's work indisputably

Speaker: NA
Text: was trade work.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think there is almost irrefutable logic for

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC to be transferred to the Ministers re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for the Department of Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and rrade. I am disappointed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has decided to leave EPIC with

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Button, which is effectively what the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision amounts to. His period of administer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Austrade-EPIC, as it is until this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is enacted, has proved to be casual, to

Speaker: NA
Text: say the least.

Speaker: NA
Text: He clearly has not shown a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the operation of those organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: or, one could say, that organisation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: noteworthy that on only one occasion Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Button, as the Minister responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade-EPIC, had a formal meeting with the

Speaker: NA
Text: former managing director of that organisation,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lindsay MACAlister. I do not wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: speculate on what the nature of that meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: was, except to say that it was very close to

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of Mr MACAlister's term as managing

Speaker: NA
Text: director of Austrade-EFIC.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the functions of

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC are of some considerable help to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian exp01ters. It is no coincidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 10 per cent of all Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exports are insured or at least dealt with in

Speaker: NA
Text: one form or another by EPIC. Given that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has the coverage for something like 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of our exports, we can conclude from

Speaker: NA
Text: that that EPIC in principle has a very import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant role to play in contributing towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: competitiveness of the Australian economy in

Speaker: NA
Text: the international marketplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Basically, EPIC has three functions. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it insures against the risk of non-payment by

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas buyers. That certainly was its tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional and original role when it was estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished back in the 1950s. Secondly, it insures

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore investments against non-conunercial

Speaker: NA
Text: losses such as war damage and so on. Thirdly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it provides concessional finance for exports of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital goods. In providing those three func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, I do not think it is really in contention

Speaker: NA
Text: that EFIC's assistance does constitute direct

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to exporters. If one takes the

Speaker: NA
Text: general insurance that EFIC undertakes, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: in many instances insurance that would not

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally be attractive to the commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: market. If it were attractive to that market, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be undertaken at a very considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: cost, at a very high premium, to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters. That is not to say that EPIC con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts that insurance business at a loss; it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not. The fact is that, with the benefit of being

Speaker: NA
Text: able to borrow in the marketplace with a

Speaker: NA
Text: government guarantee, it is therefore able to

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct that business at a lower cost than

Speaker: NA
Text: might be the case by the general business

Speaker: NA
Text: sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is worth pointing out to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that, quite legally and consistently with the

Speaker: NA
Text: GATT rules, that does constitute some direct

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to exporters. There is no doubt,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that the concessional finance that

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC provides is direct assistance to export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers; that is certainly not debatable. I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that this point was made very well in Profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sor Helen Hughes's excellent report which

Speaker: NA
Text: was produced in July 1989 entitled Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Exports-Performance Obstacles and Issues

Speaker: NA
Text: of Assistance, which I commend to

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members-of course, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have read it at the time it was produced-to

Speaker: NA
Text: read yet again. Quite apart from its analysis

Speaker: NA
Text: of these issues of direct assistance to export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, on pages 28, 29 and 30 it has a very

Speaker: NA
Text: useful analysis of the enormous benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's balance of payments of introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a broadly based goods and services tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Science and Technology and

Speaker: NA
