Text: Minister Assisting the Treasurer ( Mr Free)

Speaker: NA
Text: might like to read that. I do not think he

Speaker: NA
Text: could have read that part of the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: A point is made in that report about

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional finance. If the House would bear

Speaker: NA
Text: with me, I would like to read a little of it:

Speaker: NA
Text: Such concessional finance is seen as a defenSive

Speaker: NA
Text: measure to protect the competitive position of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian exporters in world markets, when facing

Speaker: NA
Text: 'soft' loans of competitors. The exploitation of such

Speaker: NA
Text: official credits by exporters with resulting high

Speaker: NA
Text: budgetary costs led the OECD's Arrangement on

Speaker: NA
Text: Guidelines/or Officially Supported Export Credits

Speaker: NA
Text: which sets minimum interest rates and maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: credit periods for the financing of capital goods

Speaker: NA
Text: exports. Together with the Berne union, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: a clearing house for official insurers such as EFIC,

Speaker: NA
Text: these arrangements damp down the costs of export

Speaker: NA
Text: finance and insurance subsidies. The participants

Speaker: NA
Text: are fully aware that export finance subsidies are as

Speaker: NA
Text: harmful as any other subsidies to trade. They

Speaker: NA
Text: damage small countries-

Speaker: NA
Text: which obviously includes a country such as

Speaker: NA
Text: our own-

Speaker: NA
Text: and developing country exporters which have to

Speaker: NA
Text: draw on limited resources to match industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: country subsidies.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth reflecting on that, and the points

Speaker: NA
Text: that Helen Hughes made in her report, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it raises the question of whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of EFIC can be justified at all. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence of EFIC's existence is the

Speaker: NA
Text: common defence that, as long as other count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries are doing it, it leaves us in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: where, if we did not provide that concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: finance consistent with the OECD guide-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines-the quote from Professor Hughes,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have just read out, referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines-we would lose market share,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in terms of exports of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: goods in a range of important markets. .

Speaker: NA
Text: I particularly refer to the south-east and

Speaker: NA
Text: north-east Asian markets. Most of those

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, outside Japan, are defined as

Speaker: NA
Text: developing countries and they are in our

Speaker: NA
Text: region. People like me, you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, and some honourable members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, have advocated for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time that we need to be more effective exportEFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: ers into those markets and that as an economy

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to integrate more successfully with

Speaker: NA
Text: the north-east and south-east Asian econo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mies. One of the problems we have in getting

Speaker: NA
Text: into those markets and maintaining market

Speaker: NA
Text: access once we have got into them is that,

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with the amount we devote for

Speaker: NA
Text: these purposes, the European Community,

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan and the United States spend an enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous amoUnt of money on providing so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called mixed credits and other forms of

Speaker: NA
Text: financial assistance for their own capital

Speaker: NA
Text: goods exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House are trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: get some analysis done on the impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: trading opportunities for Australia in that part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world of the types of financial subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dies that are coming from Europe, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States and Japan. There is no doubt that if we

Speaker: NA
Text: were to take away the concessional finance

Speaker: NA
Text: for the export of capital goods that EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: provides we would have less opportunity in

Speaker: NA
Text: those markets than we currently have. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the purist would argue-everybody must

Speaker: NA
Text: consider this-that the cost of providing that

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional finance needs to be properly

Speaker: NA
Text: understood. We need to understand what the

Speaker: NA
Text: net benefits of providing the concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: finance are, and not take a simplistic view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gross benefits because the gross benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: are obvious. I think the evidence seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the net benefits are there; that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a cost which is far exceeded in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from those exports to those particular

Speaker: NA
Text: markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that for the time being the

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional finance function, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also the other insurance functions under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by EFIC are justified, at least for as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as the OECD retains its code to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for concessional finance, should the OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: take that code away-I would hope it would

Speaker: NA
Text: eventually because I do not think it is in our

Speaker: NA
Text: interests as a smaller country to have that type

Speaker: NA
Text: of code in place-we will probably have to

Speaker: NA
Text: stick with this concessional finance. Once it

Speaker: NA
Text: goes we will be a major beneficiary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: disappearance of that type of concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: If one is prepared to accept the role of

Speaker: NA
Text: in performing this function, it begs the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of how successfully EPIC is handling

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole issue of concessional finance. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent Estimates committee hearing my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague Senator Bishop raised-quite

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately in the context of this debate-

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of the concessional finance provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed by EPIC for the construction of a boat

Speaker: NA
Text: called The Other Woman. This scandal was

Speaker: NA
Text: well and truly exposed by Senator Bishop and

Speaker: NA
Text: has subsequently been reasonably well publi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cised. When this Bill finally reaches the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate, Senator Bishop will have more to say

Speaker: NA
Text: on that particular issue. Suffice it for me to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, as the shadow Minister for trade, that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is an issue of some concern to us. In particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar, the potential of much of that money is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply being lost. When Senator Bishop talks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the totality of the finance provided for

Speaker: NA
Text: The Other Woman she is not just referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: funding that has come from EPIC. A lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: that money has been paid in the form of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shipbuilding bounty. Nevertheless, some of it

Speaker: NA
Text: does come from EPIC. We want more ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions answered on that particular issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the same vein, we have been told

Speaker: NA
Text: number of contacts in the finance community

Speaker: NA
Text: that EPIC has lost anything up to $110m in

Speaker: NA
Text: the shipbuilding industry alone. We would this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: like to know more about that. Perhaps when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Science and Technology

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Assisting the Treasurer responds

Speaker: NA
Text: today he might be able to give us some

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmation or otherwise that EPIC has

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable losses in the shipbuilding indusadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: try. While the Minister is about it he might

Speaker: NA
Text: care to let the coalition and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public know-since EFIC is a public instituguarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-what the total value of EFIC's current

Speaker: NA
Text: non-performing loans is and what is the gross

Speaker: NA
Text: value of its losses over the last three or

Speaker: NA
Text: years. When we have that information we

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to assess more satisfactorily the

Speaker: NA
Text: strength of EPIC's position, the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: management and, flowing naturally from that,

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of its capacity to handle

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have an organisation which is to some

Speaker: NA
Text: extent picking winners and deciding where

Speaker: NA
Text: money is going to be allocated and where

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise it might not be allocated. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: those decisions are supposed to be made with

Speaker: NA
Text: the imprimatur of the Minister. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament have a right to know the total

Speaker: NA
Text: value of EPIC's non-performing loans, the

Speaker: NA
Text: total value of any gross losses which have

Speaker: NA
Text: accrued and the nature of those losses.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition has undertaken a rather brief

Speaker: NA
Text: review of EPIC and how it works. We will be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing more work on it in the weeks ahead. In

Speaker: NA
Text: our consideration of the existence of EPIC we

Speaker: NA
Text: have really gone back to the basic point,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have in a sense briefly touched on

Speaker: NA
Text: already, of whether we need to continue with

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, given that I have answered that

Speaker: NA
Text: already in my remarks so far, we have looked

Speaker: NA
Text: to see whether it would be possible to transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: an institution such as EPIC to the private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. It is reasonable that that matter be

Speaker: NA
Text: given some thought. The conclusion that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have reached is that to do that would be very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult. I suppose international precedent

Speaker: NA
Text: gives us a guide. In the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States the equivalent organisations,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Eximbapk in the United States and the

Speaker: NA
Text: by a ECGD in the United Kingdom, have not in

Speaker: NA
Text: general been privati sed, although some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of the ECGD were privatised earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are considering privatising something

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have to generate a certain amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in buying the asset within the busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness community. I do not detect that at this

Speaker: NA
Text: had stage. In its present form, EPIC has the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the government guarantee and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore the capacity to borrow fairly cheap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly. If we privatised it without a government

Speaker: NA
Text: it would lose the commercial edge

Speaker: NA
Text: that it currently has. We could continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the government guarantee but to do

Speaker: NA
Text: four that would beg the question of why we would

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide a government guarantee to one

Speaker: NA
Text: private company, albeit a specialised banking

Speaker: NA
Text: its or non-banking financial institution, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an identical guarantee to another

Speaker: NA
Text: institution. That is not an easy matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third point that we have considered is

Speaker: NA
Text: the relationship between the existing EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian banking system. EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: offers nearly all of the medium term

Speaker: NA
Text: concessionalloans for exports that are provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed in Australia. Under the Act in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: in commercial banks have been able to lend and

Speaker: NA
Text: get an EPIC subsidy for their lending. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, the concessional loans facility

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to operate through the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banking sector. Suffice it to say that it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: rare for that to happen. It seems to me that

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the reasons that it has been very rare

Speaker: NA
Text: for that to happen is that it is a lot easier for

Speaker: NA
Text: the business community to go to a single

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose bank to get funding for projects of

Speaker: NA
Text: that kind rather than to shop around at differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent banks and, in turn, try to persuade banks

Speaker: NA
Text: to apply for the concessions. Maybe the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: would be successful and maybe they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not. Clearly, it is a complicated bureaucratic

Speaker: NA
Text: process when compared with going to a single

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having been rather negative about issues

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the privatisation of EPIC and, as an

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative, the banks simply taking over the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of EPIC and closing EPIC down,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are things that could be done in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the performance of EPIC and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove its relationship with the general banking

Speaker: NA
Text: community. A number of exporters have

Speaker: NA
Text: complained to me about delays in EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: giving approval for work that the exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: have wanted done by EPIC. Some have

Speaker: NA
Text: claimed that they have missed contracts as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of EPIC's delays. Presumably these

Speaker: NA
Text: delays, it would be argued, are caused by a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of staff and the only answer would

Speaker: NA
Text: be to increase the overall level of staffing in

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC. If we were to do that we would reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: its competitiveness by increasing its cost, and

Speaker: NA
Text: one has to make a balanced judgment about

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I point out to the House that that is an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that has been raised by a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters. It is an issue of some concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether there are ways of eliminating those

Speaker: NA
Text: delays or not, it is certainly something that

Speaker: NA
Text: more work needs to be done on. I will come

Speaker: NA
Text: later to how that possibly could be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has also been said by some that EPIC's

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of a worldwide network, as compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with some of the major international banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: means that as a financial institution assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters EPIC is unab,le to be as effective as

Speaker: NA
Text: an institution with a more extensive world-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide network. I am not proffering any simple

Speaker: NA
Text: solutions as to how we would achieve that,

Speaker: NA
Text: just as I am not offering simple solutions as

Speaker: NA
Text: to how we would deal with the delays in

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to put a proposal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. If it were reasonable about this

Speaker: NA
Text: and took debate in the Parliament on an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: such as this seriously-I think it should

Speaker: NA
Text: because that is what the Parliament is for-it

Speaker: NA
Text: might wish to establish a joint EFIC-banIdng

Speaker: NA
Text: industry working group to examine whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the commercial banks can play a bigger role

Speaker: NA
Text: in providing some of the services that EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently providing or assist with the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of those services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Martin-Or perhaps send them to a

Speaker: NA
Text: committee of the House of Representatives.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: That is right. As a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of fact, the honourable member for Macarthur,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chairman of the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Pinance and Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration, which is inquiring into the

Speaker: NA
Text: banking industry, would be aware that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been very little discussion-I accept some

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for this-in that Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular issue. Given that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's work is coming to a rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, it may be a little late for it to do

Speaker: NA
Text: much work on that. I accept some responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for less work being done on that than

Speaker: NA
Text: could have been. There might be other forums

Speaker: NA
Text: where that could be done more usefully. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that, if we did have a joint working

Speaker: NA
Text: group of EPIC and the banks, we might come

Speaker: NA
Text: up with a more rapid conclusion than we

Speaker: NA
Text: would if we depended on recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from a parliamentary committee-not

Speaker: NA
Text: to belittle the parliamentary committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note that in Britain and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States the ECGD and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eximbank both contract out to the banking

Speaker: NA
Text: sector much more of the concessional finance

Speaker: NA
Text: work than is done here in Australia. Compa-

Speaker: NA
Text: rable organisations in those two countries and

Speaker: NA
Text: their relationship with the banking community

Speaker: NA
Text: might be a good place to start.

Speaker: NA
Text: The argument goes that if one were able to

Speaker: NA
Text: use the existing commercial banking system,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than depending entirely on EPIC, one

Speaker: NA
Text: might be able to lower the Government's total

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing program for EFIC. It might give a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater opportunity for risk sharing between

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC and the banks themselves, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have an obvious advantage. There

Speaker: NA
Text: might be some capacity to reduce the redepartment

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse time for exporters' inquiries,

Speaker: NA
Text: have raised that issue already. It might give

Speaker: NA
Text: a wider based delivery system to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: greater opportunity for new and smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters to take advantage of subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: export finance. It might help with the promoBill

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of increased export awareness and experiance

Speaker: NA
Text: ence amongst Australian capital goods manuConsequential

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers. It would provide the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: have a complete one-stop shop financial

Speaker: NA
Text: packaging service using the commercial Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, rather than going to commercial banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: being shuffled off to EFIC and having

Speaker: NA
Text: both with commercial banks and EFIC. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is, I suppose, the potential for EFIC to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve cost savings, particularly in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of marketing and analysis. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: interchange of information between banks and

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC and the improved feedback and advice

Speaker: NA
Text: on changes in market conditions and/or

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements would be another benefit that

Speaker: NA
Text: could flow from that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not being prescriptive about this.

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that the Government should consider

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a working group of EFIC and the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks to see whether more could be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government itself would probably have

Speaker: NA
Text: to participate in the working group, providing

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair bit of guidance and promoting ideas,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly on the basis of experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom and the United States.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the coalition supports the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. We hope that the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: examine the feasibility of establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: working group that I have referred to, and

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Government will decide to

Speaker: NA
Text: change tack on one thing: instead of putting

Speaker: NA
Text: DITAC in the negligent hands of Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Button, who has administered Austrade and

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC with a most extraordinary degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: negligence over the last five or

Speaker: NA
Text: should have EFIC more logically transferred

Speaker: NA
Text: so that it is under the ministerial control of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not say that out of former vested interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: because once I used to be an officer of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Foreign Affairs, but simply

Speaker: NA
Text: because I think there is irrefutable logic

Speaker: NA
Text: having EFIC, Austrade, AIDAB and the they

Speaker: NA
Text: whole area of trade policy handlecl by one

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than being spread through-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I out the bureaucracy.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Text: Macarthur) (4.28 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: This afternoon I wish to speak in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 and the Export Finance and Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation (Transitional Provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments) Bill 1991 which

Speaker: NA
Text: to have been introduced into this place by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Science and Technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: Assisting the Treasurer ( Mr Free). As

Speaker: NA
Text: we have heard, the legislation will re-establish

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal the Export Finance and Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation, known as EFIC, and it will do

Speaker: NA
Text: so as an independent statutory corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: offering competitiv-'export credit facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: the greater Australian exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like the honourable member for Mayo ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Downer), I welcome this initiative. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: support somtf of the comments that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: made, particularly in respect of looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: ways in which a body such as this, working

Speaker: NA
Text: I am within the private finance community, can

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the opportunities for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters. In all sincerity, I say to him that his

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion about considering some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: working group made up of EFIC and banks

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at ways to assist in that enhancement

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian export opportunities and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: the hance the provision of finance for that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable suggestion. Despite some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments he made about the present inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Australian banking industry by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Finance and Public

Speaker: NA
Text: the Administration, that could be a possible

Speaker: NA
Text: we ongoing reference for a committee of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament in the early parts of the new year

Speaker: NA
Text: if a potential recommendation creating a

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent watchdog on the banking industry

Speaker: NA
Text: was accepted by the Government. That may

Speaker: NA
Text: or may not be one of the Committee's recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: so years, it mendations next month.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to that particular proposal, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: also worth commenting about the role of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian banks at the present time and what

Speaker: NA
Text: the future actually holds for them in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of expanding opportunities for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: in exporters to gain finance and assistance so

Speaker: NA
Text: can get into the markets that exist in

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia, particularly, and in other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Australian financial community

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, as it inevitably will, we will find

Speaker: NA
Text: more and more Australian banks, particularly,

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming globalised. We have seen this in a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of Australian banks taking corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions to locate rather extensive offices in

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas jurisdictions. We have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity taken by some of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: major banks to acquire the overseas holdings

Speaker: NA
Text: of other banks and therefore establish them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves a real presence in another market. This

Speaker: NA
Text: can only lead to the enhancement of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: as an exporting nation, particularly in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to access to finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: In some way that would complement what

Speaker: NA
Text: is being proposed in the legislation before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House today. For example, the ANZ's recent

Speaker: NA
Text: takeover of Grindlays Bank provides, an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous network, particularly throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. And the National Australia Bank has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken over a couple of the northern England

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. Again this is an inroad into a part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe which is going to become more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more important, particularly as we move to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1993, with virtual elimination of all trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: finance barriers, and perhaps even monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers, between all members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Community.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Australia it is very important not to lose

Speaker: NA
Text: sight of that point, because if we can have

Speaker: NA
Text: already established, through the assistance of

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC and Austrade, working hand in glove

Speaker: NA
Text: with the private finance community, a ready

Speaker: NA
Text: access into many of those markets, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of finance to assist in that, then the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian opportunity for export enhance-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has to grow. It is quite amazing to think

Speaker: NA
Text: that few people realise that Australia is now

Speaker: NA
Text: running a merchandise trade surplus; in such

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult economic times as we have at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment, that is probably a point that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: lost.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any opportunity to enhance our export

Speaker: NA
Text: potential is something which we must grasp

Speaker: NA
Text: with both hands. -ast year the actual mer-

Speaker: NA
Text: chandise trade surplus was something like

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.5 billion, and that was certainly a turn-

Speaker: NA
Text: around from the $3.2 billion deficit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year before. Something must be happening

Speaker: NA
Text: now; something must be right. As more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more Australian exporters are looking to ways

Speaker: NA
Text: in which they can enhance their opportunities,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in the Asian region, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: more and more the market for Australia, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to provide the financial advice and

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance for those exporters to get into those

Speaker: NA
Text: markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC, of course, will be much better

Speaker: NA
Text: equipped to assist in today's competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: export climate, because it must operate in a

Speaker: NA
Text: more commercial, and therefore accountable,

Speaker: NA
Text: way. In the Government's view, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: this will be best assured by establishing EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: as a statutory corporation. I have no disagree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with that, because the Corporation will

Speaker: NA
Text: be structured along government business

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise lines. It will therefore continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: fill the gap that I have identified in what the

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial banks and financial organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to do by providing services

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not normally available through the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector. It will be complementary to

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the honourable member for Mayo

Speaker: NA
Text: raised a very valid point-a joint working

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement might be established where we

Speaker: NA
Text: can see the best of both worlds. To date

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC's business has been at no cost to the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer. It undertakes its transactions which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government considers to be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest. I think that is quite import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant. It usually involves high risk and very

Speaker: NA
Text: important industry, trade or political consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations. So if there is not a body in place

Speaker: NA
Text: which enables finance to be made available

Speaker: NA
Text: for those export industries, the chances are

Speaker: NA
Text: that industry would fall over. So for those

Speaker: NA
Text: very real industry, trade or political consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations to have a body such as EFIC in place

Speaker: NA
Text: is quite appropriate in my view.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total exposure on the national interest

Speaker: NA
Text: account is something like $1. 3 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: which the greater bulk relates to commodity

Speaker: NA
Text: exports, particularly wheat and wool. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know whether that will continue in the future;

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact my view is that that might change,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in regard to some other commodi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties which we in this country are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce.

Speaker: NA
Text: I represent a coal producing area of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. I note in an article in today's

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Financial Review that it might be

Speaker: NA
Text: facing some difficult times in the future. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may well be that EPIC or some other consor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tium project that might be entered into would

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be looked at to provide assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: industries such as the coal industry. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand it, the coal producing areas of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country will soon be faced with rather com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive forces in respect of the prices they are

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to receive, particularly from Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: coal buyers, simply because the demand has

Speaker: NA
Text: slackened as a result of the recession not only

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country but right around the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: That cannot mean good things for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: commodity exporters, particularly of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: produce such as coal. I look forward to seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing reports on that particular matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's 12 March statement

Speaker: NA
Text: Building a More Competitive Australia recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised the need for Australian exporters to

Speaker: NA
Text: have access to competitive financial facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: and to be effective, especially in the Asia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific markets. I have commented on how

Speaker: NA
Text: significant Asia really is. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: announced its intention in that statement to

Speaker: NA
Text: re-establish EPIC as a separate entity to

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade with greater visibility and an extend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed range of services for exporters. As part of

Speaker: NA
Text: this restructuring, a $200m callable capital

Speaker: NA
Text: facility is to be provided to supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC's existing reserves of some $160m.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, of course, is bound to ensure adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: financial backing for its insurance, guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: and lending operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note that at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: EPIC covers something like 10 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's trade. As more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian producers look at opportunities to

Speaker: NA
Text: ex.port overseas-hopefully not to export

Speaker: NA
Text: unfinished products or to sell our coal, our

Speaker: NA
Text: wool and our wheat overseas and then buy it

Speaker: NA
Text: back as jumpers or something else-and are

Speaker: NA
Text: moving towards some sort of an exportable

Speaker: NA
Text: product which has been treated in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: before it is exported, perhaps we might see

Speaker: NA
Text: that 10 per cent figure rise as far as EPIC is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned. I certainly hope that is the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1990-91 EPIC supported exports totalling

Speaker: NA
Text: some $4.5 billion. That is not an insignificant

Speaker: NA
Text: amount and one can, therefore j see how

Speaker: NA
Text: important this organisation is in supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian exporters. It also insures offshore

Speaker: NA
Text: investments by Australian companies against

Speaker: NA
Text: non-commercial loss caused by things such as

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange transfer blockages, expropriation or

Speaker: NA
Text: war damage. We would have seen some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits flowing to Australian exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the recent crises in the world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cover on these investments totals something

Speaker: NA
Text: like $490m.

Speaker: NA
Text: As has been indicated, the legislation does

Speaker: NA
Text: re-establish a body which has been operating

Speaker: NA
Text: for quite some time-some 35 years. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance Australia's, export potential. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: view it will certainly supplement export

Speaker: NA
Text: activities and finat1cial activities which are not

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by private banks and by other finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial institutions. It will go some way towards

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting Australia's drive to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of exports from this country. Again I

Speaker: NA
Text: come back ,-o the point that it must not simply

Speaker: NA
Text: be primary produce, the stuff that we rip out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ground and then send away to someone

Speaker: NA
Text: else to manufacture and to sell back to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia must move more and more to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards-and the economic climate and

Speaker: NA
Text: government policy must continue to create-

Speaker: NA
Text: an environment whereby Australian exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: will feel safe in the knowledge that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: export finished products which have had some

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment in this country and, therefore, gain

Speaker: NA
Text: a greater advantage for this country. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: move more and more towards that. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that this can only be done through initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government in industry policy, starting

Speaker: NA
Text: with the 12 March statement and being

Speaker: NA
Text: carried forWard with initiatives such as this

Speaker: NA
Text: but, even more so, by looking at conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: which are created in this country to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will make one other comment on Austrade

Speaker: NA
Text: and the role it has played. I was part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation looking at the banking system of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States and had the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: talk with our representative in the mid-west

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United States. He told me and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Chairman of the Committee, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Sturt ( Mr Wilson),

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the last couple of years Austrade

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives and staff at the Austrade office

Speaker: NA
Text: in the mid-west of the United States-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: out of Chicago-have decreased from five

Speaker: NA
Text: people to one. Yet this is an absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: massive market which Australia could, with

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit of work, tap into.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it rather extraordinary when I think

Speaker: NA
Text: of some of the initiatives that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated through the Austrade office to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify the appropriate markets for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: If those people have been taken from the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States and put into Asia because we

Speaker: NA
Text: have identified that Asia offers a better

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy for Australian exporters, that is fine.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we can see that translated into increased

Speaker: NA
Text: exports from Australia into Asia and that this

Speaker: NA
Text: turns around balance of payments difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: for this country, that is fine, I have no diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty with that at all. However, if there is-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I believe there is-a massive, lucrative

Speaker: NA
Text: market in the mid-west of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: for many of the products produced in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, then perhaps it is a little short-sightbody;

Speaker: NA
Text: ed not to have the level of trade representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which we probably need in such a lo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. There are probably many other parts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United States we could give the flick

Speaker: NA
Text: to, but I think this is one which should be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: examined. I ask the Minister whether this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue could be taken on board with the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of Austrade and in the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: department.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I come back to the point I

Speaker: NA
Text: made at the beginning: this is part of an

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing commitment by this Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the appropriate infrastructure is in

Speaker: NA
Text: place for the promotion and export of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian products. It is aimed essentially at

Speaker: NA
Text: turning around difficult circumstances for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy in trying to meet our

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of trade and our balance of payments

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. It is to be encouraged. I hope it is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of several steps the Government is look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at to continue that process. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to the House.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (4.43

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-The development of an export con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sciousness and providing the opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: small business and, indeed, anybody in

Speaker: NA
Text: business in Australia to export their products

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely critical. I have had some years

Speaker: NA
Text: of ministerial experience in this body that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being discussed today. I want to look at a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of aspects of the Export Finance and

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Corporation Bill and the Export

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill. and express some cynicism about

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of yet another corporation.

Speaker: NA
Text: For many years the Reserve Bank had

Speaker: NA
Text: prime responsibility for our primary export

Speaker: NA
Text: industries, for funding the Wheat Board and

Speaker: NA
Text: so on, and I do not demur from the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reserve Bank no longer operates there to

Speaker: NA
Text: the same degree. But I am concerned that this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation really is a product of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government having made a mess of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: trade area. At the moment it has three depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I suppose one would call one a depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and a half as it has two Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the field of trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have EPIC, which is a long established

Speaker: NA
Text: as has been said, it has been going for

Speaker: NA
Text: about 35 years. It is a body which provides an

Speaker: NA
Text: essential service. I will come back and look

Speaker: NA
Text: at that service and at the legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is taking us. But what has happened

Speaker: NA
Text: is that Austrade has made an absolute disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: of the responsibilities that have been accorded

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. More and more I am coming back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: position that I adopted initially. when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: established. of saying, 'The sooner it is

Speaker: NA
Text: scrapped the better'. I will come to Austrade

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to other matters as I conclude my

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks. EPIC certainly has not worked

Speaker: NA
Text: within Austrade. The reason this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: before us is that at long last the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is realising that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to see whether we are helping the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia who want to export and,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the people who at the moment do not even

Speaker: NA
Text: know about export, whether it will make it

Speaker: NA
Text: easier for them to export. Words are great. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have read the Minister's second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech and I have heard what has been said

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House today. We are all in favour of it;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is like motherhood. But it will not jolly

Speaker: NA
Text: well work unless we have some way of

Speaker: NA
Text: getting that sperm into the mother's womb to

Speaker: NA
Text: generate the infant. With the way things are

Speaker: NA
Text: going I do not think that this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to provide that stimulus.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that setting up a new

Speaker: NA
Text: corporation will not, of itself, solve the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems. There are aspects of it that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to see, but I am worried that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, 'It is not working within Austrade,

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade is not working terribly well, so let

Speaker: NA
Text: us set up another statutory corporation'. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a great old way to resolve problems. If it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a committee, it is a corporation. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that corporations do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have an unblemished record in this nation of

Speaker: NA
Text: ours at the moment. I would rather like to see

Speaker: NA
Text: us provide the facilities to help Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: export. That is really the bottom line as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now come to the second thing that con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns me. I commend the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mayo ( Mr Downer) and indeed the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Macarthur ( Mr Martin),

Speaker: NA
Text: both of whom picked up the idea of some

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with banks and so on. But let me

Speaker: NA
Text: tell them that EFIC was really set up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: first place as an insurance corporation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: concept was insurance and reinsurance, and

Speaker: NA
Text: those remain the two main functions, although

Speaker: NA
Text: loans are a third part of EFIC's prime respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities. We also have to think of insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that in the legislation there is

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for entering into negotiations with

Speaker: NA
Text: other financial institutions, but I think

Speaker: NA
Text: have preferred, in the first place, that we had

Speaker: NA
Text: gone back to the Reserve Bank and given it

Speaker: NA
Text: this function until we got the thing worked

Speaker: NA
Text: out. I would like to see it operating very

Speaker: NA
Text: much like the Primary Industry Bank, which

Speaker: NA
Text: I legislated for and which was, as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: anything, a product of discussions that I held

Speaker: NA
Text: with the banks. On this basis, we do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: another great bureaucracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first thing that this body has to do is

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that it will not succeed if it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a representative in every port and every

Speaker: NA
Text: city. I come back briefly to what the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Macarthur concluded about

Speaker: NA
Text: our shutting down trade offices. There have

Speaker: NA
Text: been so many disasters from this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning I read about even closing our

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomatic mission in Switzerland. I can tell

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of the Government that Swiss

Speaker: NA
Text: francs are still a significant part of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas reserves. We still borrow sigmficant-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly in Swiss francs. The Government has never

Speaker: NA
Text: had a forward plan of where to set up offices

Speaker: NA
Text: and why we should have them. Shutting down

Speaker: NA
Text: offices in places such as the western United

Speaker: NA
Text: States, where there is a tremendous market for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian goods, just does not make sense,

Speaker: NA
Text: any more than it does to shut down offices in

Speaker: NA
Text: tell Switzerland. We have to work out how to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate them more efficiently, but that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: different story. Indeed, in the Swiss instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: I gather that we will turn to some

Speaker: NA
Text: international representatives that we have in

Speaker: NA
Text: Geneva and say, 'We will not have a post, but

Speaker: NA
Text: you will somehow or other continue the job'.

Speaker: NA
Text: For goodness sake, why can we not keep our

Speaker: NA
Text: posts open and, if need be, appoint some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have an international responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: as our ambassadors? Let us try to keep the

Speaker: NA
Text: posts open, but do it under another name.

Speaker: NA
Text: The same thing is absolutely essential as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as EFIC is concerned. EFIC should not set up

Speaker: NA
Text: a post in every port. What it has to do is

Speaker: NA
Text: work with existing private sector operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, when we see that it covers only

Speaker: NA
Text: around 10 per cent of Australia's trade, we

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that 90 per cent is already covered in

Speaker: NA
Text: other directions. I think we have to draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: line between big business trade and small

Speaker: NA
Text: business trade. One of the concerns that I

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have long had about our overseas trade

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements is that we have not done any-

Speaker: NA
Text: where near enough to encourage the average

Speaker: NA
Text: small to medium sized business to get export

Speaker: NA
Text: oriented. Big business is normally okay. The

Speaker: NA
Text: CRAs, the BHPs, the CSRs and so on of this

Speaker: NA
Text: world have their own access; they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to tum to the services of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not need to turn to EFIC or

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade. They rarely need to tum even to

Speaker: NA
Text: our own Department of Foreign Affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade. They have their own network. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: when we are looking at that 10 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: because much of it may well relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural commodities, and I believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: does-I am not too sure how much of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business is covered by it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should add, though, that I do not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with the suggestion that this EFIC cover

Speaker: NA
Text: should apply only to value added products.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a very real reason why we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide continued cover for our commodity

Speaker: NA
Text: exports, and never more so than at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when we are still beating at the door to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the Uruguay Round of GAIT going. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: know of the problems in Europe and of the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties of getting some change in the

Speaker: NA
Text: CAP; we know of the difficulties in Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: of providing access to eastern European

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural goods and of the political require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that there be access into Europe for

Speaker: NA
Text: those goods. We know the difficulties we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in getting the Americans to move on

Speaker: NA
Text: their export enhancement program. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: of the problems that we have with Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby we catmot even display a grain of

Speaker: NA
Text: rice let alone export Australian rice to Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: for consumption by the Japanese people, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though we produce it more efficiently and

Speaker: NA
Text: more economically and to at least the same

Speaker: NA
Text: quality as Japanese rice.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to look at EFIC and see what its

Speaker: NA
Text: task is and how it is going to carry it out. If

Speaker: NA
Text: it is to be set up as a separate corporation, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would rather it be done in such a way that we

Speaker: NA
Text: had these discussions with the banks and

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance companies first, because what I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to see this body doing is not

Speaker: NA
Text: setting up offices everywhere but essentially

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulating, lending and providing insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: through the private sector. It is for that reason

Speaker: NA
Text: that previously it was largely a government

Speaker: NA
Text: agency handled within the Department. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, I am not sure that, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: setting up a separate corporation, it could not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been handled, at least at this stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Reserve Bank. But if it is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: a separate organisation, what it has to do is

Speaker: NA
Text: try to stimulate, to provide reinsurance and to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide, if need be, interest subsidies through

Speaker: NA
Text: existing private sector lending institutions and

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance institutions so that they can get on

Speaker: NA
Text: with their business and so that the EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose is predominantly met.

Speaker: NA
Text: The role of EFIC is set down in the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and, as I have said, it covers three things.

Speaker: NA
Text: It covers insurance, reinsurance and loans. But

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a very important supplement to the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal role. One of the reasons why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically a government agency, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why privatisation will, I think, always

Speaker: NA
Text: be difficult, is that it is absolutely essential

Speaker: NA
Text: for there to be a capacity for a national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest cover. Of course, ministerial direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and the way they are to be undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: are set down in clause 9, and clause 10

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for the way they are to be financed

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a couple of difficulties that I see

Speaker: NA
Text: in this. What normally happens is that in

Speaker: NA
Text: markets that are considered to be a good risk,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the normal basis EFIC cover is taken

Speaker: NA
Text: up to a certain percentage of the loan; so that

Speaker: NA
Text: for a very good risk market EFIC might be

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to advance on a 90 per cent insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance basis, whereas if it is a poor risk market

Speaker: NA
Text: it will cut that down to 80 per cent or 70 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, perhaps even lower. The difficulty is to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure, if we can, that markets that are

Speaker: NA
Text: important to us are in some way hedged when

Speaker: NA
Text: there are political difficulties. We know that

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been enormous problems in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle East. There are problems at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment in eastern Europe with what was

Speaker: NA
Text: Yugoslavia, for example. We need to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: way by which we can continue our exports

Speaker: NA
Text: into markets of that ilk. Indeed, there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been no better example than that given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's speech when he referred to losses

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting fOlm the war in Iraq and the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems there. There are enormous problems if

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have this capacity to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest cover.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons why I disagree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Macarthur, for exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, in talking about the absolute necessity to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain cover on our commodity exports is

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are able to gain advantages from

Speaker: NA
Text: providing some funding guarantees to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union as far as wool and wheat are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned. The Soviet Union does have a

Speaker: NA
Text: political element of risk. One will not find a

Speaker: NA
Text: normal commercial lender accepting the risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of funding exports to the Soviet Union to the

Speaker: NA
Text: degree that one might like. In the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: days there have been comments about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Belarus tractor group apparently seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: acquire 50 per cent of the Australian wool

Speaker: NA
Text: stockpile. Whatever the proposition, such

Speaker: NA
Text: propositions will not succeed in the light of

Speaker: NA
Text: the political risk factor, unless we have some

Speaker: NA
Text: type of national risk area where directions can

Speaker: NA
Text: be given and where a supplemental insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: can be given through EPIC to cover what is

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary risk.

Speaker: NA
Text: To my mind, that is a critical role of EFIC.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is one of the reasons that we must retain

Speaker: NA
Text: the separate identity of EFIC outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector. There needs to be a capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide reinsurance for such a lending risk. I

Speaker: NA
Text: might add that I think the assistance provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent years by AIDAB in the lending area

Speaker: NA
Text: has been excellent. This has been a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important role of EFIC.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation provides for a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: other obligations in respect of the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest cover. I am pleased to see the require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for a corporate plan of this new-

Speaker: NA
Text: although I have reservations about this-

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory corporation. This is, of course, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed predominantly with the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: although there is a capacity to report. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be some details of the corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate plan in the reporting requirements under

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation. This is hedged in typical

Speaker: NA
Text: ambivalence in clause 85(2) of the legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Subject to subsection (3), EFIC must include in

Speaker: NA
Text: each annual report:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) particulars of every direction-

Speaker: NA
Text: this is in respect of national interest cover-

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) a statement of the principal objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC ...

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) an assessment of the extent to which EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: has achieved its principal objectives...

Speaker: NA
Text: I trust that clause 85(2)(b), which refers to a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of the principal objectives, will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we will see elements of the corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate plan that is referred to earlier in the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I think it is essential that the

Speaker: NA
Text: report should not only deal with the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest cover. I am pleased to see that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a requirement for national interest contracts

Speaker: NA
Text: to be gazetted. There will be a capacity for

Speaker: NA
Text: people to see what national interest directions

Speaker: NA
Text: have been given and what cover is provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the corporate plan is concerned, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that there is a requirement that an

Speaker: NA
Text: exposure should be made to the public and

Speaker: NA
Text: that, of course, can only be done through the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual report. I trust that the Minister, in his

Speaker: NA
Text: response, might refer to this aspect.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to make a couple of remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the constitution of the EPIC board. First

Speaker: NA
Text: "f all, I was delighted to read in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's second reading speech that Reg

Speaker: NA
Text: Nicolson, the recently retired Deputy Manag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Director of the ANZ Bank, is to head up

Speaker: NA
Text: the new board. There is no reference at this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage to other officers or the Managing Direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor. But I think it is important that there

Speaker: NA
Text: should be, to the maximum extent possible, a

Speaker: NA
Text: link with the existing private financial sector

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. We do not want as members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the board just those people who are involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in normal trade and commerce. We also want

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have financial and, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest, insurance links. Through them I think

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be a better chance of liaison and of

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving the link with the banking sector and

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance sector to which both the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Mayo and the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Macarthur referred. The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: character and nature of EPIC will be retained

Speaker: NA
Text: only if EFIC is supplemental to the financing

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions that are made available to the 90

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of exports that it does not now cover.

Speaker: NA
Text: . The concept of EFIC is important. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, I think it might well have been

Speaker: NA
Text: better if EPIC had been under the Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank for a while. We would then not have

Speaker: NA
Text: needed another statutory corporation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislation might have evolved in a different

Speaker: NA
Text: way if discussions had been held with banks

Speaker: NA
Text: and insurance houses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like the honourable member for Mayo, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have real reservations about the whole struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the administration of trade. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, DITAC is responsible for one area of

Speaker: NA
Text: trade, particularly Austrade. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade and Overseas Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We had three Ministers. But divided

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility is no way in which to maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: output at this time.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it were not for a fourth Minister, there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be virtually no dealing in what is the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal area of Australian exports. I refer, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, to the Minister for Primary Industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and Energy. So we really have four Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: involved. That fourth Minister's portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: covers oil, gas and all the minerals, including

Speaker: NA
Text: coal, to which the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur referred. He is also responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat, wool and all of our other agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: exports. I do not find that division very

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that there are problems in trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve total coordination. But I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: critical that, within an area where there is also

Speaker: NA
Text: an association with Finance and Treasury, we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not have too many people trying to admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister. For that reason, I would be inclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the suggestion of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo that it would be far better

Speaker: NA
Text: if EFIC were at least to be responsible to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade for as

Speaker: NA
Text: long as he retains a trade responsibility. I

Speaker: NA
Text: might say that for my money I would far

Speaker: NA
Text: prefer to see a separate department of trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps linked with one of the major depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the way that was done in previous

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In opening, I said that I wanted to address

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly some of the problems that will emerge

Speaker: NA
Text: from the severance of this responsibility from

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade. It is difficult in this day and age to

Speaker: NA
Text: know just how one can best provide the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of service that exporters require. The

Speaker: NA
Text: MCKinsey report certainly identified adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative problems in Austrade. There are real

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur suggested where, how and to what

Speaker: NA
Text: degree Austrade provides its present services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even this morning I read about a small

Speaker: NA
Text: exporter who said that Austrade services did

Speaker: NA
Text: not relate to the assistance he was seeking.

Speaker: NA
Text: This exporter was told, 'They did not really

Speaker: NA
Text: know anything about it but they were going

Speaker: NA
Text: to charge an exorbitant rate of something like

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 an hour in order to provide the cover'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade does not have a good record. One

Speaker: NA
Text: would hope that it can do better under its new

Speaker: NA
Text: management. But it is certainly important that

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade, EFlC, under its new corporate label,

Speaker: NA
Text: and government departmental officers link to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a better service to those who need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be encouraged to export.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has a great capacity to compete.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a wonderful work force. In spite of

Speaker: NA
Text: all of our industrial difficulties, in my view

Speaker: NA
Text: we can produce the quality and the range of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods. We can provide the service. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: also provide what the customer wants. But

Speaker: NA
Text: this cannot be done on just an occasional visit

Speaker: NA
Text: to an overseas country. It is done by consis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tently attacking a particular market, identify-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and working with the customer and, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum, coordinating efforts between the

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental agencies that provide the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice.

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC has done that, although it has had its

Speaker: NA
Text: ups and downs over the years. One would

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that in its new corporate form it can

Speaker: NA
Text: meet that export demand to a greater degree.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it should not forgo its traditional role in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to commodities which perhaps today

Speaker: NA
Text: require greater access than they ever have,

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing in mind the variation of commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: restraints in the form of tariff and non-tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers that apply in so many of our markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: By all means, let EFIC extend, where it can,

Speaker: NA
Text: its activities into the field of processed goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let it also direct a lot of its attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: small business where there is a requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: and where there is an opportunity.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Text: Lindsay-Minister for Science

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technology and Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer) (5.03 p.m.)-in reply-First of all,

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the honourable member for Mayo ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Downer), the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur ( Mr Martin) and the right honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for New England ( Mr Sinclair)

Speaker: NA
Text: for their contributions during this debate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome particularly the expression by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mayo of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's support for the Export Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Insurance Corporation Bill and the Export

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill. I think that is a recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: important role that EFIC has to play.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to deal briefly with some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the specific issues raised during the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Mayo expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: some concern about the decision taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain EFIC within the Department of Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, Technology and Commerce. I guess there

Speaker: NA
Text: are two issues here: first of all, the relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship between EFIC and the Department; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, the question of its separation from

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade. The decision to move Austrade to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio was

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to achieve a closer integration of our

Speaker: NA
Text: trade promotion activities within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian overseas diplomatic network.

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC, on the other hand, provides insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantees and lpans in support of the export

Speaker: NA
Text: of goods and services from all industry

Speaker: NA
Text: sectors, namely, commodities, manufactures

Speaker: NA
Text: and services. I should point out, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of its support in terms of individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual transactions relates to manufactured

Speaker: NA
Text: exports which fall, of course, within the scope

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry portfolio. Also, the financing

Speaker: NA
Text: of capital projects overseas has become an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly important aspect of EFIC's busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness. Unlike Austrade, the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC's services is not reliant on a presence in

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign countries-a point which seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: have escaped some speakers during this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any concern about the separation of EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: and Austrade and their location in different

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolios is also a little misplaced. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to work closely together to maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospects of success for Australian export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and this will be reinforced in a structural

Speaker: NA
Text: sense by the cross-representation of each of

Speaker: NA
Text: the managing directors on the boards of EFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: and Austrade.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased to hear that the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had largely rejected the idea of

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation. That question has been exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ined on a number of occasions but was found

Speaker: NA
Text: to be impractical. The shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the environment in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom. The changes there were largely

Speaker: NA
Text: driven by the prospect of integration into

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe in 1992 where it will be essential for

Speaker: NA
Text: credit insurers, if they are able to compete, to

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a position to insure both offshore and

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic business. Of course, that situation is

Speaker: NA
Text: not faced by Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Mayo raised a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of questions concerning EFIC's losses

Speaker: NA
Text: in shipbuilding. He asked for a response on

Speaker: NA
Text: the total value of losses and non-performing

Speaker: NA
Text: loans held by EFIC. I am informed that there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been some losses in shipbuilding, but

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing like the $110m suggested by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make two general points. These matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: detail should be properly addressed, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mayo well knows,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the devices of placing questions on

Speaker: NA
Text: notice or pursuing them through Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates committees. Also, of course, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: am anxious to assist him further, figures on

Speaker: NA
Text: total claims and recoveries are set out in

Speaker: NA
Text: EFIC's annual reports.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal of the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo for a joint working group to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of contracting business out to

Speaker: NA
Text: the commercial banking sector is an interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing one. In response, I should point out to

Speaker: NA
Text: him that that option is available now. Experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence has shown that, of course, it is more

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive because banks require a margin

Speaker: NA
Text: over and above the interest subsidy provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been able to obtain no information to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist hiql on his claims that EFIC may have

Speaker: NA
Text: been reiponsible for delays which have cost

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters contracts. There is no evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: available to me at this stage about such

Speaker: NA
Text: delays. If he has such evidence, again I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that that would be welcome. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: offered in a sense of constructive criticism,

Speaker: NA
Text: for which the honourable member for Mayo

Speaker: NA
Text: is so well known.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have additional comments concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks of the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur. I take on board what he had to say

Speaker: NA
Text: about the need for representation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: American mid-west but, more particularly, I

Speaker: NA
Text: endorse his remarks about the need that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to export finished products. It underlines

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance and the correctness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's decision to retain EFIC in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also thank the right honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for New England ( Mr Sinclair) for his contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution and for his reference to the role in

Speaker: NA
Text: previous years of the Primary Industry Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Reserve Bank. In the current environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, EFIC provides a great deal more than

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance for commodity exporters. Increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly, the direction for the future, while not

Speaker: NA
Text: neglecting the primary industry sector, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide what additional support can be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to aid growth in manufactured

Speaker: NA
Text: exports. Of course, the skills required in that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of field are much more highly special-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised than those that are available in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank. As I mentioned earlier, the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of EFIC having a post in every port

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas really does not arise because EPIC

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have or need overseas posts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Almost finally, I am assured that consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has occurred regularly and will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to occur between the banks and the insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. I am assured that they are fully

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of the continuing importance and

Speaker: NA
Text: role of EPIC. I am also advised that the

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting process will be a full and a frank

Speaker: NA
Text: one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, in response to the criticism during

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate about a number of Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: having an futerest in the trade area-including

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industry, Technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce (Senator Button), the -inister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industries and Energy ( Mr Crean)

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister for Trade and Overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: Development (Dr Blewett)-I would rather

Speaker: NA
Text: take it as evidence of the importance that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government attaches to trade promotion that

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of senior Ministers should be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved, because there are many aspects to

Speaker: NA
Text: the important question of improving our trade

Speaker: NA
Text: performance. I guess that, if we were here in

Speaker: NA
Text: another time and there were simply one

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister responsible for trade, then an opposiInterestingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of another time might equally be criticisthere

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a government for having only one Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter involved in such an important area. I

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have taken part in the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the afftrmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL

Speaker: NA
Text: PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed from 12 September,

Speaker: NA
Text: on motion by Mr Free:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 12 September, on

Speaker: NA
Text: motion by Mr Beazley:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr SMITH
Text: Bass)(5.13 p.m.)-This Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: being an amendment to the Broadcasting Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: comes at a very difficult time for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I will relate some of the high

Speaker: NA
Text: drama that took place this morning later on

Speaker: NA
Text: during my remarks. In any event, this Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of a series made to the Broadcasting Act

Speaker: NA
Text: which now marks it as probably the most

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated piece of legislation in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. There would be very few who would

Speaker: NA
Text: understand fully its reach or its ramifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: at the time of the last election

Speaker: NA
Text: were considerable moves and comments

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank have this piece of legislation subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: review-to have a rewrite. We are still wait-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to see that take place.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill clearly demonstrates yet again a

Speaker: NA
Text: need for an urgent overview of the broadcast-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing legislation. It would be hoped that the

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner that is undertaken by the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: the sooner: we might get to a very sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: position in broadcasting in this country. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill demonstrates so clearly the total confu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion that is afoot within the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, it is causing great confusion within

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill comes at a time of great signifi-

Speaker: NA
