Text: cance in that the Fairfax assets that are now

Speaker: NA
Text: held by a receiver effectively-being the

Speaker: NA
Text: second and third most profitable newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world, not just in the country-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other newspapers that are in that group,

Speaker: NA
Text: notably the Australian Financial Review and

Speaker: NA
Text: otherS, are about to be sold and bidders are

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to come to the receiver, I believe on 15

Speaker: NA
Text: October, next Tuesday, to put their bids on

Speaker: NA
Text: the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this Bill seeks to do is largely as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the proposed sale of those interests

Speaker: NA
Text: formerly held by the Fairfax group, which

Speaker: NA
Text: went into receivership, as so many of us

Speaker: NA
Text: know, because of the aborted privatisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: that group by the inheritor of the Fairfax

Speaker: NA
Text: dynasty, Mr Warwick Fairfax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth has no direct power

Speaker: NA
Text: over newspapers. However, cross-media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership rules limit an owner with a pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed interest in a commercial television

Speaker: NA
Text: licence to under 15 per cent ownership of a

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper which is associated with a service

Speaker: NA
Text: area of the television licence or where the

Speaker: NA
Text: owner is in a position to control more than 15

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of votes at a general meeting.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill requires people who propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: acquire an interest that is controlled under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act in relation to cross-media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership and foreign control rules to notify

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal of their

Speaker: NA
Text: intention. This prior notification will act as a

Speaker: NA
Text: trigger and is a less formal inquiry system

Speaker: NA
Text: than a full pre-vetting investigation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before going into some of the more detailed

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the legislation, I think it is import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant to note that what the Bill does in effect is

Speaker: NA
Text: to create even more regulation in this area. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not something that we welcome. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: broad we reject it as not being in the best

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the smooth administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's law in this area. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: created a great deal of confusion in the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: it will have in the technical application of its

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions. There is a great deal of concern,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I will refer to later, as to whether or

Speaker: NA
Text: not the legislation will actually achieve the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater scrutiny of the public interest tests that

Speaker: NA
Text: it purports to put in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: To understand this legislation, one has to go

Speaker: NA
Text: back a little while and look at what the

Speaker: NA
Text: administrator of the cross-media ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: rules and the foreign control elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act had to say about it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: administrator is a separate tribunal, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In a very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant press release of 19 July 1991, the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Acting Chairman, now Chairman, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Westerway-I might add that he is probably

Speaker: NA
Text: one of those few people in the country who

Speaker: NA
Text: understands the whole range and reach of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act, having been a senior

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the bureaucracy in the department

Speaker: NA
Text: administering this area for a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: years-detailed all the communications he

Speaker: NA
Text: had had with the Government. He set out his

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about the activities of proponents for

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase of media assets and how the reach

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ABT was in part frustrated.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a letter to the Minister for Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications ( Mr Beazley) some consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able time ago, Mr Westerway had pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that the processes involved a broad consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of many issues relating to media owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship, including a particular case referred to as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kimshaw 2UE transaction, as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: licence renewal inquiries for the Seven and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ten networks. In his letter to the Minister, he

Speaker: NA
Text: covered three main points and pointed out the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficiencies in the law. He said that there

Speaker: NA
Text: were deficiencies related to the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: approving share transactions, both the notifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations of transactions and deemed control

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions. Secondly, he said that the sanc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were often inappropriate or ineffective

Speaker: NA
Text: and that there was a need to focus on sanc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions relevant to the breach rather than ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach them through the licensing process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, he: pointed out that the current infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal arrangements for cooperation between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission and the ABT

Speaker: NA
Text: needed strengthening and he recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-membership-which, I add in passing,

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought was a commendable initiative. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, under this legislation there is sharing of

Speaker: NA
Text: information not only with the TPC but also

Speaker: NA
Text: with the FIRB, a matter which I will come to

Speaker: NA
Text: later.

Speaker: NA
Text: He then detailed a long series of flagging

Speaker: NA
Text: his concern with the Minister and came to the

Speaker: NA
Text: nub of the issue, which was the release on 18

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1991 of the ABT decision on the appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation by Kimshaw Pty Ltd to acquire control

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Sydney radio station 2UE. Kimshaw is

Speaker: NA
Text: the name of a company which is effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: a shelf company; it held the interests on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of someone else-and the someone

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: read into Hansard what the ABT said in its

Speaker: NA
Text: decision because it is the basis from which

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation springs:

Speaker: NA
Text: The ownership structure of Kimshaw was devised

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve one purpose: to preclude a breach of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership and control provisions of the Broadcast-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Act without affecting the actual ownership of

Speaker: NA
Text: interests in the 2UE licence.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the event that such structures are employed,

Speaker: NA
Text: there appears to be no quick, cheap way of testing

Speaker: NA
Text: for actual control. This may be an area for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration in any review of broadcasting legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some form of prior provisional clearance . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: might be used to prevent the architects of avoid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance schemes from enjoying their benefits for

Speaker: NA
Text: months or years until the Tribunal is in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to conclude its inquiries into them.

Speaker: NA
Text: What it is saying there is that the Act, in

Speaker: NA
Text: effect, is not working and is not addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the mischief that was outlined in the Kimshaw

Speaker: NA
Text: case in particular. Mr Westerway had been

Speaker: NA
Text: saying this for some considerable time and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had taken no action. Finally it

Speaker: NA
Text: came to the Parliament with this Bill. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: interestingly, the ABT was arguing for more

Speaker: NA
Text: than what this Bill gives. It was arguing for

Speaker: NA
Text: a mandatory prenotification procedure. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill puts in place a voluntary prenotification

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure-for want of a better term-which

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be complied with by companies that

Speaker: NA
Text: might be acquiring interests. It also broadens

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirement to incorporate associates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Associates are defined as individuals, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same terms as the income tax Act, who may

Speaker: NA
Text: have a personal interest in or a pre-existing

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in a proponent for acquisition and

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who might contravene the cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media ownership rules. If someone is in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to know that he may contravene, or

Speaker: NA
Text: have an association with someone who may

Speaker: NA
Text: contravene, he is required to notify.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the time, I pointed out in a press release

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister was of a slightly different

Speaker: NA
Text: view. Back in August at the National Press

Speaker: NA
Text: Club he said in his address that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: consider whether the ABT needed a trip-wire

Speaker: NA
Text: inserted in the Broadcasting Act which would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a list of situations which would lead to

Speaker: NA
Text: possible breaches of ownership and control

Speaker: NA
Text: laws through the use of people or companies

Speaker: NA
Text: as associates. Yet on 27 August he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would not push to give the ABT that

Speaker: NA
Text: power.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 29 August, the retiring Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: TPC, Professor Baxt, said that the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: latest comments left him with 'concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government is providing the

Speaker: NA
Text: ABT with the necessary power to evaluate all

Speaker: NA
Text: the bids'. Then on 3 September there was yet

Speaker: NA
Text: another report about a new view being pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed by the Minister to the Cabinet. I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the question then and I still have to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: question after the events of today: what

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly is the Minister's view and what

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly is the Government's view? There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of confusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then the Government came to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament with this Bill, which did not meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the ABT's advice. I have to say that I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with the full advice of the ABT. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: a full mandatory prenotification procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be of assistance to the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of this industry. This is a halfway house. It

Speaker: NA
Text: goes halfway to meeting those concerns and

Speaker: NA
Text: tries to balance off the public interest, that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining the integrity of the cross-media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership rules but at the same time allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: for there to be a reasonable operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketplace in terms of commerciality re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: So that is what the legislation tries to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: . The view that we take about this matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if one accepts that there should be cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media ownership rules, which are designed in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country to limit concentration to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: underpin the principle of diversity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: media industry, one would have to say that,

Speaker: NA
Text: where one has been advised by one's regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor that there is a mischief that has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed-and this is a proposal that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been put forward-anything that tries to go

Speaker: NA
Text: down that path to address that concetn in the

Speaker: NA
Text: broad principle probably should be supported.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that sense we will allow the legislation to

Speaker: NA
Text: pass. However, I have to say that I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: preclude the possibility of possible amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments being dealt with in the Senate, should

Speaker: NA
Text: they come forward after further study of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter given the somewhat confusing and

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary views that are put about the reach of

Speaker: NA
Text: some Of the sections. I also add that that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is further clouded by virtue of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that only today have the Australian Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: announced who their spokespersons are. As

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I can see from the list, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed their spolcesperson in this area and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is now Senator Powell, the former Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Democrats. So that matter

Speaker: NA
Text: remains to be dealt with. But on this occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: we flag our deep concern about the confusing

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of much of this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Effectively, these amendments put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: a prior provisional clearance. So someone

Speaker: NA
Text: who wants to acquire an asset, or that

Speaker: NA
Text: someone's associate, can say to the ABT,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'This is what we are intending to do. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: think it will contravene the cross-media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership nIles or the foreign control matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that are in the Act, you should hear what we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to say'. If the ABT is concerned that a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed transaction will breach those rules,

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Bill it has the right to go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Court and seek an interim order or an

Speaker: NA
Text: injunction accordingly to forestall the transac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion or to provide it with sufficient time to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the matter. It is provided with only 10

Speaker: NA
Text: days to gather this information and to become

Speaker: NA
Text: aware. Many would argue-and I would be

Speaker: NA
Text: one of those-that in the circumstances 10

Speaker: NA
Text: days might be somewhat short. It seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: a period that has been arbitrarily put into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. In the United States, I understand, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 days, and under the Trade Practices Act

Speaker: NA
Text: the period is longer as well. So there may be

Speaker: NA
Text: an argument that can be dealt with later in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate about whether or not that period ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be extended.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question is: do the changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal's powers, as proposed by the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, address the mischief that Kimshaw and

Speaker: NA
Text: the renewal of Channel 7 and Channel 10

Speaker: NA
Text: showed us existed? There is some doubt about

Speaker: NA
Text: that. That is the issue of deep concern to us,

Speaker: NA
Text: because if this proposed change is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a facade to address the concerns in

Speaker: NA
Text: the broader community about the prospect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the change in the ownership of Fairfax, one

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to say that, although the second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech of the Minister and some

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the legislation contemplate ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing the mischief, really the Bill is only

Speaker: NA
Text: dressing up the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will indicate some of the concerns which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been expressed. On Wednesday, 18

Speaker: NA
Text: September there was an article in the business

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the Australian by a well-respected

Speaker: NA
Text: commentator of long standing, Bryan Frith.

Speaker: NA
Text: The headline reads, 'Government's moves on

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax bids are just for show'. This headline

Speaker: NA
Text: and the long article under it relate to a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: which has to be addressed by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The article reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: A move designed to make the bidding easier for the

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign syndicates, coupled with action which

Speaker: NA
Text: might hinder the Packer-Black syndicate, could be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen as a shrewd method of favouring the 0 'Reilly

Speaker: NA
Text: syndicate... In practice the derisory lO-day period

Speaker: NA
Text: provided would mean that the ABT would be

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to collect evidence to the degree of sophisti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation required to convince the court of associations

Speaker: NA
Text: which result in a breach of the cross-ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: limits.

Speaker: NA
Text: That issue remains to be answered. In evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence to the print media inquiry last week, a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of concerns were raised about this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I think these need to be answered.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must point out-and I will be concise

Speaker: NA
Text: about it-that it is the Opposition's view that

Speaker: NA
Text: this process should be as transparent .as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. I have heard Government members

Speaker: NA
Text: say this as well, and I welcome hearing it. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is most important that there be no possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of any arguments or special deals that could

Speaker: NA
Text: be entered into by any of the proposed bid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders. All bidders must be able to be dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: openly. One would hope that that is the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has said that, but when we read

Speaker: NA
Text: articles such as the one from which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted and we hear comments put on the

Speaker: NA
Text: public record that raise the contrary view, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is incumbent on the Government and its

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesmen to answer those charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: some concern also has been raised about the

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign investment levels that would be

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable to the Government under the bid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members would have heard that

Speaker: NA
Text: the 20 per cent figure has been subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: great debate. Several weeks ago the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government announced that the 20 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: on its strict interpretation, was to be varied.

Speaker: NA
Text: A Caucus meeting indicated that the 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent was to be varied to allow additional

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign equity to be engaged in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: bids, and that it carried with it a non-voting

Speaker: NA
Text: element. The question of whether or not one

Speaker: NA
Text: can structure a bid to meet that requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: also remains to be answered. Many people

Speaker: NA
Text: raised doubts about that in giving evidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: the print media inquiry last week. That issue

Speaker: NA
Text: is presently causing concern for Caucus.

Speaker: NA
Text: We understand from the AAP report that

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning Caucus took that matter back for

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration. The vote was taken about

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not there ought to be a strict

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation of the 20 per cent as it relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to newspaper investments-and, of course, it

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts on the bids. I reiterate that these bids

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be on the table next Tuesday. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable result, the Left and the Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: Left combined to have 42 votes, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Right had 41 votes. The Left and the Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: Left were supporting a strict 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation. A Minister-and I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: which one; I understand that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications has lost his

Speaker: NA
Text: voice, so I assume it was not him-moved

Speaker: NA
Text: that the matter should be suspended because

Speaker: NA
Text: standing orders were offended. She needed an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute majority to have a motion such as

Speaker: NA
Text: this passed. Then Senator Mcmullan moved

Speaker: NA
Text: that there be a special Caucus meeting on

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday to consider the matter. In the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: im, the transport and communications back-

Speaker: NA
Text: bench committee and the economic backbench

Speaker: NA
Text: committee would meet on Wednesday night

Speaker: NA
Text: to prepare a report for Thursday's meeting. So

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it would be fair from any objective ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: server's point of view to say that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of confusion over the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can only say that, if people are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketplace, wanting to bid and wanting to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what the rules of the gam- are, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they see that being debated in the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: today is an Act to change the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Act while at the same time there is confusion

Speaker: NA
Text: about the limits of foreign ownership with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the newspaper industry, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be very confused and disturbed about

Speaker: NA
Text: the ability of the Government to provide some

Speaker: NA
Text: clear rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is most important in this whole process,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the pre-eminent media assets in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country are for sale, that we note the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion and the changing of the rules taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place at the same time. That must give great

Speaker: NA
Text: cause for concern. The Broadcasting Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: compounds the problem. One has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: careful because, in dealing with the bids, they

Speaker: NA
Text: are all talking their own book-and we would

Speaker: NA
Text: expect them to do so-and so one will not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily embrace one set of issues over

Speaker: NA
Text: another. The Opposition thinks the market-

Speaker: NA
Text: place ought to make this judgment, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be making it in the certainty of what

Speaker: NA

Text: station-

Text: Frith believes that this legislation will not

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to make a few comments on the

Speaker: NA
Text: background to the legislation before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. As the honourable member for Bass

Text: pointed out, the cross-media ownership

Text: are a result of this Government's determinaconglomerates

Text: tion to try to ensure greater diversity in

Text: Australia's media. The honourable member

Text: for Blaxland ( Mr Keating), the former Treas-

Text: urer, can rightly claim authorship for the

Text: cross-media ownership rules, rules which I

Text: think have made a contribution to ensuring

Text: that some of the multi-media conglomerates

Text: that we used to have in Australia have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: For someone living in Sydney before 1986,

Text: it was very difficult to get a point of view

Text: which did not come from either the Fairfax,

Speaker: NA
Text: News Ltd or Packer syndicates. For example,

Text: the Fairfax Group owned Channel 7 in price

Text: Sydney, radio station 2GB through the

Text: Macquarie operation, the Sydney Morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald, the Sun and the Australian Financial

Text: Review. News Ltd owned Channel 10, the

Text: Australian, the Daily Telegraph and the Daily

Text: Mirror. Kerry Packer's Consolidated Press

Speaker: NA
Text: owned Channel 9 in Sydney and very exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive magazine interests.

Text: In Melbourne, your constituents, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, before 1986 had the same domina-

Text: tion by News Ltd and Kerry Packer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald and Weekly Times conglomerate Christopher

Text: owned Channel 7, radio station 3DB, the Sun

Text: Pictorial and the Melbourne Herald. Again

Text: we have three multi-media conglomerates

Text: occupying very strategic positions.

Text: What is the position today? In Sydney we

Speaker: NA
Text: have different owners for channels 10, 7

Speaker: NA
Text: 9, not to mention the ABC and SBS. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations such as Hoyts and other radio

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations which have decided to put

Speaker: NA
Text: syndicates together in the radio industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: course, we have News Ltd and Fairfax domithis

Speaker: NA
Text: nating newspapers, which was the case before

Text: believe that News Ltd has too high an ownerbeen

Speaker: NA
Text: of the crucial issues which the print media

Speaker: NA
Text: would not expect me to indicate here what

Text: views might be on those issues, which

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed in our report. I think it is very

Text: ledge the fact that the cross-media ownership

Text: rules rules have meant that those multi-media

Text: have been broken up.

Text: Yes, it did not go well for Fairfax. It did

Speaker: NA
Text: not go well for young Warwick-I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to the honourable member for Bass

Text: quences of their decisions.

Text: Mr Smith-Bring Christopher Skase back.

Text: That is what has happened. The

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Bass says that

Text: Skase should be brought back; I
