Text: Having given the Government credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: Of introducing the cross-media ownership rules,

Speaker: NA
Text: is one point where I can compliment the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bass. In one recent

Speaker: NA
Text: article it was said that one of his great

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements to date has been that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: able to persuade the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: one support the cross-media ownership rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the fact that the past history of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's position on this has been

Speaker: NA
Text: my complex, to say the least, I think that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: will be credit to the honourable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we go back through Hansard reports in

Speaker: NA
Text: the period that covered the debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the cross-media ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: rules, we find that the Liberal Party argued

Speaker: NA
Text: that it should be the Trade Practices

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, and not the ABT, that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in this. The National Party, through

Speaker: NA
Text: Charles Blunt, the former member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond, and others argued that they were

Speaker: NA
Text: very concerned that the cross-media owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship rules could have a bad effect in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. The honourable member for Bass

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves credit for the fact that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: now looks like supporting the cross-media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership rules and ensuring that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: obeyed in the spirit of the law as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: letter of the law, which is the position that the

Speaker: NA
Text: current Minister for Transport and Communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations ( Mr Beazley) has taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are those limits? They mean that no

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper or radio station can own more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 per cent of a television station which covers

Speaker: NA
Text: the same service area. In return, no television

Speaker: NA
Text: station can own more than 15 per cent of any

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper that circulates to more than 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the service area. I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Burke and perhaps a

Speaker: NA
Text: few other people have been arguing that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is an inconsistency and that we need to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at a 5 per cent limit on all directions instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of allowing a differential between newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in television and television invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in newspapers. However, that is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that certainly will not be settled before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fairfax bid is closed or before the owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship of the John Fairfax group is finalised.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as this Government is concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no problem in continuing to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the cross-media ownership rules because there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a real commitment on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to ensure that the cross-media owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship rules apply and that we have that diversi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty of points of view.

Speaker: NA
Text: I confess that I got a bit confused when the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bass started his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech and said that this Bill creates even

Speaker: NA
Text: more regulation, which tended to be some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that those on his side of politics reject-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed, and that the legislation created confusion

Speaker: NA
Text: on the technical effects of the amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said that at the end of the day the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion would allow the legislation to pass and

Speaker: NA
Text: that any problems with the legislation should

Speaker: NA
Text: be addressed by the Government in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: and not by the Opposition. We are grateful

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be no division in this House on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. Members of the Opposition may

Speaker: NA
Text: think that there are some defects in the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. It is disappointing that they were not

Speaker: NA
Text: able to move amendments here today, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they wil1live to fight another day in the other

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very clear that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing this legislation as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestions and recommendations from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I personally

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the Government has done the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to require notification in examples

Speaker: NA
Text: where there could be difficulties for people

Speaker: NA
Text: bidding for media operations. We all know

Speaker: NA
Text: that at the moment most of the attention is

Speaker: NA
Text: focused on the Tourang bid for the John

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax group.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation provides for the Tourang

Speaker: NA
Text: group-the people who are deemed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: associates under the definition of this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-to notify the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal and provide certain information to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal so that it is as informed as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. The Minister for Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications is to be commended for the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that this legislation has been brought in

Speaker: NA
Text: at quite short notice to ensure that the Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Tribunal has those extra powers so

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is fully informed, can go to the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court if it believes there is a breach of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, and can take action to ensure that certain

Speaker: NA
Text: breaches are rectified. It is a very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration that the Government is not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to stand by and allow the Act to be

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored or circumvented. That is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which we support.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of the people who are opposed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourang bid for the John Fairfax group have

Speaker: NA
Text: argued that Trevor Kennedy and Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull as individuals, because they have

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: dated Press in the past, should be defined as

Speaker: NA
Text: associates and any influence which they may

Speaker: NA
Text: have should be considered to be Kerry

Speaker: NA
Text: Packer's influence. For the record, the House

Speaker: NA
Text: should be aware that in evidence to the print

Speaker: NA
Text: media inquiry last Tuesday Mr Kennedy

Speaker: NA
Text: denied that there would be such influence and

Speaker: NA
Text: made it clear that, while the Tourang group

Speaker: NA
Text: has notified the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal, it objected to any claims by people

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy or Mr Turnbull, would be exercising

Speaker: NA
Text: control or influence. As to whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that information or whether the Tribunal will

Speaker: NA
Text: require greater information, that is a decision

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have to leave to the Tribunal. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility which, I am sure, it will dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charge with proper regard to the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I wish to reaffirm my strong

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the cross-media ownership rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that they have had a positive influ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence on diversity in the Australian media.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people are unhappy with the extent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the diversity in the print media. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue which is being addressed by the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives Select Committee on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Print Media. Any suggestion that the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: which is now taking place within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government on foreign investment limits is

Speaker: NA
Text: creating confusion is made by people who

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore the fact that the alternative which

Speaker: NA
Text: currently exists provides a recipe for even

Speaker: NA
Text: greater confusion.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (6.00

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-Like the honourable member for Bass

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Smith), I confess that I have some troub-

Speaker: NA
Text: le with the timing and the nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Amendment Bill. I respect the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Dobell ( Mr Lee) and

Speaker: NA
Text: his sincerity. I can assure him that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of aspects about the timing of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that are far too reminiscent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which the Government dealt with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Vale application. We cannot change

Speaker: NA
Text: the rules in the middle of a game and we

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly cannot create a climate where no-

Speaker: NA
Text: body knows what the rules are. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: worry about the Government setting the rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might not like the rules; I might not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with aspects of them, but I am most con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about the whole approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Select Committee on the Print Media, the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction and the debate of the Broadcast-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Amendment Bill and the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax bids are being elevated to be some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that is being dealt with in the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of the general.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first rule as a parliamentarian, and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly the first rule in government, is that

Speaker: NA
Text: one never legislates subjectively. If one is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to legislate one should make up one's

Speaker: NA
Text: mind on the general principle and should

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce whatever the particular measure

Speaker: NA
Text: might be to cover the generality of the field.

Speaker: NA
Text: As soon as one legislates subjectively one

Speaker: NA
Text: creates problems and anomalies, distorts the

Speaker: NA
Text: pattern and certainly generates consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: that I do not think are desirable and in this

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, I would suggest, are commercially

Speaker: NA
Text: reprehensible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first thing that people should under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand is that the debate within Labor Caucus

Speaker: NA
Text: and the vacillation about the percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas ownership seriously prejudice the

Speaker: NA
Text: price that the three potential bidders will

Speaker: NA
Text: make for the Fairfax assets. We have to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that, quite unrelated to anything

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is doing, the receivers are

Speaker: NA
Text: properly saying, 'We want bids by a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: date'. They have set down the date. The date

Speaker: NA
Text: is next week. That is something that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: done in the commercial market outside poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tics. It is being done because the receivers

Speaker: NA
Text: have a responsibility to the creditors. Were

Speaker: NA
Text: they not to set a date and wait while the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the Labor Party made up its

Speaker: NA
Text: mind, they would be acting irresponsibly. To

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy the cries of the creditors, the receivers

Speaker: NA
Text: need to make sure that they get the best

Speaker: NA
Text: possible bid for the assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Dobell, as

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman of the Media Committee, has

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to evidence submitted to that Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee. It is public evidence and it is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: proper that he should do so. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested in evidence given to the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a variation in the price that we

Speaker: NA
Text: can pay according to the extent to which there

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to be components of overseas funds

Speaker: NA
Text: or domestic funds, the price we have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for the money, the extent to which there are

Speaker: NA
Text: associates or non-associates, the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the junk bond holders have some sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of preferential arrangement through Tourang

Speaker: NA
Text: or not, and the extent to which one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: associates-he mayor may not be an

Speaker: NA
Text: associate-involved can determine the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to which others mayor may not deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: those junk bond holders.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no complaint about the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing legislation on overseas ownership,

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which particular interests can be

Speaker: NA
Text: determined-I will address this in a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-or the way in which the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal can run its eye over forward bids

Speaker: NA
Text: and determine in advance of circumstances,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly bearing in mind the bid for 2UE

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable member for Bass referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to, to ensure that there is not a circumstance

Speaker: NA
Text: created which might breach the intent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation before the actual bid takes place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do have a concern when commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: market forces are disrupted. In the present

Speaker: NA
Text: instance it would be my strong recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the Government that we should not

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with this legislation because on

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday, 15 October, the receivers have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will receive the bids. I believe-the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bass has already said

Speaker: NA
Text: it-that there are defects in the present law.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think that we will be able to give

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient precision to the marketplace be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween now and the time those liquidators take

Speaker: NA
Text: those bids to be able to clear the position to

Speaker: NA
Text: the certain knowledge of the participants.

Speaker: NA
Text: For that reason it would qe far better

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned the debate and looked at this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: on its merits after next Monday. Equally, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would suggest to Caucus members that even

Speaker: NA
Text: though I know of their emotions and concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about overseas ownership-and I can assure

Speaker: NA
Text: them, they are not unique; there are a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians out there who worry about not

Speaker: NA
Text: only the percentage of overseas ownership but

Speaker: NA
Text: also the source of the money-it would be far

Speaker: NA
Text: better if we set aside this legislation and if

Speaker: NA
Text: Caucus set aside its debate and said, 'We

Speaker: NA
Text: have got a real worry about the percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas ownership but we are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: interfere in the process of the marketplace

Speaker: NA
Text: before the liquidators receive their bids'.

Speaker: NA
Text: It could be that after next Monday they

Speaker: NA
Text: have their debate and they introduce legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It really concerns me that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dobell has suggested that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: rather strange that Mr Kennedy should seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to comply with this legislation. Everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts that the Government has the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: to pass legislation, at least through this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber, and if he sees this legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks, 'Well, you are going to introduce it',

Speaker: NA
Text: of course he is going to try to comply with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: That should not be the basis for either Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy or any other of the participants in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bid making a judgment about what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to do. On the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: information and the law as it now exists and

Speaker: NA
Text: their interpretation of it, and the apprehension

Speaker: NA
Text: that there might be some changes, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: to make their judgment and they ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to do that between now and next

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday. I believe that would be the right

Speaker: NA
Text: way for this House to deal with this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should set aside this debate and not

Speaker: NA
Text: pass this legislation today; Caucus ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: defer its debate till after next Monday and

Speaker: NA
Text: then we can come back to it. We could then

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with the legislation next Tuesday or the

Speaker: NA
Text: day after the liquidators have received the

Speaker: NA
Text: bids. We would be in a position to make our

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment not partially, not subjectively, not

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically in relation to the Fairfax circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, but a bit more generally. The bidders

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to have to make their judgment on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of the law as it is today, knowing

Speaker: NA
Text: if we that there has been public debate, knowing

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a committee which is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a recommendation sometime before the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the year and that the laws might

Speaker: NA
Text: change before their bids come into place.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the opening position which I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: is fairly important. We have had far too much

Speaker: NA
Text: Government prevarication, far too much

Speaker: NA
Text: Government emotional reaction and far too

Speaker: NA
Text: much uncertainty in the marketplace-and,

Speaker: NA
Text: above all, we cannot afford it at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not in the brightest of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions. We do have real difficulties in

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to promote the sort of new investment

Speaker: NA
Text: that is needed and, whatever our individual

Speaker: NA
Text: views might be, the people who are putting

Speaker: NA
Text: up their bids for John Fairfax ought to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to compete in a way which ensures that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are all on even ground, that they are all

Speaker: NA
Text: competing under the law as it is now and not

Speaker: NA
Text: as it might be. So, beginning from there, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that there seems to be a shifting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sands of government policy, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: indetenninate, imprecise and really quite

Speaker: NA
Text: disruptive to the liquidator, or the receivers as

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in this instance, receiving the best

Speaker: NA
Text: bids on commercial grounds for the assets of

Speaker: NA
Text: John Fairfax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second thing I want to say is that if

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation is to be dealt with I would

Speaker: NA
Text: have preferred that at the same time we had

Speaker: NA
Text: a little more precision about where the

Speaker: NA
Text: practices legislation is going. Again before

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, and it is public knowledge, there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been debate between the AttorneyDavid

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department and the Trade Practices

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission-its Chairman, its Deputy as

Speaker: NA
Text: Chainnan and its members-as to what sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of role the trade practices legislation should

Speaker: NA
Text: play regarding the media. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about market dominance and, before

Speaker: NA
Text: one gets to that, one has to detennine what

Speaker: NA
Text: the market. Is the market print media? Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: market media in general? What is the market

Speaker: NA
Text: and how is one going to determine the role

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trade Practices Commission?

Speaker: NA
Text: I share the view of the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bass that one commendable feature about

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation is that there is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: some cross-membership. That is great, but

Speaker: NA
Text: does not really satisfy us. One of my bugs

Speaker: NA
Text: that we seem to keep on proliferating bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I spoke a few moments ago about my concern

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to EPIC. It might well be that patory areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: setting up EFIC as a separate statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: corporation is the way to go, it might well be

Speaker: NA
Text: that giving the Broadcasting Tribunal addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional power is the way to go, but I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what is going to be done about the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade practices legislation. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what role the commission is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: play. I am equally concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: role. I do not agree with the present Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Kerin) on many things, but I was inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ested to see his comment about the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the FIRE role is exercised. It is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: a correct exposition. The FIRE receives the

Speaker: NA
Text: application, then there is a discussion on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of the foreign content as to whether or

Speaker: NA
Text: not there needs to be an acceptance or rejecpowers

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the bids and the particular foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: content that is there and whether or not it

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be rejected or accepted. It does not

Speaker: NA
Text: really matter whether Caucus says it is an

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary 20 per cent and how the 20 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: is defined and whether it is equity or non-

Speaker: NA
Text: equity or quasi-equity; it is essentially a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which the FIRE and Treasury look at

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to what they see as being in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said all that, there is a problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: giving to the present Broadcasting Tribunal,

Speaker: NA
Text: trade in my view, any more power. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: the unhappy with the way the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Tribunal has been functioning since

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones departed. David Jones was

Speaker: NA
Text: exemplary in the way in which he functioned

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal,

Speaker: NA
Text: and since then the body has become far too

Speaker: NA
Text: legalistic. The extent to which a bevy of silks

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be employed in order to explain even

Speaker: NA
Text: the very humblest of licence applications is a

Speaker: NA
Text: is disgrace. We have set up this great bureau-

Speaker: NA
Text: cracy, in the legal sense, in order to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: what should be virtually routine licence

Speaker: NA
Text: of renewal applications. The powers of the ABT,

Speaker: NA
Text: to my mind, have moved way beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Parliament when the ABT

Speaker: NA
Text: was set up. I am worried that the ABT still

Speaker: NA
Text: has not enough participation from people who

Speaker: NA
Text: be are out there in the broadcasting world, not

Speaker: NA
Text: it just people who have run radio stations or

Speaker: NA
Text: is who have been involved in electronic media,

Speaker: NA
Text: but people who have a bit of interest perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: in music, drama and some of the other partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: I would prefer to see the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal as more of a body looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: public interest and less of what it sees itself

Speaker: NA
Text: as-a legal tribunal trying to adjudicate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the interpretation of aspects within the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. While I would accept that the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: FIRE Court is going to have some powers as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this legislation-and section 9 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill refers to that-it should not only be a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of legalities; it ought to be more a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of looking at what is in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: interest and how we can best serve the

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am worried about giving additional

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Broadcasting Tribunal. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to know a little more about its relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: is ship with the Trade Practices Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I would like to see a resolution of who is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to have what powers. As the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bass said, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth at the moment does not have power in

Speaker: NA
Text: the print media. It does have power with res-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect to market dominance. This intrudes and

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the whole thing a bit of a hotchpotch.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to refer to a couple of other aspects

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate. There is a worry about the

Speaker: NA
Text: narrowness of the media in Australia, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: smallness of our population and the concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of ownership. I have no doubts about

Speaker: NA
Text: that. Indeed, some have pointed with con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern-indeed quite properly-to the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which chequebook journalism seeks to influ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence individuals. There is a whole range of

Speaker: NA
Text: instances where, as politicians from both sides

Speaker: NA
Text: of politics, we can look with apprehension at

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which the media has influenced

Speaker: NA
Text: election results. Without wishing to go into it

Speaker: NA
Text: to any great degree, there is no doubt in my

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that one of the reasons the late Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMahon lost the 1972 election was the

Speaker: NA
Text: change in ownership of the Sydney Daily

Speaker: NA
Text: Telegraph. That is an historical fact. It can

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated in relation to the presentation

Speaker: NA
Text: that consumer-type news in the Daily

Speaker: NA
Text: Telegraph that the change in emphasis

Speaker: NA
Text: one side of politics to the other influenced

Speaker: NA
Text: result.

Speaker: NA
Text: Talking about chequebook journalism, I

Speaker: NA
Text: one of those who have been most concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the way in which the former wife of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)

Speaker: NA
Text: been given a great deal of publicity in what

Speaker: NA
Text: I see as a distorted presentation of what are

Speaker: NA
Text: very personal matters, distorted because they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been given a prominence which I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think is justified merely because it involves

Speaker: NA
Text: the personal life of a politician.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been suggested to me, quite seriously,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is all a matter of a particular media

Speaker: NA
Text: proprietor saying, 'Look, no matter who you

Speaker: NA
Text: are or where you are, we are able to assert

Speaker: NA
Text: authority over you. We are able to throw

Speaker: NA
Text: details of your personal life and, by throwing

Speaker: NA
Text: up details of your personal life, we are able

Speaker: NA
Text: to call on you to act in a certain way'. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been suggested to me that in this instance

Speaker: NA
Text: whole emphasis, the real target, was the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke) as this particular media

Speaker: NA
Text: proprietor is supposed to be a supporter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Blaxland ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating).

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether that is so or not, that is the impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation in our society. Our media is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: small, restricted one, and the dominance of

Speaker: NA
Text: one or two proprietors is such that people are

Speaker: NA
Text: apprehensive. That tends to taint the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which one can make a dispassionate judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: on matters of profound public policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: importance. It concerns me that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be suggestions that, through chequebook

Speaker: NA
Text: journalism, undue influence can be asserted.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is, therefore, much more difficult for us in

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament to determine the best way to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the distribution of competition, and fair

Speaker: NA
Text: and open competition, amongst different

Speaker: NA
Text: segments of the media.

Speaker: NA
Text: I happen to be a person who is against

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership restraints. I recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems with that. I am not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: argue the case now, but I am concerned that

Speaker: NA
Text: be in the present circumstances there are three

Speaker: NA
Text: of prime bidders for Fairfax. That is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: significant matter in the media area at the

Speaker: NA
Text: from moment. We have had problems with take-

Speaker: NA
Text: the overs of television stations by entrepreneurs.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are enormous financial difficulties still

Speaker: NA
Text: in the television and radio worlds. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: am that the receivers have moved into Fairfax

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that in spite of the very profit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able state of the Fairfax group, there are still

Speaker: NA
Text: has difficulties in the print media too.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that the Parliament not

Speaker: NA
Text: generate a climate of uncertainty. I strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: put it to the House that it would be far better

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to defer this legislation. In that climate,

Speaker: NA
Text: each of those bidders can put in their bids

Speaker: NA
Text: before the event. They can take note of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that there is a debate in the Labor Caucus

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the Parliament will be dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, although they will not know what

Speaker: NA
Text: up it will be. Acting under the law that now

Speaker: NA
Text: exists, they should put their bids in. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: for my money, I would prefer not only that

Speaker: NA
Text: they put their bids in, but also that the receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ers be able to make their judgment on who is

Speaker: NA
Text: the preferred bidder under the law as it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: and not face interference and intervention, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I see it, in an arbitrary way as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation this House is now debating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6.18 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr ELLIOTT
Text: parramatta) (8.00 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991, I would like at the outset to say what

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill does cover rather than deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the comments made previously which

Speaker: NA
Text: related to things that the Bill does not cover.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it may be worth while restating the

Speaker: NA
Text: key provisions of the Bill. The Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: amend the Broadcasting Act to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) require that the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal be given prior written notice of acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of interests which could contravene that Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: including a contravention that would arise if the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of associates were aggregated;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) increase the ABT's powers to gather

Speaker: NA
Text: information on the ownership and control arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for media outlets to assist the Tribunal in

Speaker: NA
Text: determining whether the ownership and control

Speaker: NA
Text: rules of the Act have been, or are likely to be,

Speaker: NA
Text: contravened; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) strengthen the powers of the Federal Court

Speaker: NA
Text: protect licensees and other companies and to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent, or prevent the continuation of, contraven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the ownership and control rules, either on

Speaker: NA
Text: an interim basis to enable proposed acquisitions of

Speaker: NA
Text: interests to be appropriately investigated or on a

Speaker: NA
Text: more permanent basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is difficult to conduct the debate on this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment Bill without reference to contem-

Speaker: NA
Text: porary affairs, particularly the Fairfax bid and

Speaker: NA
Text: so forth. But it is important to say at the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset that this particular provision has rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evance to the range of cross-media ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements that have been introduced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government as part of its broadcasting policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those cross-media ownership rules are clear

Speaker: NA
Text: and well established. What these amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: do, fundamentally, is make sure that the spirit

Speaker: NA
Text: and principles that everyone understood

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to the Broadcasting Act as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership rules are concerned are

Speaker: NA
Text: adhered to.

Speaker: NA
Text: In all the discussion that has been going on

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent weeks and months about what would

Speaker: NA
Text: happen to Fairfax, the Minister for Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Communications ( Mr Beazley) has made

Speaker: NA
Text: it abundantly clear at all times that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government would require that the cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media ownership rules, as outlined in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act, were adhered to by all the

Speaker: NA
Text: respective bidders for the Fairfax organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is with, that in mind that this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: provision has been introduced, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: gives the proactive role to the ABT, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: important in this area. It recognises the legal

Speaker: NA
Text: cases that have been referred to. Particularly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it recognises the experiences of the 2UE

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion, where it proved difficult to estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish just who had effective ownership and

Speaker: NA
Text: control of that particular organisation. Above

Speaker: NA
Text: all else, it says that the Government has the

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership rules, that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: there for a reason and are there to be applied,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it will not be possible for anyone, by

Speaker: NA
Text: a device or mechanism, to subvert the intent

Speaker: NA
Text: of those rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is wrong to suggest, as did the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for New England ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair) and the honourable member for Bass

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Smith), that some confusion is somehow

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in this process. There is not any

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion about the 15 per cent requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: to under the cross-media ownership rules. What

Speaker: NA
Text: there may have been was some people seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to extend beyond the spirit of that legal

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement. I do not know whether anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: was trying to do that when the respective

Speaker: NA
Text: people appeared before the Select Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Print Media. They said that they under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood those rules and accypted them. They,

Speaker: NA
Text: like some members of the Opposition, do not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily agree with aspects of the cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media ownership rules. Nevertheless, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have accepted the importance and relevance

Speaker: NA
Text: of them in their consideration of bids for

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax.

Speaker: NA
Text: With that in mind, I think it is right that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has taken up the suggestion-

Speaker: NA
Text: which has come from a number of quarters,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the Tribunal itself-that it needed

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the proactive investigative power to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that it could properly analyse owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and control bids for media outlets in a

Speaker: NA
Text: prospective transaction. It is fair to say that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important that the Tribunal have that right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Historically, some matters relating to media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership in Australia have been very diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult in terms of defining exactly who has

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership. I recall particularly the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: experience with television. The tracing provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions for television under the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Act do make it difficult for people to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: precisely who has ownership of all the various

Speaker: NA
Text: direct interests and who has control of those

Speaker: NA
Text: particular establishments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill, I think, clears up a lot of that

Speaker: NA
Text: ambiguity. It gives a definition of 'associates'.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the print media inquiry Mr Trevor

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy did express some criticism of this;

Speaker: NA
Text: nevertheless the Bill has cleared up the

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty as to what 'associate' means. It

Speaker: NA
Text: gives a precise definition, which I will not

Speaker: NA
Text: read out tonight, but it does make very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that where people have a direct interest the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal will have the power to go to the nub

Speaker: NA
Text: of the matter to establish what that really

Speaker: NA
Text: means in respect of the prospective purchase,

Speaker: NA
Text: share transaction or the like.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that there is a very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: argument that the media, because of its

Speaker: NA
Text: influence and its fundamental role in democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy, should be treated as a special category

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of our industry policy. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important that the Tribunal have its

Speaker: NA
Text: proactive powers. It is important that there be

Speaker: NA
Text: an overlap, as there is, between the role of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Tribunal and that of the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Commission. The cross-relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have is important in establishing the

Speaker: NA
Text: links between broadcasting and the print

Speaker: NA
Text: media particularly.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very pleasing to note that one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that hav,e been taken is to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Deputy President of the Trade Prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices Commission will sit as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Tribunal in these sorts of cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: That provides the sort of experience and

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise that is useful in getting the discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion on the respective forms of media on a

Speaker: NA
Text: coherent basis. In a democracy one can only

Speaker: NA
Text: cherish and treat very seriously the needs and

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns that we all have for information. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to make sure that the range of ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: of information is diverse so as to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the community's access to information sour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ces is taken very seriously indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is with those sorts of provisions in mind

Speaker: NA
Text: that these amendments are brought forward,

Speaker: NA
Text: as has been the case with other amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Broadcasting Act in recent times. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the first to say that some of them

Speaker: NA
Text: are fairly complex. But it is difficult, when

Speaker: NA
Text: one is dealing with transactions such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: receivership of Channel 7, to have other than

Speaker: NA
Text: complex tracing provisions. We need such

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions to ensure that we can get a full

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of who has control, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: real interest, who has real equity, and who has

Speaker: NA
Text: real influence in terms of the particular media

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that if, as the Tribunal itself has

Speaker: NA
Text: sought in the past, the Tribunal is given the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to investigate prior to the final

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions being made in these matters, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be better placed to ensure that the coherent

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit of the Broadcasting Act is complied

Speaker: NA
Text: with by all players.

Speaker: NA
Text: The licensing arrangements under the ABT

Speaker: NA
Text: have highlighted the capacity of some media

Speaker: NA
Text: players to thwart or tie up that process in

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessary litigation. Earlier this evening the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honourable member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that the Broadcasting Tribunal's

Speaker: NA
Text: actions in recent times had not been effective

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Broadcasting Tribunal had resort-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed too much to legalism. I think that in some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the most notable licence hearings involving

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting Tribunal it was anything but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting Tribunal that actually sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to tie up those matters. Rather it was some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the major players themselves who had used

Speaker: NA
Text: legal mechanisms to thwart the clear spirit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting Act at the time and had used

Speaker: NA
Text: the processes of the courts as a means of

Speaker: NA
Text: delaying and diverting the true spirit and

Speaker: NA
Text: intent of the Broadcasting Act in a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: important ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provisions in this Bill give the Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: that proactive role. They will ensure that prior

Speaker: NA
Text: written notification of acquisitions of interests

Speaker: NA
Text: is clearly established for all to see. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard, the Tourang people have already,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of the foreshadowed legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the step of referring their particular

Speaker: NA
Text: matters to the Tribunal for scrutiny in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place. That is as it should be. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that this application to interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: which could give rise to contravention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership and control rules, is clearly under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood as something that each of the respective

Speaker: NA
Text: players has to follow through.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, the range of consortia and interests

Speaker: NA
Text: which playa role in the various aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian conununity really highlight why

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a significant concern in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, all aspects of our media are very

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful weapons. It is important that if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to be serious about trying to get

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity, we should ensure that, first of all,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cross-media ownership rules apply and,

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, that the foreign ownership require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which help ensure the Australian cul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and identity that we seek from our media

Speaker: NA
Text: and which, just as importantly, I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public are concerned about, are

Speaker: NA
Text: carried through as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The impact of the notification requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: will not remove the fundamental duty of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal to establish that a contravention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act has occurred. The various bidders that

Speaker: NA
Text: are involved are required to give prior notifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. It is still up to the Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: lish that it has the grounds on which to take

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter to the Federal Court if it believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that a contravention has occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some have said-and the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass referred to this criticism-

Speaker: NA
Text: that this provision does not go far enough. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, from what has been explained so far,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Tribunal regards itself as being much

Speaker: NA
Text: better placed to be able to make judgments

Speaker: NA
Text: about these matters by having the prior

Speaker: NA
Text: notification power that this amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: provides. Admittedly, there is a tight time

Speaker: NA
Text: frame but that is there for quite obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons. The amendment will ensure that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has the scope to be able to go to the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court if it believes that a contravention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act has occurred. So the onus of proof-the

Speaker: NA
Text: presumption of innocence-that one would

Speaker: NA
Text: say applies to many Acts, will still apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting Act after this change. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, the legislation facilitates the Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: being in a position to ensure that adherence

Speaker: NA
Text: to the spirit of the law is applied all the way

Speaker: NA
Text: through the process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The intention of the Bill is not to be un-

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily intrusive as far as arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: for the ABT are concerned. Clearly, certain

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of people might be affected in some

Speaker: NA
Text: way by an associate provision that the Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: not meant to apply to. The Tribunal can make

Speaker: NA
Text: a judgment about those matters. If it deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines that further action is not required in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of certain classes of people as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: an associate notification is concerned, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter that the Tribunal can bring to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the Parliament. The matter can be

Speaker: NA
Text: laid on the table and if the regulation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: attached is deemed to be not agreed with by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament, it can be disallowed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The determination process gives the Tribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal the power to exercise its functions proper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly. At the same time, it ultimately gives the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament the sanction over those matters

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the Broadcasting Act. So to sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest in any sense that this does not achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort of objective that most people would

Speaker: NA
Text: be seeking as far as compliance with cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media ownership rules is concerned, that it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not go far enough, suggests that those

Speaker: NA
Text: people have not fully understood the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: to estab- sions of the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next matter that is important to refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of these issues obviously comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the questions relating to the impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax bid. As various speakers have said in

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate, the intention is to receive the bids

Speaker: NA
Text: on 15 October. A number of things have been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised already in this discussion. People have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'Well, the Parliament should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: getting involved in this-it should be left to

Speaker: NA
Text: the marketplace to determine the whole issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a matter for the Parliament until after

Speaker: NA
Text: the bids are in'. I think the right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England referred to that

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this evening. There are a few key

Speaker: NA
Text: points to be made on that issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all, the cross-media ownership rule

Speaker: NA
Text: has been there all the way through the

Speaker: NA
Text: process. That is not new. It is not changing

Speaker: NA
Text: the rules, as some people have suggested. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership rule, the 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: limit on newspaper ownership that is placed

Speaker: NA
Text: on a television proprietor in a major area

Speaker: NA
Text: applied well in advance of the Fairfax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration. But it has been said quite clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are going to make sure that the law-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister has made this abundantly

Speaker: NA
Text: clear-that applies in relation to that issue is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be the subject of very strict and total

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance by the Government. The amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment before us is nothing more than ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that that rule, that law, that we understood

Speaker: NA
Text: was the way the process was to work is

Speaker: NA
Text: actually going to be strictly complied with.

Speaker: NA
Text: is completely without foundation to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is somehow shifting the goal post,

Speaker: NA
Text: shifting the sands, or whatever other expresto

Speaker: NA
Text: sion is used.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of the experiences that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had already with other cases, it is clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: the will of the Parliament in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership rules should be up-

Speaker: NA
Text: held. I do not suggest that any of the particufundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: lar bidders in relation to Fairfax were not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to do that. I am saying to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that to give the Tribunal the power to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that those rules are adhered to at the outset

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to me to be pretty fundamental to a

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion about real cross-media ownership.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Opposition, as the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bass said earlier today in the debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: basically supportive of cross-media ownercountries.

Speaker: NA
Text: ship, surely it would want to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership rules are applied

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings me to the next point: what do

Speaker: NA
Text: we want to try to achieve with our media

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership? Surely there are important things

Speaker: NA
Text: that we try to achieve. We try to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a real diversity of ownership of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian media. We try to ensure that a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of opinion is expressed in all the major

Speaker: NA
Text: markets and, hopefully, in the provincial, rural dominance.

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional areas as well. Clearly, part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of that is ensuring that there are rules

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to fair competition. The tests about

Speaker: NA
Text: what is competitiveness as far as media is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned may well have to be different to

Speaker: NA
Text: what applies in other areas of what would

Speaker: NA
Text: normally come under the trade practice hiw.

Speaker: NA
Text: That leads me to the issue that was before

Speaker: NA
Text: the print media inquiry last week. The Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Commission suggested that one

Speaker: NA
Text: the things that it believes is important for

Speaker: NA
Text: future is to ensure that the test relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: competition be changed from one of market

Speaker: NA
Text: dominance to one based on the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial lessening of competition. There is

Speaker: NA

Text: may Transport and Communications) (8.40 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: start by acknowledging the contributions of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members who have spoken in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. As I progress I will make particular

Speaker: NA
Text: comment on some of the words of the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: these ourable member for Mitchell ( Mr Cadman).

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, I thank the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dobell ( Mr Lee) for his contribution, in which

Speaker: NA
Text: he put these amendments in their proper and

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate context. I endorse the statements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honourable member for Parramatta ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Elliott) on cross-media ownership. The logic

Speaker: NA
Text: of his presentation and his understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: the how the ABT operates and how it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by these amendments is apparent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I found the contributions of Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members somewhat confusing because they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not demonstrate a uniform view.

Speaker: NA
Text: The propositions which were put by the

Speaker: NA
Text: them honourable member for Bass ( Mr Smith)-

Speaker: NA
Text: who and the way in which he argued them-were

Speaker: NA
Text: and very different from the arguments which were

Speaker: NA
Text: put by the right honourable member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England ( Mr Sinclair) and the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mitchell. Both the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass and the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mitchell commented on the ALP Caucus.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that context, as the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dobell observed, whilst the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass got some parts of it correct,

Speaker: NA
Text: essentially he misunderstood-or was com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely unaware of-the process of Caucus

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitchell clearly had no idea. It might have

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted the House if they had talked to one

Speaker: NA
Text: another and at least taken a common line on

Speaker: NA
Text: what they thought was the attitude of Caucus,

Speaker: NA
Text: because they presented two very conflicting

Speaker: NA
Text: views.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their contributions demonstrate the danger

Speaker: NA
Text: of relying on media reports about what Cau-

Speaker: NA
Text: cus does or does not do. Perhaps they should

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect upon this. I suggest to them that the

Speaker: NA
Text: best thing for them to do is to be patient and

Speaker: NA
Text: all will be revealed to them. In time they will

Speaker: NA
Text: understand what the Caucus says. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: not find it out from AAP, which the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bass this evening indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: was his source.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that in particular the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mitchell referred to the nationali-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty provisions of the legislation. I advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mitchell that the only

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the nationality provisions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation occurred in 1981. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: who was responsible at that time was the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for New England. The

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions which were introduced changed the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification from a resident to a citizen. The

Speaker: NA
Text: person who came to be most affected by that

Speaker: NA
Text: was Mr Murdoch from News Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ,suggest to Opposition members that,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite their rhetoric, they need to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what this debate is about. This Bill amends a

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting Act, not a newspaper Act. If

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign ownership limits are introduced for

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers, they will be introduced not under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting Act but under the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Act, the Foreign Takeovers Act or

Speaker: NA
Text: some specific Act which might or might not

Speaker: NA
Text: be drafted for that purpose. This Bill simply

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with the way the ABT and the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court handle the actual or proposed acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of prescribed interests covered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act. It is a Bill of general

Speaker: NA
Text: principle, as the right honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: New England demands, and it will be effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive in ensuring that the spirit and letter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act are observed. Already, Mr Kennedy's

Speaker: NA
Text: actions give evidence of that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasise that, despite the view which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been expressed by the Opposition, the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: does not change the rules. This was com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented upon in some detail by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta. The requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: the current Act will determine what decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately are taken. I assure the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass that those rules already

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to any form of control-de facto,

Speaker: NA
Text: indirect, or direct. This Bill will also allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the ABT and the Federal Court to deal effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively with prospective acquisitions of pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed interests, including acquisitions of

Speaker: NA
Text: actual control.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasise that there is absolutely no

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion surrounding this Bill. The amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to the Act proposed in the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the provisions of the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Act relating to cross-media acquisitions and

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign ownership and control will be respect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed and adhered to. The Bill clarifies the

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures of the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal that intending purchasers and owners

Speaker: NA
Text: of broadcasting media will be involved in.

Speaker: NA
Text: The primary objective of the Bill-that

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings be given to the Tribunal by

Speaker: NA
Text: parties concerned in order to facilitate avoid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of any contravention of the Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Act-unfortunately seems to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: overlooked by the Opposition speakers in

Speaker: NA
Text: their haste to raise issues which were com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely extraneous to this legislation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings in this legislation are enforceable

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Federal Court. Any breach of a court

Speaker: NA
Text: order to comply with the undertakings is self-

Speaker: NA
Text: executory; that is, failure to comply with such

Speaker: NA
Text: an order is a contempt of court.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 81f2 years of this Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: we have witnessed rapid change in the field

Speaker: NA
Text: of broadcast media. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mitchell seemed intent, unfortunately, on

Speaker: NA
Text: indicating to the House that somehow or other

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government was responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: excesses of the corporate cowboys in the

Speaker: NA
Text: media industry. We would have to ask him

Speaker: NA
Text: how. I would suggest to him, if he were here,

Speaker: NA
Text: that not even he could seriously believe that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those people are responsible for their own

Speaker: NA
Text: actions, and they are the ones who are respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for putting the organisations for which

Speaker: NA
Text: they themselves had responsibility into the

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that they ended up in. I would suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member for Mitchell that he

Speaker: NA
Text: should not listen to or believe his own rhetor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic, because it clearly is a misunderstanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth stressing that over the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: years we have seen profitable broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: operations become financially threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: through their entanglement with parent or

Speaker: NA
Text: holding companies. Despite the advent of

Speaker: NA
Text: television networks, holding companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: conglomerates with complex ownership and

Speaker: NA
Text: control structures, television licence-holding

Speaker: NA
Text: companies losing control of their cash flow to

Speaker: NA
Text: contingent group liabilities and the like, the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy thrusts of this Government have kept

Speaker: NA
Text: pace with the changes we have witnessed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing that we need to observe is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition is speaking from a station-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary perspective of recent moments in history.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Broadcasting Act of 1942 was amended

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labor Government in 1987 and again

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1990. These amendments addressed the

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly complex issues of ownership and

Speaker: NA
Text: control of broadcast media.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this era of rapid change, one would think

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is appropriate that we review from time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time the processes which are involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that media regulations are appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate, and from time to time that means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of legislation which has been debated

Speaker: NA
Text: here this evening ought to be introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite its cynicism, the Opposition needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand and comprehend that the funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental desire of this Government is to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have a strong and appropriate media

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country. We accept and appreciate, as

Speaker: NA
Text: should the Opposition, the importance of an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent media, free of monopoly control

Speaker: NA
Text: or excessive foreign ownership, with quality

Speaker: NA
Text: programming and local content that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained under this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extent to which genuine freedom of

Speaker: NA
Text: speech is maintained is a measure of our

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy and something with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mitchell, perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: even the right honourable member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England and certainly the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bass ought to appreciate is a major con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern of this Government and is a legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: concern of the Caucus. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: acted to ensure freedom of speech and di-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity of media ownership in our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: These have been concerns of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: during this period of rapid change.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments set down in this Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the spirit and intent of the Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Act, as amended, will be respected

Speaker: NA
Text: and its provisions adhered to. Restrictions on

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-media ownership and on the extent of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign interest being involved in the owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and control of Australian broadcast

Speaker: NA
Text: media have been part of the policy initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government l;lnd, hence, the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendments to ,the Broadcasting Act made

Speaker: NA
Text: previously by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the domain, after all, of government to

Speaker: NA
Text: determine policy and to legislate accordingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: just as in 1981 the right honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for New E-gland, as Minister, saw fit to

Speaker: NA
Text: legislate to change the definition of nationali-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty. It is the domain of the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Tribunal, on the other hand, to moni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor and regulate compliance with legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to broadcasting. It is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: note not only that the independence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is crucial to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that all players and potential players

Speaker: NA
Text: in the broadcasting media industry comply

Speaker: NA
Text: with the legal requirements placed upon them

Speaker: NA
Text: but also that the effective functioning of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal is important in ensuring the viability

Speaker: NA
Text: and efficiency of the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might just make one observation. I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: think the -eputation of the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Mitchell was at all enhanced by his

Speaker: NA
Text: slagging off at the Chairman of the ABT. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that he might rethink his attitude, as

Speaker: NA
Text: some other members of the Opposition ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to do, about people in public office who are

Speaker: NA
Text: working on behalf of the people of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country in positions such as Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mitchell wants to slag

Speaker: NA
Text: off at him, he ought to do it outside. If he has

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations to make about these people, he

Speaker: NA
Text: should make them outside and expose himself

Speaker: NA
Text: to the full force of the law. His was a gutless

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise which ought not to be seen in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, and I believe the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mitchell approached

Speaker: NA
Text: that particular subject is something which he

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to reflect upon.

Speaker: NA
Text: One aspect of the role of the Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns broadcast media ownership. It is to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Tribunal has the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: monitor and regulate effectively in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: acquisition of broadcast media and of owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and control that the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced this Bill. Under the Bill, prior

Speaker: NA
Text: notification of acquisitions of broadc::ast media

Speaker: NA
Text: which may be in contravention of the Act is

Speaker: NA
Text: required of the intended purchaser. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: notification will ensure that intended or actual

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership changes are brought to the atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Tribunal. It will also assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasers to avoid breaches of the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ability of the Tribunal to fulfil inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendently and effectively its function qf

Speaker: NA
Text: granting approvals in relation to ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: and control of licences will be streamlined

Speaker: NA
Text: and strengthened by the legislation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal will gain increased power to gather

Speaker: NA
Text: information relevant to any inquiry it deems

Speaker: NA
Text: may be necessary to investigate further mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tersof acquisition, ownership and control that

Speaker: NA
Text: may be in contravention of the Act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government considers it is of paramount

Speaker: NA
Text: importance that the Tribunal be vested with

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary powers to carry out its functions

Speaker: NA
Text: properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: As with other initiatives of this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, safeguards to protect individuals are

Speaker: NA
Text: properly and appropriately being put in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tribunal will not be able to make public

Speaker: NA
Text: information of or about a prospective broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: cast media ownership transaction, and any

Speaker: NA
Text: information that would give a business com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitor an unfair advantage could not be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: closed by the Tribunal. These provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill will go a long way to ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: the functions of the ABT, described in section

Speaker: NA
Text: 16 of the Broadcasting Act, can and will be

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted on an independent basis. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government appropriately, as I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the rules, and it is the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal to monitor and investigate

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial activities of individuals, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies and groups associated with the owner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and control of broadcast media.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation, appropriately, contrary to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the honourable member for Mitchell had

Speaker: NA
Text: the gall to suggest, maintains the separation

Speaker: NA
Text: of functions of the Government and the ABT.

Speaker: NA
Text: It keeps the Tribunal at arm's length from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, as would be appropriate and as

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure is supported by the bulk of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition if not by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mitchell.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly the Australian Broadcasting Tribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal is the proper body for investigating the

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance with or contravention of cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: media and foreign ownership provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Act; the need for public

Speaker: NA
Text: proprietary of the broadcast licence holders

Speaker: NA
Text: and their responsibility to accurately inform,

Speaker: NA
Text: to entertain and to meet social and cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of their media audience have long been

Speaker: NA
Text: established. Ensuring that the body which is

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the monitoring of licences,

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and standards is the same body that

Speaker: NA
Text: monitors and regulates in relation to acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, ownership and control not only makes

Speaker: NA
Text: for an efficient system of public accountabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty but also makes for one with sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to effectively achieve the objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the public good to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further important aspect of this Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Amendment Bill addresses the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of who constitutes an associate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of media ownership and control. I

Speaker: NA
Text: stress that it is not the intention of the Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: make it difficult for genuine players in the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting field. It is iinportant that the

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of associate relationships in the

Speaker: NA
Text: prior notification requirement will restrict

Speaker: NA
Text: contraventions to the Act and, indeed, prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: such contraventions by enabling the Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: to take action at an early stage of acquisition

Speaker: NA
Text: and ownership changes. This will allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal to avoid the use of valuable re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources on unnecessarily prolonged investigat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ions.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said at the outset, I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and I thank honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made contributions, though the

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions made by the Opposition mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers are not ones I would agree with. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the honourable member for Bass for

Speaker: NA
Text: indicating that he will support, or at least not

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose, the amendments we will move in the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee stages of the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the afftrmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bil1 read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Northern Territory-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications) (8.58 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Clause 5, page 4, proposed paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: 90HA(3)(b), line 13, omit "that fact", substi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute ", or has reason to believe, that this

Speaker: NA
Text: section so applies because of the proposal".

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Clause 6, page 8, proposed paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: 92EA(3)(b) line 12, omit "that fact", substi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute ", or has reason to believe, that this

Speaker: NA
Text: section so applies because of the proposal".

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Clause 6, page 10, proposed subsection

Speaker: NA
Text: 92EA(13), lines 5 and 6, omit the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first amendment simply clarifies the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the Bill to ensure that, in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to notice of an acquisition of a prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in a commercial radio licence, no

Speaker: NA
Text: person should be able to argue that he or she

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a specific awareness of the precise

Speaker: NA
Text: term& of the section before being obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with it. The obligation to notify will

Speaker: NA
Text: arise when the person is aware of the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est-whether held by the person or by an

Speaker: NA
Text: associate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second amendment before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: has a similar effect to the first amendment,

Speaker: NA
Text: but in relation to commercial television

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. The third amendment simply re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moves a provision not necessary, to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that persons with prescribed interests in

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers are required to notify any acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of more than 5 per cent in a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: television service in the same area. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions already have that effect, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of this provision may have caused

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill reported with amendments; report-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-adopted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Snowdon)-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1991-92

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 12 September.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 3.

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $132,489,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $180,547,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $1,457,829,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance to theMinister for Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $170,000,000.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: Sturt) (9.02 p.m.)-I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to take part in the debate on the appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations for the Department of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and Cabinet, the Department of Finance,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of the Treasury and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance to the Minister for Finance because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in these areas-particularly in the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Treasury and the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister and Cabinet-that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility for the development and

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of policies that relate to the

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance and the stability of our whole

Speaker: NA
Text: financial system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk about a specific problem that

Speaker: NA
Text: has arisen for the electors I represent and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other taxpayers in my State of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. All honourable members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House would be aware that the State Bank of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia would have failed but for a

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer guarantee that has enabled the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of South Australia to recapitalise

Speaker: NA
Text: that bank not once, but twice, so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: complies with the capital adequacy require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale-In the interim.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: In the interim, as my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague says. In February of this year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Premier announced to shocked South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians that it was necessary for the State
