Speaker: NA
Text: Government to pump $980m into the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank. Just over six months later when he

Speaker: NA
Text: brought down his State Budget he brought a

Speaker: NA
Text: second shock to the South Australian elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate by announcing that another $1.2 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: had to be pumped in to ensure that the bank

Speaker: NA
Text: had the appropriate capital adequacy require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was because it was now allegedly the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank that was under the formal supervision of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential

Speaker: NA
Text: supervision, whereas formerly it was appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently informally under that supervision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Inquiries are being properly conducted as to

Speaker: NA
Text: who had primary responsibility or some level

Speaker: NA
Text: of responsibility for determining the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: prudential supervision. As a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representative Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Finance and Public Administration, I took

Speaker: NA
Text: part in a very interesting discussion with

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the State Bank of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia when they came to talk to us about

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank's problems and the manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they were handling them. Arising out of that

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence, it became apparent that the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank has a large number of subsidiaries. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that there might be more than 130.

Speaker: NA
Text: A significant subsidiary is a company called

Speaker: NA
Text: Beneficial Finance, a finance company which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been borrowing money and lending

Speaker: NA
Text: money. It has been borrowing money by

Speaker: NA
Text: issuing public prospectuses and getting public

Speaker: NA
Text: support. Its prospectus No. 65, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly had at the bottom of a paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement that the State Bank of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia does not guarantee, nor does it have

Speaker: NA
Text: any responsibility, for the debenture

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowings of Beneficial Finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the Committee hearings on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: record, in public evidence, the present manag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing director of the bank informed the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee that the State Government had not

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed Beneficial Finance's funding. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not very much favour the idea of banks that

Speaker: NA
Text: are too big to fail or banks that cannot fail

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have behind them a government

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee. I certainly have less favour with

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea that the risk subsidiary of a bank

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be able to fail if it enters risky

Speaker: NA
Text: business. It is stupid and scandalous for a

Speaker: NA
Text: government such as the State Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia, whose bank would have

Speaker: NA
Text: failed but for the guarantee of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and, hence, the taxpayers, to permit, let

Speaker: NA
Text: alone urge, its bank to pump good money

Speaker: NA
Text: after bad into a failing finance company

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidiary. This is what is happening with

Speaker: NA
Text: Beneficial Finance in a way that is forcing

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australian taxpayers to make a present

Speaker: NA
Text: of what could be up to $1 billion to interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional and other money market financiers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bank's managing director, Mr Ted

Speaker: NA
Text: Johnson, has challenged the correctness of

Speaker: NA
Text: this claim. Let me explain how the figure can

Speaker: NA
Text: be justified. In doing so I will outline some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the evidence which he, and his offsider, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Steve Paddison, gave to the banking inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The retail debentures are a relatively small propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Beneficial's total funding. It is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority funded out of wholesale funding markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: When later questioned on this topic, the

Speaker: NA
Text: managing director, Ted Johnson, confirmed

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: are a relatively small proportion of the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing liabilities compared with wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: finance market borrowings. Though Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Johnson was not absolutely certain of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ratio, he said that it would be between 10 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent. He promised to confirm the exact

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers-I have not heard yet, but I hope to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: supply details as to how much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outstandings of Beneficial Finance are domes-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic debentures or retail debentures, wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: funding market liabilities, liabilities to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Government or other liabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ted Johnson, in the Advertiser of 3 October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991, is quoted as saying that Beneficial had

Speaker: NA
Text: $450m in offshore debt. This represents 35

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the borrowings, given that Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Johnson is also quoted as saying that 65 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of its borrowings were domestic.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there were $195m owing on retail deben-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures, this would represent 15 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: total borrowings with the balance coming

Speaker: NA
Text: from the domestic wholesale market, repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting 50 per cent or $650m. Much of this

Speaker: NA
Text: $650m would have come from overseas as

Speaker: NA
Text: our domestic financial markets are awash with

Speaker: NA
Text: significant amounts of foreign investors'

Speaker: NA
Text: funds, which has come about as a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence of this Government's high interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: high exchange rate policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australian taxpayers should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to pay BFC's losses. The State

Speaker: NA
Text: J)overnment guaranteed the repayment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank's deposits but it did not guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: repayment of BFC's bonds, nor were they

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed by the State Bank. The debentures

Speaker: NA
Text: were not guaranteed; the money market

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments were not guaranteed, so the

Speaker: NA
Text: gnomes of Zurich, New York, Tokyo and

Speaker: NA
Text: even Sydney and Melbourne should not get a

Speaker: NA
Text: present from the South Australian taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: because now, in a retrospective way, those

Speaker: NA
Text: debentures are being given a guaranteed

Speaker: NA
Text: status. The State Bank should walk away

Speaker: NA
Text: from Beneficial Finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question might arise: what happens to

Speaker: NA
Text: the retail debenture holders? If one looks at

Speaker: NA
Text: their prospectus and tries to study the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, it could well be that the retail deben-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture holders would be paid 100c in the dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: and then there would be no problem. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should South Australian taxpayers be paying

Speaker: NA
Text: on the wholesale money markets interest at 4

Speaker: NA
Text: or 5 per cent above the borrowings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank because people lent knowing the money

Speaker: NA
Text: was at risk? They took the risk; they should

Speaker: NA
Text: now cop the loss. The South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer should not have to fund that loss.

Speaker: NA
Text: This raises the whole question of the effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cacy and appropriateness of State banks. For

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of years I have been advocating that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should be sold. I am pleased that my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues in the Liberal Party Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: the State Parliament have said that their

Speaker: NA
Text: policy is to sell the bank. It should be sold

Speaker: NA
Text: now and not later. By its crystallising its loss

Speaker: NA
Text: now and selling its books, if it has them, we

Speaker: NA
Text: as South Australians would get much more

Speaker: NA
Text: for it and we would know what we were up

Speaker: NA
Text: for, whereas if we let it drag on, it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: by bankers who are more concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: protecting bankers and the bankers' club than

Speaker: NA
Text: they are about the interests of taxpayers for

Speaker: NA
Text: whom they write blank cheques. It is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of South Australians that the bank be

Speaker: NA
Text: sold now. Its land broking and land agency

Speaker: NA
Text: firm, its merchant bank, its insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: company and all its other subsidiaries should

Speaker: NA
Text: also be sold. Who knows how much they

Speaker: NA
Text: have borrowed on unsecured risk rated high

Speaker: NA
Text: interest paper. If they go wrong-they may

Speaker: NA
Text: have; we do not know-should we as taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers be paying, or should they be allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: fail?

Speaker: NA
Text: My view is that the security of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian financial system, let alone the

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australian system, is at stake if we

Speaker: NA
Text: allow these high risk ventures that are subsid-

Speaker: NA
Text: iaries of banks to get de facto guarantees after

Speaker: NA
Text: the event when people are getting a high price

Speaker: NA
Text: for the money because of the risk they took.

Speaker: NA
Text: (TIme expired)

Speaker: Dr CATLEY
Text: Adelaide) (9.11 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to talk about the Treasury appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priation in respect of the Treasury policy as

Speaker: NA
Text: we come out of the recession that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in during this y-ar. We are in the reces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion for two interrelated reasons-the first, a

Speaker: NA
Text: long term one and the other a short term one.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the long term, it results from our being cast

Speaker: NA
Text: adrift from the British imperial economic

Speaker: NA
Text: system when Britain joined the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Community and the consequential need for us

Speaker: NA
Text: to restructure our economy, which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: featherbedded by inefficient sweetheart deals

Speaker: NA
Text: by Opposition members when in government

Speaker: NA
Text: over 30 years in airlines, tariffs for the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing sector, the ports, the education

Speaker: NA
Text: system, agriculture and the banking sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the short term, it has been occasioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: overheating the economy in 1989-90 when

Speaker: NA
Text: demand was growing at 8 per cent, supply by

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 per cent and the current account deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: matching the difference by providing a 4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent current account deficit of GDP. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, the Government slowed down the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy with tight wage, fiscal and monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. This slowdown unfortunately became

Speaker: NA
Text: a recession in the course of the calendar year

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 because of the rural crisis occasioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: run the collapse of markets for our stable products

Speaker: NA
Text: of wheat and wool and in part by the drought.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was further exacerbated by a downturn in

Speaker: NA
Text: the international business cycle, which ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pears to have an unfortunate eight year

Speaker: NA
Text: duration that is almost immutable.

Speaker: NA
Text: This recession has not been the worst

Speaker: NA
Text: recession in 60 years, no matter how loudly

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition shouts this to be the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment has not reached 10 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment was 30 per cent in the 1930s.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment in 1982-83 was over 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. At this stage, on the basis of unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment figures, we are not as bad as we were in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1982-83. On the basis of falls in output of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic production, there has not been such

Speaker: NA
Text: a fall as there was in 1982-83. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst recession since 1982-83. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: exacerbated by the international situation and

Speaker: NA
Text: by the need to restructure, but the signs are

Speaker: NA
Text: now appearing unmistakably that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: coming out of the recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at a few of these figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that they are volatile and there

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be some ambiguities, but if we pick

Speaker: NA
Text: our way through we can see the following

Speaker: NA
Text: things. Firstly, we have made unambiguous

Speaker: NA
Text: gains on the inflation front, to which I will

Speaker: NA
Text: return. We have also made unambiguous

Speaker: NA
Text: gains on the current account deficit which

Speaker: NA
Text: occasioned the change in policy two years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. In terms of outputs, there are some clear

Speaker: NA
Text: signs that we are now moving upwards in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of production. Take the housing sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example. Housing finance commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by 8.1 per cent in July to their highest

Speaker: NA
Text: level since November 1988 and they are 53.6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent above the trough of the recession in

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1989. It is true that building approvals

Speaker: NA
Text: fell back slightly by 1.2 per cent in August

Speaker: NA
Text: after rising strongly by 17.3 per cent in July,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the trend showed a growth of 2.6 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: for the second consecutive month.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Westpac/CAI survey for industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: trends showed expectations for new orders in

Speaker: NA
Text: the coming quarter to be at their most bullish

Speaker: NA
Text: for two years. Inflation expectations for

Speaker: NA
Text: December are the lowest recorded in the

Speaker: NA
Text: survey and labour shedding is also expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to slow. Retail trade rose by 2.2 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: July after a slight fall in June and over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last three months trend growth was averaging

Speaker: NA
Text: at 0.3 per cent. The Westpac/Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute measures of consumer inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: expectations have now fallen to 4 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: the September quarter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour market indicators are somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: volatile, as would be expected at this stage in

Speaker: NA
Text: the cycle, but the, August labour force

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics showed a record growth in employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of 106,000 new jobs. This also occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: with a sharp increase in the participation rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is back up to 63.4 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that the ANZ job vacancy survey

Speaker: NA
Text: is not showing any great improvement, but on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand the DEET index has shown a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear sign of having turned with an 18 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase in the three months to

Speaker: NA
Text: September, the first such increase in two

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Alongside that there have been two unam-

Speaker: NA
Text: biguous wins. One has been the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit for August, which came in

Speaker: NA
Text: well below market expectations at $507m, the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest since January 1988 and the second

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest since April 1984. Exports have set a

Speaker: NA
Text: monthly record for the third consecutive

Speaker: NA
Text: month and imports have fallen by 12.3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. The surplus on goods and services, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: exclude repayment on previous debt, was

Speaker: NA
Text: $696m, the highest on record.

Speaker: NA
Text: The overall picture that is emerging is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a slight increase and improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in output, the current account deficit is

Speaker: NA
Text: unambiguously improving and the inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: rate is going down. The inflation rate is not

Speaker: NA
Text: just going down owing to the recession. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the previous recession, which, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, was comparable in terms of output and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment results, we see that the inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: rate in 1982-83 reached a peak of over 11 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. It is now 3 per cent annualised, and

Speaker: NA
Text: prices actually fell during the first six months

Speaker: NA
Text: of this year. The recession has not alone

Speaker: NA
Text: caused the drop in the inflation rate. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: been occasioned by the continuing accord

Speaker: NA
Text: with the trade unions on wage restraint and

Speaker: NA
Text: the capacity of this Government to target

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in such a way as its programs are

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained but public sector spending re-

Speaker: NA
Text: straint is occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, the current account deficit is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: due to the recession. It is not just a question

Speaker: NA
Text: of imports going down; exports are up. The

Speaker: NA
Text: character of the exports has also changed in

Speaker: NA
Text: two very fundamental ways. They are increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly manufacturing industry goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services. In the last quarter of 1990 manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured goods exports exceeded the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: farm exports, probably for the first time in the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of this country. Similarly, the direction

Speaker: NA
Text: of these exports has changed very substantial-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly and over 60 per cent of them now go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Basin trading economies. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, we have now moved away from being

Speaker: NA
Text: an adjunct of any European economic imperi-

Speaker: NA
Text: al structure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The South K:orean market is now more

Speaker: NA
Text: important for our exports than the UK market.

Speaker: NA
Text: The east Asian newly industrialised countries

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a bigger market for us than the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Community does. Very shortly,

Speaker: NA
Text: probably next year, ASEAN will be bigger as

Speaker: NA
Text: a market for our goods than will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Community. There are plenty of

Speaker: NA
Text: signs that our education system, our media

Speaker: NA
Text: and our business culture have recognised the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to shift the character and also the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction of our exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noted in a paper yesterday that Japan's

Speaker: NA
Text: economy actually grew between 1985 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 by one France. What a staggering

Speaker: NA
Text: statistic! The capacity of these markets to

Speaker: NA
Text: absorb our goods is undoubtedly huge and we

Speaker: NA
Text: now witness our nearest neighbour, Indonesia,

Speaker: NA
Text: growing at nearly 10 per cent per annum and

Speaker: NA
Text: absorbing an increasing component of our

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing exports. Now that the ABC is

Speaker: NA
Text: to reopen in Jakarta, I hope we will get as

Speaker: NA
Text: much news on Indonesia as we get about

Speaker: NA
Text: France-although I dare say that is wishful

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn to employment. Just as this

Speaker: NA
Text: recession is not the worst in 60 years, so too

Speaker: NA
Text: the job situation is not as bad as the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion wants to represent it. There are 830,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people unemployed, which is a tremendously

Speaker: NA
Text: bad statistic but it is not one million. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has still averaged over 185,000

Speaker: NA
Text: new jobs per year for the last 8112 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: counting the latest slowdown, which is more

Speaker: NA
Text: than double the rate of job creation growth

Speaker: NA
Text: that Opposition members managed when in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. But our people are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: ask: what will be the rate of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: when this recession is put behind us and we

Speaker: NA
Text: go back into a growth phase? What can we

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably expect to be a rate of unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with which we should be satisfied?

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Hewson) says that full employment is now

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere between 5 and 6.5 per cent. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate that probably sociological changes

Speaker: NA
Text: have produced an increase in the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: women seeking work and a small reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of older men seeking work,

Speaker: NA
Text: leading to a participation rate which is up

Speaker: NA
Text: from 58 to 64 per cent. If a similar rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment is achieved in the work force in,

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 1992 as there was in 1964, just as there

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been an unemployment rate

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome in 1964 of 1.2 per cent in 1992 it is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be 5.5 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe, therefore, we can reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably look forward to a 1.2 per cent unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rate. We can, however, look to a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial reduction, and we can assist it. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: will this improvement in employment take

Speaker: NA
Text: place? Firstly, in export industries; secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: in those industries benefiting from the 8.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent reduction in interest rates which we have

Speaker: NA
Text: already achieved; thirdly, by fast tracking

Speaker: NA
Text: development projects; fourthly, by our infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure program brought on stream in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget for building better cities; and, finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the city that I represent-Adelaide-by the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of the multifunction polis which

Speaker: NA
Text: to my great dismay I note has been opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: by first the Federal Liberals and then by the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Liberals and finally by the State and

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Democrats. This is the greatest oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity for job generation to present itself in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia for the foreseeable future and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is with great dismay that I have to report

Speaker: NA
Text: that all political parties except the ALP are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to dud it. I hope the citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, come the next election, are in full

Speaker: NA
Text: cognisance of the brakes that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on employment generation in the high

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, high capital and high value-added

Speaker: NA
Text: even products that the MFP represents. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins) (9.22 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget we are debating tonight, handed

Speaker: NA
Text: down on 20 August 1991, is hardly eight

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks old but it is stone-cold dead. I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: that is to be expected of a document so

Speaker: NA
Text: vacuous, showing such a defeatist attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: towards government, and that was found to be

Speaker: NA
Text: so dispiriting by the Australian public. To-

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr night I want to ask a legitimate question:

Speaker: NA
Text: how valuable are these Budget Papers that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been presented with? This was a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government deliberately set out to

Speaker: NA
Text: hide. When the Government thinks it can

Speaker: NA
Text: make half a public relations exercise out of

Speaker: NA
Text: anything it grasps it with both hands. Take,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, the supposed 12 March state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Building a Better Australia. Even the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government could not maintain the pretence

Speaker: NA
Text: that this was a significant document; even it

Speaker: NA
Text: could not maintain the pretence that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: make any significant contribution to the life

Speaker: NA
Text: of national policy in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all the Government tried to hide the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget by bringing it forward to 3 p.m. so the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public would not be able to watch

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Then it tried to hide it, of course, by doing

Speaker: NA
Text: away with all of the rhetorical flourishes

Speaker: NA
Text: which had been used over the Keating period

Speaker: NA
Text: to try to attract public attention, the kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetorical flourishes that were made in 1987,

Speaker: NA
Text: that we were entering a golden age of eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic change, or in 1988, that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: bring home the bacon.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to compare the actual outcome in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last year with the promises that were made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1990-91 Budget and ask the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: how valuable are these Budget documents?

Speaker: NA
Text: In August 1990 the then Treasurer was using

Speaker: NA
Text: words like these: economic policy has worked

Speaker: NA
Text: and is working; the faith of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people exhibited in the Government at the

Speaker: NA
Text: election is now being repaid as the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth. A

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable rate of growth was what we were

Speaker: NA
Text: promised in August 1990. What was deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered? Negative growth: minus 0.9 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP. We were also promised that inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: would fall. Inflation did fall-not for the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons predicted in the 1990 Budget, but for

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons entirely unanticipated. We were told

Speaker: NA
Text: that the current account deficit would fall. It

Speaker: NA
Text: came down, it is true, from $22 billion to

Speaker: NA
Text: about $15 billion. A falling current account

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit: a great improvement; we only lost $15

Speaker: NA
Text: billion on the current account in that year. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were also told in August of 1990 that employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would pick up. Unemployment rates

Speaker: NA
Text: went from 6.9 per cent to 9.4 per cent. Or

Speaker: NA
Text: take this promise in the August 1990 Budget:

Speaker: NA
Text: a surplus of $8 billion. That is what we were

Speaker: NA
Text: promised in the August 1990 Budget. It came

Speaker: NA
Text: in at $1.9 billion. A surplus of $8 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: turned into $1.9 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make a point here. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has brought in laws insisting on

Speaker: NA
Text: strict standards in prospectuses. When people

Speaker: NA
Text: raise money out in the financial markets they

Speaker: NA
Text: have to make accurate financial projections

Speaker: NA
Text: about profitability, and if they do not they are

Speaker: NA
Text: held liable-not just the company directors

Speaker: NA
Text: but the accountants and everybody else. If a

Speaker: NA
Text: prospectus were put out in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: forecasting an $8 billion surplus and it came

Speaker: NA
Text: in with $1.9 billion one year later, somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: would probably go to gaol because he had put

Speaker: NA
Text: out a fraudulent prospectus. There is no other

Speaker: NA
Text: word for it: the Budget of 1990 was a fraudu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent prospectus. All of the promises that were

Speaker: NA
Text: made were dashed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had a schoolteacher who used to say to us

Speaker: NA
Text: if we were not doing well that we should put

Speaker: NA
Text: our sights high and aim for an F. Mr Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been much better to have aimed

Speaker: NA
Text: for a G in his 1990 Budget. Why? Because

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government failed absolutely to foresee

Speaker: NA
Text: the recession. What was the cause of that

Speaker: NA
Text: recession? This Government wound up

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates to dampen demand, as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of excesses in monetary policy in 1988-89,

Speaker: NA
Text: which meant that by January 1990 prime bank

Speaker: NA
Text: rates were above 20 per cent. They did not

Speaker: NA
Text: dampen demand-they washed away supply;

Speaker: NA
Text: they cleaned out small business. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: 52 per cent increase in personal bankruptcies

Speaker: NA
Text: in June 1991. Over two years there were

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 bankruptcies, not counting company

Speaker: NA
Text: liquidations or voluntary closures that did not

Speaker: NA
Text: end in liquidations. In unemployment they

Speaker: NA
Text: washed away 200,000 jobs between June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990 and June 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not need a royal commission into

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy to inquire into who was respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for this, because the prime felons have

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves confessed it. The then Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'This is the recession we had to have;

Speaker: NA
Text: we had to have it; we had to wash away those

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000 jobs, we had to wash away those

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 people now bankrupt, we had to wash

Speaker: NA
Text: away all of those companies'. Even today in

Speaker: NA
Text: Question Time the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) said, 'We recessed the economy'. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not need to have an inquiry into who was

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible. They have put their hands up:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'We did it-we were promising to you in

Speaker: NA
Text: AugusU990 that all was going to be hunky-

Speaker: NA
Text: dory; we were promising you sustained

Speaker: NA
Text: growth but the prospectus just seemed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: quite inaccurate and we brought on a reces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion instead'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the question: how valuable are these

Speaker: NA
Text: macro-economic projections when they can

Speaker: NA
Text: tum out so wrong, and indeed tum out so

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong as a result of an act of deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: Government policy? Let me make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that I take no glee from this. This rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, this rate of youth unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment where around 25 per cent of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in their teenage years are looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, is a tragedy for Australia. The economic

Speaker: NA
Text: prognostications of Treasurer Keating in his

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1990 Budget should be treated with

Speaker: NA
Text: all the seriousness of the prognostications of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nostradamus. In fact, he ought to be called

Speaker: NA
Text: Nostradamus Keating because the projections

Speaker: NA
Text: that he gave in that Budget were purely

Speaker: NA
Text: speculative, as it turned out.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a way, this illustrates one of the dangers

Speaker: NA
Text: of Canberra. I think Government members

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout that year were looking at prosper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous Canberra; they were driving around in

Speaker: NA
Text: their Commonwealth cars oblivious to what

Speaker: NA
Text: was happening in real Australia. Anyone who

Speaker: NA
Text: was living in real Australia saw what the

Speaker: NA
Text: recession was doing, saw what the interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates were doing to jobs, employment, shop

Speaker: NA
Text: closures and farms, but the people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: closeted in Canberra bringing on this reces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, which they supposed was in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: interest, were completely oblivious to the

Speaker: NA
Text: early warning signs.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is absolutely clear that out of a failure

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government came and tried to bury its

Speaker: NA
Text: own Budget. I come not to praise this Budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: I come to bury it, because if one looks at this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget one will see no coherent plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase business investment, no coherent plan

Speaker: NA
Text: to make manufacturing more productive, no

Speaker: NA
Text: coherent plan to create jobs, no coherent plan

Speaker: NA
Text: to stop farm closures and no coherent plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop bankruptcies. One cannot say, 'This is

Speaker: NA
Text: where we will attract business investment, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is where we will create jobs, this is how we

Speaker: NA
Text: will make manufacturing more productive or

Speaker: NA
Text: this is how we will cut down a raft of regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that hold back business in this country'.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no plan, there is nothing in there. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a defeatist and dispiriting document which

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia will treat with utter

Speaker: NA
Text: despair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the last speaker, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), got up and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'We will do this by fast tracking propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sals and developments', was there any state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment about that in this Budget? Was there

Speaker: NA
Text: any plan as to how that was to be done?

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the last speaker said, 'We will

Speaker: NA
Text: create a climate for business investment', was

Speaker: NA
Text: there any plan, anything significant, anything

Speaker: NA
Text: hard or anything concrete in this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget in that respect? This is an attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: which says that we can bring in a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: which says nothing, and so hedge it around

Speaker: NA
Text: with all these fine promises that we can try to

Speaker: NA
Text: put some kind of gloss on our completely

Speaker: NA
Text: defeatist approach to public policy in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, some kind of gloss of policy making

Speaker: NA
Text: through press statements that we might do this

Speaker: NA
Text: or that, this faction might do this, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTU might do this. There is no coherent

Speaker: NA
Text: policy or no coherent work in this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a sad Budget for Australia; it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: dispiriting Budget for Australia. It is a vacu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous document which has no plan, and it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: document which holds out no future and no

Speaker: NA
Text: hope for all those who have suffered under

Speaker: NA
Text: the maladministration of this Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 12 months.

Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Text: Fraser) (9.32 p.m.)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a pity that 'Mark Antony' on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: can express such concern about the unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed but that his leader demonstrates none

Speaker: NA
Text: of the compassion that he claims to show. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to use the opportunity in the debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Appropriation Bill (No.1) to speak about

Speaker: NA
Text: one institution in the Treasury portfolio, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission, and about its most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent report on the availability of capital.

Speaker: NA
Text: I confess to this Parliament that for perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time I feel sorry for the New Right

Speaker: NA
Text: ideologues in the Industry Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Imagine their dilemma at being asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate the availability of capital. Asked

Speaker: NA
Text: to investigate perhaps the most deregulated

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in this country, what would be left

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to say? Would they break their

Speaker: NA
Text: tradition of making basically the same recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations no matter what the inquiry or

Speaker: NA
Text: would they admit defeat and recommend the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission's dissolution? Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: they took the first option and are attempting

Speaker: NA
Text: to scrounge around for the last few scraps of

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulation which could still be left on the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial plate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Industry Commission believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia spends too much on private housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would like to impose more taxes on the

Speaker: NA
Text: family home to encourage us all to live in

Speaker: NA
Text: rented accommodation. Perhaps the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion would like to endorse that recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. What a disaster. One of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest achievements is its high level of

Speaker: NA
Text: home ownership. We should be encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: more people to own their own homes, not

Speaker: NA
Text: less.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Started by the Menzies

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Text: I am delighted to have

Speaker: NA
Text: that support, and I hope the Opposition will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue it. This is a good example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission's New Right recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations being in conflict with its own evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence. The only country mentioned in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission's report which has a significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: lower proportion of its investment in housing

Speaker: NA
Text: is Turkey. This is an important point. It shows

Speaker: NA
Text: where the New Right agenda, the agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: espoused by the Opposition's new and arro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gant leadership, will lead Australia. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: lead Australia into impoverishment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Industry Commission wants to let into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia any foreign bank that wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: come. As the Bank of Credit and Commerce

Speaker: NA
Text: International scandal showed, even quite large

Speaker: NA
Text: banks can be very shonky. The Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission would like to increase Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: savings by privatising pensions, me'dical care

Speaker: NA
Text: and education. It feels that removing

Speaker: NA
Text: government support for these essential ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices would force Australians to save more to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet these expenses. This is wonderful New

Speaker: NA
Text: Right economics, but would be disastrous for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Where would the clever country be

Speaker: NA
Text: without government provided education? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission seems determined to

Speaker: NA
Text: tum Australia into an impoverished Third

Speaker: NA
Text: World nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commission wants to privatise the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Development Corporation. According

Speaker: NA
Text: to it, the partial privatisations and comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive corporatisations that these important

Speaker: NA
Text: government agencies have suffered is not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. It is not enough that this has severely

Speaker: NA
Text: damaged their role in promoting the public

Speaker: NA
Text: good in an industry characterised by oligopoly

Speaker: NA
Text: and other major market failures. The Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission wants to nail them and any

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the public interest into the coffm

Speaker: NA
Text: of privatisation. Now they must not just act

Speaker: NA
Text: like private sector companies; they must be

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector companies with the inevitable

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of the public interest parts of their activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties.

Speaker: NA
Text: These New Right scorched earth policies

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave Australia with the public infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of a Third World country. But the private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector cannot flourish without a first rate

Speaker: NA
Text: public infrastructure. An uncompetitive

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector will not provide benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Competition does not just fall from

Speaker: NA
Text: the sky; it depends crucially on the framework

Speaker: NA
Text: and rules set by government which are neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to offset market failure. Remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly set framework and monopoly takes

Speaker: NA
Text: ovet:. Over the 1980s the finance industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: shown the folly of relying on self-regulation.

Speaker: NA
Text: With deregulation the Government gave

Speaker: NA
Text: practically all the responsibility for allocating

Speaker: NA
Text: credit to the private sector. What did it do

Speaker: NA
Text: with this responsibility? It went on an irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible dash for short term profits which

Speaker: NA
Text: damaged large parts of the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy. Asset prices boomed in an inflationary

Speaker: NA
Text: delusion and then crashed. Credit was mind-

Speaker: NA
Text: lessly poured into share takeovers, land

Speaker: NA
Text: speculation, empty office blocks and empty

Speaker: NA
Text: resolts. At the same time manufacturing and

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure on which our real wealth de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pends were starved of funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the Commission can say is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: private financial institutions took longer to

Speaker: NA
Text: learn the new deregulated game than expect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. What rubbish. The private financial

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions understood the game and they

Speaker: NA
Text: played it the way they wanted to, for short

Speaker: NA
Text: term profits and market share. They are little

Speaker: NA
Text: different now. The short term profits are in

Speaker: NA
Text: lending for housing and a select group of blue

Speaker: NA
Text: chip companies. Once again it is the essential

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of manufacturing and infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: that is ignored. The Commission is basically

Speaker: NA
Text: mute on how to raise our investment in these

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. \

Speaker: NA
Text: As an example of the Commission's report,

Speaker: NA
Text: it acknowledges the important role equity

Speaker: NA
Text: investment by Japanese and German banks

Speaker: NA
Text: plays in their role as long term financiers of

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry. By taking equity the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks have a stake in the future of a

Speaker: NA
Text: company, which means the banks will work

Speaker: NA
Text: very hard to make the company a success,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than selling it up as soon as it finds

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty in paying interest. So where is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission recommendation to remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank regulations over equity invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment? Nowhere to be seen. That is very

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistent.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of Australia's major economic prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems is: how do we get investment in small

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing and service businesses, invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to employ our people and produce more

Speaker: NA
Text: goods, goods we need to reduce inflationary

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure and expand exports? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission's report is a pathetic whitewash

Speaker: NA
Text: of the finance industry's continuing failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet this challenge.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commission recognises that 'smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: listed companies traditionally have better

Speaker: NA
Text: performance over the long term' but that the

Speaker: NA
Text: large financial institutional investors stick to

Speaker: NA
Text: the top 50 companies. It recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: financial institutions specialising in venture

Speaker: NA
Text: capital were basically non-existent before the

Speaker: NA
Text: early 1980s and are still inadequate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: OBCD recommends that venture capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investors should provide at least one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of market capitalisation. In Australia they

Speaker: NA
Text: only amount to 0.1 per cent, starving new,

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative businesses of funds. Yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission is content with starvation rations

Speaker: NA
Text: for the businesses which we need to build a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong manufacturing industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of recommending ways to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in small manufacturing companies,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission recommends destroying two

Speaker: NA
Text: of their rare sources of funds. Privatising the

Speaker: NA
Text: AIDC and the Commonwealth Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank will tum them into short term risk

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse institutions just like the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial sector. What the Commission should

Speaker: NA
Text: be recommending is that these agencies be

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened, not destroyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: , The AIDC and the Commonwealth Devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment Bank should have their activities

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded to include more management

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. They should playa leading role in

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing the paperwork for start-up and small

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to approach commercial lenders.

Speaker: NA
Text: They should be directly involved in financing

Speaker: NA
Text: and managerial assistance to new firms in

Speaker: NA
Text: depressed regions, particularly where tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions are closing existing industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government needs to support this with direct

Speaker: NA
Text: funds and with loan guarantees.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Industry Commission's Panglossian

Speaker: NA
Text: view of a rosy future if we just let the market

Speaker: NA
Text: rip is in stark contrast with the failures that

Speaker: NA
Text: market forces have produced in the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. The Industry Commission has recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised some of the past mistakes in the private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, but it cannot bring itself to open its

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes to market failures in the present. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission has failed to recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications of the oligopolistic nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: finance industry. Competition in this industry

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be taken for granted. It may well not

Speaker: NA
Text: be appropriate to return to the Reserve Bank's

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory era. But it is appropriate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial industry be required to justify its

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulated freedoms in a public forum. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin inquiry has been performing this

Speaker: NA
Text: function admirably. But once that inquiry is

Speaker: NA
Text: finished there will be a continuing need to

Speaker: NA
Text: prove to the public that the financial institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions deserve their self-regulation. That need

Speaker: NA
Text: can be efficiently met by placing the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: sector more directly under public surveillance

Speaker: NA
Text: by either the Reserve Bank or the Prices

Speaker: NA
Text: Surveillance Authority. I have called for this

Speaker: NA
Text: surveillance in an earlier speech here, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission report only reinforces

Speaker: NA
Text: my original concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has been successful in

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulating business investment, expanding

Speaker: NA
Text: employment-even with the present prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems-and reducing inflation. A large part of

Speaker: NA
Text: this is due to the many innovations and

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements that have been made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of finance and managerial assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to innovative new firms. The AIDC, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Development Bank, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Management and Investment Companies

Speaker: NA
Text: Licensing Board and the National Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Extension Service are just a few examples. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a Government, we must continue with an

Speaker: NA
Text: imaginative and targeted approach to building

Speaker: NA
Text: new businesses in Australia. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Text: Deakin) (9.41 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No.1) in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to proposed expenditure for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: net, the Department of Finance, the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Treasury and the Advance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance, I wish to raise addition-

Speaker: NA
Text: al concerns in respect of the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Taxation Office. Expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: on the ATO is, of course, essentially directed

Speaker: NA
Text: at enabling it to collect company and personal

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax for the Commonwealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and, in so doing, protecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity of that collection process.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my grievance debate speeches of 7

Speaker: NA
Text: March and 5 September of this year, I raised

Speaker: NA
Text: serious questions as to the effectiveness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue collection process and also queried

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of three advisory bodies to the ATO.

Speaker: NA
Text: I especially questioned the part played on

Speaker: NA
Text: those advisory bodies-that is, the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner of Taxation's advisory panel, the

Speaker: NA
Text: national tax liaison group and the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax subcommittee-by Mr Mark Leibler

Speaker: NA
Text: who, as I pointed out on 5 September, is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known as senior partner in the Melbourne city

Speaker: NA
Text: law firm of Arnold Bloch Leibler, and is a

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation lawyer of long standing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then Mr Leibler has responded

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Sydney Sun-Herald, which report-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed my last speech on this matter in consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able detail on 8 September. Mr Leibler's

Speaker: NA
Text: response is marked by emotive rhetoric rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than factual rebuttal and, if anything, gives

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to yet further doubts about his extraordi- problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: nary position as the only non-ATO member

Speaker: NA
Text: on three advisory bodies to the ATO.

Speaker: NA
Text: In his response Mr Leibler is dismissive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the influence of these advisory bodies and

Speaker: NA
Text: states that they are no different in nature

Speaker: NA
Text: from, say, the Companies and Securities

Speaker: NA
Text: Advisory Committee. For Mr Leibler's edifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, I would point out that the basis and

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions of appointment of all of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies and securities advisory bodies, plus

Speaker: NA
Text: their authority and responsibility, are clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: enshrined in parts 9 to 14 of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities Commission Act 1989. In marked

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast, neither the Income Tax Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1936 nor the Taxation Administration Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953 gives any specific legislative power for

Speaker: NA
Text: the advisory bodies to the ATO. This there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore pins appointments and even mere exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of the advisory bodies to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner's general administrative discre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion without any clear legislative limit on

Speaker: NA
Text: their power or influence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leibler further argues that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict of interest for him as a taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyer in being on these bodies. Surely he

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be serious, given his role through the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s and back into the 1970s as an adviser

Speaker: NA
Text: on major tax avoidance schemes, which is so

Speaker: NA
Text: well documented in his own words in his own

Speaker: NA
Text: numerous articles and pronouncements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minutes of the national tax liaison

Speaker: NA
Text: group meeting of 23 November 1988, as

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded in Taxation in Australia of February

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989, illustrate succinctly the dilemma of Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler's dual role. Item 14 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: New tax scam, media release.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leibler referred to media release No. 88/35 of

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 August 1988. He regarded the language used in

Speaker: NA
Text: the release as offensive particularly as it was open

Speaker: NA
Text: under the law to distribute income to beneficiaries

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way the Commissioner was trying to outlaw.

Speaker: NA
Text: He and Mr Buchanan suggested that if there was

Speaker: NA
Text: a problem then it should be solved by a change in

Speaker: NA
Text: law, not by administrative scare tactics.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Boucher noted the points raised regarding the

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation and language used in the release.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, he said that the message was directed at

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme practitioners not tax practitioners and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent that the release was threatening it was

Speaker: NA
Text: effective in countering the avoidance problem. He

Speaker: NA
Text: defended the use of administrative action that was

Speaker: NA
Text: available to him as a practical solution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, this dilemma over conflict of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest appears obvious to all except Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler. Referring specifically to Mr Leibler,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Canberra Times of 31 October 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: reported:

Speaker: NA
Text: A leading tax lawyer and adviser to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation Office has defended statements he made

Speaker: NA
Text: in a Melbourne Age interview last month that he

Speaker: NA
Text: had once had 'no qualms' about advising clients on

Speaker: NA
Text: tax-avoidance schemes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later in his response Mr Leibler does not

Speaker: NA
Text: deny that representations made by him in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 to a senior level of the ATO led to the

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal of 700 standard letters sent out by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Melbourne btanch of the ATO to trustees

Speaker: NA
Text: of schemes taking advantage of withholding

Speaker: NA
Text: tax arrangements. Frankly, I find his excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: that he wanted this matter dealt with in a less

Speaker: NA
Text: threatening manner somewhat thin, particular-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly given the Martin committee's subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: severe criticism of ATO procrastination in

Speaker: NA
Text: tackling withholding tax abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, I am astounded by Mr Leibler's

Speaker: NA
Text: claim in his response that he did not know

Speaker: NA
Text: that several companies of which he had been

Speaker: NA
Text: a director or secretary were named in the

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCabe-Lafranchi report on the bottom of the

Speaker: NA
Text: harbour tax avoidance schemes, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled in the Parliament of Victoria on 27

Speaker: NA
Text: May 1982. The report received enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: publicity at the time and was, in fact, the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject of a special Age supplement, pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished, I might add, on 7 June 1982, not 5

Speaker: NA
Text: June as I said in my grievance debate speech

Speaker: NA
Text: of 5 September last.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later in his response Mr Leibler failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily explain why in 1985 the ATO

Speaker: NA
Text: granted access to 90 per cent of procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: manuals, guides and other documents sought

Speaker: NA
Text: under an FOI request by Arnold Bloch Leibler

Speaker: NA
Text: which a rather disturbed Administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeals Tribunal found on 10 December 1985

Speaker: NA
Text: to be exempt documents the release of which

Speaker: NA
Text: would jeopardise the effectiveness of ATO

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures.

Speaker: NA
Text: In his response, Mr Leibler also does not

Speaker: NA
Text: deny the essential facts of my assertions on 5

Speaker: NA
Text: September that he did attack ATO operational

Speaker: NA
Text: staff in the Age of 26 September 1990; that he

Speaker: NA
Text: did accuse the Martin committee of conduct-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a witch hunt yet had been advising two of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 15 companies identified by the Martin

Speaker: NA
Text: committee as major users of tax havens; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as chairman of companies Numinous Nos. 3,

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 and 5, did write to shareholders concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax arrangements while a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of the capital gains tax subcommittee

Speaker: NA
Text: advising the ATO. Predictably, however, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler disputes that these instances gave rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to any conflict of interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Leibler's attack on ATO staff caused Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul Tregillis, Tax Office Branch Secretary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Sector Union, to write to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation Commissioner questioning the

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of the national tax liaison group

Speaker: NA
Text: of 'someone who has both attacked the staff

Speaker: NA
Text: of that organisation and actively assisted those

Speaker: NA
Text: working against the principal objective of that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation'. It is important to note as well

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr John Thorburn, the crack ATO

Speaker: NA
Text: auditor in Melbourne who was moved not

Speaker: NA
Text: long after Mr Leibler's attack, was at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: actually working on tax avoidance schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: involving interest withholding tax arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In his various forays into the media, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler is prone on occasions to imply that he

Speaker: NA
Text: is speaking on behalf of the Law Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. One significant event at least

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates that the Law Council views Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler's erratic expeditions in a rather differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent light. In an article in the Melbourne Sun

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1 May 1989 and a radio broadcast on the

Speaker: NA
Text: same day, Mr Leibler, ostensibly speaking on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Law Council, slammed into Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Barbara Smith of the Phillip Institute, of

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology for raising allegations about a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular form of withholding tax abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: This involved the use of certain countries

Speaker: NA
Text: with which Australia does not have a recipro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal tax treaty, though this was partly misre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported in the article as involving certain

Speaker: NA
Text: ethnic groups. Subsequently, the Secretary-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: incisively dissociated the Council from Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leibler's aggressive remarks in a letter of 12

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1990 to Minter Ellison, Mrs Smith's

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitors. The letter said, inter alia:

Speaker: NA
Text: The remarks of Mr Leibler were not sanctioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Council. Neither the Council nor executive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Law Council has given any consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, the Committee should be made

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that, for her intrepid and outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: work on withholding tax abuse, Mrs Smith is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be awarded a Master of Business from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Phillip Institute of Technology, the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: her work having been independently assessed

Speaker: NA
Text: by one examiner from the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney and another from Monash University.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the case for an early parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary inquiry into the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATO is further apparent from what I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said today. To that end, I seek leave to table

Speaker: NA
Text: certain of the various documents and articles

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have referred to throughout this speech,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have already taken the liberty of

Speaker: NA
Text: showing the Minister for Defence Science and

Speaker: NA
Text: Personnel ( Mr Bilney), who is at the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (9.51 p.m.)

Speaker: NA
Text: -I really know nothing of the matters to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honourable member for Deakin ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Aldred) has just referred. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that there are problems in a tax sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to take up what I see as an extraordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: narily difficult situation that is developing as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of the protracted drought around

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and northern New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: As recently as Question Time today, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was bottoming out of its economic

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn and that the recovery was not far

Speaker: NA
Text: away. That statement has been echoed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Kerin). It seems that this

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude has been picked up more optimistical-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly than realistically by a range of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the business community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think there needs to be some understand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that in rural Australia conditions and

Speaker: NA
Text: profitability are probably as tough today as

Speaker: NA
Text: they have ever been. There has been since

Speaker: NA
Text: time immemorial in this country a cycle of

Speaker: NA
Text: droughts. Yet, in much of Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly northern New South Wales the

Speaker: NA
Text: season this year is as bad as many can recall

Speaker: NA
Text: since the recording of weather statistics. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the trees are dying in the llectorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Wide Bay, which is represented by you,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Chairman. This is disastrous for

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture. People really cannot comprehend

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospects if there is no rain within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next month or six weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own part of the world, the dust that

Speaker: NA
Text: we see in the sky of an evening is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: product of the eruptions of Mount Pinatubo

Speaker: NA
Text: which plague the Philippines. Essentially it is

Speaker: NA
Text: dust that has been blown into the atmosphere

Speaker: NA
Text: as result of the scalded earth from the drought

Speaker: NA
Text: that is extending across so much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: northern part of this continent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it is not just the drought. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is also the problem of markets. The people of

Speaker: NA
Text: rural Australia have suffered extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties because of the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: world markets have contracted. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government claims that its efforts within

Speaker: NA
Text: GATT and the Cairns Group have been as

Speaker: NA
Text: forceful and as effective as they might have

Speaker: NA
Text: been.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bilney-Rightly so.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: But the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to understand that it has not pursued

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's cause as actively as it might have

Speaker: NA
Text: in some markets around the world. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the response of the Minister at

Speaker: NA
Text: the table because he would know, or should

Speaker: NA
Text: know, that in the Gulf states we have let the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian live sheep trade deteriorate to a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater extent than it should have.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bilney-Not so.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: I am afraid that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is wrong. I do not want to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter but I know that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: pretends that much has been done. Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation at a ministerial level which would have

Speaker: NA
Text: ensured that our voice was heard was not

Speaker: NA
Text: made early enough or adequately enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite were prepared to criticise,

Speaker: NA
Text: long before the Gulf war, the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: Saudi Arabia. No effort was made to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: a personal relationship with senior Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: in that Government. In my view, the unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate veterinary bar on the entry of live sheep

Speaker: NA
Text: has been as much a product of misunderstand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at a political level as it has at a veterinary

Speaker: NA
Text: level.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to pursue that, other than to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that this Government has not picked up a

Speaker: NA
Text: drought strategy. There is a real problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to international markets. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: just a matter of GATT-it is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: particular bilateral negotiations in a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to put to the Committee that the

Speaker: NA
Text: third dimension of the decline in small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness and the rural sector is distinctly a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of changes that have been introduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government without regard to the long

Speaker: NA
Text: term consequences. I am not suggesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: we on this side of the Committee in some

Speaker: NA
Text: way want to move into a new regulatory

Speaker: NA
Text: mode. But I want to suggest that disastrous

Speaker: NA
Text: problems flow from the range of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: which my former colleague, the former

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gwydir, the Hon. Ralph Hunt,

Speaker: NA
Text: identified about four years ago as costing

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers about $1 billion a year. To my mind,

Speaker: NA
Text: today those changes probably amount to $2

Speaker: NA
Text: billion a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want briefly to identify those problems,

Speaker: NA
Text: look at them and say to the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not just the cycle of seasons nor the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty of markets which plagues the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: sector today. There is a combination of

Speaker: NA
Text: macroand micro-economic policy. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a problem of taxation. There is a problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: the withdrawal of and change in rural support.

Speaker: NA
Text: These factors have exacerbated the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: those in the rural sector to the point where I

Speaker: NA
Text: am apprehensive about the declining value of

Speaker: NA
Text: land and the declining security of assets

Speaker: NA
Text: before the banks. I am concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on rural communities, the professions

Speaker: NA
Text: and the services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned about a situation which, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would suggest to the Prime Minister, is likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to lead not only to a continuation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's economic downturn but to an

Speaker: NA
Text: exacerbation of that situation to the point

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is going to be more unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, where the vying force of the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: sector is going to be so restricted that many

Speaker: NA
Text: family farmers are going to be forced off the

Speaker: NA
Text: land and there is going to be nobody to take

Speaker: NA
Text: over.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is all very well saying that agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: does not matter. I have heard Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers say that today the rural sector

Speaker: NA
Text: exports make up no more than 26 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the total. This is about half of what it was

Speaker: NA
Text: so many years ago. It is no use saying either

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of those working in agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture has declined. Of course it has.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we need to understand the potential for

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery in the rural sector-the potential for

Speaker: NA
Text: being able to increase our export earnings, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just in the value-added sector but in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: diversification into new industry such as

Speaker: NA
Text: aquiculture and the extent to which other

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural industries and commodity-related

Speaker: NA
Text: industries can contribute to reduce Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: burden of overseas debt and improve our

Speaker: NA
Text: balance of payments. This is significant today,

Speaker: NA
Text: provided that those who are currently produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers are able to survive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Briefly, the range of areas where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government-induced intrusion on the produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive sector has affected profitability includes

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent to which Government is prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to listen to the vocal minority-the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalists. We have seen the absolute disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: that has resulted from the Wesley Vale deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. We have seen the procrastination over

Speaker: NA
Text: Coronation Hill. We have seen the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government has not been prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept the rational use of timber and forest

Speaker: NA
Text: resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether it be the north Queensland wet-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands or whether it be the north New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales forests, there needs to be a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: balance between conservation, environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: control and the use of the resources of those

Speaker: NA
Text: forests. We need to understand that the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of that over-reaction to the environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: voice is the loss of jobs, the loss of private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector investment and the contraction of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities within the towns that service

Speaker: NA
Text: those industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, too, it is with farming. Because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax averaging provisions, farmers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: had past good seasons can be faced with a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: liability in a year of extraordinary loss. In our

Speaker: NA
Text: banking system we have seen the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which many people have been called to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: penal rates above those ordinarily charged in

Speaker: NA
Text: an interest rate regime which internationally

Speaker: NA
Text: is non-competitive. These are loans which can

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer be properly serviced.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen the introduction by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party of a range of new taxes, from capital

Speaker: NA
Text: not gains tax through to the broadening of its

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale sales tax regime, through to the

Speaker: NA
Text: elimination of a range of tax concessions that

Speaker: NA
Text: used to apply for the productive industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen, too, in the elimination of

Speaker: NA
Text: particular concessions for deductions in

Speaker: NA
Text: agriCUlture, as in business, the extent to which

Speaker: NA
Text: investment, particularly new investment, is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer attractive. So we now have a run-down

Speaker: NA
Text: in agricultural machinery and in fertiliser use

Speaker: NA
Text: and an inability to maintain the productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: of our farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to speak with great sincerity to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and tell him that, unless he

Speaker: NA
Text: understands the extent to which the drought,

Speaker: NA
Text: market conditions and his Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: actions have affected the rural sector, the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: sector tomorrow is likely to be a pale shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: of itself. Our ability to service our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: debt, to contribute to export earnings and to

Speaker: NA
Text: utilise those large tracts of land predominantly

Speaker: NA
Text: suited to the commodities, whether they are

Speaker: NA
Text: minerals or agriculture, is likely to be such

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are going to be great wildernesses

Speaker: NA
Text: which are totally contrary to the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of this country. It is within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's control to act upon them. I

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly recommend that he does not see an

Speaker: NA
Text: end to our iinancial recession until those

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances are reversed.

Speaker: NA
Text: support the right honourable member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England ( Mr Sinclair) in his comments about

Speaker: NA
Text: the rural sector. In my time, I have not seen

Speaker: NA
Text: a rural crisis of the depth that the sector is in

Speaker: NA
Text: today. My father, who is still alive, said only

Speaker: NA
Text: last week that he had not seen a drought in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland of this severity since 1946 and

Speaker: NA
Text: that towns that the nation would know as

Speaker: NA
Text: garden cities, such as Toowoomba, are now

Speaker: NA
Text: dust cities. The general impact of that is yet

Speaker: NA
Text: to be seen on the Australian economy. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: quite alarmed at what is happening today,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially in Queensland, in the rural sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very pleased that the right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England raised the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to speak tonight on the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank float. I have spent

Speaker: NA
Text: some considerable time watching the

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation issue in Australia. I have spent

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of time promoting the method of

Speaker: NA
Text: privatisation, not the philosophy, because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the method that the taxpayers of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: get their benefit. As a consequence, it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important to see what happened. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank was the easy float. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was always going to be the dead shock

Speaker: NA
Text: winner for everybody-no troubles about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: To trace the history of it, we should remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber that the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke)

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about privatisation, when it was first

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennelong ( Mr Howard) many years ago, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the cheap philosophy-the throwing away of

Speaker: NA
Text: the family silver and all of those sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: things that went with it. As time went by and

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw the development of privatisation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe and in other countries, eventually we

Speaker: NA
Text: were dragged along the trail. In South

Speaker: NA
Text: America today, all of those rheumatic left

Speaker: NA
Text: governments of that fascinating continent are

Speaker: NA
Text: into privatisation; they are into balancing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget; they are into generally getting

Speaker: NA
Text: government out of the area of control and

Speaker: NA
Text: giving people a fair go.

Speaker: NA
Text: It took until this year to get the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank up and going in this nation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: came about only through the collapse of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian State Bank. If it was not for that, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have occurred. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: had to raise some money to payout its mates

Speaker: NA
Text: down in Victoria. Despite the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister now owns a house in Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: he still represents a Victorian seat. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of that, he had to have some

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to what the Premier of Victoria had to

Speaker: NA
Text: say about it, even if some of the Ministers do

Speaker: NA
Text: not like him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, eventually this float was put

Speaker: NA
Text: together against the background of ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: hatred that goes on within the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: When eventually it was decided to pass the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, we went only as far as 30 per cent, with

Speaker: NA
