Text: the right-according to the prospectus-of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, not the directors, to direct what

Speaker: NA
Text: the dividend is. That was a very interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: example of how the Government sees priva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tisation. So, the direct control is still there.

Speaker: NA
Text: This privatisation ground away; recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations came in. What were we going to do

Speaker: NA
Text: about it? Eventually we decided to strike a

Speaker: NA
Text: price at $5.60. But no, the institutions did not

Speaker: NA
Text: like that; it might not be too good. So we got

Speaker: NA
Text: the wobbles up. We caved in and dropped 20c

Speaker: NA
Text: to $5.40 and eventually spread it around the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. But not really: we gave it to the

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions. Small investors got 400 shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: Customers of the Commonwealth Bank got

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 shares. I have received innumerable

Speaker: NA
Text: letters from people who said that they applied

Speaker: NA
Text: for 5,000 or 1,000-whatever it was-and all

Speaker: NA
Text: they got was 400 if they were not a customer

Speaker: NA
Text: and 500 if they were. Four or five weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: later, they got their money back. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank did not do too badly in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the holding of that money during

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: To bring the Committee back to the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence between $5.60 and $5.40, that was worth

Speaker: NA
Text: $48m to the taxpayers of Australia. Shares

Speaker: NA
Text: were not placed with the small investors of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, because they got only 400 in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main. A lot of people were excluded:

Speaker: NA
Text: 120,OOO-odd people got into the issue, but a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot more could have participated if the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moters and the Government, in particular, had

Speaker: NA
Text: bothered to press the issue right to the core

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia. But they did not. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-ownership bent within the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: It did not want too many people in this. It just

Speaker: NA
Text: put out that 120,000 shareholders were far too

Speaker: NA
Text: many to service and it would cost the bank a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortune, and that was not on. The shares

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been made available to every

Speaker: NA
Text: individual who wanted them and the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: promoted.

Speaker: NA
Text: What happened when they hit the market?

Speaker: NA
Text: There was an odd sale at $6.90, but in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main they were $6.40. Not too many went

Speaker: NA
Text: through. Today they are $6.90, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good $1.50 up on what the issue price was.

Speaker: NA
Text: That great judgment of knocking it down

Speaker: NA
Text: from $5.60 to $5.40 cost the taxpayers just

Speaker: NA
Text: short of $50m. Yet we hear from these superb

Speaker: NA
Text: judges of the Labor Party so much about

Speaker: NA
Text: economic judgment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I express the hope that in the future some

Speaker: NA
Text: notice will be taken of the advisers that come

Speaker: NA
Text: into these things and understand market

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures, rather than their being given away.

Speaker: NA
Text: The prospectus, which took so much effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: put together, would not have been possible

Speaker: NA
Text: without the Government guarantees that went

Speaker: NA
Text: with it. Without the Government guarantees

Speaker: NA
Text: that went with the sale of the State Bank of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria, it would not have been possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: put that prospectus together under the new

Speaker: NA
Text: laws. So it is little wonder that the total all-up

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of floating the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: came out at just a touch over $40m and

Speaker: NA
Text: 120,000 shareholders, which is a huge cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: This makes one wonder at the prospectus

Speaker: NA
Text: rules of Australia today and their relevance

Speaker: NA
Text: because the ordinary citizen who is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: subscribe to 400 shares is not going to plough

Speaker: NA
Text: through the prospectus and turn up such

Speaker: NA
Text: weighty knowledge as can the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: can determine the dividend or the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank or the government of the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ordinary citizen really wants to know that

Speaker: NA
Text: that investment is reasonably put together and

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed by the directors of the company at

Speaker: NA
Text: that moment. If that is not the case, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest is irrelevant in relation to investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: that particular corporation. I hope that some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the lessons that come out of this will be

Speaker: NA
Text: learned in the future because a large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of government enterprises will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: privatised, largely in the semi-government and

Speaker: NA
Text: State sector. As a consequence of that, a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of work will need to be done in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing, capitalisation and market projection

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Commonwealth Bank has shown

Speaker: NA
Text: that, without proper marketing and proper

Speaker: NA
Text: concern for the realities, the taxpayers will

Speaker: NA
Text: miss out. A lot of the Australian shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: who might have wanted to be in the float

Speaker: NA
Text: were -xc1uded because of the poor marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: techniques that took place in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. In view of the time, I will comment

Speaker: NA
Text: later on this matter.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (10.11 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: Just want to make a few brief remarks about

Speaker: NA
Text: two aspects of the Treasury operations. I draw

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attention of the Treasurer ( Mr Kerin)

Speaker: NA
Text: the deplorable administrative arrangement for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Insurance and Superannuation Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and also the deplorable administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: processes of the Child Support Agency. Often

Speaker: NA
Text: this type of comment is left for the adjourn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment debate. But I think this is too serious to

Speaker: NA
Text: be put off to a later hour of the evening.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Insurance and Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Con,tmission has been required by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parhament to approve and make determina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions on roll-over provisions for retirees. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, many retirees or people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have moved from one job to another and who

Speaker: NA
Text: are dependent on their investments to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain proper records and part of their income

Speaker: NA
Text: have submitted to the Insurance and Superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation Commission their returns as early as

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1990. To date many of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people have not received a final determina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. They cannot submit their taxation re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turns. They are on a brief from the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation Office by word of mouth only-a

Speaker: NA
Text: press release from the Commissioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation-that they will not be penalised.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not good enough for tax administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion nor for an important organisation such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Insurance and Superannuation Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. The processes are complex and long-

Speaker: NA
Text: winded. With the requirement of self-determi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, neither any insurance company nor the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner is prepared to guarantee the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome of the determinations presented by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Insurance and Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. It falls to the taxpayers to make

Speaker: NA
Text: a submission that they do not understand, that

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot vouch for and for which there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been an extraordinary and lengthy delay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already we have reached the month of

Speaker: NA
Text: October and many taxpayers who should have

Speaker: NA
Text: completed their taxation returns by the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: August have not done so. Many of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: owed refunds. It is deplorable that the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Science and Technology ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Free), have not taken action.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Chairman of the Insurance and Super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation Commission needs a bomb under

Speaker: NA
Text: him. It is about time that he got something

Speaker: NA
Text: moving. Elderly people in my electorate have

Speaker: NA
Text: had to wait on the telephone for up to half an

Speaker: NA
Text: hour to get a simple inquiry answered at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney office. I have waited 20 minutes just

Speaker: NA
Text: to test the system. It is a common occurrence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it easy to phone Canberra, to the head

Speaker: NA
Text: office of this outfit, but not everyone can do

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I ask the Minister to take this on notice

Speaker: NA
Text: and to do something about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The administration of the Child Support

Speaker: NA
Text: Agency is just as deplorable. There are people

Speaker: NA
Text: who do not want to be gathered into the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy of the Child Support Agency but

Speaker: NA
Text: have to fight to prevent the bureaucrats from

Speaker: NA
Text: grabbing them and putting them into the

Speaker: NA
Text: system. There is often a perfectly proper and

Speaker: NA
Text: understandable relationship between a separat- Through

Speaker: NA
Text: ed husband and wife where regular payments

Speaker: NA
Text: are made by the husband, as required by the

Speaker: NA
Text: wife, yet the Child Support Agency wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: interfere with that process-and it is difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to escape that. On the other hand, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: wives or husbands who have gone without

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for months, yet the spouses have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been pursued. In one case, despite my repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation and constant phoning, the matter had

Speaker: NA
Text: been neglected for four months. The wife had

Speaker: NA
Text: no income and the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security made it extremely difficult for her to

Speaker: NA
Text: realise any return for herself and her two

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Child Support Agency has claimed that

Speaker: NA
Text: it has 40 per cent of satisfied clients. If I were

Speaker: NA
Text: running an organisation that had a 40 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfaction rate, I would be very worried

Speaker: NA
Text: about it because I would not think that I was

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfilling niy duties properly. I ask the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter at the table to take to the Treasurer the

Speaker: NA
Text: imperative need for his personal intervention

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that this matter is resolved. The Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Agency Act needs amendment and

Speaker: NA
Text: there needs to be greater rigour and greater

Speaker: NA
Text: expedition on the part of those people respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for its administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's Department

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $804,154,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: MrWEBSTER (Macquarie) (10.17 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the first opportunity that I have had to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate you, Mr Deputy Chairman, on

Speaker: NA
Text: your appointment as a deputy chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: committees.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to focus my comments tonight on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's Department's programs

Speaker: NA
Text: which appear at page 106 of Budget Paper

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 2 under the heading of Other Services-

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage counselling organisations and related

Speaker: NA
Text: grants. In particular, I would like to focus on

Speaker: NA
Text: family an4 marriage counselling services

Speaker: NA
Text: already funded, the need for additional fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and the way in which additional funding

Speaker: NA
Text: should be applied. The coalition's policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1990 entitled 'Family and Action Plan',

Speaker: NA
Text: released prior to the last election, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The family provides the most effective means for

Speaker: NA
Text: the care and development of children, and a source

Speaker: NA
Text: of personal happiness and social support.

Speaker: NA
Text: the family, the moral, spiritual, ethical and

Speaker: NA
Text: social values of a civilised society are passed from

Speaker: NA
Text: one generation to another, so that there is a shared

Speaker: NA
Text: system of values and attitudes that unites a

Speaker: NA
Text: community and enables its members to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: shared goals from a secure base.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each ye- at about this time I try to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Committee focuses on the programs

Speaker: NA
Text: and organisations that support this vital pillar

Speaker: NA
Text: of our society. Over successive years I have

Speaker: NA
Text: argued for increased budgetary allocations for

Speaker: NA
Text: family counselling organisations, marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: education organisations and family reconcili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation centres in order that the tragedy of

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage breakdown maybe minimised.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over these same years I have been encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to see a significant boost to these types

Speaker: NA
Text: of programs, and this year is no exception. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was pleased to receive a reply to a letter that

Speaker: NA
Text: I sent to the Minister for Justice and Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer Affairs, Senator Tate, prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. His letter detailed a reconsideration

Speaker: NA
Text: of and an increase in budgetary allocations for

Speaker: NA
Text: this financial year. I had lobbied hard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for these additional funds. This year

Speaker: NA
Text: we will see a total of $16.672m directed

Speaker: NA
Text: towards marriage counselling services-a

Speaker: NA
Text: record level for such funding. I therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the Attorney-General ( Mr Duffy)

Speaker: NA
Text: and his colleague, Senator Tate, for their

Speaker: NA
Text: provision in this regard. Nevertheless, this

Speaker: NA
Text: funding is still far below what I believe is

Speaker: NA
Text: truly necessary to have a positive impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage breakdowns in our country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today the family unit faces pressures that

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps have never been faced in years past.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to the insecurity that rapid chan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ges within society bring, we are faced with

Speaker: NA
Text: high unemployment levels; record bankrupt-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies, with 12,991 for the year ended June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991; record numbers of homeless, with

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates ranging from 40,000 to 100,000;

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1.5 million Australians living below the

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty line. This year, perhaps more than

Speaker: NA
Text: any year in the past, we need to be doing

Speaker: NA
Text: everything that we can to underpin the family

Speaker: NA
Text: unit.

Speaker: NA
Text: A very interesting longitudinal study on the

Speaker: NA
Text: effects of divorce on children was published

Speaker: NA
Text: in June this year by Cherlin, Furstenberg and

Speaker: NA
Text: others and it highlighted some significant

Speaker: NA
Text: facts. This study was undertaken using a large

Speaker: NA
Text: sample of children from two-parent families

Speaker: NA
Text: in Britain and the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the opening paragraph, the writers say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The research literature leaves no doubt that,

Speaker: NA
Text: average, children of divorced parents experience

Speaker: NA
Text: more emotional and behavioural problems and do

Speaker: NA
Text: less well in school than children who live with both

Speaker: NA
Text: biological parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The writers also conclude that just as much

Speaker: NA
Text: attention needs to be paid to the processes

Speaker: NA
Text: that occur in troubled intact families as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: trauma that children suffer after their parents

Speaker: NA
Text: separate. That is a very important point. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe this highlights the need for early

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention and, if at all possible, adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: counselling prior to marriage taking place. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is this area of marriage counselling that

Speaker: NA
Text: receives the least of all. Of a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: $16.672m allocated for marriage counselling

Speaker: NA
Text: services, only $500,700 is to be directed

Speaker: NA
Text: towards marriage education, but this

Speaker: NA
Text: $500,OOO-odd still represents an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: over 100 per cent since the 1989-90 allocation

Speaker: NA
Text: for this type of service. That is commendable,

Speaker: NA
Text: however small the amount still may be.

Speaker: NA
Text: The findings of the study that I have previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously cited are supported by comments made

Speaker: NA
Text: by Dr Don Edgar, the Director of the Institute

Speaker: NA
Text: of Family Studies, as recorded in the August

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989 edition of the journal Family Matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Edgar argues as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: More services for families should be aimed at

Speaker: NA
Text: prevention early on in the process of family

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties, rather than only being targeted at those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have gone so far down the track they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: real crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Edgar calls for a move from a top-down

Speaker: NA
Text: model of family services to a more sensitive

Speaker: NA
Text: model which focuses on family resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: advice when asked for, family information

Speaker: NA
Text: access, and family enhancement skills-all

Speaker: NA
Text: very important areas. He bases his call on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Institute's findings that many of those in need

Speaker: NA
Text: of help do not know where or how to find it

Speaker: NA
Text: or they stoically refuse to seek help from

Speaker: NA
Text: family support services. Dr Edgar further

Speaker: NA
Text: argues:

Speaker: NA
Text: If we cultivated a community value of using

Speaker: NA
Text: resources made accessible to all families of expect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing advice when a problem emerges rather than a

Speaker: NA
Text: rescue from disaster, a real partnership of family

Speaker: NA
Text: and fonnal support might emerge and a real

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening of family life might result. If policy

Speaker: NA
Text: makers really want the best for families, they

Speaker: NA
Text: should seek more research infonnation on actual

Speaker: NA
Text: on the family aspirations, the actual ways in which

Speaker: NA
Text: families of different types and at different stages of

Speaker: NA
Text: the family cycle manage to cope and function on

Speaker: NA
Text: the resources they have, and to support and prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: damage to the fabric of family life.

Speaker: NA
Text: I heartily endorse Dr Edgar's comments;

Speaker: NA
Text: however, I am very disappointed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government continues to overlook these

Speaker: NA
Text: prudent priorities. In every year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government fails to reassess its focus, thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands and thousands of marriages fall apart

Speaker: NA
Text: that otherwise might have been saved. It

Speaker: NA
Text: disturbs me that the Government can see its

Speaker: NA
Text: way clear to commit over the next five years

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $8oom to the better cities project,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet cannot see its way clear to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: essential research that would do far more for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community than some vague,

Speaker: NA
Text: ill-conceived and poorly timed public rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions exercise.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the Government should be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing more to support and promote preventive

Speaker: NA
Text: programs in marriage and family education

Speaker: NA
Text: and counselling. The appropriations for these

Speaker: NA
Text: programs before us today are inadequate,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially given the current pressures of

Speaker: NA
Text: family life, with dad out of work, mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: payments that cannot possibly be met and no

Speaker: NA
Text: end in sight. There is no use denying that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are major problems here. We are spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in excess of $2 billion to prop up families

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of marriage breakdown; yet we are

Speaker: NA
Text: spending a mere $16m, almost $17m, in

Speaker: NA
Text: family counselling and a mere $500,000, or

Speaker: NA
Text: a little over, in marriage education programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the greatest needs of our society

Speaker: NA
Text: today-and this is coming out more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more, particularly in the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into the Family Law Act-and some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that all the people who come before that

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee in the public hearings are in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of, is marriage education and much

Speaker: NA
Text: more of it. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Text: Fisher) (10.27 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome this opportunity to speak to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriation Bill (No.1) and to the appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priation for the Attorney-General's Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, as it follows very quickly on the heels

Speaker: NA
Text: of a function I held last week with the Attor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney-General ( Mr Duffy) and the State Attor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney-General in Queensland, Mr Wells, with

Speaker: NA
Text: a cross-section of the legal fraternity in

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane. It was a very successful function

Speaker: NA
Text: and it provided a very good opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: practitioners in Brisbane to speak to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Attorney and outline some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the difficulties which the profession is experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: encing in Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The profession in Queensland, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in Brisbane, has in recent times undergone a

Speaker: NA
Text: most extraordinary attack on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Newspapers Ltd, the publishers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Courier-Mail and the Sunday Mail. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: a period of a bit over a month, the Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Mail in particular has run a series of articles

Speaker: NA
Text: which basically allege that the legal profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion in Queensland is completely composed

Speaker: NA
Text: of solicitors whose only aim in life is to

Speaker: NA
Text: enrich themselves at the expense of their

Speaker: NA
Text: clients. There also is a series of allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: that solicitors are engaged in dishonest prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice and that any complaint made about

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitors to the Queensland Law Society is

Speaker: NA
Text: summarily dismissed.

Speaker: NA
Text: While without doubt there are some prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems within the legal profession-and certain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly the cost of justice is of great concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament; indeed, a Senate inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: currently is being undertaken to look at this

Speaker: NA
Text: problem-I wish to set the record straight in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the work which the legal profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion provides. This is particularly relevant to

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the major Budget initiatives undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Attorney-General in the current Budg-

Speaker: NA
Text: et. That relates to a substantial increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funding to community legal

Speaker: NA
Text: centres. The funding has increased from

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.7m in the last financial year to $5.2m in

Speaker: NA
Text: being under- the current Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a press release about this increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: funding, the Minister for Justice and Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer Affairs (Senator Tate) said, among

Speaker: NA
Text: other things:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . a recent study had found that community legal

Speaker: NA
Text: centres were an invaluable resource for Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: with volunteer lawyers providing an estimated $2

Speaker: NA
Text: million worth of free legal aid each year over and

Speaker: NA
Text: above the various government payments. The

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated staff at CLCs around Australia, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with the volunteer lawyers, provide an accessible

Speaker: NA
Text: and friendly service to people in need.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a subject which I feel very strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration interrupted.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: M:r Truss)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I shall report

Speaker: NA
Text: progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. G.G.D.

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholes)-Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I

Speaker: NA
Text: propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Simmons-I require that the question

Speaker: NA
Text: be put forthwith without debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the negative.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1991-92

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed.

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Text: Fisher) (10.31 p.m.)-As

Speaker: NA
Text: I was saying, the community legal cen-es

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a very valuable role. A centre whi-h

Speaker: NA
Text: operates in my electorate, the Petne

Speaker: NA
Text: community legal service-of which I was.a

Speaker: NA
Text: foundation member in the early 1980s-1s

Speaker: NA
Text: staffed by volunteer local practitioners, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: gives a free legal service to many hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: local residents each year. Despite the very

Speaker: NA
Text: good work which is provided by the legal

Speaker: NA
Text: profession in services such as this, the attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Courier-Mail really have largely

Speaker: NA
Text: been unanswered. Unfortunately, this has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been through lack of action on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Law Society. Indeed, the Presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent of the Society has made repeated at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempts to have this side of the profession

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by the Sunday Mail and the Courier-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mail. But, despite undertakings by the editor

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Sunday Mail, Mr Jack Lunn, no such

Speaker: NA
Text: right of reply has been given to the profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some 3,500 solicitors practising

Speaker: NA
Text: in Queensland. Of those, 1,900 are principals

Speaker: NA
Text: in their own firms and 1,600 are employed

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitors. The vast majority of these solicitors

Speaker: NA
Text: operate in small businesses. In fact, some

Speaker: NA
Text: two-thirds of that number are sole practition-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers; another one-quarter belong to firms with

Speaker: NA
Text: two to four partners. Indeed, in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: there are only 16 firms which have more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 partners. That indicates that the leglll

Speaker: NA
Text: practice, at least in the State of Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: is very much a small business. It is my

Speaker: NA
Text: experience, both from being a practitioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: also since being a member of parliament, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the vast majority of practitioners underta-e

Speaker: NA
Text: their work, their duties, to the utmost of therr

Speaker: NA
Text: abilities; that they try to serve as best they

Speaker: NA
Text: can the interests of their clients; and that, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole, their services are well regarded.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is estimated that about 750,000 transac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are undertaken by Queensland solicitors

Speaker: NA
Text: each year. Of that huge number, official

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints last year to the Queensland Law

Speaker: NA
Text: Society about the handling of matt-rs by

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitors numbered some 750-that 1S 750

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints out of some 750,000 individual

Speaker: NA
Text: matters handled by solicitors. Despite the very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong inference at least from those figures

Speaker: NA
Text: that the vast majority of people are happy

Speaker: NA
Text: with the work which their solicitor does for

Speaker: NA
Text: them, no such balance has been provi-ed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the attacks launched by the Sunday MOll and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Courier-Mail against the Queensland legal

Speaker: NA
Text: profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other argument put forward is that

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitors are grossly overpaid or that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: living high off the fat of the land. Undoubted-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly some do quite well out of the profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: But in the last financial year an average self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed practitioner within Queensland, as

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed by studies done by Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Meredith of the University'of New England,

Speaker: NA
Text: might expect a net income of about

Speaker: NA
Text: $67,000-which I note is slightly better than

Speaker: NA
Text: a backbencher of parliament. Nonetheless, I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not believe that is a particularly high

Speaker: NA
Text: return for the amount of work, the effort, the

Speaker: NA
Text: training and the expertise which goes into

Speaker: NA
Text: running a legal practice. Out of that $67,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: a sole practitioner is required to provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: his or her own sick leave, holiday pay and

Speaker: NA
Text: any contribution to superannuation.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, in total, I do not believe that on the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole the legal profession is overpaid at least

Speaker: NA
Text: in the State of Queensland. Undoubtedly there

Speaker: NA
Text: are some individuals who do very well in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, and it is quite right that there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: some focus on the cost of solicitors and also

Speaker: NA
Text: of barristers, of course, in terms of this

Speaker: NA
Text: overall debate on the cost of justice. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be a balanced debate-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-What about Chris Schacht?

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Text: The sort of absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric we see coming out of the Courier-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mail and the Sunday Mail does nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: towards providing that debate. I note that my

Speaker: NA
Text: friend the honourable member for Higgins

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Costello) draws my attention to the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of Senator Schacht and the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into the cost of justice. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of the work being done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate inquiry, particularly of its Chainnan,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cooney, with whom I have had

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions about these matters, and I know

Speaker: NA
Text: he views them in a very balanced and un-

Speaker: NA
Text: biased way. Maybe not all members of that

Speaker: NA
Text: committee share his view of these matters and

Speaker: NA
Text: are a little inclined to seek the sensational

Speaker: NA
Text: approach rather than actually seek the truth,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I would not be so unkind as to identify

Speaker: NA
Text: who that individual or individuals may be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless, on the whole I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should be commended for its

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives in the Attorney-General's Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, particularly the increase in funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: community legal centres. They do excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: work and the substantial increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: money which the Government has provided

Speaker: NA
Text: will go a long way towards reinforcing this

Speaker: NA
Text: very important provision of law services in

Speaker: NA
Text: this society. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins) (10.37 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Last November the Attorney-General ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Duffy) rushed through under guillotine one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most complex and voluminous packages

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislation this Parliament will ever deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with. The day was 14 November 1990. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill was the Corporations Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill, which introduced new corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: law into Australia. The Attorney allowed only

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 minutes for debate which, when broken

Speaker: NA
Text: down, allowed 12. seconds per page of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill for all those entitled to speak. The Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: had taken three full years to get to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. This House caught a glimpse of

Speaker: NA
Text: it for about 60 minutes. In the debate on that

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, I said that in years to come a plethora

Speaker: NA
Text: loopholes and drafting errors would come to

Speaker: NA
Text: light as a result of the absence of any real

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary scrutiny. In the 11 or so months

Speaker: NA
Text: since the legislation passed this House, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry to report that my fears have material-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised. The Attorney has already come back

Speaker: NA
Text: into this House with an amendment Bill to fix

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the original package, and he will

Speaker: NA
Text: need to come back again.

Speaker: NA
Text: The requirement that a nine-digit Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: company number be printed on all business

Speaker: NA
Text: letters, statements of account, invoices, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipts, orders for goods, official notices or

Speaker: NA
Text: publications is plainly ridiculous and the law

Speaker: NA
Text: in that respect will have to be changed. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, real estate agencies, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations and advertise hundreds perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of properties for sale on a Saturday,

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to put their name and Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: company number on each one of those adver-

Speaker: NA
Text: tisements, adding to the cost of advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: but providing no real public utility. Shops,

Speaker: NA
Text: which issue receipts to people who buy items,

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to issue a receipt with an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian company number on it. Even the

Speaker: NA
Text: local milk bar, if it were a corporation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: large supermarket chains which operate

Speaker: NA
Text: trading operations through different corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: entities would have to have separate cash

Speaker: NA
Text: registers with separate Australian company

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers on all of their receipts, whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: be for the purchase of vegetables 01' milk or

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever. Plainly, the current legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements which have been suspended in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation will have to be amended.

Speaker: NA
Text: Plainly also changes are required to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraising provisions in the corporations law.

Speaker: NA
Text: With their wide reach, the prospectus provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions potentially regulate secondary trading of

Speaker: NA
Text: private placements and screen trading and

Speaker: NA
Text: potentially forbid media reports on prospec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuses. The provisions are not focused enough

Speaker: NA
Text: and they may inhibit equity raising in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had an example recently. Someone who

Speaker: NA
Text: came to see me had been told that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: putting out a prospectus was such that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: decided not to raise the equity in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: but to borrow the money offshore. If our laws

Speaker: NA
Text: add to foreign debt as an alternative to paying

Speaker: NA
Text: of the cost of raising domestic equity, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not operating properly. These laws are now

Speaker: NA
Text: being examined. Why they could not have

Speaker: NA
Text: been examined in November last year is

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week, the Federal Court ruled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Keydata case that the Corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities Panel did not have power to make

Speaker: NA
Text: interim orders in relation to takeover conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: which it was examining. The Victorian re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional commissioner of the Australia Securi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties Commission, Mr Ron Trevethan, de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed the decision as 'a bit of a shock'

Speaker: NA
Text: which placed in doubt 'the whole future and

Speaker: NA
Text: usefulness of the panel'. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: If you can't preserve the status quo before a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision is made, then what's the use of a panel at

Speaker: NA
Text: all? This is a very serious setback to the ASC and

Speaker: NA
Text: the panel itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind honourable members that this Panel,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has had a bleak future, also has a fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: short past. The Attorney-General appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: members to this Panel only a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago. The Panel itself, however, was

Speaker: NA
Text: constituted by the Australian Securities Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989, coming into operation in July 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: The law that it was to administer operated

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 January 1991 and yet the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments were made only comparatively recently.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already that Panel is requesting changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the law. If it had been appointed some time

Speaker: NA
Text: ago this could have been clarified and fixed

Speaker: NA
Text: much earlier.

Speaker: NA
Text: This illustrates the confused state of corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate administration. At a time when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Securities Panel should have

Speaker: NA
Text: been writing its June 1991 annual report, it

Speaker: NA
Text: was not in existence. The Companies Auditors

Speaker: NA
Text: and Liquidators Disciplinary Board had to

Speaker: NA
Text: write a report for 30 June 1991; it had only

Speaker: NA
Text: been going a few weeks. In an Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: committee hearing we asked what the report

Speaker: NA
Text: would be and were told effectively that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be one paragraph saying that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: year it had to report on it had had one

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting. This was not through any fault of its

Speaker: NA
Text: own but by reason of delays in the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. this shows that there have been major

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in getting the system up .and

Speaker: NA
Text: running. I believe that ultimately the system

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a better one than we had in the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Attorney-General's Department must

Speaker: NA
Text: devote a lot of work and concerted effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that real resources have now been

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated to the Australian Securities

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. The Opposition has supported

Speaker: NA
Text: that, but we must be vigilant to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: those funds which have been devoted are

Speaker: NA
Text: being properly expended. For example, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: now said that 902 people in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities Commission are working on en-

Speaker: NA
Text: forcement at a cost of $71.2m. I am aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that many of those people will be working on

Speaker: NA
Text: enforcement in relation to filings and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also aware that the Australian Securities

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission says that it has 205 matters

Speaker: NA
Text: under investigation or litigation. But has it

Speaker: NA
Text: really brought to justice the major cases?

Speaker: NA
Text: With those 902 people, can we say that all of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who profited by breaching corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: law during the decade of the 1980s have now

Speaker: NA
Text: been properly investigated and brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: justice in courts of law? If we cannot say

Speaker: NA
Text: that, we must raise the question as to whether

Speaker: NA
Text: we are getting value for our money under the

Speaker: NA
Text: current system.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this discussion of the appropriation for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney-General's Department, I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise other matters which I think should be

Speaker: NA
Text: very carefully considered by the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department. That Department must

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that in its area of operation it takes

Speaker: NA
Text: a view that is conducive to public policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: overall economic development in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot say on the one hand that we want

Speaker: NA
Text: to have economic development and get the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy moving and on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: have an Attorney-General's Department that

Speaker: NA
Text: introduces, administers or acquiesces in laws

Speaker: NA
Text: which may in fact be inimical to economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development and prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I raise as matters of concern two issues

Speaker: NA
Text: which I believe will be very destructive to the

Speaker: NA
Text: operating environment for business in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia if they should become law. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: the subjects of class actions and product

Speaker: NA
Text: liability. I am aware, of course, that these are

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives of Senator Tate, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Justice and Consumer Affairs, but he also

Speaker: NA
Text: operates programs out of the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department and it is from that

Speaker: NA
Text: Department that these initiatives will be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal to introduce neW product

Speaker: NA
Text: liability laws which are more strict than the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Community directive will make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a high risk manufacturing zone;

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no question about it. Those laws will

Speaker: NA
Text: be one more disincentive to manufacture

Speaker: NA
Text: products in Australia. They will not be condu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cive to the creation of a positive climate for

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing investment in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we put them together with the propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sals for class actions-to allow actions to be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought on behalf of a class, the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not identified and have not indicat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed their support to be part of an action-we

Speaker: NA
Text: are putting together the opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread litigation in respect of very strict

Speaker: NA
Text: liability laws.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will mean that Australia will increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of cases brought against manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turers and will take a further step down the

Speaker: NA
Text: road to a litigious society. In the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: that will not help consumers, who will pay

Speaker: NA
Text: higher prices as the cost factor, and the risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of litigation is factored into prices. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: make Australia, however, a high risk zone for

Speaker: NA
Text: business investment and manufacture. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney-General's Department to recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Text: Ryan) (10.47 p.m.)-In the

Speaker: NA
Text: time available tonight I want to speak about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trade Practices Commission, the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Act and the competitive policy

Speaker: NA
Text: perceived by the government of the day. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission was set up under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act to pursue the policy of developing

Speaker: NA
Text: competition within industry. As a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence of that, it is very interesting to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate that is occurring today since the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of Professor Fels as Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trade Practices Commission. Before doing

Speaker: NA
Text: that, it is worth seeing how, in the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's mind, it prices its priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Trade Practices Commission first

Speaker: NA
Text: came into office in 1983-84, its funding was

Speaker: NA
Text: $6.6m. In 1991-92 it is $14m. I compare this

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Parliamentary Library at $lIm, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute at

Speaker: NA
Text: $7m, the Australian Film, Television and

Speaker: NA
Text: Radio School at $lOm, the Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander Commission operating

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of $552m, the Trade Union Training

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority at $10m, the Australian Institute of

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Science at $14m and the Shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Reform. Authority at $24m. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should think of that when we think of

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has spoken a lot about

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive policy. It is all about competition,

Speaker: NA
Text: improving micro-economic reform and mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Australia improve. In one of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: examples of this, we had the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General in October of this year saying that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would examine competitive policy. In March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) said that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was a matter of highest priority. In October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 the Treasurer ( Mr Kerin) said that

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive policy was on the agenda. -

Speaker: NA
Text: While all this was occurring, there hav

Speaker: NA
Text: been no changes to the Trade Practices Ac

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are heading for a situation where there

Speaker: NA
Text: are severe challenges to the area of competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion within Australia. We can take the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the airlines, which have recently been

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulated, with the introduction of Compass

Speaker: NA
Text: Airlines. On top of that, there is the prospec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive entry of the company AAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: If one of those airlines was to be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: over-at present, I am referring to Compass-

Speaker: NA
Text: and we went back to the two-airline system,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I understand the Act there is no role for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission to participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this question, to adjudicate in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: competition.

Speaker: NA
Text: More importantly, today we have all the

Speaker: NA
Text: business about the Fairfax takeover. The,

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission says that it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: in it. Is it not supposed to be the body which

Speaker: NA
Text: determines whether competition is within the

Speaker: NA
Text: country or not? Or is that an area which

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be regarded as too close because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is close to the heart of the ALP? It wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to fix it. There is nothing like a fix with

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch, Packer and the boys. It is at it all

Speaker: NA
Text: the time. Therefore, to change the competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of the Trade Practices Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: where it should rightly be, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: walks away from it, despite what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General ( Mr Duffy), the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the Treasurer said in the last 12 i

Speaker: NA
Text: months about competitive policy. They just do i

Speaker: NA
Text: not mean it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: A committee was set up to look at section

Speaker: NA
Text: 45D of the Trade Practices Act. That commit-I

Speaker: NA
Text: tee was supposed to come out with a quick

Speaker: NA
Text: report. We never heard a word from it. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: floating around somewhere. It disappeared.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there was the question of the Griffiths

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee report. It came out with a variety

Speaker: NA
Text: of recommendations. 'TWo and a half years

Speaker: NA
Text: later there was a response. That response

Speaker: NA
Text: itemised the changes that were deemed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary, which included cost recovery

Speaker: NA
Text: measures, increases in penalties, statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: remedies in respect of breaches, legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of the merger consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: process---in other words, the authorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: process-and the ABS data system for use by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trade Practices Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there has been no action from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, not a word, despite these assur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ances from the Prime Minister, the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Attorney-General about competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. The reason they do not want to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: this is that they have a number of conflicting

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. One is their big mates and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: is the big unions. The big unions are particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly worried about this because one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations that came around is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should address ourselves to the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties. The penalties under the current Act

Speaker: NA
Text: are $250,000 and up to $5m. The recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations are that this ought to be addressed. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was outmoded. Professor Baxt, the retiring

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, and even the Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: said that. In New Zealand the penalty is $5m,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is $lOm in the USA and $70m in Germany.

Speaker: NA
Text: An amount of $250,000 will hardly shake the

Speaker: NA
Text: boots here unless we do something about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing has happened for the simple reason

Speaker: NA
Text: that the unions do not want it. Under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 45D a finding against them in those new

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks could send them broke. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has passed that one by and

Speaker: NA
Text: forgotten about it altogether.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am surprised that we have not addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: the changes th3,t are in the wind. Since the

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the chairmanship of the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Commission, the only major case

Speaker: NA
Text: under section 50 was the Australian Meat

Speaker: NA
Text: Holdings case in 1978. That was put to' the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of market dominance. As a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence, there have been relatively few rulings

Speaker: NA
Text: which have gone past the authorisation

Speaker: NA
Text: process. I am a believer in pragmatic politics

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think the authorisation process has a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: to commend it. It saves costs, and people can

Speaker: NA
Text: see their way through it as long as the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission is quite clear as to what the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Act says and what Government poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cy is, as reflected by the Trade Practices Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: We now have proposals put forward-there

Speaker: NA
Text: are certainly talks under way-by the current

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission to change the

Speaker: NA
Text: law. The test will now be a substantial lessen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of competition. I have not heard from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. All I have heard from is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not heard any response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition as to what its view is, so I pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ume that we are doing nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of the economy of Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: because of its relative smallness, one of our

Speaker: NA
Text: great dangers is the takeover of monopolies

Speaker: NA
Text: with monopolistic power, both within business

Speaker: NA
Text: and within the labour market. That is unheal-

Speaker: NA
Text: thy for Australia and unhealthy for the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment of this nation. For all sorts of reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: we ought not to allow the concentration of

Speaker: NA
Text: power in both sides of the equation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under section 46, which is another very

Speaker: NA
Text: controversial area of the trade practices law,

Speaker: NA
Text: while there has only really been one major

Speaker: NA
Text: case-the Queensland Wire case-I suspect

Speaker: NA
Text: that the same approach ought to be that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: authorisation route is taken by the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner and by the practitioners, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a far better understanding of law and the

Speaker: NA
Text: process itself. There really is very small court

Speaker: NA
Text: law about the Trade Practices Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are not a lot of lawyers who participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in it to any marked degree. As a consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, I would hope that we consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: position well before any changes are made to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trade Practices Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I believe that government business

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises ought to be brought within the

Speaker: NA
Text: realm of the Trade Practices Act. By doing

Speaker: NA
Text: that, we would get a far better competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: nature to Australia. Particularly in the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Government areas, we cannot have major

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations in direct competition with private

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise that act outside the law as it relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to a number of particular government oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations. They disadvantage private enterprise

Speaker: NA
Text: and they disadvantage themselves. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies) (10.57 p.m.)---I

Speaker: NA
Text: address that portion of the Attorney-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Department's Budget concerning the delivery

Speaker: NA
Text: of family services, in particular, marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: education and counselling, family mediation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the family skills program. These are the

Speaker: NA
Text: programs through which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: supports marriage and family life. La';t year

Speaker: NA
Text: 116,959 couples married in Australia. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: same year 42,635 were divorced-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: 36.45 per cent of the number of marriages. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is estimated that some 55 per cent of these

Speaker: NA
Text: divorces involved one or more children-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, 45,000 children were left with single

Speaker: NA
Text: parents in single parent homes last year. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975 over 700,000 Australian children have

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered the emotional trauma of parental

Speaker: NA
Text: divorce.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total expenditure on family services is

Speaker: NA
Text: $16.6m, of which $11.7m is expended on

Speaker: NA
Text: grants to marriage counselling and just

Speaker: NA
Text: $500,700 on marriage education grants. Less

Speaker: NA
Text: than $5 per marriage is spent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government on education programs, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of picking up the pieces is $2.5 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: or some $12,000 for each separation.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I could speak at length about the

Speaker: NA
Text: inequity of this allocation, particularly to

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage education, my purpose tonight is to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the mismanagement by the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of even this pittance. The Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: no adequate policy for the allocation of

Speaker: NA
Text: grants. At a recent meeting of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Association for Marriage Education, at which

Speaker: NA
Text: I was present, an officer of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the Department developed a number of formu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lae and asked the Minister to choose one. He chose

Speaker: NA
Text: to make grants on the basis of last year's expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture minus one-off expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: While this might sound reasonable, the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there is no proper basis for this funding

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. In a letter to agencies, the Director of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Office of Family Services admitted:

Speaker: NA
Text: As with many community programs of this nature,

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies and programs have been funded over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years on an ad hoc basis with inadequate financial

Speaker: NA
Text: information on the levels of services being provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for grants received, little needs based planning and

Speaker: NA
Text: no forward agreement as to what was expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: be delivered for the grant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Winder continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: At the time of the 1990-91 Budget it was, unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, not possible on the information available

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the Minister with a clear picture of what

Speaker: NA
Text: services were being funded and where and thus

Speaker: NA
Text: where he might allocate additional funds as a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the Minister for Justice had

Speaker: NA
Text: not established a policy for funding family

Speaker: NA
Text: services since his appointment in September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1987, and only late last year did he move to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The process chosen illustrates further the

Speaker: NA
Text: scandal in the management of the Office of

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Services. In 1990 the office appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: a consultative committee, comprising repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the peak organisations; namely,

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage Guidance Australia, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Marriage Counselling Organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, Centacare Australia, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Association for Marriage Education and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic Society for Marriage Education. This

Speaker: NA
Text: committee has met on at least six occasions,

Speaker: NA
Text: during which time it reviewed submissions for

Speaker: NA
Text: new funding and made certain recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to the office. I believe that most of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's recommendations have been

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that so little funding is allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: family services, why did the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: expend thousands of dollars on establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: this committee, only to ignore its advice? On

Speaker: NA
Text: what basis did the Minister then allocate the

Speaker: NA
Text: new funds? Yet the Minister seems unaware

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are any problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the Senate Estimates Committee on 5

Speaker: NA
Text: September, Senator Macdonald suggested to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister that the five peak organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia are very unhappy with

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of the qffice, to which

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Tate replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: I can say adamantly and categorically that that

Speaker: NA
Text: is utterly wrong. I have never seen peak organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions so happy with any form of consultation that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been undertaken within my portfolio in the four

Speaker: NA
Text: and a half years I have been a Minister. The

Speaker: NA
Text: transformation in the relationship between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department and the peak organisations in family

Speaker: NA
Text: services has been quite astonishing. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: tlley are working very well and in fact playa huge

Speaker: NA
Text: role in the advice that I get as to the priorities for

Speaker: NA
Text: funding various projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Macdonald then asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, you have not received a request from

Speaker: NA
Text: them for an investigation to be initiated into the

Speaker: NA
Text: to operation and administration of the family services

Speaker: NA
Text: section of your Department?

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Tate replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: No, not that I know of.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even if the Minister had not received a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: from Dr Warwick Hartin, the National Direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of Marriage Guidance Australia who wrote

Speaker: NA
Text: to Mr Winder on behalf of the five peak

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies on 4 September 1991, in which he

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that the peak bodies wished to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of an overall policy framework

Speaker: NA
Text: for the delivery of family services before any

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines were put in place, and even if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had not seen letters to him from

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies questioning the basis of their funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for this year, he must have been aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: letter dated 25 July 1991, in which his senior

Speaker: NA
Text: adviser said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been concerned for some time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding situation has been misunderstood.

Speaker: NA
Text: This letter, on 25 July, was sent in response

Speaker: NA
Text: to a telephone conversation in which Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hartin had questioned and complained of the

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation and disbursement of funds. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Minister not aware of this some six

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks later when he appeared at the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, or was he?

Speaker: NA
Text: There is widespread dissatisfaction from

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies about the conduct of this aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the portfolio. Indeed, I believe that Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Tate has been sent a letter in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: in which four peak bodies expressed their

Speaker: NA
Text: general dissatisfaction about funding and the

Speaker: NA
Text: absence of government family policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet there is still no evidence of any policy

Speaker: NA
Text: underlying the allocation of funds. I know of

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies that have provided little or no

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage education ,Programs, yet have been

Speaker: NA
Text: funded year after year. I am informed, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, that Marriage Guidance, South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; received $10,000 for marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: education last year. It advertised three proincompetence,

Speaker: NA
Text: grams, two of which had to be cancelled

Speaker: NA
Text: the other one only went ahead because of an

Speaker: NA
Text: overflow from another agency, and its funding

Speaker: NA
Text: has been increased to $10,500 this year. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: Anglican Family Services, New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: which provided programs for 500 couples,

Speaker: NA
Text: received only $6,000 which has been reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: this year to $5,800. And there are other

Speaker: NA
Text: programs which receive no funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where is the much vaunted equity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation? I could give other examples. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: Director's progress report on financial

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements, Mr Winder states that the Minisinequity

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, in a letter to agencies approving

Speaker: NA
Text: grants:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . expressed concern at the practice of some

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies to budget for and incur deficits, to expand

Speaker: NA
Text: services and to purchase property without, appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently, ensuring that funds would be available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet the Minister has allowed the same situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to continue this year. In a letter sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies just last month, Senator Tate states:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . because several agencies had over committed

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in 1990-91 contrary to firm advice last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, it was necessary in some circumstances for

Speaker: NA
Text: additional funds to be allocated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect has been to reduce the available

Speaker: NA
Text: funds for one-off expenditure from $500,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to $106,000. Even the further allocation is

Speaker: NA
Text: inequitable. Where agencies complained, they

Speaker: NA
Text: received additional funds. Indeed, an officer

Speaker: NA
Text: of the section stated two weeks ago:

Speaker: NA
Text: All agencies that asked for a review got one.

Speaker: NA
Text: He also stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: .. the Minister allocated further funds to Agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: which asked for a review.

Speaker: NA
Text: few days I am informed that Marriage Guidance,

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, complained and received an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $42,000, but Anglicare, Queensland, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was told by an officer of the section when it

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke to him 'not to rock the boat' received

Speaker: NA
Text: no additional funding at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a scandal when so little is allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage education in particular, and family

Speaker: NA
Text: services in general, for such inequity to be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed by the Minister. Time precludes me

Speaker: NA
Text: from mentioning other examples of ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: including the failure to publish

Speaker: NA
Text: aild a new version of the Marriage and You

Speaker: NA
Text: brochure for two years after a draft had been

Speaker: NA
Text: approved, the incompetence in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring of visits and the failure to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider alternative structures proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies themselves. While the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General ( Mr Duffy) may respond by pointing

Speaker: NA
Text: to the increase in funding over the past three

Speaker: NA
Text: years, may I remind him of the extremely low

Speaker: NA
Text: base from which the funding started, the

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing inadequacy of the allocation and

Speaker: NA
Text: arthe gross inefficiencies and demonstrated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the system over which he presides

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1991 and for which he is responsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed expenditure, $1,358,873,000.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Text: Fadden) (11.08 p.m.)-I will

Speaker: NA
Text: confine my comments tonight to the aviation

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the estimates. There has probably

Speaker: NA
Text: been no other area of government operation

Speaker: NA
Text: that has undergone such massive change and

Speaker: NA
Text: is about to undergo such massive change as

Speaker: NA
Text: the area of aviation during this past 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months. We have seen systems change in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of new air traffic control arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed for Australia; we have seen a mas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive change in the nature of airport ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia; we have seen tremendous pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sures placed on general aviation; we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen the Government decision to go ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: with the privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australian Airlines; and we have seen a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision made not to change aviation policy

Speaker: NA
Text: during the term of this Government. Of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that are about and of all the reforms

Speaker: NA
Text: that have to be made there is one that stands

Speaker: NA
Text: out more than any other; that is, the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: to build the third runway at Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to make a couple of comments

Speaker: NA
Text: about this tonight. The Opposition believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that the third runway proposal is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most critical pieces of micro-economic reform

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia needs to undertake urgently; in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, needs to undertake now. The benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia will derive from the construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of that third runway are innumerable. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not mean that Sydney will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: handle the growth of traffic coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia over these next several years; it does

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that we will be able to get more effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciencies from our domestic airline services

Speaker: NA
Text: and from our international airline services. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does mean that our air freight will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: become more competitive and, even more

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, it does mean a tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the lifestyle of a great number of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who live around that particular

Speaker: NA
Text: airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already the dogs are barking. Already we

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeing from some members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government a concerted campaign to sink this

Speaker: NA
Text: most important piece of micro-economic

Speaker: NA
Text: reform that Australia must lmdertake at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment. This concerns the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I put the Government on notice now that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is fully prepared to back any

Speaker: NA
Text: final decision to go ahead with the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: (Kingsford-Smith) Airport third runway, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we trust that that final decision will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: as soon as possible. It does concern us when

Speaker: NA
Text: we see statements from the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: was talking about the decision, and from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Kerin), saying that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: important to go ahead with this project. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does concern us that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Barton says:

Speaker: NA
Text: If at the end of the day that is the best the Treasur-

Speaker: NA
Text: er can say . . . that we have to do it to send a

Speaker: NA
Text: signal to business ... then frankly we ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: pack the Labor Party in Government and the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: economy up.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is even more concerning when a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Crown comes out after a statement by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port (Senator Collins) and says:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the EIS firmly established a basis for effective-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly managing all environmental issues and . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: identified no barriers to proceeding with the third

Speaker: NA
Text: runway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet the Minister for Higher Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment Services ( Mr Dawkins) said that

Speaker: NA
Text: in his view:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the EIS fails to provide a basis for the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: to proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that if the Minister continues that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular line he really has no other option

Speaker: NA
Text: but to resign from the Government, to get out

Speaker: NA
Text: and to join his friends on the back bench.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the stories that are being put

Speaker: NA
Text: around now are really quite fatuous. Let us be

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear: this third runway decision is

Speaker: NA
Text: about improving the lifestyle of a great

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people in the City of Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: About 170,000 are now affected by moderate

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft noise. That figure will drop to 82,000

Speaker: NA
Text: once the new runway is built. The 54,700

Speaker: NA
Text: people seriously affected by aircraft noise will

Speaker: NA
Text: drop to 26,900.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed third runway has been around

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last 20 years. A decision for an addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional rtmway was made by the coalition in

Speaker: NA
Text: government in 1983 under the stewardship of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Rume ( Mr Fife).

Speaker: NA
Text: It should have been built then. This runway

Speaker: NA
Text: is about efficiencies and it is about providing

Speaker: NA
Text: proper services to the people of rural New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. It is about creating 40,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: for the people of New South Wales and, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only that, being able to provide jobs within

Speaker: NA
Text: the tourist industry right around Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also turn my attention very briefly to the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision by the Government during this past

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months not to change its international

Speaker: NA
Text: aviation policy for Australia in the life of this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular Parliament. This decision was made

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure, it said, that we would have the best

Speaker: NA
Text: possible price options for Qantas. May I say

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was deeply disturbed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's decision on an application by

Speaker: NA
Text: the only charter airline operator coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Britannia Airways of Luton in the

Speaker: NA
Text: UK, that it not be allowed to service the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney market this year. That particular

Speaker: NA
Text: decision has taken about $14m out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney economy. While the scheduled ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices operating in and out of Australia suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered immensely from the Gulf war in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times, it was in fact Britannia which kept its

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the contract and continued, with 90-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus per cent load factors, to bring tourists to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently I was in the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: I had discussions with Britannia Airways. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was taken through that airline's projections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the UK charter market to Australia. It believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that potentially within 5 to 10 years the

Speaker: NA
Text: chartei)'market to Australia could be half a

Speaker: NA
Text: million people. This year we will get about

Speaker: NA
Text: 14,000 through the charter programs. It is just

Speaker: NA
Text: not good enough for the officials of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Transport and Communications

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, for the Minister to say it is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about the dilution of traffic, because it is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: As has been proved around the world time

Speaker: NA
Text: and time again, if we get into that charter

Speaker: NA
Text: market we are into a totally new market.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite interesting to go through the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures from the Department on the expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture effects of visitors from the UK. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very real distinction between the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: is spent here by people using the scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: airlines and the time spent by and the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure of people using the charter services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I took out. those figures for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight's exercise to try to bring home to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government the importance of a very liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: charter policy in and out of Australia. Sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: uled carriers bring visitors to Australia who

Speaker: NA
Text: stay 40 days, and that is fine. While they are

Speaker: NA
Text: here they spend $1,761. The charter operators

Speaker: NA
Text: come here on an all-inclusive package holiday

Speaker: NA
Text: and stay for 22 days spending $1,779. That is

Speaker: NA
