Text: really the distinction-these charter people,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are used to using these services around

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe and beyond, are in fact the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: asset that we could get out of that UK market

Speaker: NA
Text: because they spend more money and they

Speaker: NA
Text: spend it within the infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I give this warning to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping and Aviation Support: if, on any

Speaker: NA
Text: applications for charter programs, the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: is not loosened in the future, once again

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will miss out because the new

Speaker: NA
Text: market that is coming on stream for the UK

Speaker: NA
Text: and Europe is South Africa. South Africa has

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of similar attractions to Australia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: recent times, for example, we read that Virgin

Speaker: NA
Text: Atlantic Airways of the UK had applied for

Speaker: NA
Text: and in principle had received approval for two

Speaker: NA
Text: services a week into Australia. It will not

Speaker: NA
Text: operate with any less than four services a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. What has it done? It has applied for

Speaker: NA
Text: and got rights to South Africa because the

Speaker: NA
Text: attractions are similar, it is 16 hours closer in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of flying time, and there is only about

Speaker: NA
Text: two hours difference in terms of time zones.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are to maximise the number of visi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors coming into Australia, we have to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that our aviation policy is right. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: present aviation policy just restricts charter

Speaker: NA
Text: operators to some of the smaller airports, and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is nothing wrong with that, but those

Speaker: NA
Text: that wipe out Sydney completely are a bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: a danger for the future development of tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism and the wealth that it can bring to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It seems very strange to me that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is prepared to provide charter

Speaker: NA
Text: rights into Sydney for Aeroflot, for Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Lanka, for Lot, the Polish airline, for Lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: Chile, for Air Mauritius and for Air Malta,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet it will not do it as part of an overall

Speaker: NA
Text: package tour for an outfit like Britannia

Speaker: NA
Text: Airways which, after all, is only including

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney as part of an overall itinerary which

Speaker: NA
Text: includes the prepaid destinations of Cairns,

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is soon to apply for rights to fly into Darwin,

Speaker: NA
Text: Alice Springs and, indeed, into Hamilton

Speaker: NA
Text: Island off the Queensland coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: So if the Minister does nothing more during

Speaker: NA
Text: the life of this Parliament, at least he should

Speaker: NA
Text: have the sense to recognise the tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution that can be made out of proper

Speaker: NA
Text: charter rights into Australia and open up this

Speaker: NA
Text: place to that huge market. It is a completely

Speaker: NA
Text: new market, a market we will not have access

Speaker: NA
Text: to unless these charters are allowed to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the individual airports of the UK.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Throsby) (11.17 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: planned to make a wide-ranging speech this

Speaker: NA
Text: evening concerning the appropriation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Transport and Communica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, but in fact the speech is on my desk

Speaker: NA
Text: because at 9 0' clock this evening I received,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the internal mail system, one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: biased and misinformed pieces of lUbbish-I

Speaker: NA
Text: could not distinguish it by calling it journal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism-I have seen in my nine years as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament. An accompanying

Speaker: NA
Text: letter informed me this article, entitled 'Time

Speaker: NA
Text: to get tough on the waterfront', will appear in

Speaker: NA
Text: the October issue of that intellectual giant,

Speaker: NA
Text: Reader s Digest. I must say the accompanying

Speaker: NA
Text: letter was as lurid and as misinformed as the

Speaker: NA
Text: offending article.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having spent most of the past year as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Transport, Communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations and Infrastructure, I visited most of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ports around Australia as part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into land and seaports interface

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. I can say with some authority that this

Speaker: NA
Text: article is full of lies, distortions and misinforthe

Speaker: NA
Text: mation. It takes a naive and simplistic ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach and places all the blame for our

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient waterfront on the Waterside

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reform of the waterfront is well advanced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, some members of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: confuse waterfront refornl with reform of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Waterside Workers Federation. The Waterside

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Federation has been continually

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked by the Opposition and is now at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacked by the Reader 50 Digest. From reading

Speaker: NA
Text: the biased article in the Reader s Digest, one

Speaker: NA
Text: could be excused for thinking that nothing has

Speaker: NA
Text: been achieved on waterfront reform. This, like

Speaker: NA
Text: most of the article, is a lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us ask what waterfront reform is really

Speaker: NA
Text: about. The waterfront is a reactor. It does not

Speaker: NA
Text: make anything. It makes nothing at all. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not build anything. It provides a service.

Speaker: NA
Text: People bring things to the waterfront by sea

Speaker: NA
Text: and take them away on land or vice versa.

Speaker: NA
Text: The timetables are very much determined by

Speaker: NA
Text: those who use the waterfront, whether by sea

Speaker: NA
Text: or by land. It is not done by the waterfront.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said before, the waterfront reacts. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Reader s Digest article goes on at length

Speaker: NA
Text: about the cost to importers and exporters, but

Speaker: NA
Text: what do we find? Exporters tum up at the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront after the deadline for a ship has

Speaker: NA
Text: closed wanting to get boxes or bags onto

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels. Why are they not there on time?

Speaker: NA
Text: Usually they have a minimum of seven days

Speaker: NA
Text: notice. Why do the cargoes not come in at an

Speaker: NA
Text: even pace over those seven or 10 days?

Speaker: NA
Text: Explain that to the exporters. Explain to

Speaker: NA
Text: them why 90 per cent of the trucks that go

Speaker: NA
Text: onto the waterfront are empty and come out

Speaker: NA
Text: full or go in full and come out empty. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reader 50 Digest article did not mention this.

Speaker: NA
Text: the The situation with these trucks is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: wharfies' fault. Why are our exporters not

Speaker: NA
Text: getting a decent deal on transport service rates

Speaker: NA
Text: to and from the waterfront? Why is this

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense tolerated? Why is it that when

Speaker: NA
Text: goods come onto the waterfront they sit there

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting to be taken away? The first three days

Speaker: NA
Text: on the waterfront are free when goods come

Speaker: NA
Text: off a ship. Fifteen per cent of the goods go

Speaker: NA
Text: out on the first day, 20 per cent go out on the

Speaker: NA
Text: second day, and there is one almighty lUsh on

Speaker: NA
Text: third day. All that lUsh generates a peak,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it generates confusion and congestion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who gets the blame? Again, it is the wharfies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The exporters will always tell us that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are all tucked in behind the big shed; blame

Speaker: NA
Text: them. But, as exporters, they do not get their

Speaker: NA
Text: goods to the wharf on time and they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: check with their agents to see whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: could get a better deal or a better rate for

Speaker: NA
Text: having the goods there a few days earlier. As

Speaker: NA
Text: importers, they do not check whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: could get a dedicated time for their ship's

Speaker: NA
Text: arrival so that they could get an even spread

Speaker: NA
Text: of ships arriving at the terminal, thus reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the peaks and the congestion. None of these

Speaker: NA
Text: things have been done. The truck queues are

Speaker: NA
Text: not caused by the wharfies but by the shippers

Speaker: NA
Text: who cannot organise to get their cargoes to

Speaker: NA
Text: and from the ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: The farmers who scream loudest are among

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst offenders in this regard. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: offending article in the Reader s Digest, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are told of a farmer from somewhere in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria who spent some time on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne wharf, and he went on at great

Speaker: NA
Text: length about the inefficiency. In my area of

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Kembla, the Waterside Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation and the farmers from the western

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the State around Parkes and Dubbo

Speaker: NA
Text: have worked together to understand each

Speaker: NA
Text: other's problems-and they have done it very

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to have an efficient system for

Speaker: NA
Text: moving cargoes in and out of ports. For some

Speaker: NA
Text: trucks-and I say this coming from a trucking

Speaker: NA
Text: background-payment for queuing is a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: venient money earner. We have to stop this

Speaker: NA
Text: business of trucks unloading and then leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: empty. There has to be better coordination.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is truly little point in clearing

Speaker: NA
Text: obstacles at the waterside if the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: wharf gate remain in place. The most expenvisited

Speaker: NA
Text: sive aspect of the waterfront today is

Speaker: NA
Text: tugboats. That is.where the real cost is today.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we do not hear this from the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: or from the leader writers on our national

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers or the Reader s Digest. No, we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear that the waterfront is the site of some

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst work practice rorts, overmanning

Speaker: NA
Text: and inefficiency. But it is not the wharfies;

Speaker: NA
Text: is the other players on the waterfront. What

Speaker: NA
Text: is always missed out is that there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: players on the waterfront.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear a lot about the wonderful overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: ports and the ones that we are to be compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with such as Rotterdam or Singapore and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: this article, Yokohama-although I never

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that that was such an efficient port.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is to be a comparison between our

Speaker: NA
Text: ports-say, Port Kembla-and Rotterdam or

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore, then give our ports the equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will deliver the results. These com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parisons are always very selective, and hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable members opposite are also very

Speaker: NA
Text: selective in the ports that they pick out in

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia. They should go to some of the ports in

Speaker: NA
Text: Thailand and a few of the other ports in

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, not the few that they pick out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore is all we hear about. They should

Speaker: NA
Text: go around the ports of South East Asia and

Speaker: NA
Text: make a comparison with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: ports-even with the inadequate equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have in Australian ports. As I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: give us the equipment in our ports-a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of cranes and so on-and we will achieve the

Speaker: NA
Text: results.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another point about making comparisons in

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with the waterfront is that it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: only the equipment but also the users of the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront that must be considered. Would the

Speaker: NA
Text: business people of Singapore or Rotterdam go

Speaker: NA
Text: on with the nonsense that the business people

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia go on with? Would they have all

Speaker: NA
Text: their cargo come in late? If we are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: make these comparisons, let us compare the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole work process and not just one aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the waterfront.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must say that the hypocrisy of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the waterfront is really amazing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the me. Sometimes I wonder whether any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: at the honourable members opposite have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: the waterfront. I must say that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the never seen any of them wandering around

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Kembla. Their ideologically blinkered

Speaker: NA
Text: view distorts any rational debate with them

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding reform on the waterfront. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: all the waffle from the Opposition members

Speaker: NA
Text: of and the rubbish in this article, has anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: ever heard them say anything other than a

Speaker: NA
Text: it criticism of the wharfies? I have not heard of

Speaker: NA
Text: a single plan from the Opposition to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity on the waterfront. Why? Because

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not have any plans.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition's only plan is to bash the

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and to put in the troops, a move

Speaker: NA
Text: applauded in this article by the Reader s

Speaker: NA
Text: Digest. Honourable members opposite would

Speaker: NA
Text: be much more credible on waterfront reform

Speaker: NA
Text: if they could come up with their own plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminating some of the waterfront practices

Speaker: NA
Text: of the users of the ports. For example, what

Speaker: NA
Text: would the Opposition do about queuing,

Speaker: NA
Text: timely delivery of cargo, electronic transfer of

Speaker: NA
Text: documents and antiquated equipment? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will not speak on these issues

Speaker: NA
Text: because it has absolutely no policies on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it clear: I am not arguing that

Speaker: NA
Text: sorting out the ports is easy. But it is simplis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic to think that the problem lies only with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wharfies. The Waterside Workers Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: has been largely restructured, without

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial disputation. If the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to talk about inefficiencies and rorts,

Speaker: NA
Text: it should look at the other users of the water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front and lift its eyes above the Waterside

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great pity that this article in the

Speaker: NA
Text: October issue of the Reader's Digest is so

Speaker: NA
Text: inaccurate and distorted. I note that the next

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker to take part in this debate is the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Gilmore ( Mr Sharp).

Speaker: NA
Text: As he is extensively quoted in this article,

Speaker: NA
Text: which includes the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Hewson), I will be very interested to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: what he has to say. It is very interesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: the writers of this article did not contact any

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is just a mouthpiece for the farmers, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Gilmore and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition. I must say it is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the most disgraceful pieces of journal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism that I have ever seen and it is also the

Speaker: NA
Text: most inaccurate. I have been asked to do my

Speaker: NA
Text: best to publicise it. I will most certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: publicise it by publicising the lies and the

Speaker: NA
Text: distortion in this rubbish.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Text: Gilmore) (11.27 p.m.)-It is

Speaker: NA
Text: with some interest and pleasure that I follow

Speaker: NA
Text: my friend the honourable member for Throsby

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hollis) in consideration of the Appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation Bill (No.1) in committee. I, like he, will

Speaker: NA
Text: focus my comments on the matters relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: the waterfront, but following the comments

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honourable member for Throsby

Speaker: NA
Text: I will have a somewhat different introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: from that I had planned. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member made a concerted attack on the

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility of an article in the Reader's Di-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest, an article which I have read and found

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one that represented the case more fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: than the honourable member for Throsby

Speaker: NA
Text: would think.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt whatsoever that the case

Speaker: NA
Text: put by the Reader's Digest article is one

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the view of many people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian society today. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Throsby and others on his side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House will take offence at that view, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it has come about because of the incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: excesses, rorts and militancy of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have worked on the Australian water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front. Those excesses and rorts have cost

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian society about $1,OOOm a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Throsby takes

Speaker: NA
Text: great offence at the fact that in the Reader's

Speaker: NA
Text: Digest article wharfies are being blamed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the problems of the Australian waterfront. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me point out to him that there is good justifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation for blaming wharfies; wharfies certain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly deserve a great deal of blame for what goes

Speaker: NA
Text: on in the Australian waterfront. It is wharfies

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been able to get away with wages

Speaker: NA
Text: of around $47,000 a year, on average, for '1

Speaker: NA
Text: 27-hour work week, on average. It is wharfies

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been able to use their incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: union muscle, their industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: muscle, to achieve working conditions which

Speaker: NA
Text: most people in the Australian work force

Speaker: NA
Text: would consider to be some type of workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: paradise.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sorts of allowances and the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions that wharfies get are unique in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian work force. Nobody else in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian work force can enjoy the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions that wharfies get. Who has heard

Speaker: NA
Text: of people who can be paid for 20 years with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out ever turning up at their place of work?

Speaker: NA
Text: Who has heard of people who can work as a

Speaker: NA
Text: tag team where the team is divided into two,

Speaker: NA
Text: half the team turns up and does the work, the

Speaker: NA
Text: other half goes home? Both halves of the

Speaker: NA
Text: team get full pay although only half the team

Speaker: NA
Text: actually did any work. There are countless ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ercises that one could run of the sorts of rorts

Speaker: NA
Text: that have operated on the Australian water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Throsby is partly right in his criticism in the

Speaker: NA
Text: sense that it is not entirely the fault of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Waterside Workers Federation of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are problems on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront. It is also the fault of the managers

Speaker: NA
Text: of waterfront labour; that is, the stevedores.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the ones who have given in and

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the easy option in times gone past and

Speaker: NA
Text: who have let the Waterside Workers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and its members get away with the sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of rorts and excesses that it has. Let us share

Speaker: NA
Text: the blame around a bit further and say it is

Speaker: NA
Text: also the stevedores.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are going to be totally honest about

Speaker: NA
Text: this, we also have to share the blame a little

Speaker: NA
Text: further and blame governments of the past-

Speaker: NA
Text: governments on both sides of the political

Speaker: NA
Text: fence. In this day and age, we should blame

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party's side of the political fence

Speaker: NA
Text: for what goes on today. It is governments that

Speaker: NA
Text: have allowed the stevedores and the wharfies

Speaker: NA
Text: to get away with the conditions that apply on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian waterfront today. As the Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Commission and as our own Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter ( Mr Hawke) have pointed out, it costs the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy at least $1,000m a year

Speaker: NA
Text: for the inefficiencies. So is it any wonder that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reader s Digest has an attack on the

Speaker: NA
Text: wharfies of Australia? Can we blame people

Speaker: NA
Text: such as those who write articles in Reader s

Speaker: NA
Text: Digest for taking umbrage at the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: things that go on on the Australian water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front? I think their views would be typical of

Speaker: NA
Text: the views of most people around Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Throsby tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to blame the lack of international' best prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices on our Australian waterfront on inad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equate equipment: somehow or other, we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not achieve these international standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency because we do not have the equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to match other countries like Singapore

Speaker: NA
Text: and other parts of the world. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we do have the type of equipment. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been extensively throughout the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront. I think I have visited virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: every major port and a lot of regional ports in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I can assure honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that the types of portainer cranes, straddle

Speaker: NA
Text: cranes, fork-lifts and all of that sort of equipdetailed

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that operate here in Australia are exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: the same as equipment that operates in

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore, Rotterdam and Philadelphia.

Speaker: NA
Text: If one looks at the Government's waterfront

Speaker: NA
Text: reform program, one will find that under its

Speaker: NA
Text: program, National Terminals, the second

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest stevedore operator in Australia, hopes

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve, when it has fully completed its

Speaker: NA
Text: reform programs, 23 TEUs-that is, 20-foot

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent unit lift rate -per hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-What is it in Singapore?

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Text: Honourable members get

Speaker: NA
Text: upset about a comparison with Singapore. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me take a comparison between a likeminded

Speaker: NA
Text: people and Australians. Let me look at a port

Speaker: NA
Text: like Philadelphia in the United States. They

Speaker: NA
Text: can manage 33 TEUs per hour; that is, 33 20-

Speaker: NA
Text: foot equivalent containers can be lifted onto

Speaker: NA
Text: a ship in the port of Philadelphia every hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia, after the Government's water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front reform program has been completed, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be hoping to get 23. Is that any sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: international best practice? Of course, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not. That is highlighting the failure of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's reform program.

Speaker: NA
Text: One can look at the cost of lifting those

Speaker: NA
Text: containers. It is around $225 a container to

Speaker: NA
Text: lift them from the shore to the ship in an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian port. That is a rough estimate, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is fairly accurate. In Singapore-which we

Speaker: NA
Text: were just talking about a moment ago-the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent container costs between $100 and

Speaker: NA
Text: $120 to lift. In .the United Kingdom it is

Speaker: NA
Text: around $140 a container to lift. So one can

Speaker: NA
Text: see that the equipment in those ports-be it

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Singapore, Philadelphia or wherever

Speaker: NA
Text: else one wants to compare with-is exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: the same. The difference is the rate at which

Speaker: NA
Text: we work-the sorts of work practices that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in Australia now and the sorts of work

Speaker: NA
Text: practices that we will still have post this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's reform program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Throsby went

Speaker: NA
Text: on about the fact that the Opposition does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a waterfront reform plan. In fact, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally incorrect. In the last election, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition went to the voters with a water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front reform policy that was nine pages in

Speaker: NA
Text: length. We have several more pages to add to

Speaker: NA
Text: that policy since those days. Our policies are

Speaker: NA
Text: and deal with the very fatal flaw that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government leaves in its waterfront

Speaker: NA
Text: reform program; that is, its determination to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave Australian wharfies with a job for life.

Speaker: NA
Text: No workplace in Australia enjoys a job for

Speaker: NA
Text: life except the Australian waterfront. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: so special about wharfies? Why are they

Speaker: NA
Text: different from any other worker in Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason is the Waterside Workers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has unashamedly used its industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: muscle to get that condition for its workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is being kept by Labor's people, by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and, as a result of that, no

Speaker: NA
Text: wharfie can be sacked.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of the Government's program,

Speaker: NA
Text: after two years we have had a 14.5 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in the numbers of people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian waterfront. As a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recession that the Government gave us, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a 30 per cent downturn in the

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of trade over the Australian water-

Speaker: NA
Text: front. What does that mean? It means that

Speaker: NA
Text: today, after two years of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: three-year waterfront reform program,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's waterfront is now more over-

Speaker: NA
Text: manned than it was before the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: started the reform program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tell me whether that is the sort of reform

Speaker: NA
Text: program it should be proud of. Tell me

Speaker: NA
Text: whether that is not a reasonable reason for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reader:SDigest article to make some criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of and outrage at what is going on in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian waterfront today. It is for those

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons that the Government will find that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reader:SO Digest and many other fair-minded,

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced reports-looking at it not from the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unionist point of view, not from the

Speaker: NA
Text: stevedores' point of view, not from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's point of view, but from the

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary Australian's point of view: the users

Speaker: NA
Text: of the waterfront, the people who pay for the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront in Australia -are justified in the

Speaker: NA
Text: outrage that they have about the conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: that apply on the Australian waterfront today

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Government's reform program. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of two years of waterfront reform, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is worse off on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront than when it began its program.

Speaker: NA
Text: That highlights the inadequacy of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr WRIGHT
Text: Capricornia) (11.37 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to raise a matter that relates to another

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the Transport and Telecommunica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions portfolio. I refer to the plan that will

Speaker: NA
Text: take place over the next six months whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: a second telecommunications network will be

Speaker: NA
Text: phased in. We are aware that part of Telecom

Speaker: NA
Text: is virtually being privatised and we are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a private enterprise player involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the delivery of telecommunications. I person-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally regret that decision. I am on the record

Speaker: NA
Text: saying it elsewhere. But that is a fact of

Speaker: NA
Text: political life.

Speaker: NA
Text: My concern tonight is not privatisation, but

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy. There have been significant changes

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent years regarding access to telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications information. I am specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the information monitored and

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded by Telecom.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am aware that the office of the Attomey-

Speaker: NA
Text: General ( Mr Duffy) is looking at some mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters that relate to interpretation. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation as to what ought to be acces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible. Under the old Telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: (Interception) Act there were very, very tough

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions as to what one could access. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is not just talking about the electronic white

Speaker: NA
Text: pages which are really just a duplication of

Speaker: NA
Text: the telephone book, not just silent numbers,

Speaker: NA
Text: not just numbers to name. One must realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that often people have tried to find out the

Speaker: NA
Text: name of the person by having a telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: number rather than looking up the name and

Speaker: NA
Text: chasing th- number.

Speaker: NA
Text: It really goes back to the intercepted

Speaker: NA
Text: information. This is intercepted information

Speaker: NA
Text: not by individuals, but by Telecom itself. To

Speaker: NA
Text: simplify the matter, I am referring to records

Speaker: NA
Text: of calls; the information that Telecom has

Speaker: NA
Text: collected relating to the bills; the call charger

Speaker: NA
Text: records-CCRs as they are called-records of

Speaker: NA
Text: calls to someone by whom from some place

Speaker: NA
Text: and when and where. In the past this sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: information has only been available to the law

Speaker: NA
Text: enforcement agencies; the National Crime

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority, the Australian Federal Police and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Securities Commission. ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously has special privileges as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important that we protect this

Speaker: NA
Text: information from unwarranted access. It really

Speaker: NA
Text: means that if one can get access to that sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of detail one knows all about the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals-Australians. In fact, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about something like up to six million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who can now be traced simply

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the sorts of phone calls they make,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly STD calls which are timed; they

Speaker: NA
Text: are monitored.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, in the past there were great

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions under the Telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: (Interception) Act. I want to place on record

Speaker: NA
Text: credit to Telecom for the self-imposed stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ards. It has a very enviable record over a long

Speaker: NA
Text: period for being strict as to who can get at

Speaker: NA
Text: those records. But the question now arises:

Speaker: NA
Text: will the same standards be applied by the

Speaker: NA
Text: private player, unless enforced very specifical-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly by legislation? What seems to have hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened is that there is now some question as

Speaker: NA
Text: to whether the old interception rules will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to the new telecommunications Act. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems that State organisations, State police

Speaker: NA
Text: and other semi or partial law enforcement

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies now appreciate the fact that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: get at this detail. So any State instrumentali-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty-I suppose even local authorities or statu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory authorities-could start using section 88

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Telecommunications Act to trace the

Speaker: NA
Text: whereabouts of people who owe money,

Speaker: NA
Text: people who may have broken the law and

Speaker: NA
Text: people who may be up on charges for, say,

Speaker: NA
Text: fishery problems, problems with Customs or

Speaker: NA
Text: even with the Department of Social Security.

Speaker: NA
Text: The mind boggles as to who now may have

Speaker: NA
Text: access to Telecom records because of what

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be a loose interpretation of section

Speaker: NA
Text: 88. I believe that we need to understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: seriousness of this problem in privacy terms,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of attitude to privatisation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: urge an urgent review of the present position.

Speaker: NA
Text: More importantly, we should bring down laws

Speaker: NA
Text: that will strengthen the controls that Telecom

Speaker: NA
Text: is trying to impose voluntarily and ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next six months when we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: private player that those rules are enforceable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can see enormous problems developing, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just with the electronic white pages. No one

Speaker: NA
Text: would mind that. After all, if one is willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: have one's name in the phone book, one

Speaker: NA
Text: would not mind some law enforcement agen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cy being able to access this information on

Speaker: NA
Text: line.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other issues relating to silent

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers. I argue that we ought to require a

Speaker: NA
Text: written application. But, when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: other matters, one must question whether

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone should have automatic access to call

Speaker: NA
Text: charge records, in other words the billing

Speaker: NA
Text: system. Should people have access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: information that relates to the types of sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems that one has, whether PABX or fax

Speaker: NA
Text: systems. Should they have access to STD

Speaker: NA
Text: records, international direct call records,

Speaker: NA
Text: reverse call records, 0055 call r-cords or

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecard calls-in fact anything that is time

Speaker: NA
Text: call related. By having those records, some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one could virtually trace the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: people right across this nation---'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer-This is what the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government has been doing.

Speaker: Mr WRIGHT
Text: I am not aware of that. All

Speaker: NA
Text: I know is that we in this Parliament have a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to ensure that our constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: are protected against unwarranted and un-

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary access to that information. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: all I am asking for. I kn,ow that the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General has people looking at this. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: raised the matter with the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications (Me Beazley).

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo ( Mr Downer) must be concerned. No

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentarian would want undue access. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want anyone to be able to get hold of

Speaker: NA
Text: call charge records to know the movements,

Speaker: NA
Text: activities or whereabouts of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens unnecessarily. That is okay if it is

Speaker: NA
Text: crime related. But we have provision for that

Speaker: NA
Text: already for the NCA, the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police, ASIO and other agencies, be they

Speaker: NA
Text: commercially criminally oriented or other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise.

Speaker: NA
Text: But when it comes to a private competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor-and that is what we will get here-will

Speaker: NA
Text: it apply the same standards as Telecom has

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntarily imposed? Will we have a system

Speaker: NA
Text: where the company will sell any information?

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent times in the media we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about banks being able to trace

Speaker: NA
Text: debtors. We have seen situations where

Speaker: NA
Text: private eye agencies have been able to get

Speaker: NA
Text: information even through Social Security and

Speaker: NA
Text: other government instrumentalities. It boggles

Speaker: NA
Text: the mind as to what would happen if we had

Speaker: NA
Text: such open access here.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems that the real issue is whether or not

Speaker: NA
Text: the call charge records are still protected by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask that that be clarified; I ask that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament give this question the due priority

Speaker: NA
Text: and the importance that it deserves and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we determine, by regulation, by strengthening

Speaker: NA
Text: section 88 of the present Act or by some

Speaker: NA
Text: other means, exactly who shall have access.

Speaker: NA
Text: Should it be the Federal, State and local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities and statutory authorities? If so,

Speaker: NA
Text: under what conditions? At the moment a

Speaker: NA
Text: policeman could come along and gain access

Speaker: NA
Text: to the records via a search warrant or a

Speaker: NA
Text: subpoena. There ought to be after-access

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring. It has been recommended that we

Speaker: NA
Text: do that when the NCA is able to have war-

Speaker: NA
Text: rants and so on, to ensure that warrants have

Speaker: NA
Text: been issued with good reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely, whilst we do not want to inhibit or

Speaker: NA
Text: restrict law enforcement procedures or needs

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessarily, there have to be rules, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: argue strongly for that. We simply cannot rely

Speaker: NA
Text: on a private enterprise player in the telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications area adopting what Telecom has

Speaker: NA
Text: done in the past. We simply cannot allow

Speaker: NA
Text: such vagueness and looseness in the present

Speaker: NA
Text: law. We need certainty; we need to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that regulations can be imposed which are

Speaker: NA
Text: known to the players and which can be relied

Speaker: NA
Text: upon and enforced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, we need to protect the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of citizens. Any applicant-even an applicant

Speaker: NA
Text: from the law enforcement area-should be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to explain why he or she wants that

Speaker: NA
Text: information. Again I stress that we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the electronic white pages; we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about that coded, recorded, timed

Speaker: NA
Text: call information, be it STD or otherwise.

Speaker: NA
Text: There ought to be controls on who has access.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a need for monitoring and random

Speaker: NA
Text: checking. We need to ensure that this loop-

Speaker: NA
Text: hole which appears to exist is closed. I call on

Speaker: NA
Text: other members of parliament to support me in

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposition.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: Wannon) (11.46 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No.1)

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991-92 and to the appropriations for the land

Speaker: NA
Text: transport area, in particular, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: remind honourable members of the reactions

Speaker: NA
Text: to this year's Budget-a Budget that seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: have sunk without trace almost as quickly as

Speaker: NA
Text: it arrived, no doubt to the relief of the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Kerin). But I think it is time we

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded him of some of the things that were

Speaker: NA
Text: said. For example, the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Road Transport Federation put it

Speaker: NA
Text: very succinctly and' bluntly when he said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'This year's Federal Budget is the worst

Speaker: NA
Text: possible result for the road transport industry'.

Speaker: NA
Text: It could not be any plainer than that. That

Speaker: NA
Text: comment highlights other aspects of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, but, most importantly, I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights the problems which are facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: transport area and, in particular, the road

Speaker: NA
Text: transport area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst going through my notes for my

Speaker: NA
Text: speech in response to last year's Budget, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was amazed to find on looking at that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse that I could just about use it again this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It is 12 months on, and what has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed? What has the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved? The answer is: very little. In one

Speaker: NA
Text: year we have seen almost no progress in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of land transport. But, worse than that,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been thrown into a recession

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the worst we have seen in 60 years; for

Speaker: NA
Text: some people, it is probably the worst they

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen in nearly 100 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I suppose we have to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government some credit. The National Rail

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation agreement has been signed and

Speaker: NA
Text: that does offer some hope. But it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: put into context. The new start-up date for the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Rail Corporation is February 1992-

Speaker: NA
Text: seven months after it was supposed to start

Speaker: NA
Text: operation. No doubt that new agreement is

Speaker: NA
Text: based very much on a hopeful, optimistic

Speaker: NA
Text: approach but, while all of us would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: see it succeed, we also ought to be realistic

Speaker: NA
Text: and ask many questions-which I will come

Speaker: NA
Text: to in a little while.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also looking at the major sector of

Speaker: NA
Text: our land transport, namely, our road transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is facing one of its most difficult periods in

Speaker: NA
Text: many decades. Not only that, this very diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult time is being exacerbated very much by

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the Federal Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed uncertainty to creep in and has in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: created confusion as to what the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: really faces.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is 'little wonder when we look at things

Speaker: NA
Text: such as truck sales that we find the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: sales today at their lowest for 30 years. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeing a level of truck sales in this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: which is somewhat akin to the 1950s. That in

Speaker: NA
Text: itself is nothing short of disastrous for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dealers. It also carries implications for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of our major land transport sector. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: only have we seen the sales drop but also we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen second-hand trucks literally drop in

Speaker: NA
Text: value to one half of their value a year ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: All ,of the problems-particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion-have been brought about by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government still not giving the industry clear

Speaker: NA
Text: direction, despite the fact that in May last

Speaker: NA
Text: year proposals were first published for a

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the whole truck registration scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: for a threatened increase in the charges for

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy trucks. More than 12 months later,

Speaker: NA
Text: operators still do not know what that will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean. Clearly, it is unacceptable, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has much to answer for in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ray that it has treated these operators.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moving specifically to the road funding

Speaker: NA
Text: area, it is worth making it clear that road

Speaker: NA
Text: funding in this Budget has fallen by over 2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Despite what the Minister for Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport ( Mr Robert Brown) might say when

Speaker: NA
Text: he goes around and talks about the land

Speaker: NA
Text: transport budget, we still come back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that road funding has fallen in real terms

Speaker: NA
Text: by $36m. In plain, simple language, that

Speaker: NA
Text: Real Road Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: Year Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Allocation Expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: Change-.

Speaker: NA
Text: Source: Federal Budget Papers

Speaker: NA
Text: means that the great promise that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke) and the MiDister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Land Transport gave before the last election

Speaker: NA
Text: that road funding would not fall in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: already has been broken.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we look at what happens to major roads,

Speaker: NA
Text: we see that there is a fall of 4.4 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: real terms. Funding for arterial roads has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen by nearly 18 per cent in real terms, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: no provision was made to allow the States to

Speaker: NA
Text: find alternative sources of revenue for this

Speaker: NA
Text: fall. If we look at the records, since 1983-84

Speaker: NA
Text: road funding has fallen nearly 20 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: real terms under this Government. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred at the same' time as revenue from

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel tax has increa-ed by over 120 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table

Speaker: NA
Text: which puts this on an annual basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: The table read as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure and Petrol Excise Revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: Actual Fuel Fuel Roads

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise Excise AsA

Text: Revenue Rate Percent

Speaker: NA
Text: (Cents of

Speaker: NA
Text: Per Excise

Speaker: NA
Text: Litre)

Speaker: NA
Text: $m $m $m clL

Text: Note: Non-farm GDP deflator used

Speaker: NA
Text: (aJ

Text: Estimate

Text: First full year of Fraser Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor automatically

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: This table highlights

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what has happened to the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money going to road funding; what has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened to the amount of fuel excise that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been raised in revenue for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth; and what has happened to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fuel excise rate in cents per litre, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has been indexed since 1984. The table shows

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly that the amount of money being

Speaker: NA
Text: spent on roads has steadily declined from a

Speaker: NA
Text: position in 1983-84 of 63c in every dollar of

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel excise to about 23.3c in 1991-92. Clearly,

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has a very shabby record in

Speaker: NA
Text: its treatment of the motorist and, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: the road transport area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Baldwin-That is a very unkind thing

Speaker: NA
Text: to say.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: It may be unkind, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: am putting out the facts for everyone to see.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also seen indecision about where

Speaker: NA
Text: road transport charging is going. We have not

Speaker: NA
Text: only seen the difficulties facing the truck

Speaker: NA
Text: retail area but also seen that the recession that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government told us that we had to have

Speaker: NA
Text: has had a very marked effect on the road

Speaker: NA
Text: transport industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, in the June quarter, because of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government induced recession, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: fall of 9.5 per cent in interstate road freight

Speaker: NA
Text: moved. That followed a similar fall in the

Speaker: NA
Text: March quarter. It is also worth noting that,

Speaker: NA
Text: while fuel excise continues to be indexed, the

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation of road funding ended on 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: this year and there has been no commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Budget to increase it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to go into some detail about

Speaker: NA
Text: what the whole Special Premiers Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on road user charging is supposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to mean. At this stage, we are deeply con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about the impact that the agreement is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to have on rural and remote Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: to calculate real value, 1984-85 prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: road funding to Local Government ($231.8rn).

Speaker: NA
Text: oil, heating oil, airline fuel and kerosene.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bicentennial Road Development Program and first year

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed the excise to the CPr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite repeated calls by the Opposition over

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months for a proper impact study to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done, so far virtually nothing has been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: All that has been promised is a fairly small

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into the effect of increased charges for

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy vehicles on grain and beef in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and the Northern Territory. Interestingly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was put that way, although the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory does not grow wheat.

Speaker: NA
Text: These proposals do not look at the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on people living in rural towns. We believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is something of great concern. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: also of great concern considering the major

Speaker: NA
Text: disparity between the figures quoted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in his address to Grains 2000

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Northern Territory Government in its

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed analysis on the likely impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: increased charging on road users, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: on those living in rural and remote areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many questions to be asked in this

Speaker: NA
Text: whole area and there are many questions

Speaker: NA
Text: which have not been answered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I believe the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: every right and responsibility to continually

Speaker: NA
Text: raise these questions until the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: does give full and frank answers to what these

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of charges mean. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Baldwin) agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11.58 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTICES

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Duffy to present a Bill for an Act to

Text: That the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges the right of self-determination

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Ukraine;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes the declaration of independence and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the declaration is to be put to the Ukrainian

Speaker: NA
Text: people for confirmation in December 1991;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) believes that, subject to such confirmation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ukraine meeting the criteria for independ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent statehood, the international community,

Speaker: NA
Text: including Australia, should support its inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence by diplomatic recognition; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) calls upon the Australian Government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: meantime to support the aspirations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ukrainian people by:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) establishing a consulate in the Ukraine;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) opening a trade office in Kiev; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) ensuring the Ukraine gets its fair share of

Speaker: NA
Text: the training and management scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government is offering to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: Farrow Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 167)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Treasurer, upon notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 22 August 1990:

Speaker: NA
Text: (l) Did Part II of the Financial Corporations Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1974 come into operation on 7 August 1974, the

Speaker: NA
Text: day on which the Act received the Royal Assent.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) On what dates were the three building

Speaker: NA
Text: societies associated with the Farrow Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: registered with the Reserve Bank under Part II.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Did Part III of the Act come into operation

Speaker: NA
Text: on 1 October 1974, the day fixed by Proclamation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and were regulations under Part III made on

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 May 1984 and 27 April 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) On what dates have the three building

Speaker: NA
Text: societies furnished statements to the Reserve Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with the regulations referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: part (3).

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Does Part IV of the Act cover asset ratios,

Speaker: NA
Text: lending policies and interest rates of registered

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) When was consideration last given to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: claiming a date on which Part IV would come into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Parts I, II and V of the Act came into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation on 7 August 1974. The first regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Act, entitled Financial Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: (Initial Returns) Regulations, were signed on

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 October 1974. The Financial Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: (Statistics) Regulations commenced on 27 May

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The following four building societies associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated with Farrow Corporation were entered on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Register of Corporations on the dates shown:

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong Building Society (previously known

Speaker: NA
Text: as Geelong Permanent Building Society Ltd)-23

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: Countrywide Building Society-6 March 1985

Speaker: NA
Text: Pyramid Building Society (previously known

Speaker: NA
Text: as Pyramid Permanent Building Society)-4

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: . Federation Building Society (previously known

Speaker: NA
Text: as Federation Permanent Investment Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Society)-ll September 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation Building Society was subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: absorbed by Pyramid Building Society on 31

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Part III of the Act came into operation on 1

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1974. The Financial Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: (Statistics) Regulations dated 18 May 1984, which

Speaker: NA
Text: repealed the former Regulations of 1976, 1977 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978, are the basis of current statistical forms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Regulations, dated 27 April 1989,

Speaker: NA
Text: deleted the need in the 1984 Regulations to send

Speaker: NA
Text: copies of completed statistical forms to the Statisti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cian.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) All four building societies lodged returns as

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of each month. Federation Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Society ceased lodging returns in late 1989 when

Speaker: NA
Text: it was absorbed by Pyramid Building Society.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Part IV of the Act concerns the regulation

Speaker: NA
Text: and control of the business of financial corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: and covers controls over asset ratios, lending

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and interest rates of financial corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: with total assets in Australia of $5 million or more.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) In 1974 Part IV was seen as providing

Speaker: NA
Text: reserve powers over financial corporations to be

Speaker: NA
Text: used, if necessary, for monetary policy, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: prudential supervision, purposes. The powers were

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly equivalent to those applicable to banks

Speaker: NA
Text: covered in the Banking Act. Monetary policy no

Speaker: NA
Text: , longer relies on these powers in the Banking Act

Speaker: NA
Text: but is exercised through open market operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recourse to Part IV of the Financial Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Act is not, therefore, relevant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural Industries Grants

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 415)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Taylor asked the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1990:

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to grants for rural related research

Speaker: NA
Text: and development made by the Rural Industries

Speaker: NA
Text: Research and Development Corporation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: formerly by the Australian Special Rural Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, (a) how many applications for grants were

Speaker: NA
Text: received for 1990-91, (b) who received grants, (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: what was the amount of each grant and (d) for

Speaker: NA
Text: what project was each grant approved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: 420 new applications for grants and 85

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarship applications were received for 1990-91

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Rural Industries Research and Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation, and formerly by the Australian Special

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural Research Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: Appendix 2 in the Australian Special Rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Council Annual Report 1989-90, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will be forwarded to your office, provides a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: tailed answer to Questions (b), (c) and (d). Please

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the following projects were also supported

Speaker: NA
Text: in this period:

Speaker: NA
Text: Economics of Farm Health

Speaker: NA
Text: and Safety ($60,000)

Speaker: NA
Text: Agroforestry review ($8,000) Bureau of Rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Life Insuran-e Act

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 561)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Treasurer, upon notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 13 February 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Wh,en were the (a) Occidental Life Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: -ompany of Australia Limited and (b) Royal Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Australia Limited registered under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Life Insurance Act 1945.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has each of the companies referred to in part

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) duly (a) supplied the statutory returns and other

Speaker: NA
Text: additional information required by the Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Superannuation Commission and (b) complied

Speaker: NA
Text: with the guidelines issued, pending a review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, by the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) On what date and by what process did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Life Insurance Australia Limited change its

Speaker: NA
Text: name to Regal Life Insurance Limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Wh,at progress has been made with the

Speaker: NA
Text: complete review of the Act's outdated provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the Commission drew attention in its

Speaker: NA
Text: report for 1989-90.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) (a) Occidental Life Insurance Company of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Limited was registered under the Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Act 1945 on 16 September 1974.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Royal Globe Life Assurance Company

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited was registered under the Life Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1945 on 3 May 1960. The company's registra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was changed to Royal Life Insurance Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited on 31 March 1982 and was changed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Regal Life Insurance Limited on 3 August 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Prior to 30 September 1990, both companies

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied all required statutory returns and other

Speaker: NA
Text: information, and complied with relevant guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: issued by the Insurance and Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. Subsequent to 24 October 1990, the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies have been under investigation or subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to the control of a Judicial Manager. The

Speaker: NA
Text: information being provided by them since then has

Speaker: NA
Text: included copies of the Judicial Manager's reports,

Speaker: NA
Text: regular updates on developments, and other

Speaker: NA
Text: information sought by the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Royal Globe Life Assurance Company

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited was incorporated in Victoria under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies Act 1958 on 24 March 1960. The

Speaker: NA
Text: NSW Ag Dept

Speaker: NA
Text: company's name was changed to Royal Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Australia Limited on 9 February 1982

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources. and was again changed under the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies (Victoria) Code to Regal Life Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited on 29 June 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) A number of measures arising out of a review

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Life Insurance Act 1945 were recently

Speaker: NA
Text: passed by the House of Representatives and are

Speaker: NA
Text: now before the Senate. The measures include:

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase in the minimum capital require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to $10 million from the current $2 million,

Speaker: NA
Text: coupled with more stringent operational require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments regarding the maintenance of capital;

Speaker: NA
Text: measures to enable pre-vetting of changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership or control of Ii-e insurance companies,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to disqualify a person who has been bank-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupt, or convicted of an offence relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance law or dishonest conduct, from acting

Speaker: NA
Text: as a director or principal officer of a company;

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustments to the powers of the Commission-

Speaker: NA
Text: er to facilitate formal investigation processes and

Speaker: NA
Text: a reduction in the period allowed for companies

Speaker: NA
Text: to submit annual financial statements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The major issues which continue to be under

Speaker: NA
Text: review relate to the level of solvency margin that

Speaker: NA
Text: is appropriate to be maintained in statutory funds

Speaker: NA
Text: and associated actuarial and technical matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several submissions, including major submissions

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Life Insurance Federatioh of Australia, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: received. i Work in connection with the review,

Speaker: NA
Text: including a survey of United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canadian legislation, is proceeding in the Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Superannuation Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the complex actuarial and technical issues

Speaker: NA
Text: involved make it pifficult to forecast a precise date

Speaker: NA
Text: for completion of the review, it is expected that the

Speaker: NA
Text: review will be completed early next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnamese Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 667)

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has provision been made for immigration to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia of those Vietnamese who worked for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forces during the Vietnam War.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has information been collected to identify

Speaker: NA
Text: how many are still in Vietnam and who would

Speaker: NA
Text: migrate to Australia if they had the opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Have any applications from persons such as

Speaker: NA
Text: those referred to in part (2) been received by

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration officials; if so, how many.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Are the applicants referred to in part (3) eli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gible under the Special Humanitarian Program as

Speaker: NA
Text: former allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hand-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) There are no special provisions in place for

Speaker: NA
Text: the migration of former employees of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Forces. Since 1988, when revised pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures for emigration were agreed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnamese authorities, the criteria for migration

Speaker: NA
Text: from Vietnam have been essentially the same as

Speaker: NA
Text: those applying to any other country.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) In 1984 a list was compiled of Indochinese

Speaker: NA
Text: with claimed links with Australia requesting

Speaker: NA
Text: resettlement. 1Welve of these claimed former

Speaker: NA
Text: employment with the Australian forces (one of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom however had stronger ties with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States).

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Australian Embassy in Bangkok (respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for most of the processing of Vietnamese

Speaker: NA
Text: migration applications) advises that they are aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of one letter requesting migration advice from a

Speaker: NA
Text: person claiming to be a former employee of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian armed forces, but have not received any

Speaker: NA
Text: actual migration applications. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Embassy in Hanoi has had three enquiries but no

Speaker: NA
Text: applications. Such people may have migrated under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Vietnam Migration Procedures in the past but

Speaker: NA
Text: cases cannot be separately identified on this basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Applications for entry under the in-country

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Humanitarian Program are normally only

Speaker: NA
Text: 90nsidered from designated countries: Vietnam is

Speaker: NA
Text: not one of these. Applications from persons in non-

Speaker: NA
Text: designated countries are considered only where

Speaker: NA
Text: exceptional and compelling circumstances exist,

Speaker: NA
Text: and are considered on their merits. Links with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are a consideration in claims to resettle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under this program.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Housing Strategy: Cost

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 788)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing and Community Services, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 7 May 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What is the total cost of the National Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Strategy and related projects, including current

Speaker: NA
Text: and prospective research into the perceived problem

Speaker: NA
Text: of locational disadvantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What sum will be spent on research into

Speaker: NA
Text: locational disadvantage.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The estimated cost of the National Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategy for 1990-91 was $1,467,820, and for 1991-

Speaker: NA
Text: 92 is $1,390,000. This does not include the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: staff from my Department who have assisted, and

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to assist, with research and development

Speaker: NA
Text: of particular issues as required.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: National Health Strategy Review

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 822)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Bob Woods asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health, Housing and Community Services,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 15 May 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Will the national health strategy review have

Speaker: NA
Text: far-reaching implications for (a) the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: profession and (b) the private health industry;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is either the medical profession or the private

Speaker: NA
Text: health insurance industry represented on the

Speaker: NA
Text: advisory body to the review; if not, why not.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) (a) and (b) The answer to this question will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be known until the Director of the Strategy has

Speaker: NA
Text: reported progressively to the Government on each

Speaker: NA
Text: of the terms of reference and the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: both considered those reports and decided what

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, if any, are appropriate.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) No. While the membership of the Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee to the National Health Strategy includes

Speaker: NA
Text: eminent members of the medical profession, they

Speaker: NA
Text: are not formal representatives of the profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Advisory Committee was established to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring together individuals with a diverse range of

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas and experience. In particular, Ms Macklin

Speaker: NA
Text: was seeking ideas and opinions unfettered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: constraints which inevitably apply to office holders

Speaker: NA
Text: representing individual organisations. The Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee was not established as a fonnal consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation process.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am advised that consultation has been, and will

Speaker: NA
Text: be, undertaken as a continuous process throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the Strategy. The consultants

Speaker: NA
Text: with responsibility for individual issues are expect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to consult with relevant groups as a routine

Speaker: NA
Text: activity; as issues and background papers are

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively released there will be further oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity for interest groups and individuals to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: comments and views; and in some cases there may

Speaker: NA
Text: be a need for further consultation prior to Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: Macklin providing advice to the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, all interest groups have an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to present their views during any stage and

Speaker: NA
Text: on any related issue of the development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Health Strategy Review

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 823)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Bob Woods asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health, Housing and Community Services,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 15 May 1991:

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: their specific role, (b) what are their names and

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications, (c) on what basis were they selected

Speaker: NA
Text: and (d) what remuneration does each receive.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a), (b) and (c) There are no appointed advisers

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the development of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Strategy apart from those persons included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the answer to Question 821 and the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Advisory Committee, whose names and qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations are listed below and whose role is covered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the answer to Question 822.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr John Stewart Deeble, BCom PhD

Speaker: NA
Text: DipHospAdmin(NSW).

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Martin Ferguson, BEe(Hons).

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor John Davis Hamilton, MB(Hons)

Speaker: NA
Text: BS(Hons) FRCP(Lon) FRCP(C).

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Maurice M (Greg) Herring, MBBS

Speaker: NA
Text: DAvMed(Lon) FACOM MHP(NSW) FRACMA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Kerin O'Dea, BSc PhD.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Judith Parker, RN BA(Hons) PhD.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor David Penington, BM BCh DM

Speaker: NA
Text: FRCP(Lon) FRACP FRCPA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Frederick Bryce Phillips, MB BS FAMA.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Christopher George Scarf, MB BS FRACMA

Speaker: NA
Text: MHA(NSW).

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Dick Scotton, BA BEe PhD.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Louise Sylvan, BA MPA(Canada).

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) Nil.
