Text: Industry Commission: Staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 828)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones asked the Treasurer, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 15 May 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What (a) total number of staff and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: number of professional staff, by discipline, were

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by the Industry Commission and its

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor, the Industries Assistance Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: in each financial year since 1985-86.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many professional staff currently

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by the Industry Commission have worked

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the Australian Public Service for longer

Speaker: NA
Text: than two years and in what areas of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: and what locations were they employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How many professional staff currently

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by the Industry Commission have worked

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry (a) in general and (b) within manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing, and in what industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) How many professional staff currently

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by the Industry Commission hold (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: PhDs and (b) Masters' degrees and in what disci-

Speaker: NA
Text: plines and from which universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I (5) How many professional staff employed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission are (a) Keynesians or (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: i

Speaker: NA
Text: interventionists.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) When was the last Keynesian or intervention-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist recruited by the Industry Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Is a commitment to Keynesianism an impedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to being employed by the Industry Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) Has employment of professional staff whose

Speaker: NA
Text: views differ from the prevailing economic ortho-

Speaker: NA
Text: doxy been considered so that various options are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) Does any Commissioner support fostering a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of economic philosophies within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) Is the Industry Commission familiar with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Socratic method of argument; if so, (a) is it used at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission or (b) are any differences express-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed within the Commission purely on matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: detail and presentation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) (a) Table 1 provides details of staff employed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Industry Commission under the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Professional staff are defined as staff with

Speaker: NA
Text: tertiary qualifications. Of the 230 staff at 22 May

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991, 148 have been awarded at least one degree.

Speaker: NA
Text: A total of 175 degrees or post graduate diplomas

Speaker: NA
Text: have been awarded to these staff. Details of these

Speaker: NA
Text: awards are set out in Table 2. Information for

Speaker: NA
Text: previous years is not available.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Thirty-nine professional staff have been

Speaker: NA
Text: employed outside the Australian Public Service for

Speaker: NA
Text: a cumulative period longer than two years. Details

Speaker: NA
Text: are provided in Table 3.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) (a) Of the professional staff employed, 35

Speaker: NA
Text: have previous experience of two years or more in

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in general. Table 4 provides details.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Of the professional staff, 5 have had experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in manufacturing.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) (a) and (b) Eight professional staff of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission hold a PhD; 3 of these do not hold a

Speaker: NA
Text: Masters' degree. Twenty-seven professional staff

Speaker: NA
Text: collectively hold 30 Masters' degrees. Details are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in Table 5.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) The Industry Commission records no

Speaker: NA
Text: information with which to answer this question. It

Speaker: NA
Text: recruits on merit.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) Commissioners seek to have available to

Speaker: NA
Text: them a range of views gathered from staff, through

Speaker: NA
Text: the public inquiry process and other consultants.

Speaker: NA
Text: As at 30 June 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: Total Staff 326

Speaker: NA
Text: Notes: Figures for 1990-91 are for the period

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission's responses to the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance's Stafftng Statistics Surveys.

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) The Industry Commission Act 1990 provides

Speaker: NA
Text: for the conduct of inquiries by the Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commission is required to publicise inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: and hold hearings. Generally, the Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: produces an issues paper to stimulate discussion,

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks written submissions from interested parties,

Speaker: NA
Text: holds public hearings and produces a draft report

Speaker: NA
Text: for comment and discussion before presenting a

Speaker: NA
Text: final report to the Government. The essence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission's approach is dialectic and open. See

Speaker: NA
Text: also the answer to question (9).

Speaker: NA
Text: Dja Dja Wrung Aboriginal Cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Association Funding

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 877)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Wooldridge asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What sum of federal funds was (a) allocated

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) distributed to the Dja Dja Wrung Aborig-

Speaker: NA
Text: inal Cultural Association in Bendigo in (a) 1989-90

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) On what basis and under what criteria were

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds allocated.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) For what purposes were the funds intended.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Have the funds been adequately acquitted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tickner-The Aboriginal and Torres

Speaker: NA
Text: Strait Islander Commission has provided me

Speaker: NA
Text: with the following information in response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission (ATSIC) did not provide funds to an

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation entitled Dja Dja Wrung Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Cultural Association. ATSIC did, however, (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: allocate and (b) distribute funds to the Bendigo Dja

Speaker: NA
Text: Dja Wrung Aboriginal Association Inc. amounting

Speaker: NA
Text: to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Bendigo Dja Dja Wrung Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Association Inc is an Aboriginal co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible to receive funding under the Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no other such co-operative servicing

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals in Bendigo or surrounding district. The

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria for the allocation of funds are set out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: current ATSIC Corporate Plan, Program 2, Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Advancement.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Association is funded to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Development support Program to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal community of Bendigo and district. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Association also has an internal training program

Speaker: NA
Text: and a rental assistance program. In addition, funds

Speaker: NA
Text: were provided to enable the Association to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: an Economic Development Conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) All funds provided to the Association in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989-90 Financial Year have been acquitted. Funds

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in the 1990-91 Financial Year are not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: due for acquittal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cultural Objects: Control

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 881)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 4 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Did a study group of experts prepare a

Speaker: NA
Text: Prelimin-y Draft UNIDROIT Convention on

Speaker: NA
Text: Stolen or Illegally Exported Cultural Objects during

Speaker: NA
Text: three sessions between 1988 and 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Did Australia participate in any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sessions of the study group of experts.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Does the preliminary draft convention

Speaker: NA
Text: amplify and clarify the 1970 UNESCO Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of

Speaker: NA
Text: Cultural Property, to which Australia became a

Speaker: NA
Text: party on 30 October 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Did the Australian member of the Governing

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of UNIDROIT attend the Council meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: in Rome between 21 and 24 May 1991 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIDROIT meeting to discuss the Principles for

Speaker: NA
Text: International Commercial Contracts in Rome

Speaker: NA
Text: between 27 and 31 May 1991 but not the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIDROIT meeting of governmental experts on

Speaker: NA
Text: the preliminary draft convention in Rome between

Speaker: NA
Text: 6 and 10 May 1991; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Which other member states of UNIDROIT

Speaker: NA
Text: participated in the meetings in Rome in May 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Does UNIDROIT expect to hold a further

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of governmental experts on the preliminary

Speaker: NA
Text: draft convention in February or March 1992; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: will Australia participate. .

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Participation in the UNIDROIT study group

Speaker: NA
Text: of experts was in an individual, rather than repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentative, capacity. Dr L Prott, then of the Law

Speaker: NA
Text: Faculty of the University of Sydney, attended the

Speaker: NA
Text: sessions in her personal capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The preliminary draft convention is intended

Speaker: NA
Text: to clarify and improve the application of Article

Speaker: NA
Text: 7(b)(ii) of the UNESCO Convention on the Means

Speaker: NA
Text: of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import,

Speaker: NA
Text: Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Property.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Session of the Governing Council of UNIDROIT

Speaker: NA
Text: in Rome from 21-24 May 1991 as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brazil was recently invited to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIDROIT Working Group on Principles for

Speaker: NA
Text: International Commercial Contracts in his personal

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity and attended the 15th meeting in Rome

Speaker: NA
Text: from 27-31 May 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 6 to 10 May 1991 UNIDROIT meeting on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Preliminary Draft Convention on Stolen or

Speaker: NA
Text: Illegally Exported Cultural Objects was one for

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental experts. Accordingly, invitations were

Speaker: NA
Text: not issued to experts in their personal capacities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of Australian representation by a

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental expert was considered by my Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in conjunction with the Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. In the light of other priorities for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental representation at international meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, and having regard to budgetary considerations,

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision was made not to send a governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: expert to that meeting.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Members of the Governing Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIDROIT are elected by reason of their personal

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise and standing and not as representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: Member States. All members of the Governing

Speaker: NA
Text: Council were represented either personally or by

Speaker: NA
Text: substitutes at the 70th Session held on 21-24 May

Speaker: NA
Text: The fifteenth session of the UNIDROIT Working

Speaker: NA
Text: Group on Principles for International Commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: Contracts, held on 27-31 May 1991, was attended

Speaker: NA
Text: by experts in their personal capacities not as

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of Member States. Accordingly, no

Speaker: NA
Text: Member States of UNIDROIT attended this

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first session of the Committee of Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental Experts on the International Protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: Cultural Property, held on 6-10 May 1991, was

Speaker: NA
Text: attended by representatives of 41 Member States of

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIDROIT: Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Canada,

Speaker: NA
Text: China, Colombia, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Egypt,

Speaker: NA
Text: Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Holy See,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hungary, India, Iran, Ireland, Italy, Mexico,

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Pakistan, Poland,

Speaker: NA
Text: Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Senegal, South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Tunisia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Thrkey, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, United States of America, Uruguay,

Speaker: NA
Text: Venezuela and Yugoslavia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) A second session of the UNIDROIT Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee of Governmental Experts on the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection of Cultural Property is expected to be

Speaker: NA
Text: held in early 1992, with the possibility of a third

Speaker: NA
Text: session being held later in 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of Australian representation at the

Speaker: NA
Text: next meeting will be considered by my Department

Speaker: NA
Text: in conjunction with the Department of the Arts,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese Currency: Use in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 932)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sharp asked the Treasurer, upOn notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 20 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Do some Japanese-owned businesses in Cairns,

Speaker: NA
Text: Qld, accept only Japanese currency and refuse to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept Australian currency; if so, (a) is the practice

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibited and (b) what action will he take to end

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that there have been media reports

Speaker: NA
Text: that some businesses in Cairns are apparently only

Speaker: NA
Text: accepting payment in Japanese yen and refusing to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept Australian currency. I am unaware, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: if these businesses are Japanese-owned.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to the specific questions you raised regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) There is nothing in the Currency Act 1965

Speaker: NA
Text: that would preclude a business or individual acting

Speaker: NA
Text: in the manner described. While Section 16(1) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Currency Act 1965 and Section 36(1) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank Act 1959 give legal tender status to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian coins and notes, this does not mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: they necessarily have to be accepted. Legal tender

Speaker: NA
Text: status is relevant only in relation to the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: an existing debt where a method of payment is not

Speaker: NA
Text: specified in the terms of an arrangement giving rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to that debt. It would have no application where a

Speaker: NA
Text: person merely offered an amount of money in

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange for goods to be provided or services to be

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied. Consistent with this, there is no legal

Speaker: NA
Text: provision that would prevent a business from

Speaker: NA
Text: stipulating that payment must be made in Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: yen.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) There has been no restrictions on the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign currency in Australia, nor on the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dollar outside Australia, since exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade UnionfPurpose

Speaker: NA
Text: to APHEDA for return of exiles and refugees to South Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: 45,000* to APHEDA for contribution towards costs of ANC donor

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: 411,000 to APHEDA Health Education for Kanak Women in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Caledonia

Speaker: NA
Text: for South Mricans funds-SAPSA

Speaker: NA
Text: controls were removed when the dollar was floated

Speaker: NA
Text: Shops in 1983.. Any business in Australia which declines

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept Australian currency would appear,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, to be depriving itself of potential custom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and thereby restricting its own commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade: Staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 935)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industry, Technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce? upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is there a delay in filling the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: Managing Director, Austrade; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is he able to say whether (a) the position

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in part (1) will be readvertised and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr W Ferris will be an applicant.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Will the number of staff in Austrade be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced; if so, (a) by what number and (b) will that

Speaker: NA
Text: number include (i) inoperative staff, (ii) staff lost

Speaker: NA
Text: through natural attrition and (iii) overseas locally

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Are some of the senior management staff

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised in the MCKinsey review involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: placing staff into a new structure for Austrade.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What sum has been spent on implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the MCKinsey review and on

Speaker: NA
Text: the associated task force.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Was $10 000 allocated to the task force

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in part (5); if so, was this sum inad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equate and where will additional funds be obtained.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) What is the state of consultation and develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of associated procedures with unions affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the restructuring of Austrade.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) Is implementation of the recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the MCKinsey review being hastened solely because

Speaker: NA
Text: elections to convert from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Scheme to the Public Sector

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Scheme must be made by 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991; if so, (a) what efforts did Austrade make to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the election date for Austrade staff and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: was tenure offered to certain Austrade staff; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: by what process.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) Does the position of Deputy Managing

Speaker: NA
Text: Director appear in the structure recommended by

Speaker: NA
Text: the MCKinsey review; if not, what is the status of

Speaker: NA
Text: the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) Did the MCKinsey review propose that a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of positions remain temporarily located in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra; if'so, what is the status of the affected

Speaker: NA
Text: staff, particularly with respect to redundancy and

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) Has Austrade developed an effective re-

Speaker: NA
Text: deployment and training program for staff affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by restructuring.

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) What (a) number of SES positions and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation for SES salaries in Austrade (i) existed

Speaker: NA
Text: before the MCKinsey review and (ii) will there be

Speaker: NA
Text: after the review's recommendations are implement-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) How many general manager positions in

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade were filled by applicants from (a) outside

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) within the public sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) From what Australian Public Service levels

Speaker: NA
Text: and salary ranges were the applicants referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: part (13)(b) promoted.

Speaker: NA
Text: (15) How many highly skilled staff will Austrade

Speaker: NA
Text: lose as a result of relocation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-The Minister for Industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology and Commerce has provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: following answer. to the honourable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The appointment of Mr Ralph Evans as

Speaker: NA
Text: Managing Director of Austrade was announced' on

Speaker: NA
Text: 9 July 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) See answer to (1).

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) It is estimated that by the time staff separathe

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are completed in mid-1992, the net reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: will be 155.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) (i) No. (ii) Yes. (iii) No.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) No members of senior management were

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the MCKinsey review.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) and (6) The sum spent on implementing the

Speaker: NA
Text: MCKinsey review recommendations was $1.046

Speaker: NA
Text: million, arising from salaries of Austrade staff

Speaker: NA
Text: working on implementation tasks, travel costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: recruitment of the Managing Director and general

Speaker: NA
Text: managers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Costs of relocation and redundancy payments are

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet finalised. There was no specific allocation

Speaker: NA
Text: of $10,000 to a task force.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Appropriate consultation as set out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant Award has occurred, and is continuing to

Speaker: NA
Text: occur, with staff associations on general retrench-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment principles, structure, staffmg, facilities and

Speaker: NA
Text: review.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) Implementation of the MCKinsey review

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations was not hastened solely because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the superannuation question.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) In response to a formal approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Retirement Benefits Office, Austrade was advised

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was not possible for an extension to be given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the election date.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Structural recommendations flowing from the

Speaker: NA
Text: :MCKinsey review were presented for endorsement

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Chairman and the Acting Managing Director

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of May 1991. The proposals were then

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the Staff Associations in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the consultative process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Restaffing of the new structure commenced in

Speaker: NA
Text: the week prior to 30 June and is continuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senior Placement Teams were appointed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman and the Acting Managing Director. These

Speaker: NA
Text: teams reviewed the relative merits of the members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the staff in the Senior Management Service and

Speaker: NA
Text: provided recommendations to the Chairman and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Managing Director.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other staff whose functions remained substantial-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly unchanged in the new structure were notified of

Speaker: NA
Text: their transfer to the new structure prior to 30 June.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) No. Appointment to the position of Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Managing Director is at the discretion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. The MCKinsey Review indicated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of Deputy Managing Director would be

Speaker: NA
Text: assigned one of the key management roles within

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation. No decision has been taken on the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) Yes. The scheme includes assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: staff for, and their redeployment to, positions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: new structure, change management and personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: development. In addition staff have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: access to professional outplacement advice, finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial planning advice and general counselling ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices.

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) (a) (i) 86, excluding staff of the Export

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance & Insurance Corporation (EPIC).

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) As at 13 September 1991,77 SES positions

Speaker: NA
Text: exist, excluding staff of the Export Finance &

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Corporation (EFIC).

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) (i) $5.88 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) $5.46 million (estimated).

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) Successful applicants were appointed for a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of 3-5 years from the following Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service levels and salary ranges:

Speaker: NA
Text: (15) Unknown at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade: Engagement of Consultants

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 946)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Downer asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industry, Technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce, upon notice, on 21 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What sum did Austrade spend in engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: Egon Zehnder International management consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tants to recruit ten new general managers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What sum did Austrade spend in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: that referred to in part (1) in recruiting the new

Speaker: NA
Text: general managers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What salary will each of the new general

Speaker: NA
Text: managers receive.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Has Austrade engaged Robert Dempsey

Speaker: NA
Text: public relations consultants since 1989;

Speaker: NA
Text: what capacity and (b) what sum was paid to Robert

Speaker: NA
Text: Dempsey (i) since 1989 and (ii) on average per

Speaker: NA
Text: month.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Does Austrade employ (a) about 15 qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: journalists in its Public Affairs Unit and (b) a firm

Speaker: NA
Text: of public relations consultants; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Will any journalists employed by Austrade be

Speaker: NA
Text: made redundant during the restructuring of

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade; if so, (a) how many journalists, (b) how

Speaker: NA
Text: much of the Public Affairs Unit's work will be

Speaker: NA
Text: contracted out and (c) what will be the resulting (i)

Speaker: NA
Text: cost and (ii) saving.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-The Minister for Industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology and Commerce has provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: following answer to the honourable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Austrade has incurred $213,800 in profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional fees, airfares and out of pocket expenses in

Speaker: NA
Text: engaging Egon Zehnder International management

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants to recruit ten new general managers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Austrade has also spent $115,100 on airfares,

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation and advertising costs in recruiting

Speaker: NA
Text: and interviewing candidates for the new general

Speaker: NA
Text: manager positions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Robert Dempsey Consultants was engaged to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the following services advice to Manager

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications on continuing the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrade's Communications programs to review

Speaker: NA
Text: and plan overall Communications programs speech

Speaker: NA
Text: writing support and advice for the Chairperson and

Speaker: NA
Text: Managing Director of Austrade other activities as

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed with Manager Communications.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) (a) As at 9 August 1991 Austrade employed

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 qualified journalists.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Yes. The public relations consultants were

Speaker: NA
Text: employed to provide strategic advice as distinct

Speaker: NA
Text: from the day-to-day journalistic services provided

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Austrade journalists.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Potentially, yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Up to 5 may be made redundant.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Present plans are for editorial services and

Speaker: NA
Text: some artwork services to be contracted out.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) (i) The cost is dependent upon the volume of

Speaker: NA
Text: publications to be completed in 1991/92 which has

Speaker: NA
Text: yet to be determined following on changes arising

Speaker: NA
Text: if so, (a) in from the review of Austrade.

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) Similarly, savings have yet to be deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined; preliminary assessments indicate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: current average cost of publication could be

Speaker: NA
Text: halved under the new arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 948)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ford asked the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many Defence houses are there in

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston North, Vic., (a) in total and (b) which are

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by the Department of Defence and how

Speaker: NA
Text: many are occupied in each case.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What structural, ventilation and heating

Speaker: NA
Text: problems: exist in the occupied houses referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: in part (1) and what action will be taken to rectify

Speaker: NA
Text: those problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What action will be taken to rectify structur-

Speaker: NA
Text: al, ventilation and heating problems in the unoccu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pied houses referred to in part (1) after restructur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) has

Speaker: NA
Text: been completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Has the rental for a Defence house in

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston North increased from $123 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: to $170 per week for a person who has recently left

Speaker: NA
Text: the ADF.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bilney-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Defence Housing Authority manages 92

Speaker: NA
Text: houses in Frankston North, 'of which it owns 2

Speaker: NA
Text: houses and leases 2 from private owners, all 4 of

Speaker: NA
Text: which are occupied. The remaining 88 houses are

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by the Victorian Ministry of Housing; of

Speaker: NA
Text: which:

Speaker: NA
Text: 49 have been identified as unsuitable for

Speaker: NA
Text: retention and are leased to the private sector

Speaker: NA
Text: pending their disposal-3 of these are vacant

Speaker: NA
Text: 39 houses are made available to Service

Speaker: NA
Text: families-l of these is vacant.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) To the Authority's knowledge, none has

Speaker: NA
Text: significant structural problems and indeed no such

Speaker: NA
Text: problems have been advised by tenants; all have

Speaker: NA
Text: gas heating which is maintained in working order;

Speaker: NA
Text: and all are provided with fixed ventilation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Any problems brought to the Authority's

Speaker: NA
Text: notice will be addressed immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hilton Bombing

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 949)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mack asked the Attorney-General, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 21 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Following the quashing of the conviction of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Timothy Anderson for the Hilton bombing, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government now urge the NSW Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to open a comprehensive inquiry into the Hilton

Speaker: NA
Text: bombing.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Will the federal Government fully cooperate

Speaker: NA
Text: with any inquiry opened by the NSW Government

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Hilton bombing.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Why has the Government never opened a

Speaker: NA
Text: public inquiry to determine (a) why the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: federal agencies failed to (i) prevent the Hilton

Speaker: NA
Text: bombing and (ii) find the perpetrators and (b) the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature and extent of those agencies' involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: in any investigations concerning Mr Anderson.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Will the Government open a full and open

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into the Hilton bombing and all matters

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning it connected with the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and its agencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What were the roles of: (a) the Australian Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity Intelligence Organization (ASIO), (b) ASIO's

Speaker: NA
Text: auxiliary services, including the VIP Protection

Speaker: NA
Text: Unit, (c) the Australian Federal Police (AFP), (d)

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Defence Force (ADF), (e) the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Police and (t) the Special Branch of the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Police in ensuring the security of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Meeting (CHOGRM) at the Sydney Hilton in 1978.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) In what manner were the security operations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the federal and NSW agencies and personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in part (5) coordinated.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Was an officer placed in charge of security

Speaker: NA
Text: operations overall; if so, what was the officer's

Speaker: NA
Text: name.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) If direction for security operations was given

Speaker: NA
Text: jointly by federal and State officers, what were the

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) names and (b) the respective responsibilities of

Speaker: NA
Text: those officers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) What were the responsibilities of (a) Mr Don

Speaker: NA
Text: Marshall; (b) Superintendent Reginald Douglas and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Inspector Perrin.

Speaker: NA
Text: (lO) Was Mr Marshall (a) in charge of ASIO's

Speaker: NA
Text: VIP Protection Unit at the time of the Hilton

Speaker: NA
Text: bombing, (b) dismissed after the explosion, (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: reinstated soon after, and (d) later promoted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of Deputy Director of ASIO; if so, why

Speaker: NA
Text: was he dismissed, reinstated and promoted.

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) Is it a fact that neither Mr Marshall nor

Speaker: NA
Text: Superintendent Douglas gave evidence before (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1982 coronial inquiry in Sydney into the Hilton

Speaker: NA
Text: bombing and (b) any of the subsequent court

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings concerned with the event.

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) Why did ASIO's VIP Protection Unit, the

Speaker: NA
Text: AFP, the ADF, and the overseas-trained anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorist personnel of the NSW Police fail to detect

Speaker: NA
Text: the bomb.

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) Were sniffer dogs used; if not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) Was the bin in which the bomb had been

Speaker: NA
Text: placed searched in accordance with established

Speaker: NA
Text: security procedures; if not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (15) Did certain police officers over a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: three days direct that the garbage bin not be

Speaker: NA
Text: emptied; if so, (a) who gave the direction and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (16) Were any security personnel who were

Speaker: NA
Text: rostered for duty at the Hilton about the time of the

Speaker: NA
Text: explosion not present at the time; if so, (a) who

Speaker: NA
Text: were they and (b) why were they not present.

Speaker: NA
Text: (17) What are the names of the security person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel who were on duty at or near the Hilton (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: before, (b) during and (c) after the explosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: (18) Did ASIO personnel work with NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Branch personnel on security for the

Speaker: NA
Text: CHOGRM conference; if so, who were the person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel from each organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (19) Was the Special Air Services involved with

Speaker: NA
Text: the security operation (a) before, (b) during or (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: after the explosion; if so, what was the nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: that involvement.

Speaker: NA
Text: (20) Were security forces carrying out surveil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lance in the vicinity of the Hilton from a red or

Speaker: NA
Text: orange Torana sedan with registration number

Speaker: NA
Text: HXS-496 immediately before the explosion; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) who were the personnel, (b) did they give

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence at the 1982 coronial inquiry or any

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent court hearing concerning the event; if

Speaker: NA
Text: not, why not and (c) will he endeavour to make

Speaker: NA
Text: them available for any future inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: (21) Has his attention been drawn to statements

Speaker: NA
Text: made to persons including Mr Terry Griffiths, a

Speaker: NA
Text: former NSW Police officer injured by the explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary to former Senator Mason, to the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: that the ASIO personnel were involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hilton bombing; if so, have the statements been

Speaker: NA
Text: investigated; and if so, (a) when, (b) by whom, (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: with what result and (d) what action was taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: (22) Were more than 20 ASIO personnel trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred within Australia and abroad after the Hilton

Speaker: NA
Text: bombing; if so, (a) how many, (b) what are their

Speaker: NA
Text: names, (c) where were they transferred and (d)

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (23) Was ASIO's VIP Protection Unit required

Speaker: NA
Text: to account for its failure to locate the bomb and to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent its detonation; if so, (a) what account did

Speaker: NA
Text: it give and (b) what action was taken in response.

Speaker: NA
Text: (24) Did ASIO at any time assist in the investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations, arrest or convictions of Mr Anderson; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) what assistance did they provide, (b) when was

Speaker: NA
Text: it provided and (c) to whom was it provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: (25) Did ASIO supply marijuana to members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ananda Marga in return for information.

Speaker: NA
Text: (26) Was Mr Richard Seary an agent or an

Speaker: NA
Text: informant of ASIO.

Speaker: NA
Text: (27) Was ASIO involved in with the late Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: John Melton, a student at the University of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: (28) Did ASIO have any knowledge of or

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with (a) explosives found in a locker

Speaker: NA
Text: held in the surname of Melton at the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and (b) the circumstances in

Speaker: NA
Text: which those explosives and a section of a news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper found with them were destroyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (29) Was Mr Melton ever employed as an agent

Speaker: NA
Text: or informant, or was he involved with, the Special

Speaker: NA
Text: Branch or any other branch of the NSW Police.

Speaker: NA
Text: (30) Are ASIO personnel trained in the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: explosives.

Speaker: NA
Text: (31) Have ASIO personnel trained (a) narcotics

Speaker: NA
Text: agents or (b) personnel of other agencies in the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of explosives.

Speaker: NA
Text: (32) Has Mi Griffiths ever been investigated or

Speaker: NA
Text: placed under surveillance by ASIO; if so, (a) when

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (33) Has ASIO ever tapped Mr Griffiths's

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone; if so, (a) when and (b) why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (34) Did ASIO remove Mr Griffiths's file from

Speaker: NA
Text: his doctor's premises in Macquarie Street, Sydney,

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Text: In answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question, I am advised as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1), (2) and (3) In the years following the events

Speaker: NA
Text: which are the subject of the honourable Member's

Speaker: NA
Text: question, procedures have been reviewed extensive-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly, particularly in the light of the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Report of the Protective Security Review

Speaker: NA
Text: which Mr Justice Hope sent to the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: on 15 May 1979. The report is on the public

Speaker: NA
Text: record. While the Commonwealth had a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for and interest in the safety of the

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting delegates at the 1978 CHOGRM, the bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: explosion outside the Hilton Hotel in Sydney in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact involved offences against the laws of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. Therefore, it is for that State and not

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to decide whether another

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry might be warranted. If the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government were to decide that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a further inquiry, the Commonwealth would, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, co-operate fully.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) No) for the reasons outlined immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: above.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) (a) ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: ASIO provided infonnation to the Protective

Speaker: NA
Text: Services Co-ordination Centre (PSCC), including

Speaker: NA
Text: threat assessments, daily situation reports, personal

Speaker: NA
Text: security checks as requested by PSCC and audio

Speaker: NA
Text: counter-measure tests conducted at the Hilton prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to the CHOGRM for the purposes of infonnation

Speaker: NA
Text: security. In 1978 PSCC was a division of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Administrative Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) ASIO:S auxiliary services, including the VIP

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection Unit

Speaker: NA
Text: No such services or units have been identified.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable Member may be referring to the

Speaker: NA
Text: VIP Protection Unit within the PSCC which in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978 was a division of the Department of Adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative Services. At that time the role of the PSCC

Speaker: NA
Text: included the assessment of intelligence from ASIO

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth Police and the general co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordination of security planning for CHOGRM.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) The AFP

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP did not exist in 1978. Its predecessor,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Police, were essentially respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for the close personal protection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting Heads of Government as they moved

Speaker: NA
Text: around Sydney and security within specified areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Hilton Hotel.

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) The ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: The ADF had no specific role in the CHOGRM

Speaker: NA
Text: security arrangements before the explosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the explosion on 13 February 1978, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF helped the NSW Police secure the road and

Speaker: NA
Text: rail routes to Bowral. At the last moment it was

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to ferry the visiting dignitaries in helicop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters which the ADF provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) The NSW Police

Speaker: NA
Text: The NSW Police were responsible for security

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the Hilton Hotel, and areas inside the hotel,

Speaker: NA
Text: except the CHOGRM meeting room and accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation floors (which were the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Police) and (jointly with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Police) security during the move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the delegates.

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) NSW Special Branch

Speaker: NA
Text: Consistent with the practice of successive

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Governments, it would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate to comment on the internal arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of an instrumentality of a State government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) The PSCC was primarily responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: co-ordination of the planning of the security

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for CHOGRM in 1978.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) No. The division of responsibilities was

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed between Commonwealth and State agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to CHOGRM.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) The Cornmissioner of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Police, jointly with the Commissioner of the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Police, had operational responsibility for security

Speaker: NA
Text: during CHOGRM. The Commonwealth Police

Speaker: NA
Text: Head-of-Operation was Chief Superintendent G L

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce. The officer in charge of PSCC's responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities in respect of CHOGRM was Mr D Evans.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) (a) Mr Marshall held the position of Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinator (Infonnation and Intelligence) in PSCC.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Marshall was responsible for assessing

Speaker: NA
Text: information relating to the overseas and interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of CHOGRM security while the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Police addressed the local situation. Mr Marshall

Speaker: NA
Text: also acted as a link Crocated in Canberra) between

Speaker: NA
Text: the CHOGRM Security Co-ordination Centre at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hilton in Sydney and the PSCC in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Senior Superintendent R Douglass was

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Chief Superintendent, Metropolitan Area,

Speaker: NA
Text: NSW Police. He was the NSW Police offiCer

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately in charge of security planning for the

Speaker: NA
Text: CHOGRM.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Inspector J Perrin was an officer of the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Police.

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) (a) No. (b) No. (c) No. (d) No.

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) Mr Marshall has never given evidence, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: has he been subpoenaed to give evidence, at any

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings concerning the Hilton Hotel bombing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth has no records concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: actions of Senior Superintendent Douglass.

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) On the information available, it is clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: each Commonwealth agency took all appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: measures within their individual spheres of respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility. Security procedures, no matter how exact-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, cannot guarantee that such incidents will not

Speaker: NA
Text: happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) The Commonwealth Government under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stands that sniffer dogs were not used. The only

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth agency with responsibilities outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the hotel was the Commonwealth Police which,

Speaker: NA
Text: jointly with the NSW Police, provided personal

Speaker: NA
Text: protection services to the delegates. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that in 1978 the only sniffer dogs available in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney region belonged to the army and they were

Speaker: NA
Text: trained for different and specifically military

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) As noted in the reply to question (5) above,

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth agencies had responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: security within certain parts of the hotel.

Speaker: NA
Text: (15) See No. (14) above.

Speaker: NA
Text: (16) to (18) Consistent with the practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: successive Commonwealth Governments, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to confirm or deny matters which relate

Speaker: NA
Text: directly to ASIO's operations. Nor do I think. it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be appropriate to name non-ASIO security

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel or to reveal operational measures taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect security.

Speaker: NA
Text: (20) See the response to question (5) which sets

Speaker: NA
Text: out Commonwealth responsibilities. In view of this

Speaker: NA
Text: division of responsibilities between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the States no Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies were involved in operational security in

Speaker: NA
Text: the vicinity of the hotel immediately before the

Speaker: NA
Text: explosion.

Speaker: NA
Text: (21) Yes, I am aware of the allegations. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, nothing which the Commonwealth has

Speaker: NA
Text: received from either Mr Griffiths or Mr Monaghan

Speaker: NA
Text: has amounted to more than unsubstantiated allega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It would not be appropriate to initiate an

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry on the basis of rumour and conjecture. '

Speaker: NA
Text: (22) to (28) Consistent with the practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: successive Commonwealth Governments, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to confirm or deny matters which relate

Speaker: NA
Text: directly to ASIO's operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: (29) It would not be appropriate to comment on

Speaker: NA
Text: matters relating to the enforcement of the criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: law of New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: (30) to (34) Consistent with the practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: successive Commonwealth Governments, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to confirm or deny matters which relate

Speaker: NA
Text: directly to ASIO's operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Maritime College

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 951)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Shack asked the Minister for Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment Services, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 21 June 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 491

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 10 April 1991, page 2368), did the

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of overseas students enrolled in Master

Speaker: NA
Text: Class 1/2 and Second Mate courses at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Maritime College increase from 17.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of a combined intake of 40 students in 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: to 80 per cent of a combined intake of 80 students

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1990; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Did the College carry out student recruitment

Speaker: NA
Text: campaigns'in, or directed at, (a) India, (b) Malaysia

Speaker: NA
Text: or (c) any other countries between 1985 and 1990;

Speaker: NA
Text: if so, what was the total cost to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: of these campaigns.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is Commonwealth funding of the College di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly related to the number of students it can

Speaker: NA
Text: attract, irrespective of whether the students are

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia or overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What is the breakdown by nationality of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas students who attended (a) Master Class

Speaker: NA
Text: 1/2 and (b) Second Mate courses at the College in

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Further to the information provided at part (3)

Speaker: NA
Text: of his answer to question No. 491, (a) did (i) 63

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas Master Class 1/2 students receive tuition

Speaker: NA
Text: to the value of $378,000 and (ii) 34 overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Mate students receive tuition to the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of $102,000 between 1986 and 1989 and (b) did

Speaker: NA
Text: those students receive free tuition under recognist;d

Speaker: NA
Text: aid programs; if so, (i) what programs and (ii) were

Speaker: NA
Text: those programs cancelled or suspended in 1989 to

Speaker: NA
Text: effect a change in Government policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Has free or subsidised tuition been provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for overseas students in any course other than

Speaker: NA
Text: Master Class 1/2 and Second Mate courses between

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Have any overseas students failed to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: their financial obligations in relation to the Over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas Student Charge, course costs or other fees; if

Speaker: NA
Text: so, (a) how many students are involved, (b) what

Speaker: NA
Text: sum is owed and (c) how many students have had

Speaker: NA
Text: their enrolments cancelled pursuant to subparagraph

Speaker: NA
Text: 18(1)(e)(i) of the Higher Education Funding Act

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Baldwin-The following answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question is based on

Speaker: NA
Text: material supplied by the Australian Maritime

Speaker: NA
Text: College:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) In 1986, there were 41 students enrolled in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Master Class 1/2 and 2nd Mate courses at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrl,\lian Maritime College. Of these, 9 were

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas students, comprising 22 per cent of those

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolments.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were 156 students enrolled in the Master

Speaker: NA
Text: Class 1/2 and 2nd Mate courses in 1990. Of these

Speaker: NA
Text: 124 students (79 per cent) were from overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increase in the number of overseas students

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolled at the Australian Maritime College reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: in part the Commonwealth's policy of encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas students to Australia on a full fee paying

Speaker: NA
Text: basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: . (2) Yes. In December 1986 a promotional

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign was undertaken in Singapore. In 1987

Speaker: NA
Text: similar promotional campaigns were undertaken in

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore, Hong Kong and Malaysia. In 1989 its

Speaker: NA
Text: promotional activities were conducted in Malaysia

Speaker: NA
Text: while in 1990 they were in India and Pakistan. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 the College's overseas promotional activities

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken place in India, Pakistan and Fiji.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the inception of full fee courses in 1990,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of these overseas promotional campaigns

Speaker: NA
Text: has been met from profits generated by these

Speaker: NA
Text: courses.

Speaker: NA
Text: the College between 1986 and 1988 are not avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Overseas students enrolled at the College

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1986 and 1989 either were funded under

Speaker: NA
Text: aid programs administered by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Intemational Development Assistance Bureau or

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted under the Government's sponsored student

Speaker: NA
Text: program in which case they paid visa fees. From

Text: 1990 all commencing overseas students entering

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia including those under overseas aid

Speaker: NA
Text: programs did so under the Full Fee Paying Over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas Students Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Free education has not been provided to any

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas students. The number of subsidised or

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsored overseas students who were enrolled in

Speaker: NA
Text: courses other than the Master Class 1/2 or Second

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to 1990 the cost of overseas promotional

Speaker: NA
Text: visits were met from the College's operating grants.

Speaker: NA
Text: The College advises the costs were:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Commonwealth funding for higher education

Speaker: NA
Text: programs is based on the Australian Maritime

Speaker: NA
Text: College's agreed educational profile and student

Speaker: NA
Text: load for Australian students.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The nationalities of the overseas students

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolled in the Master Class 1/2 and 2nd Mate

Speaker: NA
Text: Courses in 1989 and 1990 were as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Master Class 1/2 Students 2nd Mate Students
