Speaker: NA
Text: (7) The Australian Maritime College has advised

Speaker: NA
Text: that 17 overseas students have failed to meet their

Speaker: NA
Text: financial obligations to the College in full for

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation costs amounting to $9,104.50. No

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolments have been cancelled for non payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fluoresceut Light Globes

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 955)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Technology, upon notice, on 20

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What toxic compounds exist in standard and

Speaker: NA
Text: other commercially available fluorescent light

Speaker: NA
Text: globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What practices are followed in the disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: of fluorescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What is the environmental impact of these

Speaker: NA
Text: practices.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Is he able to say what quantities of the toxic

Speaker: NA
Text: compounds referred to in part (1) are released

Speaker: NA
Text: annually into the environment through the disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: of fluorescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Are there recycling technologies whlch would

Speaker: NA
Text: allow an alternative to placing used fluorescent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes in landfill; if so, what is their commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: viability.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) How do the toxic components of fluorescent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes compare with those of the new generation

Speaker: NA
Text: of incandescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Is the toxic composition of incandescent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes greater than that of the earlier generation of

Speaker: NA
Text: fluorescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The toxic compounds present in fluorescent

Speaker: NA
Text: light globes are mercury and lead. Cadmium was

Speaker: NA
Text: also present in some globes manufactured in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia before 1983 and may be present in some

Speaker: NA
Text: imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Disposal of fluorescent globes is left to

Speaker: NA
Text: individual customers or contractors and spent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes usually go to municipal landfill.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The environmental impact of these practises

Speaker: NA
Text: is not fully known. However, there is no evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: that current disposal methods are producing unac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptable levels of contamination. Studies carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out in 1983 by the State Pollution Control

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission could detect no mercury (at an analyti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal sensitivity of 0.1 microgram/litre) in samples of

Speaker: NA
Text: leachate from a representative sample of municipal

Speaker: NA
Text: landfills.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Fluorescent globes manufactured in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: have a mercury content of less than 15 milligrams

Speaker: NA
Text: per globe. In addition to mercury, globes manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured in Australia that have soldered pins also

Speaker: NA
Text: contain lead levels less than 200 milligrams per

Speaker: NA
Text: globe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that 15 million fluorescent globes are

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured in Australia and 3 million of these

Speaker: NA
Text: have soldered pins, then annually 225 kilograms of

Speaker: NA
Text: mercury and 400 kilograms of lead is available for

Speaker: NA
Text: release to the environment from Australian manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not have figures for the precise composition

Speaker: NA
Text: of imported fluorescent globes. However, if one

Speaker: NA
Text: assumes that the 3 million imported fluorescent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes have a similar composition to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: globes, then the total potential release into the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment is approximately 270 kilograms of

Speaker: NA
Text: mercury and 480 kilograms of lead annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) I am not aware of any viable recycling

Speaker: NA
Text: technologies for fluorescent globes. However, there

Speaker: NA
Text: has recently become available a disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: technology known as lamp crushing which claims

Speaker: NA
Text: to recover the residue from spent globes for

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment and disposal. This technology is being

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed by globe manufacturers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Incandescent globes have no toxic compo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nents other than the lead contained within their

Speaker: NA
Text: soldered contacts. The new generation of compact

Speaker: NA
Text: fluorescent globes have a similar toxic content to

Speaker: NA
Text: normal fluorescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Incandescent globes have a lower toxic

Speaker: NA
Text: composition than fluorescent globes, including

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier generations. The mercury content of current

Speaker: NA
Text: fluorescent globes, including compact fluorescent

Speaker: NA
Text: globes, is less than that for earlier generations of

Speaker: NA
Text: fluorescent globes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Metham Sodium

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 958)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Filing asked the Minister for Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business and Customs, upon notice, on 20

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Will metham sodium, used to control weeds

Speaker: NA
Text: in vegetable crops, be subject to a 15 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: import tariff following its reclassification in

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1990; if so, (a) why and (b) will the

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition jeopardise the international market share

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian market gardeners because of their

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting higher costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Why was there a shortage in the supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: metham spdium in Western Australia in early 1991,

Speaker: NA
Text: a critical petiod for potato farming.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beddall-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been no reclassification of metham so-

Speaker: NA
Text: dium.

Speaker: NA
Text: Metham sodium imported in a form put up for

Speaker: NA
Text: retail sale, in packing for retail sale and as a

Speaker: NA
Text: preparation is classified in heading 3808 of Sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act and is dutiable at

Speaker: NA
Text: a rate of 10 per cent from Developing Countries

Speaker: NA
Text: and 15 per cent from other sources. These rates

Speaker: NA
Text: will phase down to Free from Developing Countries

Speaker: NA
Text: and 5 per cent from other sources from 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: Metham sodium imported as an organo-sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: compound and not put in a form previously de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed is classified in heading 2930 of Schedule

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 to the Customs Tariff Act and is free from duty.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am informed that the unusual shortage in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia early this year resulted from

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion of apple orchards to other uses and the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to treat the soil with weed controllers which

Speaker: NA
Text: created a high demand for the chemical.

Speaker: NA
Text: War Widow Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 961)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Harry Woods asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Why cannot eligibility for war widow pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions be extended to spouses of deceased female

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Do existing legislative provisions presume

Speaker: NA
Text: that the husband is the breadwinner and that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no dependence upon female veterans; if so, is

Speaker: NA
Text: this presumption anomalous.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Why was the Veterans' Entitlements Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 specifically exempted from the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Humphreys-The answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Recent amendments to the Veterans' Entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments Act extended eligibility for war widow's

Speaker: NA
Text: pension to spouses of all female members and

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans, irrespective of when death occurred,

Speaker: NA
Text: provided that, at the time of death the female

Speaker: NA
Text: member or veteran was in receipt of the Special

Speaker: NA
Text: (Totally and Permanently Incapacitated) rate of dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability pension or its equivalent, the Extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: Disablement Adjustment, or where death is or was

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted as being related to war or defence

Speaker: NA
Text: The earliest date of effect for payment in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of war widower's pension is 22 January 1991,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was the date the Government announced its

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to eliminate areas of discrimination against

Speaker: NA
Text: females from the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Prior to the recent amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Entitlements Act, the legislative provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions relating to war widows' pensions derived

Speaker: NA
Text: from principles which were generally accepted at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of World War I and subsequent wars and

Speaker: NA
Text: war-like operations. These principles were based on

Speaker: NA
Text: the concept that the husband was the breadwinner

Speaker: NA
Text: and, therefore, there was no presumption of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence on the female veteran.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the change in community attitudes towards

Speaker: NA
Text: women and the assignment of female ADF mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers to the Persian Gulf the Government decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to remove this significant area of discrimination but

Speaker: NA
Text: retained existing provisions relating to treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: and pensions which operate in favour of women.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) When the Sex Discrimination Bill was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced m 1983, the then Repatriation Act

Speaker: NA
Text: contained many differences in benefits for males

Speaker: NA
Text: and females. At the time that the Sex Discrimina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Act 1984 was first enacted, the Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1920 was specifically exempted by paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: 40(2)(c) of that Act. By section 10 of the Acts

Speaker: NA
Text: Interpretation Act 1901, that reference in the Sex

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination Act to the Repatriation Act was

Speaker: NA
Text: then construed as a reference to the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act 1986 which repealed the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The position now is that the Statute Law

Speaker: NA
Text: (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1988 has deleted

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph 40(2)(c) from the Sex Discrimination

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, as this exemption is no longer necessary. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to the Repatriatibn Act was to legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: in force prior to 1 August 1984, the date the Sex

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination Act came into effect. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Entitlements Act is a later enacted Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: it overrides the Sex Discrimination Act, and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that there is any inconsistency between the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the two Acts, the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: later Act will prevail.

Speaker: NA
Text: Inquiry into Merchant Navy War

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 963)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Moore asked the Minister for Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: service. Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Was the report of the MCGirr inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: merchant navy war veterans completed on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has the report been presented to Parliament;

Speaker: NA
Text: if not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Has the war service of merchant navy war

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans been reCognised; if not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What action will the Government take in

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the recommendations of the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the MCGirr inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Humphreys-The answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Report on the MCGirr Inquiry into mer-

Speaker: NA
Text: chant navy war veterans was completed on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1989.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Report was not tabled in the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Terms of Reference for the Inquiry -ere for

Speaker: NA
Text: it to report to the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The contribution of the merchant navy to the

Speaker: NA
Text: war effort has been recognised in Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The Seamen's War Pensions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowances Act 1940 provides for pension and

Speaker: NA
Text: other benefits in respect of war caused disablement.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition service pensions may be provided under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The Government has responded to the MCGirr

Speaker: NA
Text: Report by announcing in the 1990-91 Budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of a non-taxable lump sum of $10,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: surviving ex-prisoners of war who were illegally

Speaker: NA
Text: interned in Nazi concentration camps during World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II, would be extended to Australian merchant

Speaker: NA
Text: mariners with effect from 21 August 1990. In meet

Speaker: NA
Text: addition, in the 1991-92 Budget the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that Repatriation treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: would be granted to Australian mariners on the

Speaker: NA
Text: same basis as Australian war veterans with effect

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 December 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pharmacy Allowance Payments

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 966)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Bob Woods asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged, Family and Health Services, upon allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 20 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Under what criteria will essential pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances be paid to pharmacists.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many essential pharmacy allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: payments have been made.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How many pharmacists will receive payments

Speaker: NA
Text: under the essential pharmacy allowance and what

Speaker: NA
Text: will the average yearly payment be.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) From what date are pharmacists eligible to

Speaker: NA
Text: claim the allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What total sum is expected' to be paid under

Speaker: NA
Text: the allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Was there a delay in finalising the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which payments under the allowance would be

Speaker: NA
Text: made; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Will intetest be paid to pharmacists who have

Speaker: NA
Text: had to wait several months for payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Staples-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The criteria for a pharmacist to qualify for an

Speaker: NA
Text: Essential Pharmacy Allowance are:

Speaker: NA
Text: being open a minimum of 20 hours;

Speaker: NA
Text: being more than 10 kilometres from the

Speaker: NA
Text: nearest pharmacy;

Speaker: NA
Text: having a claimable Pharmaceutical Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme/Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme prescription volume of less than 15,000

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptions in 1989-90.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The number of pharmacists who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: approved for payment of the Essential Pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowance to the August meeting of the Pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Restructuring Authority was 177. All pharmacists

Speaker: NA
Text: have been paid up to and including June. The July

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are currently being processed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The number of pharmacists who will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: payments under the Essential Pharmacy Allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: is unknown as any pharmacist is free to apply at

Speaker: NA
Text: any time for the allowance if they believe they

Speaker: NA
Text: the eligibility criteria. Average payments will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be available until the end of the first year of

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits operation of the allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The allowance commences on the first day of

Speaker: NA
Text: the month following the date that Essential Phar-

Speaker: NA
Text: macy Allowance is approved by the Pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Restructuring Authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) The Government has provided funds of $3

Speaker: NA
Text: million, in 1991-92 to meet payments for this

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) There was a delay by the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission in implementing the computer pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams to calculate and pay the Essential Pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowance. The recording elements of the programs

Speaker: NA
Text: were available in early June while the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: programs were available in late July. Any delays in

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the payment routines were a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: having tol ensure the accuracy of payments to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) No. It is not Government policy to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: interest on outstanding payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: World Decade for Cultural Development

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 979)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Further to the answers to questions Nos. 166

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 21 December 1990, page 4973) and 851

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 20 August 1991, page 119), will

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia participate in the third regular session of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Intergovernmental Committee of the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Decade for Cultural Development.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: The Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Trade has provided the following

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to the honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not a member of the Intergovern-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental Committee of the World Decade for Cultur-

Speaker: NA
Text: al Development and will not be a participant in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's third regular session.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kakadu National Park

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 987)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister for the Arts,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: What were the dates and texts of the World Heri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage Committee's decisions on Kakadu National

Speaker: NA
Text: Park.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) At its 5th Session (26-30 October 1981) the

Speaker: NA
Text: World Heritage Committee decided to inscribe

Speaker: NA
Text: Stage I of Kakadu National Park on the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage List. The Committee:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'noted that the Australian Government intend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator

Speaker: NA
Text: Rivers Region as part of Kakadu National Park

Speaker: NA
Text: and recommended that such areas be included in

Speaker: NA
Text: the site inscribed on the World Heritage List and

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the Region the environmental protection

Speaker: NA
Text: measures specified in the relevant legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to be enforced.'

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) At its 11th Session (7-11 December 1987)

Speaker: NA
Text: the World Heritage Committee decided to include

Speaker: NA
Text: Stage II of Kakadu National Park in the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Heritage List. The Committee:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'recalled that at its 5th session held in Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: (Australia) in 1981, while inscribing Kakadu

Speaker: NA
Text: National Park on the World Heritage List, it had

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that the Australian Government intended

Speaker: NA
Text: to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator

Speaker: NA
Text: Rivers Region as part of Kakadu National Park

Speaker: NA
Text: and had recommended that such areas be includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed in the site inscribed on the World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: List. The. Committee therefore welcomed the

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of the site to include such areas, which

Speaker: NA
Text: had been favourably reviewed by ICOMOS and

Speaker: NA
Text: mCN. The Committee accordingly decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: include Stage II in the site inscribed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: World Heritage List. The Committee commended

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian authorities for having taken

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate legislative measures to prohibit

Speaker: NA
Text: mineral exploration and mining and for their

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to restore the natural ecosystems of the

Speaker: NA
Text: site. It also encouraged the Australian authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider further'extending the World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: site to include Stage 3 of the National Park and

Speaker: NA
Text: to modify the boundaries of Stages 1 and 2 in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to protect the entire catchment area, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: include the cultural values to the East of the

Speaker: NA
Text: present National Park.

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Finally the Committee requested the Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian authorities to provide further information on

Speaker: NA
Text: the possible impact of proposed military training

Speaker: NA
Text: activities in areas adjacent to the World Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: site.'

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO Convention No. 169

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 989)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 853

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 21 June, 1991, page 5343), and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of the UN General Assembly resolution of 18

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1990 proclaiming 1993 as International

Speaker: NA
Text: Year of the World's Indigenous People, has ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention No. 169: Tribal and Indigenous Peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples, 1989, been included in the priority list of 9

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO conventions for ratification by Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What other conventions have been included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the list.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: The Minister for Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations has provided the following answers

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member's questions:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Convention No. 169 has not been included in

Speaker: NA
Text: the priority list of 9 ILO Conventions for ratifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by Australia. However, it is among the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions to be examined by the interdepartmental

Speaker: NA
Text: Taskforce established in June 1991 to review 74

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO Conventions which Australia has not ratified.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Taskforce will be reporting to me periodically

Speaker: NA
Text: over the next 12 to 18 months with lists of Conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions recommended for early ratification.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate the significance of this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention to Australia. It is my intention, there- Premiums

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, that it receive early consideration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Taskforce, and will be the subject of close consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation with relevant Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander communities, and the States and Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The 9 priority Conventions agreed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour at their meeting in November 1990 are:

Speaker: NA
Text: C.53 Officers' Competency Certificates, 1936

Speaker: NA
Text: C.58 Minimum Age (Sea) (Revised), 1936

Speaker: NA
Text: C.92 Accommodation of Crews (Revised), 1949

Speaker: NA
Text: C.133 Accommodation of Crews (Supplementary

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions), 1970

Speaker: NA
Text: C.135 Workers' Representatives, 1971

Speaker: NA
Text: C.151 Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978

Speaker: NA
Text: C.155 Occupational Safety and Health, 1981

Speaker: NA
Text: C.162 Asbestos, 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: C.167 Safety and Health in Construction, 1988.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Costs and Laws

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 993)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Following publication of 'Selected Statistics on

Speaker: NA
Text: the General Insurance Industry for the year ended

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 June 1990' by the Insurance and Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner, is the Minister able to bring up-to-

Speaker: NA
Text: date the information on compensation costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: laws provided in the answer to question No. 43

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 17 September 1990, page 2027).

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: The Minister for Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations has provided the following answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Costs

Speaker: NA
Text: On the basis of figures provided in the Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: and Superannuation Commissioner's publication

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Selected Statistics (')n the General Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry for the year ended 30 June 1990' the

Speaker: NA
Text: updated figures for 1989-90 are:

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation 3rd Party

Speaker: NA
Text: $m $m

Speaker: NA
Text: Direct

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration

Speaker: NA
Text: The percentage increases on premiums between

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation 3rd Party

Speaker: NA
Text: * Direct

Speaker: NA
Text: Premiums 65.8 -3.8

Speaker: NA
Text: Earned

Speaker: NA
Text: Premiums 20.3 10.4

Speaker: NA
Text: * The 65.8 per cent increase in Workers Compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation reflects the inclusion, for the first time, of

Speaker: NA
Text: Workers Compensation figures for the NSW

Speaker: NA
Text: Workcare scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Laws

Speaker: NA
Text: Since June 1990 the following events have occur-

Speaker: NA
Text: red:

Speaker: NA
Text: Significant reforms to WorkCover were intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in NSW through the Workers Compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Amendment) Act 1991. These include improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to common law entitlements and the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of provision for a second injury scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland Parliament passed the Workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Act 1990, which took effect from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 1991. The new Act retains the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: philosqphy of fairness and equity for employers and

Speaker: NA
Text: employees with work related injuries but new

Speaker: NA
Text: inlprovements in benefits for injured workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Extensive amendments have been made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: WorkCover scheme in South Australia since

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1990. The major amendments are in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to power to exclude certain workers from

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage, weekly payments, compensation for

Speaker: NA
Text: medical expenses, orphan benefits, exempt employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, registration and levy payments, review proceed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, representation, medical advisory panels,

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewable decisions and dishonesty/offences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tasmanian Workers Compensation Act was

Speaker: NA
Text: amended to indeflinify authorised officers who act

Speaker: NA
Text: in the course of their duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Important changes to the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Health Act were passed in the August 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: sittings of the Legislative Assembly. The changes

Speaker: NA
Text: affect benefits for claimants, permanent impairment

Speaker: NA
Text: injuries and a number of related issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: UN Convention on the Law of the Sea

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 994)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Overseas Development, upon notice, on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) On 14 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1973),

Speaker: NA
Text: did the then Minister for Foreign Affairs inform

Speaker: NA
Text: House that its unanimous resolution on the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention on the Law of the Sea had been

Speaker: NA
Text: forn1ally conveyed to the US Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) On what subsequent occasions and by what

Speaker: NA
Text: means has Australia's support for the Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: been conveyed to the USA.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Further to his answer to question No. 178

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 18 September 1990, page 2125),

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration been given to

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives in the same way as they were successful-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly conveyed in June 1991 concerning the Protocol

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Antarctic Treaty.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: The answer to the honourable scale

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Australia has been in direct and

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with the United States Government over

Speaker: NA
Text: law of the sea issues since 1981 when the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives conveyed its unanimous resolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the United Nations Convention on the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Sea to the United States Government. In

Speaker: NA
Text: those contacts, Australia continues to emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: significance of the Convention, which embodies a

Speaker: NA
Text: delicate balance of the interests of all States,

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a comprehensive regime governing the

Speaker: NA
Text: uses of the ocean. In particular we stress to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Government the value to all members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the international community of the entry into

Speaker: NA
Text: force of a universally acceptable Convention.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The negotiation of the Protocol to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Antarctic Treaty differs substantially from the

Speaker: NA
Text: current situation regarding the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention on the Law of the Sea. Negotiations on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Antarctic Treaty are still taking place. In June 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States asked for more time to study a

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise formula, which had been agreed to by

Speaker: NA
Text: all the other Treaty Parties, on the last outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: substantive issue for settlement of the Protocol. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was therefore appropriate for representations to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the United States. These were successful

Speaker: NA
Text: and on 4 July President Bush announced that the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States could accept the formula. The

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations are due to be concluded and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Protocol opened for signature in October.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the case of the Law of the Sea Convention the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is much more complicated and delicate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The negotiation of that Convention is long over.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1982, the United States position has been that

Speaker: NA
Text: Part XI of the Convention dealing with deep seabed

Speaker: NA
Text: mining is unacceptable in its current form.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australia and the United States are now participat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in consultations under the auspices of the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary-General to explore the scope for bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: into force a universally acceptable Convention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bilateral Aid

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 995)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: has Overseas Development, upon notice, on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: conveying Australia's August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Further to the answers to questions Nos. 164

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 7 November 1990, page 3505) and 850,

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 20 August 1991, page 119), what is the

Speaker: NA
Text: and nature of direct bilateral aid to Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: by (a) Japan, (b) Sweden and (c) Finland.

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: regular member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) In 1989, the last year for which figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: available, Japanese aid to Vietnam amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: $US 1.55 million. Of this technical assistance was

Speaker: NA
Text: Law $US 1.24 million and grant assistance was $US

Speaker: NA
Text: 310,000. This compares to Japan's total bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: the aid expenditure of over $US 6 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan seeks to encourage Vietnam to be more

Speaker: NA
Text: in forthcoming in the Cambodia peace process and

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic economic reform. It is thus taking what

Speaker: NA
Text: it calls a cautious approach and will not resume a

Speaker: NA
Text: full bilateral aid program, in terms of grants and

Speaker: NA
Text: loans, until further progress is made on the Cambo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dian question. Instead, Japan has expanded econom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic cooperation from humanitarian aid to small scale

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance. For example the Japan Inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national Cooperation Agency (nCA) has sent some

Speaker: NA
Text: experts to Vietnam and is gradually increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of Vietnamese trainees (economic managers

Speaker: NA
Text: and medical students etc.) in Japan. Japan hopes to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase this to 50 over the 1991-92 Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Sweden's bilateral development assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: program to Vietnam for the 1990-91 financial year

Speaker: NA
Text: was 300 million Krona or SUS 47.8 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Direct Government to Government aid to

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam was scaled down from 1987 and was to

Speaker: NA
Text: be suspended from 1990 unless Vietnam withdrew

Speaker: NA
Text: its forces from Cambodia. Sweden's Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Cooperation, Hjelm-Wallen, an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced a resumption of the normal bilateral aid

Speaker: NA
Text: program during her visit to Vietnam in June 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principal projects are industrial rehabilitation

Speaker: NA
Text: (providing mainly equipment and some technical

Speaker: NA
Text: advice and training), health and reafforestation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Finland plans to provide SUS 14.2 million or

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 million Finnish Markka by the 1991 calendar

Speaker: NA
Text: year and to increase this to SUS 16.6 million or 70

Speaker: NA
Text: million Finnish Markka in 1993. Most of this will

Speaker: NA
Text: be grant aid with a small but significant amount in

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of technical cooperation.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the three years to 1990, no new projects

Speaker: NA
Text: were commenced due to Vietnam's military

Speaker: NA
Text: presence in Cambodia at that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principal projects include a vocational school

Speaker: NA
Text: attached to a repair dock in Pha Rung, an urban

Speaker: NA
Text: water supply project for Hanoi and a feasibility

Speaker: NA
Text: study for a similar water supply project for Hai

Speaker: NA
Text: Phong. A container port for Ho Chi Minh City is

Speaker: NA
Text: under consideration in association with the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: Archer River Property and Swan

Speaker: NA
Text: Brewery Site

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 996)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hollis asked the Minister for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: What developments have taken place in the (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliaments and (b) courts of (i) !Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the Archer River property and (ii)

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia concerning the Swan Brewery

Speaker: NA
Text: site since the answers to questions Nos. 180

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 8 November 1990, page 3074) and 536

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 7 May 1991, page 3169).

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tickner-The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) (a) In respect of the Archer River property in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, I am advised that under the provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the recently enacted Aboriginal Land Act 1991,

Speaker: NA
Text: National Parks are available Crown lands, which

Speaker: NA
Text: upon declaration by the Governor in Council by

Speaker: NA
Text: Gazette notice, can become land that may be

Speaker: NA
Text: claimed and granted to a group of Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people. It has been announced by the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that following upon proclamation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act, the National Park at Archer River will be

Speaker: NA
Text: declared by the Governor in Council as claimable

Speaker: NA
Text: land.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) I am advised that there have been no further

Speaker: NA
Text: developments in the courts on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) (a) The Western Australian Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: moved to amend its Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972-

Speaker: NA
Text: 80 to bind the Crown except in instances where

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency public works may interfere with

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal sites. As previously advised, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill has been withdrawn from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Legislative Council for further

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment and has not been re-introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) The Western Australian Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: appealed to the State Full Court against the finding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Supreme Court that the Premier's approval

Speaker: NA
Text: of the redevelopment of the brewery building was

Speaker: NA
Text: void. The Court has reserved its decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Grants to Schools

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1000)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Bailey asked the Minister for Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Education and Training, upon notice, on

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Are Commonwealth grants to schools needed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the start of the school year to enable schools to

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase books and equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Was the delivery of Commonwealth grants to

Speaker: NA
Text: schools changed in January 1991, without warning,

Speaker: NA
Text: to quarterly payments; if so, why.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dawkins-The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Commonwealth general recurrent grants are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to State and Territory government educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion systems and to approved non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants to government school systems are paid in

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve monthly instalments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth General Recurrent Grants are

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to non-government schools and systems as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent in January

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in July (cumulative total 75 per cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in October (cumulative total 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth grants therefore commence being

Speaker: NA
Text: paid before the start of the school year.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The only change made in January 1991 to

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of grants was the change to General

Speaker: NA
Text: Recurrent Grant payments to non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: school systems from:

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in January

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in April (cumulative total 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in July (cumulative total 75 per cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in October (cumulative total 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: to:

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent in January

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in July (cumulative total 75 per cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent in October (cumulative total 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent)

Speaker: NA
Text: The changed payment arrangement was done in

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with system representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason for this change was to bring systemic

Speaker: NA
Text: schools into line with the payment arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: non-systemic schools, and to provide additional

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance towards the costs of teacher award

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oaths and Affirmations

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1001)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Melham asked the Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: When did the Government last consider the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of the (a) oaths and affirmations of allegiance and

Speaker: NA
Text: of office to be taken by (i) Justices of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court under the Judiciary Act 1903 and (ii) Judges

Speaker: NA
Text: under the (A) Australian Capital Territory Supreme

Speaker: NA
Text: Court Act and (B) Family Law Act 1975 and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: oath or affirmation of office taken by Judges under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976.

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The oath or affirmation of allegiance as con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in the Schedule to the Constitution was last

Speaker: NA
Text: considered by the Government in 1988. The oath

Speaker: NA
Text: or affirmation of office for Justices or Judges as

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the relevant Acts was last considered

Speaker: NA
Text: in;

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) (i) 1979 (High Court Act 1979).

Speaker: NA
Text: The above dates refer to the last amendments of

Speaker: NA
Text: the relevant sections of the appropriate Acts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tobacco: Treatment with CFCs

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1007)

Speaker: NA
Text: ' Mr Mack asked the Minister for the Arts,

Speaker: NA
Text: I Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Were companies which manufacture cigar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ettes in Australia licensed by the R. J. Reynolds

Speaker: NA
Text: company of the USA to use a Reynolds' patented

Speaker: NA
Text: process involving the treatment of tobacco with

Speaker: NA
Text: Freon; if so, which companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Are any companies in Australia using any

Speaker: NA
Text: process involving the treatment of tobacco with

Speaker: NA
Text: Freon; if so, which companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is Freon a trade name for a chlorofluoro-

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon (CFC) gas.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Is she able to say whether there are any

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to (a) the manufacturer or (b) the public

Speaker: NA
Text: from treating tobacco with CFCs; if so, what are

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Does the treatment of tobacco with CFCs

Speaker: NA
Text: accord with the Government's objectives concern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the use of ozone depleting gases; if not, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government review this use of CFCs.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Licensing arrangements between companies

Speaker: NA
Text: are private contracts, details of which usually

Speaker: NA
Text: remain confidential between the parties concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Until recently CFC was used for loosening or

Speaker: NA
Text: fluffing tobacco compressed for transport. Release

Speaker: NA
Text: of pressure fluffs the tobacco ready for filling

Speaker: NA
Text: cigarettes. Alternative methods are now used.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) The elimination of CFC from the process is

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the Government's objectives of

Speaker: NA
Text: phasing out ozone depleting substances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cigarettes: Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1008)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mack asked the Minister for Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business and Customs, upon notice, on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is he able to say whether cigarette manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turers in Australia treat tobacco with chlorofluoro-

Speaker: NA
Text: carbons to reduce the amount and weight of

Speaker: NA
Text: tobacco required to produce a given number of

Speaker: NA
Text: cigarettes; if so, does the Government collect less

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue from cigarette manufacturers because the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant taxes are levied by weight.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is he able to say whether taxes in the USA

Speaker: NA
Text: are levied per thousand cigarettes; if so, would

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue be increased if Australian cigarette taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: were levied in the same manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beddall-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) I am advised that Australian cigarette manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers no longer treat tobacco with chlorofluoro-

Speaker: NA
Text: carbons (CFC's). Excise on tobacco and cigarettes

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently based on tobacco weight and not on the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of cigarettes produced. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: thus does not collect less revenue per weight of

Speaker: NA
Text: tobacco consumption if expansion agents are used.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) In the United States, excise on cigarettes is

Speaker: NA
Text: levied per thousand cigarettes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that the current US taxes are $10

Speaker: NA
Text: per 1000 for 'small' cigarettes and $21 per 1000

Speaker: NA
Text: for 'large' cigarettes.

Speaker: NA
Text: If excise were levied per cigarette, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: per kilogram of tobacco, the revenue effect would

Speaker: NA
Text: depend on the rates chosen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The methodology for levying excise and the

Speaker: NA
Text: setting of rates to achieve certain revenue expecta-

Speaker: NA
Text: -ions are matters for my colleague the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: and are under continuing review.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carriage Of Grain: Regulation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1016)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawker asked the Minister for Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Did wheat marketing legislation enacted in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989 allow for the deregulation of the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: carriage of grain.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Does the Victorian Government continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: regulate the carriage of grain to rail.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) If the legislation referred to in part (1) has

Speaker: NA
Text: been implemented and the Victorian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to regulate the carriage of grain, why

Speaker: NA
Text: does he allow the situation to continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-The answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Wheat Marketing Act 1989 allowed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the deregulation of the domestic carriage of grain.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, this deregulation only applies to grain

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the subject of a contract relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: state or export trade. The Federal Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have the Constitutional power to legislate on

Speaker: NA
Text: intra-state trading in grain.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Victorian Government continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: regulate to rail the transport of grains over a

Speaker: NA
Text: distance of 60 km where the grain is transported

Speaker: NA
Text: only within Victoria, unless the vehicle is owned

Speaker: NA
Text: by the grain grower.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Victorian Government is acting within

Speaker: NA
Text: its powers under the Constitution to regulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: transport of grain which is the subject of intra-state

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. The Commonwealth's powers under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution cover interstate and export trade only.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government adopted the recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations of the Royal Commission into Grains

Speaker: NA
Text: Storage, Handling and Transport in 1988 which

Speaker: NA
Text: included a recommendation that this restriction be

Speaker: NA
Text: removed. However, it was recognised that imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of most of the findings was a matter for

Speaker: NA
Text: the States which to a large extent have not agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Royal Commission recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Assets Sales

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1017)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale asked the Minister for Finance,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Further to the information set out in 1991-92

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget paper No.2 at Table 1, 9D concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: assets sales receipts, payments and totals and the

Speaker: NA
Text: details of assets sales set out at pages 3.289-294 of

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget paper No.1, will he provide (a) figures for

Speaker: NA
Text: the receipts and payments for each of the assets

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to be sold during 1991-92 and (b) the

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciliation of those figures.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's questions is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) and (b) No. For obvious commercial reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not the practice of the Government to release

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates of the expected receipts (and associated

Speaker: NA
Text: payments) in respect of individual asset sales which

Speaker: NA
Text: have yet to be finalised. The release of such figures

Speaker: NA
Text: would be prejudicial to the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: interests in its dealings with potential purchasers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the assets concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Trade Offices

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1021)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer asked the Minister repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the Minister for Industry, Technology

Speaker: NA
Text: inter- and Commerce, upon notice, on 3 September

Speaker: NA
Text: Further to the answer to question No. 908

Speaker: NA
Text: (Hansard, 20 August 1991, page 133), which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian trade offices have been (a) opened and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) closed since 6 January 1986 and on what dates.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Australian Trade Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Region

Speaker: NA
Text: Americas

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Markets

Speaker: NA
Text: OceaniafSE Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Australian Trade Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Region

Speaker: NA
Text: Americas

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Markets

Speaker: NA
Text: Oceania/SE Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes-worlcplace change: the meaning

Speaker: NA
Text: behind the words

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1022)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs GALLUS asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: and how was that figure determined.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: The Minister for Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations has provided the following answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer the honourable member to Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Question No. 1068 asked by Senator Calvert on 26

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1991. My answer appeared in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard on 3 September 1991, p.1140 and covers

Speaker: NA
Text: the information being sought by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member. Both the question and answer are set out

Speaker: NA
Text: below.

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Senator Calvert asked the Minister for Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations, upon notice, on 26 July 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What was the total cost of the booklet

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled, Changes, dealing with workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: reform, which was distributed by the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many booklets were produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) To whom was the booklet distributed and

Speaker: NA
Text: what were the distribution costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Were quotations obtained for the printing

Speaker: NA
Text: of the booklet and where was it printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Is it envisaged that further copies of

Speaker: NA
Text: similar booklets will be produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cook-the answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: senator's question is:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The total production cost was $187,970.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) A total of 530,000 booklets was produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The booklets were distributed to as many

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals and organisations involved in work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place reform as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: 390,000 copies of the booklet were distribut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed through one edition of the Weekend

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian at a total cost of $19,900.

Speaker: NA
Text: A total of 45,000 were distributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: following organisations:

Speaker: NA
Text: employer organisations;

Speaker: NA
Text: union organisations;

Speaker: NA
Text: trades and labour councils;

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Members of Parliament and Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors;

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and State Government

Speaker: NA
Text: departments and agencies;

Speaker: NA
Text: educational institutions;

Speaker: NA
Text: work change advisers;

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Resource Centre managers;

Speaker: NA
Text: migrant worker liaison officers;

Speaker: NA
Text: Government business enterprises; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total cost of this distribution was $10,480.

Speaker: NA
Text: The remaining 95,000 are being distributed to

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and individuals on request. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 50 copies are requested, there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of 35 cents for each additional copy.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Yes, by AGPS (Contract SPC90/16). The

Speaker: NA
Text: winning quote was supplied by Pirie Printers

Speaker: NA
Text: Sales Pty Ltd, Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Evaluative research is currently under way

Speaker: NA
Text: to assess its impact and determine if further

Speaker: NA
Text: booklets of this type should be produced.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Broadcasting Service

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1033)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Bob Woods asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications, upon notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 3 September 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) Has he instructed SBS management to

Speaker: NA
Text: reassess its scheduling proposals in order to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: access for small language communities to radio

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting; if so (a) what were the details of his

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions and (b) has SBS management rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: those instructions by refusing to change its original

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has he undertaken to accelerate the establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a second broadcasting frequency for SBS

Speaker: NA
Text: Radio in Sydney.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) No. SBS program content and scheduling

Speaker: NA
Text: issues are the responsibility of the SBS Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) No. I am currently examining options for

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfying ethnic community needs for ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: language radio programming. The options include

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of a second SBS radio service in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aerospace Technologies of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Aircraft Services

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1044)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr J ull asked the Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many aircraft have been serviced by

Speaker: NA
Text: Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: Services (A STAAS) since it was established.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What aircraft types have been serviced.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) For whom was the work undertaken.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) How many staff are employed by ASTAAS

Speaker: NA
Text: at Avalon, Vic.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Have any of the staff referred to in part (4)

Speaker: NA
Text: been hired overse-; if so, (a) how many, (b) what

Speaker: NA
Text: is the designation of each and (c) will further

Speaker: NA
Text: recruitment from overseas occur; if so, (i) when

Speaker: NA
Text: and (ii) how many staff will be recruited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bilney-The Minister for Defence has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the following answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1)-(5) Aerospace Technologies of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: (ASTA) and its subsidiary, ASTA Aircraft Services,

Speaker: NA
Text: are companies at arm's length from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. While the Government owns 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the shares in ASTA, it is not able to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: for the companies or provide the detail sought in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to their commercial operations. The Annual

Speaker: NA
Text: Report of ASTA for 1989-90 was tabled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives on 8 May 1991. Further

Speaker: NA
Text: information could be sought directly from the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aerospace Technologies of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Aircraft Services

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1045)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jull asked the Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What are the ownership arrangements of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: Services at Avalon, Vic.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Will the Government completely privatise

Speaker: NA
Text: this facility; if so, (a) when and (b) will any portion

Speaker: NA
Text: be floated publicly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bilney-The Minister for Defence has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the following answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Shareholdings in ASTAAS are:

Speaker: NA
Text: 70.9 per cent ASTA

Speaker: NA
Text: 29.1 per cent Hong Kong Aircraft Engi-

Speaker: NA
Text: neering Company (HAECO)

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Government has indicated its intention

Speaker: NA
Text: to ultimately place ASTA in the private sector. At

Speaker: NA
Text: this stage, no plans for further privatising either

Speaker: NA
Text: ASTA or ASTAAS are before the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expo 92: Pavilion Staff

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1049)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jull asked the Minister for Arts, Sport,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 4

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: , (1) How many staff will be employed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Pavilion at Expo '92 in Seville, Spain.

Speaker: NA
Text: (-) How many of the staff referred to in part (1)

Speaker: NA
Text: will be (a) locally engaged in Spain and (b) hired

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What qualifications are required for pavilion

Speaker: NA
Text: staff hired in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) How many staff have been hired in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and of these how many were hired in each State.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Simmons- The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Ninety-one (91) staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) (a) 1\venty-six (26), (b) Sixty-five (65)

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Skills and experience in project management,

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities management, staff control, public relations

Speaker: NA
Text: and protocol work are required, as appropriate, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the administrative positions which have been adver-

Speaker: NA
Text: tised within' the Australian Public Service. For

Speaker: NA
Text: most, but not all of these positions, a knowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Spanish language is required.

Speaker: NA
Text: Experience in the food service and hospi-lity

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, facility management and financial control

Speaker: NA
Text: are required by the contract catering staff. A

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of the Spanish language will be an

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Applicants for forty-five (45) Pavilion Attendant

Speaker: NA
Text: positions advertised nationally on 6 July 1991 are

Speaker: NA
Text: required to be fluent in English and Spanish and

Speaker: NA
Text: preferably possess skills in at least one other major

Speaker: NA
Text: European language. Other essential qualities include

Speaker: NA
Text: a good general knowledge of Australia, confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in addressing large groups of people and previous

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in crowd management.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Seven (7) administrative staff have already

Speaker: NA
Text: been selected. Of these four (4) are from the ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: and three (3) from NSW. The Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: General designate resides in NSW.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are you paying too much

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1072)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Andrews asked the Minister represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade, upon notice, on 12 September 1991:

Speaker: NA
Text: Has the Department of Foreign Mfairs and Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared a booklet entitled Are you paying too

Speaker: NA
Text: much; if so, (a) how many copies were published,

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) what was the cost, (c) to which individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations are copies being distributed and are

Speaker: NA
Text: copies being sent overseas; if so, (i) how many

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) to which countries?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: The Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Trade has provided the following

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to the honourable member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) 8,000 copies are being published.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) $40,000 (estimated).

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) (i) and (ii) About 6000 copies are being

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed overseas, mainly in the member count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries of the EC: Belgium, Luxembourg, Britain,

Speaker: NA
Text: France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, The Netherlands,

Speaker: NA
Text: Denmark, Ireland, Germany and Greece. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: be distributed by Australian missions in those

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to community groups and individuals able

Speaker: NA
Text: to influence or contribute to the current debate

Speaker: NA
Text: and about the future of the EC's Common Agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: Policy (CAP), including consumers, taxpayers,

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers, parliamentarians, environmentalists, busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness groups and the news media. Precisely which

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and individuals is being left to the

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion of Australian missions which are best

Speaker: NA
Text: placed to target the distribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, the pamphlet will be distributed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's partners in the Cairns Group, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian missions in other countries where there

Speaker: NA
Text: may be a demand for it, for example, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia the pamphlet is being made available

Speaker: NA
Text: to groups and individuals who request copies.
